target: You, mistress, all this trouble is because of you.

orig: translate old to modern: Still be ’t yours.
target: It’s all still yours.

orig: translate old to modern: No more of that.
target: No more of these thoughts.

orig: translate old to modern: I'th’ air or th’ earth?
target: Is it in the air or the earth?

orig: translate old to modern: Did I not, fellow?
target: Didn’t I?

orig: translate old to modern: Monsieur the challenger, the Princess calls for you.
target: Mister Challenger, the princess wants to speak to you.

orig: translate old to modern: No more.
target: Oh, shut up.

orig: translate old to modern: But how long shall that title “ever” last?
target: But how long will “ever” last?

orig: translate old to modern: God knows I loved my niece, And she is dead, slandered to death by villains That dare as well answer a man indeed As I dare take a serpent by the tongue.— Boys, apes, braggarts, jacks, milksops!
target: God knows I loved my niece, and now she’s dead—slandered to death by cowards who would just as likely fight a real man as I would grab a poisonous snake by the tongue.

orig: translate old to modern: Zounds, sir, you are one of those that will not serve God, if the devil bid you.
target: Zounds, sir, you are one of those who wouldn’t serve God if the devil asked you to.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou art a traitor— Off with his head.
target: You’re a traitor.—Off with his head.

orig: translate old to modern: Being entertained for a perfumer, as I was smoking a musty room, comes me the Prince and Claudio, hand in hand, in sad conference.
target: As I was working on one musty room, the Prince and Claudio entered.

orig: translate old to modern: And they have conspired together,—I will not say, you shall see a masque; but if you do, then it was not for nothing that my nose fell a-bleeding on Black- Monday last, at six o'clock i' the morning, falling out that year on Ash-Wednesday was four year in the afternoon.
target: And they have conspired together; I’ll not say you shall see a party, but if you do, then it was not for nothing that my nose started bleeding on last Black Monday at six o'clock in the morning, falling out that year on Ash-Wednesday was four years in the afternoon.

orig: translate old to modern: Though it pass your patience and mine to endure her loud alarums, why, man, there be good fellows in the world, an a man could light on them, would take her with all faults, and money enough.
target: Guys who’d take her with all her faults, provided there were enough money involved.

orig: translate old to modern: What, of Venice?
target: What, of Venice?

orig: translate old to modern: Go, presently inquire, and so will I, Where money is; and I no question make, To have it of my trust, or for my sake.
target: Go now and ask where money can be found, And I will too, and I will not object To borrowing it on my account or in my name.

orig: translate old to modern: For this night, to bed, and dream on the event.
target: Meanwhile, let’s go to bed and dream about this.

orig: translate old to modern: For not alone The death of Fulvia, with more urgent touches, Do strongly speak to us, but the letters too Of many our contriving friends in Rome Petition us at home.
target: Fulvia’s death and the pressing concerns related to it are not the only reasons I am eager to go; friends in Rome have also sent many letters advising my return.

orig: translate old to modern: I pray you.
target: I beg you.

orig: translate old to modern: If you will live, lament.
target: If you do intend to live, then mourn.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, friends.
target: Come, friends.

orig: translate old to modern: Amaze the welkin with your broken staves—
target: Startle even the sky with the sound of your lances cracking.

orig: translate old to modern: I am old and foolish.
target: I’m old and foolish.

orig: translate old to modern: Faith, niece, you tax Signor Benedick too much, but he’ll be meet with you, I doubt it not.
target: But I’m sure he’ll get even with you.

orig: translate old to modern: I see, sir, you are liberal in offers: You taught me first to beg; and now, methinks, You teach me how a beggar should be answer'd.
target: I see, sir, you are free in making offers; You taught me to beg first, and now I think You teach me how to answer a beggar.

orig: translate old to modern: I should be still Plucking the grass, to know where sits the wind; Peering in maps, for ports, and piers, and roads: And every object that might make me fear Misfortune to my ventures, out of doubt Would make me sad.
target: I’d be Still plucking the grass to know where the wind blows, Looking over maps for ports and piers and roads; And every object that would make me afraid of Misfortune to my ships, Would make me sad without a doubt.

orig: translate old to modern: Why art thou angry?
target: Why are you enraged?

orig: translate old to modern: And yet to win her, all the world to nothing!
target: And yet, against all odds, I win her over!

orig: translate old to modern: Did I, Charmian, Ever love Caesar so?
target: Charmian, did I ever love Caesar as much as this?

orig: translate old to modern: And did not they Put on my brows this wreath of victory, And bid me give it thee?
target: And didn’t they Put this wreath of victory on my brows, And told me to give it you?

orig: translate old to modern: Tranio, let’s go.
target: Tranio, let’s go.

orig: translate old to modern: a sail.
target: a sail.

target: But you have to.

orig: translate old to modern: Hag-seed, hence!
target: Offspring of a witch, come here!

orig: translate old to modern: Hold, there’s expenses for thee.
target: Wait, here’s a coin for you.

orig: translate old to modern: In such a time as this it is not meet That every nice offense should bear his comment.
target: In such a time as this, it isn’t fair That every silly offense should uphold his criticism.

orig: translate old to modern: Marry, that am I and my partner.
target: Sir, that would be me and my partner.

orig: translate old to modern: And know it now, the Senate have concluded To give this day a crown to mighty Caesar.
target: The Senate has concluded To give a crown to mighty Caesar this day.

orig: translate old to modern: And O you mortal engines, whose rude throats The immortal Jove's dread clamors counterfeit, Farewell!
target: And, O you mortal device, whose rude throats Pretend to be the immortal Jove's dread clamors, Farewell!

orig: translate old to modern: Who’s born that day When I forget to send to Antony Shall die a beggar.
target: Whoever is born on a day I forget to send a message to Antony will die a beggar.

orig: translate old to modern: Yet Edmund was beloved.
target: Still, Edmund was beloved.

orig: translate old to modern: Good madonna, why mournest thou?
target: My dear madam, why are you in mourning?

orig: translate old to modern: I must be one of these same dumb wise men, For Gratiano never lets me speak.
target: I must be one of these same dumb wise men, Because Gratiano never lets me speak.

orig: translate old to modern: tis for the dead, not for the quick; therefore thou liest.
target: It is for the dead, not for the quick, therefore you lie.

orig: translate old to modern: Our reasons are so full of good regard That were you, Antony, the son of Caesar, You should be satisfied.
target: Our reasons are so full of good regard That were you, Antony, the son of Caesar, You should be satisfied.

orig: translate old to modern: I pray you, though you mock me, gentlemen, Let her not hurt me.
target: I beg you, although you mock me, gentlemen, Don’t let her hurt me.

orig: translate old to modern: Draw, you rogue, or I’ll so carbonado your shanks.
target: Draw your sword, scoundrel, or I’ll slice your thighs like flank steak.

target: It is not honesty in me to discuss What I have seen and known.

orig: translate old to modern: His beard was grizzled, no?
target: His beard was grizzly, no?

orig: translate old to modern: And so do I.
target: And so do I.

target: Indeed they say that the senators Mean to establish Caesar as a king tomorrow,And that he will be king everywhere, In every place, except here in Italy.

orig: translate old to modern: That, sir, which I will not report after her.
target: That, sir, which I will not report about her.

orig: translate old to modern: And I.
target: Me too.

orig: translate old to modern: A customer!
target: A customer!

orig: translate old to modern: Lend me your hand.
target: Lend me your hand.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis he.
target: It is he.

orig: translate old to modern: But who is with him?
target: But who’s with him?

orig: translate old to modern: No.
target: No.

orig: translate old to modern: This wretch hath part confess'd his villainy.
target: This wretch has part confessed his villainy.

orig: translate old to modern: At once, good night: Stand not upon the order of your going, But go at once.
target: Only go at once.

orig: translate old to modern: I pray thee, moralize them.
target: Please, educate me.

orig: translate old to modern: My Lord Bassanio, since you have found Antonio, We two will leave you; but at dinner-time, I pray you have in mind where we must meet.
target: My Lord Bassanio, since you have found Antonio, We’ll leave you; but, at dinnertime, Please remember where we’re meeting.

orig: translate old to modern: I fear your disposition.
target: I don’t trust you.

orig: translate old to modern: Then there’s life in ’t.
target: Sa, sa, sa, sa.

orig: translate old to modern: So please your majesty That we may wake the king?
target: Would you mind if we woke up the king?

orig: translate old to modern: And when I have stol'n upon these sons-in-law, Then, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill!
target: And when I’ve sneaked up on my sons-in-law, then I’ll kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill!

orig: translate old to modern: I am one, my liege, Whom the vile blows and buffets of the world Have so incensed that I am reckless what I do to spite the world.
target: I am one, my liege, Whom has been so angered by the vile blows and beatings of the world That I am reckless in what I would do to spite the world.

orig: translate old to modern: No, nothing but ourselves.
target: No, nothing but ourselves.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou dost thy office fairly.
target: You do your job well.

target: Rise, princes, and, with a spirit of honor more sharply edged than your swords, rush to the battlefield: Charles Delabreth, High Constable of France; you dukes of Orléans, Bourbon, Berri, Alençon, Brabant, Bar, and Burgundy; Jaques Chatillon, Rambures, Vaudemont, Beaumont, Grandpré, Roussi, and Fauconberg, Foix, Lestrale, Bouciqualt, and Charolois.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou canst tell why one’s nose stands i' th' middle on ’s face?
target: Do you know why the nose is in the middle of a person’s face?

orig: translate old to modern: I do believe you think what now you speak; But what we do determine oft we break.
target: I believe you believe what you say now, But what we determine to, often we don’t.

orig: translate old to modern: Yes.
target: Yes.

orig: translate old to modern: So full of shapes is fancy That it alone is high fantastical.
target: Love is so vivid and fantastical that nothing compares to it.

target: This might be my lord so-and-so, that praised my lord such-and-such's horse when he meant to ask for it, might it not?

orig: translate old to modern: I took no more pains for those thanks than you took pains to thank me.” That’s as much as to say, “Any pains that I take for you is as easy as thanks.” If I do not take pity of her, I am a villain.
target: I didn’t take any more pains bringing this message than you took pains in thanking me.” That’s like saying, “Any thing I do for you is as easy as saying ‘thank you.’” If this doesn’t move me to take pity on her, I’m a horrible person.

orig: translate old to modern: Strives in his little world of man to outscorn The to-and-fro–conflicting wind and rain.
target: Small but brave in his surroundings, he’s trying to stand up against the wind and rain blowing back and forth.

target: I would not.

target: Why?

target: Is  Would your Mightiness care to wash his hands?

target: Let me be your servant.

orig: translate old to modern: Ready.
target: Ready.

orig: translate old to modern: Yea, marry, that’s the eftest way.—Let the watch come forth.
target: Yes, good idea; that’s the

orig: translate old to modern: Who’s there?
target: Who’s there?

target: That’s a lame threat from a toy gun, a poor individual’s private displeasure with a monarch.

target: Mr. Cobweb; good monsieur, get all your weapons in your hand and kill me a red-hipped humble-bee on the top of a thistle; and, good monsieur, bring me his honey-bag.

target: Be the person you know you are, and you’ll be as powerful as this person you fear.

target: I’ll do the best I can, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: What needed, then, that terrible dispatch of it into your pocket?
target: Then why did you have to stick it in your pocket in such a hurry?

orig: translate old to modern: How may we try it further?
target: How can we find out more?

orig: translate old to modern: Do, good my friend.
target: Do, my good friend.

orig: translate old to modern: to Adrian] [to Sebastian] Why, in good time.
target: Why, in good time.

orig: translate old to modern: My father’s death—      Thy life hath it dishonored.
target: By my father’s death— Your life has dishonored his death.

orig: translate old to modern: E'en so, my lord.
target: Just like that, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: The object poisons sight; Let it be hid.
target: The object of poison’s sight; Let it be hidden.

target: Where is that moron of a cook?

target: Sir, we were discussing how our garments now seem as fresh as they were when we were at the wedding of your daughter, who is now Queen, in Tunis.

orig: translate old to modern: A greater gift than that I’ll give my cousin.
target: I’ll give you a greater gift than that, nephew.

orig: translate old to modern: The man grows mad.
target: The man’s going crazy.

orig: translate old to modern: Directly, I am going to Caesar's funeral.
target: Directly, I’m going to Caesar's funeral.

target: Heaven truly knows that you are as false as hell.

target: Bring the villain out.

target: Richmond is sailing on the sea.

target: Beware the Ides of March.

target: Then what’s Antony?

target: You’ve got it.

target: Regards to Theseus, our renowned duke!

target: What angel wakes me from my flowery bed?

target: Yes, I truly think He did great good.

orig: translate old to modern: So.— Thus then, thou most renowned: Caesar entreats Not to consider in what case thou stand’st, Further than he is Caesar.
target: Just remember that he is Caesar.

target: Is he sane?

orig: translate old to modern: Well, God 'eild you!
target: Well, God protect you!

target: Speak, I command you.

orig: translate old to modern: I humbly thank your ladyship.
target: I humbly thank your ladyship.

orig: translate old to modern: Methinks sometimes I have no more wit than a Christian or an ordinary man has.
target: Sometimes I think I’m no smarter than average.

target: We both obey, And here we give up ourselves, without reservation, To lay our service freely at your feet, To be commanded.

orig: translate old to modern: Have you eyes?
target: Have you got eyes?

orig: translate old to modern: Farewell, and let your haste commend your duty.
target: Farewell and hurry to do your duty.

target: I am sorry that you will leave my father like this: Our house is hell, and you, a happy devil, Robbed it of some taste of boredom.

orig: translate old to modern: This was not counterfeit.
target: That was no show.

orig: translate old to modern: You are thought here to be the most senseless and fit man for the constable of the watch; therefore bear you the lantern.
target: You’re thought to be the most

target: Indeed, my lord, it followed very soon after.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, good Sir Toby.
target: No, good Sir Toby.

orig: translate old to modern: wherefore sink you down?
target: Why have you collapsed?

orig: translate old to modern: Me, a groat?
target: Me, a penny?

orig: translate old to modern: He is as horribly conceited of him, and pants and looks pale, as if a bear were at his heels.
target: He’s pale and hyperventilating, as if a bear were chasing him.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou hast done a deed— I care not for thy sword; I'll make thee known, Though I lost twenty lives.
target: You have done a deed, I don’t care about your sword; I'll make you famous, Although I lose twenty lives.

orig: translate old to modern: What does he say of Brutus?
target: What does he say about Brutus?

orig: translate old to modern: Gentlemen both, we will not wake your patience.
target: Gentlemen, we won’t stay here and anger you further.

orig: translate old to modern: You make me strange Even to the disposition that I owe, When now I think you can behold such sights, And keep the natural ruby of your cheeks When mine is blanch'd with fear.
target: You treat me like a stranger Unlike my usual self, When I wonder now how you can behold such sights, And keep the natural ruby of your cheeks, When mine are blanched with fear.

orig: translate old to modern: What can it not?
target: What can’t it do?

orig: translate old to modern: Your Majesty says very true.
target: Your Majesty is quite right.

orig: translate old to modern: These blazes, daughter, Giving more light than heat, extinct in both Even in their promise, as it is a-making, You must not take for fire.
target: These blazes, daughter, Giving more light than heat, dead in both, Even in their promises, dying as they are being made, Must not be taken for real fire.

orig: translate old to modern: Is my lord angry?
target: Is my lord angry?

orig: translate old to modern: Well, well, away.
target: Well, well, let’s go.

orig: translate old to modern: God’s arm strike with us!
target: May God’s arm strike on our side!

orig: translate old to modern: Thou mak'st me merry; I am full of pleasure.
target: You make me happy: I am full of pleasure.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay.
target: Yes, I do.

orig: translate old to modern: There lives within the very flame of love A kind of wick or snuff that will abate it; And nothing is at a like goodness still; For goodness, growing to a pleurisy, Dies in his own too much.
target: Within the very flame of love, there lives A kind of wick or snuff that will put it out, And nothing is worse than goodness staying still, For goodness, growing to an infectious flu, Dies in his own too much.

orig: translate old to modern: I embrace it.
target: I’m game.

orig: translate old to modern: I do not know, my lord, what I should think.
target: My lord, I don’t know what I should think.

orig: translate old to modern: This will put them out of fear.
target: This will keep them from being frightened.

orig: translate old to modern: Is there a murderer here?
target: Is there a murderer here?

target: But let’s shake hands, Menas.

orig: translate old to modern: Witless else her son.
target: Too bad about the son!

orig: translate old to modern: Know you what Caesar means to do with me?
target: Do you know what Caesar intends to do with me?

orig: translate old to modern: Bounteous madam, Whatever shall become of Michael Cassio, He's never anything but your true servant.
target: Generous madam, Whatever shall become of Michael Cassio, He'll never be anything but your true servant.

orig: translate old to modern: The weight of this sad time we must obey.
target: We must remember the gravity of this sad day.

orig: translate old to modern: Come one more; Two of both kinds makes up four.
target: Come on, one more; Two boys and two girls makes up four.

orig: translate old to modern: If they speak but truth of her, These hands shall tear her; if they wrong her honor, The proudest of them shall well hear of it.
target: If they have spoken the truth about Hero, I will tear her apart with my bare hands.

orig: translate old to modern: Never so weary, never so in woe, Bedabbled with the dew, and torn with briers, I can no further crawl, no further go; My legs can keep no pace with my desires.
target: I have never been so weary, never so sad, Wet from the dew, and torn with briers; I can’t crawl any further.

orig: translate old to modern: What Antony shall speak, I will protest He speaks by leave and by permission, And that we are contented Caesar shall Have all true rites and lawful ceremonies.
target: Whatever Antony shall speak, I’ll formerly declare That he speaks with our permission And that we are happy that Caesar shall Have all true rights and lawful ceremonies.

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll to the throng.
target: I’m going back into battle.

orig: translate old to modern: And yonder, Caesar.
target: And there comes Caesar.

orig: translate old to modern: This broken joint between you and her husband entreat her to splinter; and, my fortunes against any lay worth naming, this crack of your love shall grow stronger than it was before.
target: Beg her to fix this broken joint between you and her husband, and, I’ll bet against any thing worth naming, this crack in your love shall grow stronger than it was before.

orig: translate old to modern: We do, my lord.
target: We are, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, shall we hear this music?
target: Well, should we hear some music?

orig: translate old to modern: I pray thee mark me.
target: Please, listen to me.

orig: translate old to modern: What is thy name?
target: What is your name?

orig: translate old to modern: Go tread the path that thou shalt ne'er return.
target: Go walk the path that you will never return from.

orig: translate old to modern: This prince hath neither claimed it nor deserved it And therefore, in mine opinion, cannot have it.
target: The prince has done neither; therefore, in my opinion, he isn’t really protected by sanctuary.

orig: translate old to modern: I will not charm my tongue; I am bound to speak.
target: I will not control my tongue; I have to speak.

orig: translate old to modern: Here comes the fool, i' faith.
target: Look, here comes the fool.

orig: translate old to modern: I do the wrong, and first begin to brawl.
target: I do the wrong and am the first to start quarrels.

orig: translate old to modern: And so she did.
target: And so she did.

target: Your highness, could you send me on a mission to the ends of the earth?

orig: translate old to modern: For three months,—well.
target: For three months; right?

orig: translate old to modern: O, now you weep, and I perceive you feel The dint of pity.
target: O, now you weep and I can see that you feel The blow of pity.

orig: translate old to modern: She did deceive her father, marrying you; And when she seem'd to shake and fear your looks, She loved them most.
target: She deceived her father by marrying you; And when she seemed to shake and fear your looks, She loved them most.

orig: translate old to modern: Fabian can scarce hold him yonder.
target: Fabian can hardly control him over there.

orig: translate old to modern: Is it so, countrymen?
target: Is that the way it is, countrymen?

target: Here's our chief guest.

orig: translate old to modern: How chances it they travel?
target: How is it that they travel?

target: Who is nothing to you in this kind of merry joking, so you may continue and still laugh at nothing.

orig: translate old to modern: Thus much the business is: we have here writ To Norway, uncle of young Fortinbras— Who, impotent and bed-rid, scarcely hears Of this his nephew's purpose—to suppress His further gait herein, in that the levies, The lists, and full proportions, are all made Out of his subject; and we here dispatch You, good Cornelius, and you, Voltimand, For bearers of this greeting to old Norway, Giving to you no further personal power To business with the King, more than the scope Of these dilated articles allow.
target: we have here written To Norway, uncle of young Fortinbras, Who, impotent and bed-rid, knows nothing Of his nephew's intentions, to stop His further progress in this plan because the levies, The lists, and full proportions are all made Without his knowledge, and we are sending You, good Cornelius, and you, Voltimand, To take this greeting to old Norway, Without giving you any further personal power To do business with the king, more than the scope Of these detailed items allow.

target: To hear this, Desdemona would seriously listen, But still the house affairs would draw her away, Which she would finish in a great hurry, and She’d come again, and eat up my stories With a greedy ear, which I observing, Once I took a rare hour; and found good ways To draw a prayer of earnest enthusiasm from her So that I would lengthen all my stories, Which she had already heard bits and pieces of, But not all of them.
