target: That same cowardly giant-like roast beef has devoured many people from your family.

orig: translate old to modern: By my troth, Nerissa, my little body is a-weary of this great world.
target: Honestly, Nerissa, my little body is weary of this great world.

orig: translate old to modern: had I but the means To hold a rival place with one of them, I have a mind presages me such thrift, That I should questionless be fortunate.
target: If I only had the means To compete with one of them, I have a mind that predicts such good luck for me That I will undoubtedly be a very lucky one.

orig: translate old to modern: My servant, sir!
target: My servant!

orig: translate old to modern: First, forward to the temple; after dinner Your hazard shall be made.
target: First, forward to the temple: after dinner Your choice shall be made.

orig: translate old to modern: Someone take order Buckingham be brought To Salisbury.
target: Someone deliver the order that Buckingham be brought to Salisbury.

orig: translate old to modern: Will you yield and this avoid Or, guilty in defense, be thus destroyed?
target: Will you surrender and avoid all this or be called to account for the destruction of this town?

orig: translate old to modern: You shall, my lord.
target: You will, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Now is it time to arm.
target: It’s time to put our armor on.

orig: translate old to modern: Sir, for your hurts, myself will be your surgeon.
target: Sir, for your hurts, I myself will be your surgeon.

orig: translate old to modern: I know no answer.
target: I don’t know what to say.

orig: translate old to modern: I told him you were sick.
target: I told him you were sick.

orig: translate old to modern: And Duncan's horses—a thing most strange and certain— Beauteous and swift, the minions of their race, Turn'd wild in nature, broke their stalls, flung out, Contending ’gainst obedience, as they would make War with mankind.
target: And Duncan's horses, a thing most strange and certain, Beautiful and swift, the darlings of their race, Turned wild in nature, broke their stalls, flew out, Rebelling against obeying their masters, as if they would make War with mankind.

orig: translate old to modern: What’s that to thee?
target: What’s the difference?

orig: translate old to modern: All’s but naught.
target: Now all is for nothing.

orig: translate old to modern: I'll play this bout first; set it by awhile.
target: I’ll play this bout first, put it aside a while.

orig: translate old to modern: They shall, Nerissa; but in such a habit, That they shall think we are accomplished With that we lack.
target: They shall, Nerissa; but in such a costume That they’ll think we are finished With that we don’t have.

orig: translate old to modern: Draw, you rascal!
target: Draw your sword!

orig: translate old to modern: But now, my lord.
target: Just now, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Advantage is a better soldier than rashness.
target: Strategy makes a better soldier than haste.

orig: translate old to modern: What are thy comings in?
target: What income, what profit does it bring in?

orig: translate old to modern: Art thou of Cornish crew?
target: Are you with a Cornish company?

orig: translate old to modern: This tempest will not give me leave to ponder On things would hurt me more.
target: This storm protects me from thoughts that would hurt me more.

orig: translate old to modern: If the matter were good, my lord, I durst swear it were his.
target: If he’d written nice things, I’d swear yes right away.

orig: translate old to modern: Take this from this, if this be otherwise.
target: Take this from this, if this isn’t the case now.

orig: translate old to modern: Hail, most dear Caesar!
target: Greetings, dearest Caesar!

orig: translate old to modern: My noble girls!
target: My gallant girls!

orig: translate old to modern: But is there no sequel at the heels of this mother's admiration?
target: But isn’t there a sequel that follows this mother's surprise?

orig: translate old to modern: Tis not needed yet.
target: It is not needed yet.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis done.
target: It’s a bet.

orig: translate old to modern: Never, my lord.
target: Never, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: I serve you, madam.
target: I’m at your service, madam.

orig: translate old to modern: But look to it: Find out thy brother, wheresoe'er he is.
target: But do this: find your brother, wherever he is.

orig: translate old to modern: You shall not come to them.
target: You shall not come to them.

orig: translate old to modern: Trouble him no more Till further settling.
target: Don’t trouble him further until his mind is more settled.

orig: translate old to modern: Tell him, when that our princely father York Blessed his three sons with his victorious arm, He little thought of this divided friendship.
target: Tell him that when our noble father, the duke of York, gave his three sons his blessing, he never imagined that our friendship would come to this.

orig: translate old to modern: The grief that does not speak Whispers the o'er fraught heart, and bids it break.
target: The grief that does not speak Builds up softly in the heart, and bids it break.

orig: translate old to modern: Look how thy servants do attend on thee, Each in his office ready at thy beck.
target: Look how your servants wait on you, each one ready to do whatever you command.

orig: translate old to modern: Take them in.
target: Take them in.

orig: translate old to modern: I therefore apprehend and do attach thee For an abuser of the world, a practicer Of arts inhibited and out of warrant.— Lay hold upon him.
target: I therefore arrest and attack you As an abuser of the world, a practitioner Of the forbidden and illegal arts.

orig: translate old to modern: Now I must To the young man send humble treaties, dodge And palter in the shifts of lowness, who With half the bulk o’ th’ world played as I pleased, Making and marring fortunes.
target: Now I will have to send my humble proposal of peace to that young man.

orig: translate old to modern: What other bond Than secret Romans that have spoke the word And will not palter?
target: What other bonds Than secret Romans, that have spoken the word, And will not negotiate without honor?

orig: translate old to modern: O, they did urge it still unto the king.
target: Oh, they continually urged the king to do it.

orig: translate old to modern: Go take this shape, And hither come in't: go; hence with diligence!
target: Go, change into a spirit, And come here invisibly: go, come here with care!

orig: translate old to modern: Remember me.’ I have sworn't.
target: remember me.

orig: translate old to modern: And, my gracious duke, Be it so she will not here before your Grace Consent to marry with Demetrius, I beg the ancient privilege of Athens: As she is mine, I may dispose of her; Which shall be either to this gentleman Or to her death, according to our law Immediately provided in that case.
target: Since she belongs to me, I may dispose of her, Which shall be either to this gentleman Or to her death, according to our law Which is fit to these circumstances.

orig: translate old to modern: Here is a letter Found in the pocket of the slain Roderigo, And here another.
target: Here is a letter Found in the pocket of the murdered Roderigo, And here another.

orig: translate old to modern: And so in me, and so, I think, in all.
target: And so do I. I think we all do.

orig: translate old to modern: Pale, or red?
target: Was he pale or red?

orig: translate old to modern: Thou naughty knave, what trade?
target: You naughty, Deceitful man, what’s your trade?

orig: translate old to modern: Faith, sir, so-so.
target: Well, so-so.

orig: translate old to modern: They sit conferring by the parlor fire.
target: They sit chatting by the parlor fire.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis time to look about.
target: It’s time to reassess the situation.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, by heaven, My blood begins my safer guides to rule, And passion, having my best judgement collied, Assays to lead the way.
target: Now, by heaven, My blood begins to rule my safer sense, And passion, having influenced my better judgment Tries to lead the way.

orig: translate old to modern: I would it might prove the end of his losses!
target: I wish it might prove the end of his losses.

orig: translate old to modern: When in your motion you are hot and dry— As make your bouts more violent to that end— And that he calls for drink, I'll have prepared him A chalice for the nonce; whereon but sipping, If he by chance escape your venom'd stuck, Our purpose may hold there.
target: While you’re moving around and you are hot and dry, Since you’ll make your bouts more violent to that purpose, and he calls for drink, I’ll have prepared a Goblet for him for that purpose, so that even only sipping, If he escapes your stick of venom by luck, We can be successful this way.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, I’ll end the song.—Sirs, cover the while; the duke will drink under this tree.—He hath been all this day to look you.
target: The duke will drink under this tree.—He’s been looking for you all day, you know.

orig: translate old to modern: Indeed, that is out of the air.
target: Indeed, that is out of the air.

orig: translate old to modern: If he ask for me, I am ill and gone to bed.
target: If he asks to see me, tell him I’m sick and went to bed.

orig: translate old to modern: Reads] Sweet Bassanio, my ships have all Reads] miscarried, my creditors grow cruel, my estate is very low, my bond to the Jew is forfeit; and since, in paying it, it is impossible I should live, all debts are cleared between you and I, if I might but see you at my death; Notwithstanding, use your pleasure: if your love do not persuade you to come, let not my letter.
target: Sweet Bassanio, my ships have all sunk, my creditors grow cruel, my funds very low, my promise to pay to the Jew is in default; and since, in paying it, it is impossible for me to live, all debts between you and me are canceled if I might only see you at my death.

orig: translate old to modern: What is it she does now?
target: What’s she doing now?

orig: translate old to modern: For us, we will resign During the life of this old majesty To him our absolute power.
target: As for me, I’m surrendering all my power over to him, giving him absolute authority for the rest of his life.

orig: translate old to modern: O, answer me!
target: O, answer me!

orig: translate old to modern: Well then, your bond; and, let me see.
target: Well then, your promise to pay; and, let me see.

orig: translate old to modern: The higher Nilus swells The more it promises.
target: The higher the Nile flows, the better the harvest.

orig: translate old to modern: Which is the merchant here, and which the Jew?
target: Which is the merchant here, and which the Jew?

orig: translate old to modern: Give me,” quoth I.
target: Give me," said I.

orig: translate old to modern: A living drollery.
target: A living puppet show.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, if you were but an inch of fortune better than I, where would you choose it?
target: Well, if you could have just an inch of better fortune than me, where would you like the improvement?

orig: translate old to modern: If it pass against us, We lose the better half of our possession, For all the temporal lands which men devout By testament have given to the Church Would they strip from us, being valued thus: “As much as would maintain, to the King’s honor, Full fifteen earls and fifteen hundred knights, Six thousand and two hundred good esquires; And, to relief of lazars and weak age Of indigent faint souls past corporal toil, A hundred almshouses right well supplied; And to the coffers of the King besides, A thousand pounds by th' year.” Thus runs the bill.
target: If it does pass, the Church will lose more than half of what it possesses, because the bill would strip us of enough real estate left to the church by wealthy, pious men in their wills to support fifteen earls and fifteen hundred knights, six thousand two hundred squires, and a hundred well-supplied almshouses for the relief of lepers, old-age pensioners, the poor, and those too weak or sick to work.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, madam, twenty several messengers.
target: Yes, madam, twenty different messengers.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, know'st thou any harm's intended towards him?
target: Why, do you know if any harm's intended towards him?

orig: translate old to modern: A worthy fool!
target: A worthy fool!

orig: translate old to modern: The merchandise which thou hast brought from Rome Are all too dear for me.
target: The merchandise you bring from Rome is too expensive for me.

orig: translate old to modern: Go to thy cold bed and warm thee.
target: Go play with yourself.

orig: translate old to modern: Is Claudio thine enemy?
target: Is Claudio your enemy?

orig: translate old to modern: Which is he that killed the deer?
target: Which one of you killed the deer?

orig: translate old to modern: I humbly take my leave.
target: I humbly say goodbye.

orig: translate old to modern: When Prospero is destroyed.
target: When Prospero is destroyed.

orig: translate old to modern: Believe what?
target: Believe what?

orig: translate old to modern: What a pretty thing man is when he goes in his doublet and hose and leaves off his wit!
target: What a strange sight—a man who has put on all his fancy clothes but forgotten his brain at home!

orig: translate old to modern: Who then shall blame His pester'd senses to recoil and start, When all that is within him does condemn Itself for being there?
target: Who, then, shall blame him when His own vexed senses begin to recoil and attack, When all that is within him revolts against him?

orig: translate old to modern: I am not Stephano, but a cramp.
target: Don’t touch me: I am not Stephano, but a cramp.

orig: translate old to modern: Give me the daggers.
target: Give me the daggers.

orig: translate old to modern: When, without stratagem, But in plain shock and even play of battle, Was ever known so great and little loss On one part and on th' other?
target: When was there ever before so great a loss on one side and so little on the other, in the ordinary and equal clash of battle?

orig: translate old to modern: Let's assist them, For our case is theirs.
target: Let’s join them, Since our predicament is the same as theirs.

orig: translate old to modern: Calls your Worship?
target: Did you call for me, your Worship?

orig: translate old to modern: My father charged you in his will to give me good education.
target: My father instructed you in his will to give me a good education.

orig: translate old to modern: Sweet Hero, now thy image doth appear In the rare semblance that I loved it first.
target: Sweet Hero; when I imagine you now, you seem as beautiful as you did when I first loved you.

orig: translate old to modern: Thanks, Rosencrantz and gentle Guildenstern.
target: Thanks, Rosencrantz and gentle Guildenstern.

orig: translate old to modern: The messengers!
target: Call the messengers!

orig: translate old to modern: No, by this hand.
target: No, honestly.

orig: translate old to modern: Belike you slew great number of his people?
target: You probably killed a lot of his men?

orig: translate old to modern: But did’st thou see them dead?
target: But did you see them dead?

orig: translate old to modern: Captain Jamy is a marvelous falorous gentleman, that is certain, and of great expedition and knowledge in th' aunchient wars, upon my particular knowledge of his directions.
target: Captain Jamy is a wonderfully valorous gentleman, that’s certain, one with great learning and knowledge concerning ancient warfare, I happen to know from his maneuvers.

orig: translate old to modern: I can, Petruchio, help thee to a wife With wealth enough, and young and beauteous, Brought up as best becomes a gentlewoman.
target: I can help you find a wife who’s rich, young, beautiful, and reared in a manner fit for a gentlewoman.

orig: translate old to modern: My lord, as I was sewing in my closet, Lord Hamlet, with his doublet all unbraced, No hat upon his head, his stockings fouled, Ungartered, and down-gyved to his ankle; Pale as his shirt, his knees knocking each other, And with a look so piteous in purport As if he had been loosed out of hell To speak of horrors, he comes before me.
target: My lord, as I was sewing in my chamber, Lord Hamlet, with his shirt all unbuttoned, No hat upon his head, his stockings dirty, Not pulled up, and fallen down around his ankles, Pale as his shirt, his knees knocking together, And with a look so pitiful in its meaning As if he had been freed out of hell To speak of horrors, he comes before me.

orig: translate old to modern: How heavy weighs my lord!
target: My lord is so heavy!

orig: translate old to modern: That I was disdainful and that I had my good wit out of The Hundred Merry Tales!
target: Who said that I was disdainful, and that I got all my best lines out of a bad joke book?!

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, then indeed she cannot choose but hate thee, Having bought love with such a bloody spoil.
target: Then she has no choice but to hate you, as you purchased her love with murder.

orig: translate old to modern: Could not this make thee know, The hate I bare thee made me leave thee so?
target: Couldn’t this make you know That the hate I have for you made me leave you like that?

orig: translate old to modern: My lady is within, sir.
target: My lady Olivia’s inside, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Not a mouse stirring.
target: Not a mouse stirring.

orig: translate old to modern: What concern they?
target: What concern are they?

orig: translate old to modern: Shall I have the thought To think on this; and shall I lack the thought That such a thing, bechanc'd, would make me sad?
target: If I had the mind To think about all this, and if I lacked the mind to see That such a thing could happen, wouldn’t it make me sad?

orig: translate old to modern: Though to have her and death were both one thing.
target: Even if marrying her meant I died.

orig: translate old to modern: No jutty, frieze, Buttress, nor coign of vantage, but this bird Hath made his pendant bed and procreant cradle; Where they most breed and haunt, I have observed The air is delicate.
target: I have observed that the air is delicate In areas where they frequently breed and visit.

orig: translate old to modern: Content, in faith; I'll seal to such a bond, And say there is much kindness in the Jew.
target: Happily, in faith; I'll put my seal to such a promise to pay, And say there is much kindness in the Jew.

orig: translate old to modern: Madam, I will.
target: I will, madam.

orig: translate old to modern: Whither should I fly?
target: Where should I fly?

orig: translate old to modern: I say she never did invent this letter.
target: The point is that she didn’t write this letter.

orig: translate old to modern: He calls me “boy” and chides as he had power To beat me out of Egypt.
target: He calls me “boy” and scolds me as if he had the power to whip me out of Egypt.

orig: translate old to modern: This is my treasurer.
target: This is my treasurer.

orig: translate old to modern: If any wretch have put this in your head, Let heaven requite it with the serpent's curse!
target: If any wretch has put this in your head, Let heaven repay them with the serpent's curse!

orig: translate old to modern: They that stand high have many blasts to shake them, And if they fall, they dash themselves to pieces.
target: People in high positions are shaken by many blasts of wind, and when they fall, they shatter into pieces.

orig: translate old to modern: There is a lord will hear you play tonight; But I am doubtful of your modesties, Lest over-eyeing of his odd behavior— For yet his Honor never heard a play— You break into some merry passion And so offend him.
target: There is a particular lord who will watch you perform tonight.

orig: translate old to modern: What Conrade!
target: Be  Conrade!

orig: translate old to modern: Done to death by slanderous tongues Was the Hero that here lies.
target: Here lies Hero, The heroic maiden killed by slanderous words.

orig: translate old to modern: Here come the lovers, full of joy and mirth.
target: Here come the lovers, full of joy and mirth.— Joy, gentle friends!

orig: translate old to modern: The pig, or the great, or the mighty, or the huge, or the magnanimous are all one reckonings, save the phrase is a little variations.
target: The pig or the mighty or the huge or the magnanimous—they all mean the same thing, with some variation.

orig: translate old to modern: Farewell.
target: Goodbye.

orig: translate old to modern: The soul and body rive not more in parting Than greatness going off.
target: When a great person departs, it causes more pain than when the soul leaves the body.

orig: translate old to modern: I had rather give his carcass to my hounds.
target: I had rather give his carcass to my hounds.

orig: translate old to modern: Our course will seem too bloody, Caius Cassius, To cut the head off and then hack the limbs Like wrath in death and envy afterwards; For Antony is but a limb of Caesar.
target: Our plan will seem too bloody, Caius Cassius, To cut off the head, and then hack off the arms and legs, Like anger in death and jealousy afterwards, Because Antony is but a limb of Caesar.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, let me alone for swearing.
target: Don’t worry about me not swearing enough.

orig: translate old to modern: What wouldst thou have, Laertes?
target: What would you ask, Laertes?

orig: translate old to modern: Beatrice— In faith, I will go.
target: Beatrice— I swear, I’m going.

orig: translate old to modern: My thanes and kinsmen, Henceforth be Earls, the first that ever Scotland In such an honor named.
target: My barons and relatives, From this point forward you are earls, the first that Scotland ever Named to such an honor.

orig: translate old to modern: Say that she rail; why then I’ll tell her plain She sings as sweetly as a nightingale.
target: If she rants, I’ll tell her that she sings as sweetly as a nightingale.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, by my holidam, here comes Katherina!
target: By all that’s holy, here comes Katherina!

orig: translate old to modern: If you be gentlemen, Do me this right: hear me with patience.
target: Be good enough to hear me out.

orig: translate old to modern: Go you and prepare Aliena, for look you, here comes my Rosalind.
target: Go get Aliena ready—because, look, here comes my Rosalind.

orig: translate old to modern: Is it so brave as lass?
target: Is it so brave a girl?

orig: translate old to modern: The business she hath broached in the state Cannot endure my absence.
target: I must go and continue the business Fulvia started.

orig: translate old to modern: Infer fair England’s peace by this alliance.
target: Claim fair England’s peace depends on this alliance.

orig: translate old to modern: I have no food for thee.
target: I’ve got no food to give you.

orig: translate old to modern: I hoped thou shouldst have been my Hamlet's wife; I thought thy bride-bed to have deck'd, sweet maid, And not have strew'd thy grave.
target: I hoped you would have been my Hamlet's wife, I thought to have decorated your bride-bed, sweet maid, And not your grave.

orig: translate old to modern: And you are come in very happy time, To bear my greeting to the senators And tell them that I will not come today.
target: And you’ve come at a very happy time To bear my greeting to the Senators, And tell them that I can’t come today.

orig: translate old to modern: Since they did plot The means that dusky Dis my daughter got, Her and her blind boy's scandaled company I have forsworn.
target: Since they plotted With the dark god of the underworld to kidnap my daughter, I have sworn not to be in Her and her blind boy's scandalous company.

orig: translate old to modern: Happily he's the second time come to them; for they say an old man is twice a child.
target: Happily this is the second time he uses them, for they say an old man is twice a child.

orig: translate old to modern: You make me study of that: she was of Carthage, not of Tunis.
target: You made me study that one; she was from Carthage, not of Tunis.

orig: translate old to modern: Think on Lord Hastings.
target: Then run away.

orig: translate old to modern: And do you, Gratiano, mean good faith?
target: And you, Gratiano, are you sincere?

orig: translate old to modern: Talkers are no good doers.
target: Talkers aren’t good doers.

orig: translate old to modern: O, how fit a word Is that vile name to perish on my sword!
target: Oh, how fitting it is that That vile name should perish on my sword!

orig: translate old to modern: You tremble and look pale.
target: You tremble and look pale.

orig: translate old to modern: What else, fellow?
target: What else did you hear?

orig: translate old to modern: Well are you welcome to the open air.
target: Welcome to the open air again.

orig: translate old to modern: We’ll speak with thee at sea.
target: We’ll meet you at sea.

orig: translate old to modern: Signior Baptista, my business asketh haste, And every day I cannot come to woo.
target: Signior Baptista, I’m actually in a bit of a hurry.

orig: translate old to modern: Yes, one place else, if you will hear me name it.
target: Yes, and one other place, if you’ll only let me name it.

orig: translate old to modern: What, art mad?
target: What, are you crazy?

orig: translate old to modern: And when shalt thou see him again?
target: And when will you see him again?

orig: translate old to modern: I know not why he comes.
target: I don’t know why he’s come here.

orig: translate old to modern: Whither wilt thou lead me?
target: Where will you lead me?

orig: translate old to modern: No messenger but thine, and all alone Tonight we’ll wander through the streets and note The qualities of people.
target: Tonight we’ll wander through the streets and observe the people.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, thy godhead laid apart, Warr’st thou with a woman’s heart?
target: Why do you pity him?

orig: translate old to modern: And of women.
target: And women.

orig: translate old to modern: The “why” is plain as way to parish church: He that a fool doth very wisely hit Doth very foolishly, although he smart, Not to seem senseless of the bob.
target: Well, it’s as plain as the beaten path to a parish church.

orig: translate old to modern: Fulvia is dead.
target: Fulvia is dead.

orig: translate old to modern: But now, I tell thee—keep it to thyself— This day those enemies are put to death, And I in better state than e'er I was.
target: But now, I tell you—keep it to yourself, though—those enemies of mine are being put to death today, and I’m better than I’ve ever been.

orig: translate old to modern: First, he commends him to your noble self.
target: First, he sends his regards.

orig: translate old to modern: Wilt thou tell a monstrous lie, being but half a fish and half a monster?
target: Will you tell a monstrous lie, being only half fish and half a monster?

orig: translate old to modern: I myself heard the king say he would not be ransomed.
target: I myself heard the king say he would not be ransomed.

orig: translate old to modern: There is no other way, Unless thou couldst put on some other shape And not be Richard, that hath done all this.
target: There isn’t any other way, unless you took on another form and became someone else.

orig: translate old to modern: Some men there are love not a gaping pig; Some, that are mad if they behold a cat; And others, when the bagpipe sings i' the nose, Cannot contain their urine: for affection, Master of passion, sways it to the mood Of what it likes, or loathes.
target: There are some men that don’t love a dead pig; Some that are crazy if they see a cat; And others, when they hear the song of the bagpipe, Cannot hold their urine, because sympathy, Mistress of passion, persuades passion to the mood Of what it likes or hates.

orig: translate old to modern: Will you go?
target: Will you come?

orig: translate old to modern: But then I saw no harm, and then I heard Each syllable that breath made up between them.
target: But then I saw no harm, and then I heard Each syllable that was exchanged between them.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, madam, have I offered love for this, To be so flouted in this royal presence?
target: Why, madam, have I offered you my love only to be flouted in front of the king?

orig: translate old to modern: Hence, horrible villain, or I’ll spurn thine eyes Like balls before me!
target: Get out, you horrible bastard, or I’ll gouge out your eyes.

orig: translate old to modern: Was ever woman in this humor won?
target: And has anyone ever won her, as I’ve done?

orig: translate old to modern: Now are we well prepared to know the pleasure Of our fair cousin Dauphin, for we hear Your greeting is from him, not from the king.
target: I’m ready now to hear what my good cousin the Dauphin has to say—for I hear that the greeting you bear is from him, not the king.

orig: translate old to modern: If you do stir abroad, go armed.
target: If you go outside, arm yourself.

orig: translate old to modern: Then you live about her waist, or in the middle of her favours?
target: Then you live about her waist, or in the middle of her favors?

orig: translate old to modern: Who is that calls so coldly?
target: Who calls so coldly?

orig: translate old to modern: No.
target: No.

orig: translate old to modern: To what end?
target: And what would that accomplish?

orig: translate old to modern: He is attended with a desperate train.
target: His attendants are desperate, violent men.

orig: translate old to modern: Time, thou anticipatest my dread exploits.
target: Time, you anticipate my dread deeds.

orig: translate old to modern: Here's Cassio hurt by villains.
target: Here's Cassio, hurt by villains.

orig: translate old to modern: Where have you hid yourself?
target: Where have you been hiding?

orig: translate old to modern: Therefore, my lords, omit no happy hour That may give furth'rance to our expedition; For we have now no thought in us but France, Save those to God, that run before our business.
target: Now, lords, don’t let slip any opportunity that might be advantageous for our expedition.

orig: translate old to modern: No.
target: No.

orig: translate old to modern: I am afraid, methinks, to hear you tell it.
target: It scares me just to hear you talk about it.

orig: translate old to modern: Whom should I knock?
target: Whom should I knock?

orig: translate old to modern: No more words.
target: Go ahead—say “Amen.” No more talking.

orig: translate old to modern: Tranio, I saw her coral lips to move And with her breath she did perfume the air.
target: Tranio, I saw her coral-pink lips move and perfume the air with her breath.

orig: translate old to modern: I will unto Venice To buy apparel 'gainst the wedding day.
target: I’m off to Venice to buy outfits for the wedding.

orig: translate old to modern: Aside.
target: Aside.

orig: translate old to modern: And leave out thee?
target: And leave you out?

orig: translate old to modern: A very handsome man.
target: A very handsome man.

orig: translate old to modern: Here’s a night pities neither wise man nor fool.
target: This storm has no pity for either wise men or fools.

orig: translate old to modern: But for a satisfaction of my thought; No further harm.
target: Only to satisfy my thought, No further harm.

orig: translate old to modern: What may this mean That thou, dead corse, again, in complete steel, Revisits thus the glimpses of the moon, Making night hideous, and we fools of nature So horridly to shake our disposition With thoughts beyond the reaches of our souls?
target: What does this mean, That you, dead corpse, again in full armor, Revisit us in the light and shadows of the moon, Making night hideous, and making us fools of nature Shake our dispositions so horridly With thoughts that go beyond the reaches of our souls?

orig: translate old to modern: You know me well.
target: You know me too well.

orig: translate old to modern: Bring me but to the very brim of it, And I’ll repair the misery thou dost bear With something rich about me.
target: Take me to the edge of it, and I’ll reward all your troubles with something valuable.

orig: translate old to modern: Stay, give me drink.
target: Stay, give me drink.

orig: translate old to modern: Truly, and I hold ambition of so airy and light a quality that it is but a shadow's shadow.
target: Truly, and I hold ambition of so airy and light a quality that it is but a shadow's shadow.

orig: translate old to modern: Get you to church, and have a good priest that can tell you what marriage is.
target: Get yourself to a church and have a proper priest, who can tell you what marriage is all about, marry you.

orig: translate old to modern: Tell us the manner of it, gentle Casca.
target: Tell us how it happened, gentle Casca.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, but ask my opinion too of that.
target: No, but ask my opinion too about that.

orig: translate old to modern: What is the matter there?
target: What’s the matter there?

orig: translate old to modern: The sin of my ingratitude even now Was heavy on me.
target: The sin of my ingratitude even now Was heavy on me.

orig: translate old to modern: I take no pleasure In aught an eunuch has.
target: I’m not interested in anything a eunuch can do.

orig: translate old to modern: Who is conductor of his people?
target: Who is leading his men?

orig: translate old to modern: Sir, I cannot.
target: Sir, I cannot.

orig: translate old to modern: If I gave them all my living, I’d keep my coxcombs myself.
target: If I gave them all I own, I’d have two fool’s caps for myself.

orig: translate old to modern: We must speak by the card, or equivocation will undo us.
target: We must speak by the book or lying will undo us.

orig: translate old to modern: But, since the affairs of men rest still incertain, Let's reason with the worst that may befall.
target: But, since the affairs of men still seem uncertain, Let's think about the worst that can happen.

orig: translate old to modern: I will not go today, and ere I do It shall be what o'clock I say it is.
target: We won’t go today—or any day until it’s clear that it shall be whatever time I say it is.

orig: translate old to modern: Stay, you imperfect speakers, tell me more.
target: Wait, you incomplete speakers, tell me more.

orig: translate old to modern: This was sometime a paradox, but now the time gives it proof.
target: This used to be contradictory, but now the time proves it’s true.

orig: translate old to modern: Peace then, no words.
target: Peace then!

orig: translate old to modern: I shall do’t, my lord.
target: Consider it done, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Didst thou not kill this king?
target: You killed this king, didn’t you?

orig: translate old to modern: Our size of sorrow, Proportioned to our cause, must be as great As that which makes it.
target: The size of my sorrow must be as great as its source.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis two or three, my lord, that bring you word Macduff is fled to England.
target: It is two or three, my lord, that bring you word Macduff is fled to England.

orig: translate old to modern: Put your torches out.
target: Put out your torches.

orig: translate old to modern: I shall do my friends no wrong, for I have none to lament me; the world no injury, for in it I have nothing.
target: I won’t wrong any of my friends, because I don’t have any to mourn for me, and I won’t have wronged the world, because I don’t have anything in the world.

orig: translate old to modern: A friend?
target: A friend!

orig: translate old to modern: The letters that he speaks of  May be my friends.
target: The letters he spoke of may help me.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis with him in standing water, between boy and man.
target: He’s somewhere between boy and man.

orig: translate old to modern: What are you?
target: What’s your message?

orig: translate old to modern: If partially affined, or leagued in office, Thou dost deliver more or less than truth, Thou art no soldier.
target: If partially connected or together in office, You deliver more or less than truth, You are no soldier.

orig: translate old to modern: Pardon me, Julius!
target: Pardon me, Julius!

orig: translate old to modern: What dost thou say?
target: What did you say?

orig: translate old to modern: So, good night unto you all.
target: So, good night to you all.

orig: translate old to modern: That is the sum of all, Leonato.—Signior Claudio and Signior Benedick, my dear friend Leonato hath invited you all.
target: And that’s everything, Leonato.—Claudio, Benedick—my dear friend Leonato has invited you all to stay here at Messina.

orig: translate old to modern: So is Lysander.
target: So is Lysander.

orig: translate old to modern: Thus I’ll visit her.
target: I’ll see her like this.

orig: translate old to modern: Caesar, thy thoughts Touch their effects in this.
target: Caesar, you thought this would happen.

orig: translate old to modern: I am so much a fool, should I stay longer, It would be my disgrace and your discomfort.
target: I am so much a fool, that if I stayed longer, It would be my disgrace and your discomfort.

orig: translate old to modern: thieves!
target: Thieves!

orig: translate old to modern: Why, good sir?
target: Why, good sir?

orig: translate old to modern: Pray, do not mock me.
target: Please don’t make fun of me.

orig: translate old to modern: A carrion Death, within whose empty eye There is a written scroll?
target: A skull, whose empty eye has A written scroll in it!

orig: translate old to modern: Prepare we for our marriage; on which day, My Lord of Burgundy, we’ll take your oath, And all the peers', for surety of our leagues.
target: Let us prepare for our wedding.—On that day, I’ll take your oath of loyalty, my Lord of Burgundy and all my peers, to guarantee my treaty.

orig: translate old to modern: Marry, it is your brother’s right hand.
target: Your brother’s right-hand man.

orig: translate old to modern: He, he, ’tis he.
target: He, he, it is he.

orig: translate old to modern: I hate the Moor; And it is thought abroad that 'twixt my sheets He has done my office.
target: I hate the Moor; And it is widely thought that he has done my job Between my sheets.

orig: translate old to modern: I will not trouble thee, my child.
target: I won’t bother you.

orig: translate old to modern: Nor have we herein barr'd Your better wisdoms, which have freely gone With this affair along.
target: We have not disregarded Your good advice, which has freely gone Along with this affair.

orig: translate old to modern: Yet, coming from him, that great med’cine hath With his tinct gilded thee.
target: But since you come from him, you’re saturated with his healing spirit.

orig: translate old to modern: Master Constable, you go not the way to examine.
target: Master Constable, you’re going about this all wrong.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, good fellow, put thine iron on.
target: Come on, good fellow, help me into that armor you’re carrying.

orig: translate old to modern: It is.
target: This is  It is, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: The name of Cassius honors this corruption, And chastisement doth therefore hide his head.
target: The name of Cassius honors this corruption, And, for that reason, punishment hides his head.

orig: translate old to modern: Since Cleopatra died I have lived in such dishonor that the gods Detest my baseness.
target: Since Cleopatra died, I have lived in such dishonor that the gods despise my disgrace.

orig: translate old to modern: I never was nor never will be false.
target: I was never disloyal, and I never will be.

orig: translate old to modern: I have of late—but wherefore I know not— lost all my mirth, forgone all custom of exercises; and indeed, it goes so heavily with my disposition that this goodly frame, the earth, seems to me a sterile promontory; this most excellent canopy, the air, look you, this brave o'erhanging firmament, this majestical roof fretted with golden fire, why, it appears no other thing to me than a foul and pestilent congregation of vapours.
target: I have of late, but why I don’t know, lost all my joy, given up all habits of exercises, and indeed, I am so depressed that this good frame, the earth, seems to me to be a sterile outpost, this most excellent canopy, the air— look—, this brave sky hanging over us, this majestic roof divided with golden fire, why, it seems to me to be nothing but a dirty and disgusting meeting of vapors.

orig: translate old to modern: For even now I put myself to thy direction and Unspeak mine own detraction; here abjure The taints and blames I laid upon myself, For strangers to my nature.
target: for even now I put myself to your direction, and Take back my own detraction of myself; here renounce The taints and blames I laid upon myself, As strangers to my nature.

orig: translate old to modern: He does well to commend it himself; there are no tongues else for's turn.
target: He does well to praise himself, because no one else will praise him.

orig: translate old to modern: Bring me just notice of the numbers dead On both our parts.
target: Bring me an exact report of the number of dead on both sides.

orig: translate old to modern: You’ll “never trust his word after.” Come, ’tis a foolish saying.
target: You’ll “never trust his word again.” Come on, that was a stupid thing to say.

orig: translate old to modern: You know my mind.
target: You know what I intend.

orig: translate old to modern: how otherwise?— Will you be ruled by me?
target: How can it be otherwise?

orig: translate old to modern: Hold your peace.
target: Come, hold your peace.

orig: translate old to modern: Set down your venerable burden, And let him feed.
target: Set the honorable old man down and let him eat.

orig: translate old to modern: And I for Rosalind.
target: And like I am for Rosalind.

orig: translate old to modern: Crystal is muddy.
target: Crystal is muddy.

orig: translate old to modern: Our general cast us thus early for the love of his Desdemona; who let us not therefore blame.
target: Our general put us early like this for the love of his Desdemona, whom we won’t blame.

orig: translate old to modern: Twas this flesh begot Those pelican daughters.
target: I’m the one who fathered those bloodsucking daughters.

orig: translate old to modern: Bid them all fly.
target: Order them to escape.

orig: translate old to modern: If all the wine in my bottle will recover him, I will help his ague.
target: If all the wine in my bottle will help him, I will help his malaria.

orig: translate old to modern: Then we are rid of Litio.
target: So Litio’s out of the picture.

orig: translate old to modern: Yea, leave that labor to great Hercules, And let it be more than Alcides' twelve.
target: Yes, leave that labor to great Hercules—it’s worse than the previous twelve put together.

orig: translate old to modern: I thank you for your company, but, good faith, I had as lief have been myself alone.
target: Thanks for your company but, really, I would have preferred being alone.

orig: translate old to modern: I will compound this strife.
target: I will settle this matter.

orig: translate old to modern: Yes, certainly, and out of doubt and out of question, too, and ambiguities.
target: Yes, absolutely, no question or ambiguity about it.

orig: translate old to modern: I know that virtue to be in you, Brutus, As well as I do know your outward favor.
target: I know you’ve that virtue, Brutus, As well as I know your face.

orig: translate old to modern: Now he’ll outstare the lightning.
target: Now he’ll work himself up to a fury.

orig: translate old to modern: Scorn and defiance, slight regard, contempt, And anything that may not misbecome The mighty sender, doth he prize you at.
target: Scorn and defiance, indifference, contempt, and any insult that wouldn’t disgrace the mighty sender—that’s the value he puts on you.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, marry, now unmuzzle your wisdom.
target: Yes, please; unleash your wisdom.

orig: translate old to modern: If we do meet again, why, we shall smile; If not, why then this parting was well made.
target: If we do meet again, why, we’ll smile; If not, why, then this parting was the right thing to do.

orig: translate old to modern: O Lord, my lord, if they were but a week married, they would talk themselves mad.
target: Oh, Lord, if they were married, they’d drive themselves crazy within a week.

orig: translate old to modern: I am glad to see your Honor.
target: I’m glad to see you.

orig: translate old to modern: Not a false gallop.
target: It’s not a false gallop, anyway.

orig: translate old to modern: How goes the night, boy?
target: How’s your night going, boy?

orig: translate old to modern: I dare avouch it, sir.
target: Yes, I do.

orig: translate old to modern: Zounds, that's fulsome!
target: that's sickening.

orig: translate old to modern: A proper man.
target: He’s an admirable man.

orig: translate old to modern: I' faith, or I either?
target: Me too.

orig: translate old to modern: So, fare thee well.
target: So, good-bye.

orig: translate old to modern: As sweet as balm, as soft as air, as gentle— O Antony!—Nay, I will take thee too.
target: The poison is as sweet as balm, as soft as air, as gentle—Oh, Antony!—No, I’ll take you too.

orig: translate old to modern: She creeps.
target: She creeps along.

orig: translate old to modern: Welcome, my lord.
target: Welcome, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Truly, I would the gods had made thee poetical.
target: Really, Audrey, I wish you were more poetical.

orig: translate old to modern: A poor virgin, sir, an ill-favored thing, sir, but mine own.
target: This poor virgin isn’t much to look at, sir, but she’s mine.

orig: translate old to modern: No, Messala.
target: No, Messala.

orig: translate old to modern: There's something in his soul O'er which his melancholy sits on brood; And I do doubt the hatch and the disclose Will be some danger; which for to prevent, I have in quick determination Thus set it down: he shall with speed to England For the demand of our neglected tribute.
target: There's something in his soul Over which his depression sits like a bird on an egg, And I doubt that egg will hatch and the “bird” Will be something dangerous, which to prevent, I have quickly decided To write it down like this.

orig: translate old to modern: to Alonso] How fares my gracious sir?
target: How are you, my gracious sir?

orig: translate old to modern: Go then and muster men, but leave behind Your son George Stanley.
target: Then go gather your men, but leave behind your son, George Stanley.

orig: translate old to modern: Say, What, is Horatio there?
target: What, is that Horatio with you?

orig: translate old to modern: With him?
target: With him!

orig: translate old to modern: Sayest thou so?
target: Do you really mean that?

orig: translate old to modern: For, look you, how cheerfully my mother looks, and my father died within's two hours.
target: Because look how cheerfully my mother looks, and my father died within these two hours.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, the next day Was our sea-fight; and what to this was sequent Thou know'st already.
target: Now, the next day Was our sea-fight, and what followed You know already.

orig: translate old to modern: what, ho!
target: What, hello!

orig: translate old to modern: And the hour, I think, is come To give him hearing.
target: And, in fact, I think they’re meeting together right now.

orig: translate old to modern: A good persuasion; therefore, hear me, Hermia.
target: A good argument; therefore, listen to me, Hermia.

orig: translate old to modern: Wonder not till further warrant.
target: But don’t keep wondering without more proof.

orig: translate old to modern: If she be a traitor, Why so am I.
target: If she’s a traitor, why then, so am I.

orig: translate old to modern: Double, double, toil and trouble; Fire burn and cauldron bubble.
target: Double, double, toil and trouble; Fire, burn; and caldron, bubble.

orig: translate old to modern: Marry, they say my uncle grew so fast That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old.
target: Indeed, they say my uncle grew so fast that he could gnaw on a crust of bread when he was two hours old.

orig: translate old to modern: I swear to thee, by Cupid's strongest bow, By his best arrow, with the golden head, By the simplicity of Venus' doves, By that which knitteth souls and prospers loves, And by that fire which burn'd the Carthage Queen, When the false Trojan under sail was seen, By all the vows that ever men have broke, In number more than ever women spoke, In that same place thou hast appointed me, Tomorrow truly will I meet with thee.
target: I swear to you by Cupid's strongest bow, By his best arrow, the one with the golden head, By the simplicity of Venus' doves, By that which knits souls and favors lovers, And by that fire which burned Dido, the Carthage queen, When the false Trojan, Aeneas, was seen sailing away,— By all the vows that men have forever broken, In greater numbers than women have ever spoken,— In that same place you have described to me, I will meet you tomorrow, truly.

orig: translate old to modern: My masters, are you mad?
target: Are you all crazy?

orig: translate old to modern: Come, sit on me.
target: Come sit on me.

orig: translate old to modern: What's the boy Malcolm?
target: What about the boy Malcolm?

orig: translate old to modern: Where is he?
target: Where is he?

orig: translate old to modern: The more fool, madonna, to mourn for your brother’s soul being in heaven.
target: Then you’re a fool for being sad that your brother’s soul is in heaven.

orig: translate old to modern: Comes his army on?
target: Is his army coming?

orig: translate old to modern: Since my dear soul was mistress of her choice, And could of men distinguish her election, Sh'hath seal'd thee for herself.
target: Since my dear soul controlled her choice, And could recognize men of truth, her choice Has taken you for herself.

orig: translate old to modern: Now all the plagues that in the pendulous air Hang fated o'er men’s faults light on thy daughters!
target: Then may your daughters be cursed with all the horrible fates that await sinners!

orig: translate old to modern: Speak thou now.
target: Speak now.

orig: translate old to modern: Thy Edward he is dead, that killed my Edward, Thy other Edward dead, to quit my Edward; Young York, he is but boot, because both they Matched not the high perfection of my loss.
target: Your son Edward, who stabbed my son Edward, is dead.

orig: translate old to modern: An apple, cleft in two, is not more twin Than these two creatures.
target: These two people are as identical as two halves of an apple.

orig: translate old to modern: To threaten me with death is most unlawful.
target: For you to threaten to kill me is most unlawful.

orig: translate old to modern: In Parthia did I take thee prisoner, And then I swore thee, saving of thy life, That whatsoever I did bid thee do, Thou shouldst attempt it.
target: In Parthia I took you prisoner; And then I made you swear, since I saved your life, That whatever I asked you to do, You should attempt it.

orig: translate old to modern: You are wel- come to Elsinore.
target: You are welcome to Elsinore.

orig: translate old to modern: The food that to him now is as luscious as locusts, shall be to him shortly as acerb as the coloquintida.
target: The food that is now as luscious as locusts to him shall be shortly be as bitter as the bitter apple drug.

orig: translate old to modern: Let's after him, Whose care is gone before to bid us welcome: It is a peerless kinsman.
target: Let’s go after the man Whose has gone before us to bid us welcome.

orig: translate old to modern: Look how thou dream’st!
target: Look at you, standing there in a stupor!

orig: translate old to modern: If you grow foul with me, Pistol, I will scour you with my rapier, as I may, in fair terms.
target: If you get nasty with me, Pistol, I’ll stab you with my sword, in fair play.

orig: translate old to modern: dead!
target: dead!

orig: translate old to modern: An I may hide my face, let me play Thisbe too.
target: If I can hide my face, let me play Thisbe too.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, but to my choice: Who chooseth me, shall get as much as he deserves.
target: Well, to my choice: “Who chooses me shall get as much as he deserves.” I will assume I am deserving.

orig: translate old to modern: It is not, nor it cannot come to, good.
target: It is not good and it cannot come to good.

orig: translate old to modern: Soldier, thou art; but his whole action grows Not in the power on ’t.
target: Soldier, you are.

orig: translate old to modern: So kind a father!—Be my horses ready?
target: Such a kind father!—Are my horses ready?

orig: translate old to modern: In pity of the challenger’s youth, I would fain dissuade him, but he will not be entreated.
target: Because he’s so young, I’ve tried to discourage him, but he won’t listen.

orig: translate old to modern: Haply when I shall wed That lord whose hand must take my plight shall carry Half my love with him, half my care and duty.
target: Hopefully when I get married, I’ll give my husband half my love and half my sense of duty.

orig: translate old to modern: Hence, saucy eunuch!
target: Get out, insolent eunuch!

orig: translate old to modern: Say again: where didst thou leave these variets?
target: Tell me again, where did you leave these varlets?

orig: translate old to modern: A gentleman?
target: A gentleman?

orig: translate old to modern: Here lies the east.
target: This direction is east.

orig: translate old to modern: You’re fall’n into a princely hand.
target: You’re in the charge of an honorable man.

orig: translate old to modern: He is afeard to come.
target: He’s afraid to come in.

orig: translate old to modern: So is the bargain.
target: That’s the deal.

orig: translate old to modern: And yet it is danger To make him even o'er the time he has lost.
target: But it’s dangerous to make him try to make sense of the time he lost.

orig: translate old to modern: If thou didst ever hold me in thy heart, Absent thee from felicity awhile, And in this harsh world draw thy breath in pain, To tell my story.
target: If you ever did hold me in your heart, Stay away from happy things for a while, And, in this harsh world, draw your breath in pain To tell my story.

orig: translate old to modern: Hearty thanks.
target: Thank you very much.

orig: translate old to modern: Horrible steep.
target: No, it’s dreadfully steep.

orig: translate old to modern: Marcus Octavius, Marcus Justeius, Publicola, and Caelius, are for sea; But we keep whole by land.
target: Marcus Octavius, Marcus Justeius, Publicola, and Caelius will go by sea, but we’ll keep the bulk on land.

orig: translate old to modern: Lead me.
target: Lead the way.

orig: translate old to modern: We do not mean the coursing snatchers only, But fear the main intendment of the Scot, Who hath been still a giddy neighbor to us.
target: What we have to worry about is a full-scale invasion from Scotland—always an unreliable neighbor.

orig: translate old to modern: Come.
target: Come on.

orig: translate old to modern: Ha!
target: Ha!

orig: translate old to modern: Iago hath direction what to do; But notwithstanding, with my personal eye Will I look to't.
target: Iago has orders on what to do; But, nevertheless, with my own eyes I will look to it myself.

orig: translate old to modern: The great rage, You see, is killed in him.
target: His insane period is over.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, do you so: let not me take him then, For if I do, I'll mar the young clerk's pen.
target: Well, do so: don’t let me take him then; Because, if I do, I'll break the young clerk's pen.

orig: translate old to modern: What have I kept back?
target: What did I keep for myself?

orig: translate old to modern: He is ready at the door: he comes, my lord.
target: He is ready at the door; he comes, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: And will she yet abase her eyes on me, That cropped the golden prime of this sweet prince And made her widow to a woeful bed?
target: And yet she cheapens herself by turning her gaze on me, who cut her sweet prince’s life short and made her a widow?

orig: translate old to modern: What’s thy passion?
target: What’s wrong with you?

orig: translate old to modern: Keep your word, Silvius, that you’ll marry her If she refuse me.
target: Silvius, keep your promise to marry Phoebe if she refuses me.

orig: translate old to modern: Thy adversary’s wife doth pray for thee.
target: Why?

orig: translate old to modern: Some good man bear him carefully from hence; I'll fetch the general's surgeon.
target: Some good men carry him carefully from here; I'll fetch the general's surgeon.

orig: translate old to modern: One dead, or drunk?
target: A drunkard or a corpse?

orig: translate old to modern: Unto the dignity and height of fortune, The high imperial type of this earth’s glory.
target: No, advancement to the dignity and height of honor, to a high, imperial kind of glory.

orig: translate old to modern: My lady bade me tell you, that, though she harbors you as her kinsman, she’s nothing allied to your disorders.
target: My lady told me to tell you that while she lets you stay at her house because you’re a relative, she doesn’t approve of your behavior.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou dost see I eat.
target: Can’t you see I’m eating?

orig: translate old to modern: Here we.
target: This is our station.

orig: translate old to modern: Go to, go to; you have known what you should not.
target: You have known what you should not.

orig: translate old to modern: Then ’tis like the breath of an unfee’d lawyer.
target: In that case it’s like the words of an unpaid lawyer.

orig: translate old to modern: It is an accustomed action with her, to seem thus washing her hands.
target: She’s accustomed to it, to seem to washing her hands in this way.

orig: translate old to modern: Down from the waist they are centaurs, though women all above.
target: Women are sex machines below the waist, though they’re chaste up above.

orig: translate old to modern: Both, both, my girl.
target: Both, both, my girl.

orig: translate old to modern: For taking one’s part that’s out of favor.
target: For standing up for this unpopular king.

orig: translate old to modern: Good Margaret, run thee to the parlor.
target: Margaret, run into the sitting room.

orig: translate old to modern: He hath assembled Bocchus, the King of Libya; Archelaus, Of Cappadocia; Philadelphos, King Of Paphlagonia; the Thracian king, Adallas; King Manchus of Arabia; King of Pont; Herod of Jewry; Mithridates, King Of Comagen; Polemon and Amyntas, The Kings of Mede and Lycaonia, With a more larger list of scepters.

target: You cannot, sir, take from me anything that I will more willingly part with, except my life, except my life, except my life.

target: Yes,” said my uncle Gloucester, “Small plants are graceful, while ugly weeds grow fast.” And since then, I’ve wished I wouldn’t grow so fast, because sweet flowers are slow while the weeds grow in a hurry.

target: Isn’t it monstrous that this actor here, Only in a play, in a dream of passion, Could force his soul so to his own actions That his grew pale from the words of the speech, Tears in his eyes, separation from reality in his face, A broken voice, and his whole function matching Forms to his role?
