target: To have no hope that he is drowned is another way to have such a high hope, That even Ambition can’t see beyond it, But defies belief.

orig: translate old to modern: The harlot's cheek, beautied with plastering art, Is not more ugly to the thing that helps it Than is my deed to my most painted word.
target: The prostitute's cheek, covered with makeup, Isn’t more ugly to the thing that helps it Than is my deed to my very artificial words.

orig: translate old to modern: The king hath heard them, to the which as yet There is no answer made.
target: The king has heard them, but as yet has made no answer.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, and truly, you were best.
target: Yes, and truly; you had better answer.

orig: translate old to modern: Who of my people hold him in delay?
target: Who’s talking to him now?

orig: translate old to modern: Then, Brutus, I have much mistook your passion, By means whereof this breast of mine hath buried Thoughts of great value, worthy cogitations.
target: Then, Brutus, I have really misunderstood your passions, Which is why this my heart has forgotten Thoughts of great value, worthy thoughts.

orig: translate old to modern: Yea, Richard, when I know, for I protest As yet I do not.
target: I’ll tell you as soon as I know, Richard, because at this point I have no idea.

orig: translate old to modern: Must I remember?
target: Must I remember?

orig: translate old to modern: O dear!
target: Oh dear!

orig: translate old to modern: And look you get a prayer book in your hand And stand between two churchmen, good my lord, For on that ground I’ll make a holy descant.
target: And make sure to carry a prayer book in your hand and to stand between two priests, okay?

orig: translate old to modern: Say you so?
target: You say so?

orig: translate old to modern: Here it is, I think.
target: Here it is, I think.

orig: translate old to modern: You have not a man in all Athens able to discharge Pyramus but he.
target: There’s not a man in all Athens able to play Pyramus but he.

orig: translate old to modern: One sees more devils than vast hell can hold; That is the madman.
target: One sees more devils than vast hell can hold; That is the madman.

orig: translate old to modern: Truly, shepherd, in respect of itself, it is a good life; but in respect that it is a shepherd’s life, it is naught.
target: Well, in and of itself, it is a good life, but given that it’s a shepherd’s life, it’s worthless.

orig: translate old to modern: Caesar, beware of Brutus; take heed of Cassius; come not near Casca; have an eye to Cinna; trust not Trebonius; mark it well Metellus Cimber; Decius Brutus loves thee not; thou hast wronged Caius Ligarius.
target: Caesar, beware of Brutus; be careful of Cassius; don’t come near Casca; watch Cinna; don’t trust Trebonius; pay attention to Metellus Cimber; Decius Brutus doesn’t love you; you’ve sinned against Caius Ligarius.

orig: translate old to modern: Fair lady, do you think you have fools in hand?
target: Do you think you’ve got a couple of fools on your hands here?

orig: translate old to modern: Then, if ever thou dar’st acknowledge it, I will make it my quarrel.
target: Then, if you dare to acknowledge it, I’ll take up my quarrel with you.

orig: translate old to modern: It is a massy wheel, Fix'd on the summit of the highest mount, To whose huge spokes ten thousand lesser things Are mortised and adjoin'd; which, when it falls, Each small annexment, petty consequence, Attends the boisterous ruin.
target: It is a massive wheel, Set at the top of the highest mountain, In which its huge spokes, ten thousand little things Are firmly glued together, that, when the wheel falls, Each small piece, insignificant event, Adds to the noisy ruin of the country.

orig: translate old to modern: What!
target: What!

orig: translate old to modern: Is it not Hero?
target: Isn’t my name Hero?

orig: translate old to modern: Sir, He is with Caesar.
target: Sir, he’s with Caesar.

orig: translate old to modern: Nothing.
target: Nothing.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis figured in my tongue.
target: I’ve told you.

orig: translate old to modern: Mark Antony,— Pardon me, Caius Cassius.
target: Mark Antony,— Pardon me, Caius Cassius.

orig: translate old to modern: I pity you.
target: I feel sorry for you.

orig: translate old to modern: and squabble?
target: and squabble?

orig: translate old to modern: Many good morrows to my noble lord.
target: Good morning, my noble lord.

orig: translate old to modern: What stay had I but Edward?
target: What support did I have other than Edward?

orig: translate old to modern: A sailor's wife had chestnuts in her lap, And mounch'd, and mounch'd, and mounch'd.
target: A sailor's wife had chestnuts in her lap, And munched, and munched, and munched.

orig: translate old to modern: I fear me you’ll be in till then.
target: I’m afraid you’ll keep going until then.

orig: translate old to modern: He may recover yet.
target: He may recover yet.

orig: translate old to modern: Hamlet, this pearl is thine; Here's to thy health.
target: Hamlet, this pearl is your, Here's to your health.

orig: translate old to modern: Good sir, I do in friendship counsel you To leave this place.
target: Good sir, as a friend, I advise you to leave this place.

orig: translate old to modern: Farewell!
target: Goodbye!

orig: translate old to modern: What place?
target: What place?

orig: translate old to modern: His means of death, his obscure burial— No trophy, sword, nor hatchment o'er his bones, No noble rite nor formal ostentation, Cry to be heard, as 'twere from heaven to earth, That I must call't in question.
target: I agree, His means of death, his obscure burial, No trophy, sword, no coat of arms over his bones No noble rites or state funeral, Cry to be heard, from heaven to earth as it were, That I must call it into question.

orig: translate old to modern: I charge thee, be not thou more grieved than I am.
target: I insist, don’t be more distressed than I am.

orig: translate old to modern: Yon ribaudred nag of Egypt— Whom leprosy o’ertake!—i’ th’ midst o’ th’ fight, When vantage like a pair of twins appeared Both as the same, or rather ours the elder, The breeze upon her, like a cow in June, Hoists sails and flies.
target: Right in the middle of the fight, just when the battle could have gone either way—actually we had a slight advantage—that immoral Egyptian nag—May she die of leprosy!—suddenly became frightened, and turned her ships around and fled.

orig: translate old to modern: If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is none of the Prince’s subjects.
target: If he won’t stop when he’s told to, then he isn’t one of the Prince’s subjects.

orig: translate old to modern: O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!
target: O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!

orig: translate old to modern: His bark is stoutly timber'd, and his pilot Of very expert and approved allowance; Therefore my hopes, not surfeited to death, Stand in bold cure.
target: His ship is heavily timbered, and his captain is Very experienced and has a good reputation; Therefore my hopes, not excessively fed to death, Stand in heavy anxiety.

orig: translate old to modern: With this I depart—that, as I slew my best lover for the good of Rome, I have the same dagger for myself, when it shall please my country to need my death.
target: With this, I leave — that, as I killed my best friend for the good of Rome, I have the same dagger for myself, to be used when it shall please my country to need my death.

orig: translate old to modern: A could never abide carnation.
target: He could never bear carnation.

orig: translate old to modern: Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony, who, though he had no hand in his death, shall receive the benefit of his dying, a place in the commonwealth, as which of you shall not?
target: Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony, who, although he had no hand in his death, shall receive the benefit of his dying, a place in the commonwealth, just as you all will.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay 'tis twice two months, my lord.
target: No, it is four months, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Come to what is important in ’t.
target: Get to the point now.

orig: translate old to modern: Wilt thou be pleased to hearken once again to the suit I made to thee?
target: Will it please you to listen once again to the favor I asked you?

orig: translate old to modern: Come, my dear love, The purchase made, the fruits are to ensue; That profit's yet to come 'tween me and you.
target: Come, my dear love, The purchase made, the fruits are to follow, That profit is still to come between me and you.

orig: translate old to modern: Indeed?
target: Indeed?

orig: translate old to modern: Tell me where it is.
target: Tell me where you live.

orig: translate old to modern: I saw him put down the other day with an ordinary fool that
target: The other day I saw him defeated in a

orig: translate old to modern: When it is lighted, come and call me here.
target: When it is lit, come back and call me here.

orig: translate old to modern: Even he.
target: That’s the one.

orig: translate old to modern: I go.
target: I’m going now.

orig: translate old to modern: To ’t, luxury, pell-mell—for I lack soldiers.
target: Get to it, be lustful, sleep around—I need soldiers for my army.

orig: translate old to modern: Ha, ha!
target: Ha, ha!

orig: translate old to modern: Hath the fellow any wit that told you this?
target: Is this servant of yours a smart man?

orig: translate old to modern: My comfort is that old age, that ill layer-up of beauty, can do no more spoil upon my face.
target: My comfort is that old age, that poor preserver of beauty, can’t make my face any worse than it already is.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, poor remains of friends, rest on this rock.
target: Come, poor remains of friends, rest on this rock.

orig: translate old to modern: Who alone suffers, suffers most i' th' mind, Leaving free things and happy shows behind.
target: The person who suffers alone suffers the most.

orig: translate old to modern: To seek my uncle in the Forest of Arden.
target: To the Forest of Arden, to find your father.

orig: translate old to modern: Yes, marry, sir.
target: Yes, of course.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis certain he hath passed the river Somme.
target: He’s certainly crossed the river Somme.

orig: translate old to modern: I warrant you, sir; The white cold virgin snow upon my heart Abates the ardour of my liver.
target: I promise you, sir, The cold, white, virgin snow on my heart Holds back my passion.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, let me clutch thee.
target: Come, let me clutch you.

orig: translate old to modern: Good, good.
target: Good, very good.

orig: translate old to modern: When Caesar lived, he durst not thus have moved me.
target: When Caesar lived, he wouldn’t dare insult me like this.

orig: translate old to modern: Foul words is but foul wind, and foul wind is but foul breath, and foul breath is noisome.
target: If you had foul words in your mouth, then your breath must be foul, and foul breath is nauseating.

orig: translate old to modern: If I do die before thee, prithee shroud me In one of those same sheets.
target: If I die before you, I beg you, shroud me In one of those same sheets.

orig: translate old to modern: I will not leave him now till Cassio Be call'd to him.
target: I will not leave him now until Cassio Is called to him.

orig: translate old to modern: These sentences, to sugar or to gall, Being strong on both sides, are equivocal.
target: These sentences, to sweetness or to bitterness, Being strong on both sides, are equal.

orig: translate old to modern: What, do you shake at that?
target: What, you shake at that?

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll have no halves.
target: I’ll have no halves.

orig: translate old to modern: You, uncivil lady, To whose ingrate and unauspicious altars My soul the faithfull’st off'rings have breathed out That e'er devotion tendered—what shall I do?
target: I breathed from my soul the most faithful offerings to your ungrateful altars that any devoted person has ever offered—what more am I supposed to do?

orig: translate old to modern: Most like.
target: Yes, it does.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, she defies me Like Turk to Christian.
target: Why, she challenges me like a Muslim would challenge a Christian.

orig: translate old to modern: Be ’t so.
target: So be it.

orig: translate old to modern: If you have poison for me, I will drink it.
target: If you have poison for me, I’ll drink it.

orig: translate old to modern: He is not very tall—yet for his years he’s tall.
target: He’s not very tall, but he’s tall enough for his age.

orig: translate old to modern: Help!
target: Help!

orig: translate old to modern: Will money buy ’em?
target: Will money buy them?

orig: translate old to modern: Where is Metellus Cimber?
target: Where is Metellus Cimber?

orig: translate old to modern: Nor I, my lord, in faith.
target: Nor I, my lord, really.

orig: translate old to modern: Hath it not, boy?
target: Haven’t you, boy?

orig: translate old to modern: It cannot be.
target: It cannot be.

orig: translate old to modern: Do not you meddle.
target: Don’t bother with it.

orig: translate old to modern: None but his enemies.
target: No one but his enemies.

orig: translate old to modern: To him, Sir Topas.
target: Go to him, Sir Topas.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, if you be an undertaker, I am for you.
target: If you’re someone who gets into fights, I’ll fight with you.

orig: translate old to modern: Whither are they vanish'd?
target: Where did they vanished to?

orig: translate old to modern: We see it and will say it.
target: We understand you’re just doing it for us, and we’ll be sure to say so.

orig: translate old to modern: So can I.
target: I can too.

orig: translate old to modern: O brave touch!
target: Oh brave touch!

orig: translate old to modern: Nothing, good monsieur, but to help Cavalery Cobweb to scratch.
target: Nothing, good sir, but for you to help Mr. Cobweb scratch my head.

orig: translate old to modern: Can no prayers pierce thee?
target: Can any prayers get through to you?

orig: translate old to modern: I thank thee for that gird, good Tranio.
target: I thank you for that quip, good Tranio.

orig: translate old to modern: What dost thou mean by this?
target: What do you mean by this?

orig: translate old to modern: Teach me.
target: Tell me.

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll ask them.
target: I’ll ask them.

orig: translate old to modern: We are the queen’s abjects and must obey.— Brother, farewell.
target: Farewell, brother.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, this is an arrant counterfeit rascal.
target: Why, that man is a total fraud and rascal.

orig: translate old to modern: I did say so When first I raised the tempest.
target: I said so When first I raised the storm.

orig: translate old to modern: Attend the lords of France and Burgundy, Gloucester.
target: Go escort the lords of France and Burgundy, Gloucester.

orig: translate old to modern: Shall Kate be my wife?
target: Shall Kate be my wife?

orig: translate old to modern: Will you go?
target: Will you come with us?

orig: translate old to modern: Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice and desire her to rise.
target: Good Ursula, go wake my cousin and ask her to get up.

orig: translate old to modern: Now near enough; your leavy screens throw down, And show like those you are.
target: Now that we’re near enough, throw the branch down, And look like the men you are.

orig: translate old to modern: A friend should bear his friend's infirmities, But Brutus makes mine greater than they are.
target: A friend should tolerate his friend's shortcomings, But Brutus makes mine greater than they are.

orig: translate old to modern: Or to be naked with her friend in bed An hour or more, not meaning any harm?
target: Or to be naked with her friend in bed An hour or more, not meaning any harm?

orig: translate old to modern: Great Mark Antony Is now a widower.
target: Great Mark Antony is a widower now.

orig: translate old to modern: I'll silence me even here.
target: I’ll hide here silently.

orig: translate old to modern: But in this case of wooing, A child shall get a sire, if I fail not of my cunning.
target: But in this case of wooing, a child shall father his own father—if my wits don’t fail me.

orig: translate old to modern: Bid farewell to your sisters.
target: Say goodbye to your sisters.

orig: translate old to modern: I'll touch my point With this contagion, that, if I gall him slightly, It may be death.
target: I’ll touch the point of my sword with this poison so that, if I touch him slightly, It will kill him.

orig: translate old to modern: Know you any, count?
target: Do you know any, count?

orig: translate old to modern: Now, Catesby, what says your lord to my request?
target: Now, Catesby, what does your lord say to my request?

orig: translate old to modern: Yet I insisted, yet you answer'd not, But with an angry wafture of your hand Gave sign for me to leave you.
target: Still I insisted; still you didn’t answer, But, with an angry wave of your hand, You gave me a sign to leave you.

orig: translate old to modern: I am even The natural fool of fortune.
target: No rescue for me?

orig: translate old to modern: My lord, here stays without, A messenger with letters from the doctor, New come from Padua.
target: My lord, There is a messenger waiting outside With letters from the doctor, Just now arrived from Padua.

orig: translate old to modern: Here comes his Majesty.
target: Here comes his Majesty.

orig: translate old to modern: Yea, and my father.
target: Yes, and my father.

orig: translate old to modern: How now?
target: Hello.

orig: translate old to modern: The king doth keep his revels here tonight; Take heed the queen come not within his sight; For Oberon is passing fell and wrath, Because that she as her attendant hath A lovely boy, stolen from an Indian king.
target: Oberon is really angry and annoyed, Because she, just like her attendant, has A lovely boy, that was stolen from an Indian king; She has never had so sweet a baby that was stolen.

orig: translate old to modern: I swear I’ll cuff you if you strike again.
target: I swear I’ll smack you if you hit me again.

orig: translate old to modern: O sir, you are old.
target: Sir, you’re old.

orig: translate old to modern: And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?
target: And did they ask you to tell Beatrice about this, madam?

orig: translate old to modern: Refuse it not.
target: Don’t refuse it.

orig: translate old to modern: We would so, and then go a-bat-fowling.. [to Gonzalo] Nay, good my lord, be not angry.
target: We would so, and then go swindling.

orig: translate old to modern: What, ho!
target: What, ho!

orig: translate old to modern: What news?
target: What was it?

orig: translate old to modern: That she may long live here, God say amen.
target: So that England may live a long life like this, let God say amen!

orig: translate old to modern: By my troth, he’ll yield the crow a pudding one of these days.
target: I swear, he’ll be food for the crows soon.

orig: translate old to modern: Good old knight, Collect them all together at my tent.
target: Good old knight, gather them all together at my tent.

orig: translate old to modern: Prison, my lord?
target: Prison, my lord!

orig: translate old to modern: By your leave, hostess.
target: With your permission, hostess.

orig: translate old to modern: Who governs here?
target: Who’s the ruler here?

orig: translate old to modern: Marry, God forbid!
target: Damn it, God forbid!

orig: translate old to modern: A thousand thanks, Signior Gremio.
target: Many thanks, Signior Gremio.

orig: translate old to modern: I am not treacherous.
target: I am not treacherous.

orig: translate old to modern: And that distill'd by magic sleights Shall raise such artificial sprites As by the strength of their illusion Shall draw him on to his confusion.
target: And that drop, distilled by magic tricks, Shall raise such unnatural spirits, That, by the strength of their deception, Shall add to his confusion.

orig: translate old to modern: Be aidant and remediate In the good man’s distress.
target: May they relieve a sick old man’s suffering.

orig: translate old to modern: True, my lord.
target: True, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Nor what I have done by water.
target: Neither can my accomplishments at sea.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, I will give you way for these your letters, And do't the speedier that you may direct me To him from whom you brought them.
target: Then you can direct me To him you delivered them for.

orig: translate old to modern: What sense had I of her stol'n hours of lust?
target: What sense did I have of her stolen hours of lust?

orig: translate old to modern: There is a river in Macedon, and there is also, moreover, a river at Monmouth.
target: There is a river in Macedon, and there is likewise a river in Monmouth.

orig: translate old to modern: She did show favor to the youth in your sight only to exasperate you, to awake your dormouse valor, to put fire in your heart and brimstone in your liver.
target: She flirted with the messenger boy to exasperate you, fire up your passions, and make you angry and jealous.

orig: translate old to modern: If Hercules and Lichas play at dice Which is the better man, the greater throw May turn by fortune from the weaker hand: So is Alcides beaten by his page; And so may I, blind fortune leading me, Miss that which one unworthier may attain, And die with grieving.
target: If Hercules and Lichas threw dice to decide Who was the better man, the best throw May be turned by luck to come from the weaker hand: So Alcides was beaten by his boy servant; And I might too, with blind Fortune leading me, Miss that treasure which a more unworthy man may get, And I’ll die from grieving.

orig: translate old to modern: Look how she rubs her hands.
target: Look how she rubs her hands.

orig: translate old to modern: If he say so, may his pernicious soul Rot half a grain a day!
target: If he said so, may his evil soul Rot half a grain a day!

orig: translate old to modern: Thou must be patient.
target: You have to be patient with me.

orig: translate old to modern: Marry, that should you if I were your mistress, or I should think my honesty ranker than my wit.
target: Indeed, you would be out if I were your mistress—if my chastity is worth as much as my wit.

orig: translate old to modern: Get you gone And hasten your return.
target: Now go, and hurry back.

orig: translate old to modern: Also King Lewis the Tenth, Who was sole heir to the usurper Capet, Could not keep quiet in his conscience, Wearing the crown of France, till satisfied That fair Queen Isabel, his grandmother, Was lineal of the Lady Ermengare, Daughter to Charles the foresaid duke of Lorraine, By the which marriage the line of Charles the Great Was reunited to the crown of France.
target: Another case: King Lewis the Tenth, who was sole heir to the usurper Capet, could not rest easy as king until he was assured that Queen Isabel, his grandmother, was a direct descendent of the Lady Ermengare, daughter of the aforementioned Charles duke of Lorraine, by which marriage the line of Charles the Great was reunited with the throne of France.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou art thy father’s daughter.
target: You are your father’s daughter.

orig: translate old to modern: I say, amen.
target: I say, amen.

orig: translate old to modern: A sweeter and a Lovellier gentleman, Framed in the prodigality of nature, Young, valiant, wise, and, no doubt, right royal, The spacious world cannot again afford.
target: He was graced with lots of natural gifts, he was young, valiant, wise, and no doubt meant to be king.

orig: translate old to modern: The duke must grant me that.
target: The duke will agree with me on that.

orig: translate old to modern: Let me but meet you ladies one hour hence, And I’ll salute your Grace of York as mother And reverend looker-on, of two fair queens.
target: In just an hour from now, Duchess of York, I’ll be saluting you as the mother of two beautiful queens.

orig: translate old to modern: I saw Mark Antony offer him a crown, yet 'twas not a crown neither, 'twas one of these coronets and, as I told you, he put it by once.
target: I saw Mark Antony offer him a crown;—yet it wasn’t a crown either, it was one of these large hats;—and, as I told you, he pushed it aside once.

orig: translate old to modern: Stay with us.
target: Stay with us tonight.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, I will forget the condition of my estate to rejoice in yours.
target: If  Well, I’ll just forget the difficulties of my situation, in order to focus on the happiness of yours.

orig: translate old to modern: Would not they speak?
target: They wouldn’t say anything?

orig: translate old to modern: Most reverend signior, do you know my voice?
target: Very reverend Signior, do you know my voice?

orig: translate old to modern: Why, horns, which such as you are fain to be beholding to your wives for.
target: Why, his cuckold’s horns, of course—the kind you men are always blaming on your wives.

orig: translate old to modern: I follow thee.
target: I follow you.

orig: translate old to modern: In wisdom I should ask thy name.
target: Normally I would ask you what your name is first.

orig: translate old to modern: Look, sir, I bleed.
target: Look, sir, I’m bleeding.

orig: translate old to modern: If they will fight with us, bid them come down, Or void the field.
target: If they seek battle with us, have them come down or else clear the field.

orig: translate old to modern: But, my good lord, this boy is forest-born And hath been tutored in the rudiments Of many desperate studies by his uncle, Whom he reports to be a great magician Obscurèd in the circle of this forest.
target: But, my lord, this boy was born in the forest and has been schooled not in the usual subjects but only in magic.

orig: translate old to modern: He hath done good service, lady, in these wars.
target: Signior Benedick served well in the war, my lady.

orig: translate old to modern: Minion, thou liest.
target: You lying brat.

orig: translate old to modern: Nor will you tender less.
target: I know you’ll offer nothing less than that.

orig: translate old to modern: Hath an argosy cast away, coming from Tripolis.
target: has his largest ship lost, coming from Tripolis.

orig: translate old to modern: The King, sir— Ay, sir, what of him?
target: The king, sir Yes, sir, what about him?

orig: translate old to modern: I had forgot the reward.
target: I forgot about the reward.

orig: translate old to modern: There lies your love.
target: Your “love” is lying there.

orig: translate old to modern: I little thought You would have followed.
target: I didn’t think you would follow me.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, I'll set you forth.
target: Well, I'll point you in the right direction.

orig: translate old to modern: Six or seven thousand is their utmost power.
target: Six or seven thousand, at most.

orig: translate old to modern: I think it well, my lord.
target: I think you’re right, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Soft!
target: Hang on!

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll do the service of a younger man In all your business and necessities.
target: I’ll do everything a younger man could do for you.

orig: translate old to modern: Do you sing it, and I’ll dance it.
target: You sing, and I’ll dance.

orig: translate old to modern: Humbly I thank your Grace.
target: Humbly I thank your grace.

orig: translate old to modern: Name Cleopatra as she is called in Rome.
target: Call Cleopatra what the Romans call her.

orig: translate old to modern: By Cheshu, I think he will plow up all if there is not better directions.
target: By Jesus, I think they will blow up everything if we don’t improve our tactics.

orig: translate old to modern: Hail to your lordship!
target: Greetings to your lordship!

orig: translate old to modern: I have a ship Laden with gold.
target: I have a ship full of treasure.

orig: translate old to modern: If thou rememb'rest aught ere thou cam'st here, How thou cam'st here thou mayst.
target: If you remember anything before you came here, How you came here, you may remember.

orig: translate old to modern: The Jove of power make me most weak, most weak, Your reconciler!
target: May the god of power make me, the weakest of the weak, your mediator.

orig: translate old to modern: I pray, sir, tell me, is it possible That love should of a sudden take such hold?
target: Sir, is it possible that a person could fall in love so suddenly?

orig: translate old to modern: What do you mean To dote thus on such luggage?
target: What do you mean By being so stupidly fond like this on such goods?

orig: translate old to modern: Tis meet I should be used so, very meet.
target: It’s right I should be used this way, very right.

orig: translate old to modern: I'll run from thee and hide me in the brakes, And leave thee to the mercy of wild beasts.
target: I'll run from you, and hide in the bushes, And leave you to the mercy of wild beasts.

orig: translate old to modern: Refrain to-night, And that shall lend a kind of easiness To the next abstinence; the next more easy; For use almost can change the stamp of nature, And [either master] the devil, or throw him out With wondrous potency.
target: The next more easy, For use can almost change what is natural, And can either curb the devil or throw him out With wondrous effectiveness.

orig: translate old to modern: Let him speak, my lord, Upon his peril, that I have reserved To myself nothing.
target: My lord, he will swear on his life that I haven’t kept a thing.—Tell the truth, Seleucus.

orig: translate old to modern: Scratching could not make it worse an ’twere such a face as yours were.
target: If he has a face like yours, a good scratching couldn’t make him look any worse.

orig: translate old to modern: He bears The third part of the world, man.
target: He carries a third of the world.

orig: translate old to modern: Lo!
target: Lo!

orig: translate old to modern: Your wisdom should show itself more richer to signify this to the doctor; for, me to put him to his purgation would perhaps plunge him into far more choler.
target: You’d be wiser and look better if you told all this to the doctor, because for me to try to purge him of anger would probably make him more angry.

orig: translate old to modern: Give me thy hand, And let me see thee in thy woman’s weeds.
target: Give me your hand and let me see you dressed in woman’s clothing.

orig: translate old to modern: Soldiers, have careful watch.
target: Soldiers, watch carefully.

orig: translate old to modern: To lend me arms and aid when I required them, The which you both denied.
target: I overlooked your request, but I did not deny it.

orig: translate old to modern: To feed were best at home; From thence the sauce to meat is ceremony; Meeting were bare without it.
target: With no toasts, you might as well stay home, because Away from home, ceremony is the sauce to meat, Getting together would be bare without it.

orig: translate old to modern: Wert thou not my brother, I would not take this hand from thy throat till this other had pulled out thy tongue for saying so.
target: If you weren’t my brother, I’d leave this hand of mine on your neck until I’d pulled out your tongue for talking like this.

orig: translate old to modern: And prompt me, plain and holy innocence!
target: And prompt me, plain and holy innocence!

orig: translate old to modern: Why, then let’s home again.
target: All right then, back home we go.

orig: translate old to modern: Those linen cheeks of thine Are counselors to fear.
target: Those linen cheeks of your Are counselors to fear.

orig: translate old to modern: As whence the sun ’gins his reflection Shipwrecking storms and direful thunders break, So from that spring whence comfort seem'd to come Discomfort swells.
target: Just as when the sun rises and Shipwrecking storms and terrible thunder stop, So from that man, who seemed to bring comfort, Discomfort got worse.

orig: translate old to modern: Farewell.
target: Farewell.

orig: translate old to modern: Hold, there’s half my coffer.
target: It’s half of all my money.

orig: translate old to modern: Why do we hold our tongues, That most may claim this argument for ours?
target: Why do we stop talking, That most may claim we did this?

orig: translate old to modern: Sir Toby will be sworn that I am no fox, but he will not pass his word for two pence that you are no fool.
target: Sir Toby would bet a fortune that I’m not smart, but he wouldn’t bet two cents that you’re not a fool.

orig: translate old to modern: The noble Brutus is ascended.
target: The noble Brutus is on the platform.

orig: translate old to modern: Adieu, my lord.
target: Farewell, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: No man bears sorrow better.
target: No man handles sorrow better.

orig: translate old to modern: Let me go with him.
target: Let me go with him.

orig: translate old to modern: Give me your neaf, Monsieur Mustardseed.
target: Give me your hand, Mr. Mustardseed.

orig: translate old to modern: Virtue is beauty, but the beauteous evil Are empty trunks o'erflourished by the devil.
target: Virtue is beauty, but someone beautiful and wicked is like an empty box decorated by the devil.

orig: translate old to modern: Mine eyes are made the fools o’ the other senses, Or else worth all the rest.
target: My eyes are made the fools of by the other senses, Or else my eyes are worth all the rest.

orig: translate old to modern: Amen to that, sweet powers!
target: Amen to that, sweet powers!

orig: translate old to modern: If thou follow him, thou must needs wear my coxcomb.—How now, nuncle?
target: If you work for him, you’re a fool and should wear a fool’s cap.—So how’s it going, uncle?

orig: translate old to modern: Tis call'd the evil: A most miraculous work in this good King, Which often, since my here-remain in England, I have seen him do.
target: It is called “the evil,” A most miraculous work in this good king, Which often, since my stay in England, I have seen him do.

orig: translate old to modern: Art rich?
target: Are you rich?

orig: translate old to modern: I have seen the day That with this little arm and this good sword I have made my way through more impediments Than twenty times your stop.
target: I have seen the day That I have made my way through more impediments With this little arm and this good sword Than you could stop twenty times.

orig: translate old to modern: Worthy Montano, you were wont be civil; The gravity and stillness of your youth The world hath noted, and your name is great In mouths of wisest censure.
target: Worthy Montano, you were inclined to be civil; The world has marked he gravity and stillness of your youth and your name is great In mouths of wisest respect.

orig: translate old to modern: What is between you?
target: What is going on between you?

orig: translate old to modern: Would not this, sir, and a forest of feathers—if the rest of my fortunes turn Turk with me—with two Provincial roses on my razed shoes, get me a fellowship in a cry of players, sir?
target: Wouldn’t this do it, sir, together with a forest of feathers if the rest of my fortunes turn against with me, with two Provincial roses on my shoes I took off, to get me a fellowship for writing with a pack of players, sir?

orig: translate old to modern: Is not thy master with him?
target: Isn’t your master with him?

orig: translate old to modern: I shall, my lord.
target: I shall, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Three thousand ducats;—'tis a good round sum.
target: Three thousand dollars; it’s a good round sum.

orig: translate old to modern: What wife?
target: what wife?

orig: translate old to modern: They met so near with their lips that their breaths embraced together.
target: They came so close with their lips that their breaths hugged each other.

orig: translate old to modern: If it be found so, some will dear abide it.
target: If it’s found to be so, someone will dearly pay for it.

orig: translate old to modern: Away with him!
target: Take him away!

orig: translate old to modern: Thyself do grace to them, and bring them in.
target: Introduce yourself to them, and bring them in.

orig: translate old to modern: We are no tyrant, but a Christian king, Unto whose grace our passion is as subject As is our wretches fettered in our prisons.
target: I am no tyrant but a Christian king, whose emotions are as tightly controlled as the wretches who languish in our prisons.

orig: translate old to modern: O, my daughter!
target: O, my daughter!

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll leave you, lady.
target: I’ll leave you, lady.

orig: translate old to modern: This if she perform, She shall not sue unheard.
target: Then I’ll listen to her.

orig: translate old to modern: ill luck, ill luck?
target: Bad luck, bad luck?

orig: translate old to modern: Why should she write to Edmund?
target: Why would she write to Edmund?

orig: translate old to modern: Pardon me, I pray you.
target: I beg your pardon.

orig: translate old to modern: Art thou mad?
target: Are you insane?

orig: translate old to modern: I am weary of you.
target: I’m tired of you.

orig: translate old to modern: And for I know she taketh most delight In music, instruments, and poetry, Schoolmasters will I keep within my house, Fit to instruct her youth.
target: And because I know how fond she is of music, playing her instruments, and poetry, I plan to hire live-in tutors for her.

orig: translate old to modern: his sword, Which was declining on the milky head Of reverend Priam, seem'd i' the air to stick.
target: his sword, Which was declining on the milky head Of reverend Priam, seemed in the air to stick.

orig: translate old to modern: With what I get, I mean; and so do they.
target: With what I get, I mean, as they do.

orig: translate old to modern: Are you so gospell'd, To pray for this good man and for his issue, Whose heavy hand hath bow'd you to the grave And beggar'd yours for ever?
target: Are you such believers in the gospel that you would pray for this good man and for his children, the same man whose heavy hand has led you to death, and made your families beggars?

orig: translate old to modern: Let me choose; For, as I am, I live upon the rack.
target: Let me choose; Because as I am, I live in torture.

orig: translate old to modern: Prithee, peace!
target: Pray you, peace!

orig: translate old to modern: Durst thou have look'd upon him being awake, And hast thou kill'd him sleeping?
target: Did you dare to look at him, being awake, And have you killed him sleeping?

orig: translate old to modern: See, they encounter thee with their hearts’ thanks.
target: See, they greet you with their hearts' thanks.

orig: translate old to modern: What man is that?
target: Who is that man?

orig: translate old to modern: Let me hear from you.
target: What do you say?

orig: translate old to modern: Why, madam, if I were your father’s dog, You should not use me so.
target: Ma'am, you wouldn’t treat me like this if I were your father’s dog.

orig: translate old to modern: Go to him, Dolabella, bid him yield.
target: Tell him to surrender.

orig: translate old to modern: Gentlemen all, I do suspect this trash To be a party in this injury.
target: Gentlemen all, I suspect this trash To be a party to this injury.

orig: translate old to modern: Down, strumpet!
target: Down, prostitute!

orig: translate old to modern: It's the wind.
target: It's the wind.

orig: translate old to modern: Stand from the hearse, stand from the body.
target: Stand from the hearse, stand from the body.

orig: translate old to modern: It doth not fit me.
target: You’re right.

orig: translate old to modern: Farewell, and thanks.
target: Farewell, and thanks.

orig: translate old to modern: Ho!
target: Ho!

orig: translate old to modern: Be ’t as our gods will have ’t.
target: It will be as the gods see fit.

orig: translate old to modern: No, uncle, but our crosses on the way Have made it tedious, wearisome, and heavy.
target: It wasn’t the journey itself, uncle, but the troubles we encountered that made it wearisome and dull.

orig: translate old to modern: Adieu.
target: Goodbye.

orig: translate old to modern: Madam, do you.
target: You talk to him, ma'am.

orig: translate old to modern: What, are you hurt, lieutenant?
target: What, are you hurt, lieutenant?

orig: translate old to modern: Why, you speak truth.
target: It’s true.

orig: translate old to modern: I did hear him groan.
target: I heard him groan.

orig: translate old to modern: Seafaring men, sir.
target: Sailors, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Will you have me, lady?
target: Will you take me, my lady?

orig: translate old to modern: Mother, for love of grace, Lay not that flattering unction to your soul That not your trespass but my madness speaks.
target: Mother, for love of grace, Don’t put that flattering oil on your soul That says my craziness speaks and not your sin.

orig: translate old to modern: God bless your worship!
target: God bless you, sir!

orig: translate old to modern: Most villanously, like a pedant that keeps a school i' the church.
target: Oh, he looks like a pathetic Sunday school teacher.

orig: translate old to modern: Some tardy cripple bear the countermand, That came too lag to see him burièd.
target: Some tardy cripple must have taken the counter-order, who came after Clarence was already buried.

orig: translate old to modern: Why do you infect yourself with them?
target: Why bother with them?

orig: translate old to modern: Is it not like the King?
target: Isn’t it like the King?

orig: translate old to modern: Peace!
target: Silence!

orig: translate old to modern: You have an excellent armor, but let my horse have his due.
target: You have wonderful armor, but give my horse his due.

orig: translate old to modern: What you have said I will consider; what you have to say I will with patience hear, and find a time Both meet to hear and answer such high things.
target: I’ll think about what you’ve said; I’ll patiently hear what you’ve to say, and find a time When I can both meet with you to hear and answer such high things.

orig: translate old to modern: In brief, for so the season bids us be, Prepare thy battle early in the morning, And put thy fortune to the arbitrament Of bloody strokes and mortal-staring war.
target: To be brief—as the occasion requires—prepare to fight early in the morning, when your future will be decided.

orig: translate old to modern: Let Hercules himself do what he may, The cat will mew, and dog will have his day.
target: Let Hercules himself do what he may, The cat will mew and every dog will have his day.

orig: translate old to modern: That's a fair thought to lie between maids' legs.
target: That's a fair thought to lie between maids' legs.

orig: translate old to modern: Towards Chertsey, noble lord?
target: Toward Chertsey, noble lord?

orig: translate old to modern: But who comes here?
target: But who is this?

orig: translate old to modern: He weeps for what is done.
target: He weeps for what is done.

orig: translate old to modern: Pish for thee, Iceland dog, Thou prick-eared cur of Iceland!
target: Pish to you, you mangy dog, you pointy-eared Icelandic mutt.

orig: translate old to modern: Twill endure wind and weather.
target: Wind and rain can’t wash it off.

orig: translate old to modern: O, horrible!
target: O, horrible!

orig: translate old to modern: What in your own part can you say to this?
target: What, in your own part, can you say to this?

orig: translate old to modern: What trumpet is that same?
target: What trumpet is that one?

orig: translate old to modern: A messenger from Caesar.
target: A messenger has arrived from Caesar.

orig: translate old to modern: For se offendendo; it cannot be else.
target: It can’t be anything else.

orig: translate old to modern: She returns this ring to you, sir.
target: She’s sending this ring back to you, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Sure there's some wonder in this handkerchief; I am most unhappy in the loss of it.
target: Surely there's some magic in this handkerchief; I am very unhappy at the loss of it.

orig: translate old to modern: Sooth, madam, I hear nothing.
target: Really, madam, I hear nothing.

orig: translate old to modern: Heaven doth truly know it.
target: Heaven does truly know it.

orig: translate old to modern: In his lawless fit, Behind the arras hearing something stir, Whips out his rapier, cries 'A rat, a rat!
target: In his wild fit, Hearing something stir behind the curtain, He whips out his knife, cries 'A rat, a rat!

orig: translate old to modern: What sayest thou now?
target: What do you say?

orig: translate old to modern: Let go my hand.
target: Let go of my hand.

orig: translate old to modern: My cause is hearted; thine hath no less reason.
target: My cause is fixed in my heart; yours has no less reason.

orig: translate old to modern: To bed?
target: To bed!

orig: translate old to modern: Tongue nor heart Cannot conceive nor name thee.
target: Tongue nor heart Cannot comprehend or name you!

orig: translate old to modern: Please you, draw near.—Louder the music there!
target: Please come closer.— Make the music louder, please!

orig: translate old to modern: Not a jot more, my lord.
target: Not a jot more, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Is't not enough, is't not enough, young man, That I did never, no, nor never can, Deserve a sweet look from Demetrius' eye, But you must flout my insufficiency?
target: Isn’t it enough, isn’t it enough, young man, That I never did, no, nor never can Deserve a sweet look from Demetrius' eye, But you must joke about what I’m lacking?

orig: translate old to modern: Now, for my life, she’s wandering to the Tower, On pure heart’s love, to greet the tender prince.— Daughter, well met.
target: Now, on my life, the young child must be headed to the Tower to greet the young princes, whom she adores.

orig: translate old to modern: Fair love, you faint with wandering in the wood; And, to speak troth, I have forgot our way; We'll rest us, Hermia, if you think it good, And tarry for the comfort of the day.
target: Fair love, you are exhausted with wandering in the forest.

orig: translate old to modern: Give me that boy, and I will go with thee.
target: Give me that boy and I will go with you.

orig: translate old to modern: How smart a lash that speech doth give my conscience!
target: How hurting a lash that speech gives my conscience!

orig: translate old to modern: It is not so express'd, but what of that?
target: It is not expressly stated; but so what?

orig: translate old to modern: Ay.
target: Yes.

orig: translate old to modern: Or blessèd was't we did?
target: Or was it a blessing that we did?

orig: translate old to modern: And why should Caesar be a tyrant then?
target: And why should Caesar be a tyrant then?

orig: translate old to modern: We all expect a gentle answer, Jew.
target: We all expect a gentle answer, Jew.

orig: translate old to modern: At land, thou know’st How much we do o’ercount thee.
target: Yes, on land you do outnumber me.

orig: translate old to modern: Good morrow, Caesar.
target: Good morning, Caesar.

orig: translate old to modern: My name is Roderigo.
target: My name is Roderigo.

orig: translate old to modern: She made good view of me, indeed so much That sure methought her eyes had lost her tongue, For she did speak in starts distractedly.
target: It’s true she looked at me a lot, in fact, she looked at me so much that she seemed distracted, and couldn’t really finish her sentences very well.

orig: translate old to modern: Breathe Merriman, the poor cur is embossed, And couple Clowder with the deep-mouthed brach.
target: Let Merriman catch his breath—the poor dog’s foaming at the mouth.

orig: translate old to modern: Such as she says my lord did say I was.
target: Such as she says my lord said I was.

orig: translate old to modern: Who builds stronger than a mason, a ship- wright, or a carpenter?
target: Who builds stronger than a mason, a shipbuilder, or a carpenter?

orig: translate old to modern: Better Macbeth Than such an one to reign.
target: Better Macbeth Than such an one like me to reign over Scotland.

orig: translate old to modern: What say you?
target: What did you say to me?

orig: translate old to modern: O, wilt thou darkling leave me?
target: Oh, will you, a dark-natured man, leave me?

orig: translate old to modern: Gentlemen, let's look to our business.
target: Gentlemen, let's look to our business.

orig: translate old to modern: Why no, no more than reason.
target: No, no more than is reasonable.

orig: translate old to modern: Twill be naught, But let it be.
target: But never mind.

orig: translate old to modern: Come on and kiss me, Kate.
target: Come on and kiss me, Kate.

orig: translate old to modern: What was the second noise for?
target: What was the second noise for?

orig: translate old to modern: Think you so?
target: Do you think so?

orig: translate old to modern: For mine own part—no offense to the general, nor any man of quality—I hope to be saved.
target: For my own part, no offense to the general, nor any man of quality, I hope to be saved.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, Signior, what news?
target: What’s up, mister?

orig: translate old to modern: This is practice, Gloucester.
target: You were tricked into fighting, Gloucester.

orig: translate old to modern: At my lodging.
target: At my lodging.

orig: translate old to modern: Go you and tell my daughter I would speak with her.
target: Go and tell my daughter I want to speak with her.

orig: translate old to modern: He, sir.
target: He, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: And I another.
target: And I will give you another one.

orig: translate old to modern: Let it be so.
target: Let it be so.

orig: translate old to modern: Woe, alas!
target: Woe, alas!

orig: translate old to modern: I know this is a joyful trouble to you; But yet ’tis one.
target: I know this is a joyful trouble to you, It is still only one.

orig: translate old to modern: Fair princess, you have lost much good sport.
target: Fair princess, you’ve missed some good sport.

orig: translate old to modern: Here comes Sir Toby halting.
target: Here comes Sir Toby, limping.

orig: translate old to modern: Is he not honest?
target: Isn’t he honest?

orig: translate old to modern: You know it is the feast of Lupercal.
target: You know it is the feast of the priest Lupercus.

orig: translate old to modern: I know the good King and Queen have sent for you.
target: I know the good king and queen have sent for you.

orig: translate old to modern: When could they say till now that talk'd of Rome That her wide walls encompass'd but one man?
target: When could they say, until now, those that talked about Rome, That her wide walls were ruled by only one man?

orig: translate old to modern: I must stay with the lackeys with the luggage of our camp.
target: I have to stay with the servants, who are with our camp’s luggage.

orig: translate old to modern: Would you not have me honest?
target: What, you don’t want me to be chaste?

orig: translate old to modern: O plague right well prevented!
target: Oh, a plague has been prevented, thank God!

orig: translate old to modern: He were a brave mon- ster indeed, if they were set in his tail My man-monster hath drowned his tongue in sack.
target: He would be a brave monster indeed, if they were set in his tail.

orig: translate old to modern: Be that the uttermost, and fail not then.
target: Let that be the latest, and be on time.

orig: translate old to modern: Sister, welcome.
target: You are welcome here, sister.

orig: translate old to modern: What hast thou done?
target: What have you done?

orig: translate old to modern: So, uncle, there you are.
target: So, uncle, there you are.

orig: translate old to modern: Shall we go, coz?
target: Yes.

orig: translate old to modern: Yea, and I will weep a while longer.
target: Yes, and I’ll keep crying a while longer.

orig: translate old to modern: Is ’t so saucy?
target: Is it that aggressive?

orig: translate old to modern: Tis safer to be that which we destroy Than by destruction dwell in doubtful joy.
target: It is safer to be what we destroy, Rather than, by destruction, live in uncertain joy.

orig: translate old to modern: Remember’st thou any that have died on ’t?
target: Do you remember anyone who died of it?

orig: translate old to modern: If your messenger find him not there, seek him i' the other place yourself.
target: If your messenger can’t find him there, look for him in the other place yourself.

orig: translate old to modern: Be you and I behind an arras then; Mark the encounter.
target: You and I will be behind a curtain then, Listening to their encounter.

orig: translate old to modern: He’s coming, madam.
target: He’s coming, ma'am.

orig: translate old to modern: Here's fine revolution, and we had the trick to see't.
target: Here's fine turnaround, if we were able to see it.

orig: translate old to modern: For the Dauphin, I stand here for him.
target: Regarding the Dauphin, you can speak to me.

orig: translate old to modern: The advancement of your children, gentle lady.
target: The advancement of your children, noble lady.

orig: translate old to modern: Do not for one repulse forgo the purpose That you resolved t'effect.
target: Don’t, for one denial, lose the action That you swore to do.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, I’ll go hide the body in some hole Till that the duke give order for his burial.
target: Well, I’ll go hide the body in some hole until the duke gives orders for his burial.

orig: translate old to modern: Is that his answer?
target: Is that his answer?

orig: translate old to modern: It is Captain Macmorris, is it not?
target: It’s Captain Macmorris, right?

orig: translate old to modern: God grant that some, less noble and less loyal, Nearer in bloody thoughts, and not in blood, Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did, And yet go current from suspicion.
target: It’s clear that someone less noble, less loyal, more bloody-minded than Clarence but not a blood relation, deserves as bad an end as my brother, but he goes free.

orig: translate old to modern: Prince John is this morning secretly stolen away.
target: I’ll get there first and tell him what we found out.

orig: translate old to modern: The King doth wake tonight and takes his rouse, Keeps wassail, and the swaggering upspring reels, And as he drains his draughts of Rhenish down, The kettle-drum and trumpet thus bray out The triumph of his pledge.
target: The King stays awake tonight and has a drinking party, Keeps toasting, and the swaggering morning whirls, And, as he drinks down his drafts of Rhine wine, The kettle-drum and trumpet thus noisily announce The triumph of his drinking it all down at once.

orig: translate old to modern: Your loss is as yourself, great, and you bear it As answering to the weight.
target: You are a remarkable person and your loss is equally remarkable.

orig: translate old to modern: Swounds, show me what thou'lt do.
target: God’s wounds, show me what you'll do.

orig: translate old to modern: Say’st me so, friend?
target: Tell me, friend.

orig: translate old to modern: Trust not to rotten planks.
target: Don’t trust rotten planks.

orig: translate old to modern: That nothing do but meditate on blood, To swearing and stern looks, diffused attire, And everything that seems unnatural.
target: They grow like savages—like soldiers who meditate on nothing but blood—surrounded by swearing and stern looks, ragged clothing and everything unnatural.

orig: translate old to modern: Provoke him, that he may; for even out of that will I cause these of Cyprus to mutiny, whose qual- ification shall come into no true taste again but by the displanting of Cassio.
target: Provoke him so that he will; because even out of that, I will make these men of Cyprus rebel, whose character won’t come back to their original calmness unless Cassio is replaced.

orig: translate old to modern: Leave him to my displeasure.—Edmund, keep you our sister company.
target: Leave him to my wrath.—Edmund, go with my sister-in-law.

orig: translate old to modern: By your pardon, I will myself into the pulpit first, And show the reason of our Caesar's death.
target: I’ll go onto the platform first, And explain our Caesar's death.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou dost belie her, and thou art a devil.
target: You lie about her, and you are a devil.

orig: translate old to modern: Where's the Thane of Cawdor?
target: Where's the Baron of Cawdor?

orig: translate old to modern: You have little cause to say so.
target: You don’t have reasonto say so.

orig: translate old to modern: Nature presently distilled Helen’s cheek, but not her heart, Cleopatra’s majesty, Atalanta’s better part, Sad Lucretia’s modesty.
target: Nature took Helen’s  Cleopatra’s majesty, The best of Atalanta, And unhappy Lucretia’s modesty.

orig: translate old to modern: Oh, I die for food.
target: Oh, I’m dying of hunger.

orig: translate old to modern: What wouldst thou write of me, if thou shouldst praise me?
target: What would you write about me, if you should praise me?

orig: translate old to modern: Zounds, who is there?
target: Damn it, who’s there?

orig: translate old to modern: The sum of all I can, I have disclosed.
target: I’ve told you everything I know.

orig: translate old to modern: O, for a chair, To bear him easily hence!
target: O, for a chair, To carry him easily from here!

orig: translate old to modern: What players are they?
target: What players are they?

orig: translate old to modern: The villany you teach me I will execute; and it shall go hard but I will better the instruction.
target: The villainy you teach me I’ll use; and it shall be hard but I’ll make the lesson better.

orig: translate old to modern: His hour is almost past.
target: He’s almost late.

orig: translate old to modern: Seyton!
target: Seyton!

orig: translate old to modern: O, she that might have intercepted thee, By strangling thee in her accursèd womb, From all the slaughters, wretch, that thou hast done.
target: The woman who might have blocked you from all the murders you’ve committed by strangling you in her cursed womb.

orig: translate old to modern: I told him what I thought, and told no more Than what he found himself was apt and true.
target: I told him what I thought; and told no more Than what he himself discovered was right and true.

orig: translate old to modern: Beg that thou mayst have leave to hang thyself: And yet, thy wealth being forfeit to the state, Thou hast not left the value of a cord; Therefore thou must be hang'd at the state's charge.
target: Beg that you may have permission to hang yourself; And still, your wealth being the penalty to pay the state, You haven’t got the value of a string left; So you must be hanged at the state's expense.

orig: translate old to modern: I say she shall.—And first begin with her.
target: I say she shall.—And first begin with her.

orig: translate old to modern: Happy the parents of so fair a child.
target: Your parents are lucky to have such a lovely child.

orig: translate old to modern: Pisa, renownèd for grave citizens, Gave me my being and my father first, A merchant of great traffic through the world, Vincentio, come of the Bentivolii.
target: I was born in Pisa, famous for its serious citizens, like my father before me; my father, Vincentio, a successful, world-traveled merchant, was one of the

orig: translate old to modern: No, by no means.
target: No, by no means.

orig: translate old to modern: Sirs, I will practice on this drunken man.
target: What do you think?

orig: translate old to modern: Your honor calls you hence.
target: Your honor is the reason you are leaving.

orig: translate old to modern: An your ladyship will have it as it ought to be, you must allow  Prithee, read i' thy right wits.
target: If you want things done in the right way, you’ll have to let me read a crazy letter in a crazy voice.

orig: translate old to modern: Or, if you borrow one another’s love for the instant, you may, when you hear no more words of Pompey, return it again.
target: Or you can pretend to settle your differences until this matter with Pompey is finished.

orig: translate old to modern: Some two months hence up higher toward the north He first presents his fire, and the high east Stands as the Capitol, directly here.
target: Some two months away, up higher toward the North, He first shines, and the high East Stands, just as the Capitol, directly here.

orig: translate old to modern: My lord, you play'd once i' th' university, you say?
target: My lord, you acted once when you were in the university, you say?

orig: translate old to modern: Music i’ th’ air.
target: There’s music coming out of thin air.

orig: translate old to modern: A pestilent gall to me!
target: A constant pain to me!

orig: translate old to modern: God be wi' you, princes all.
target: God be with all of you, princes.

orig: translate old to modern: None, my lord.
target: None, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Is he married?
target: Is he married?

orig: translate old to modern: Be not acknown on't; I have use for it.
target: Mind your own business ; I have use for it.

orig: translate old to modern: Be attentive.
target: Pay attention.

orig: translate old to modern: I pray you give me leave.
target: I beg you, leave me alone.

orig: translate old to modern: Fare thee well.
target: Good-bye.

orig: translate old to modern: I have not seen him this two days.
target: I haven’t seen him for two days.

orig: translate old to modern: The foe vaunts in the field.
target: The enemy is making its appearance on the battlefield.

orig: translate old to modern: Or do you play the flouting jack, to tell us Cupid is a good hare-finder and Vulcan a rare carpenter?
target: Or are you just teasing?

orig: translate old to modern: It then draws near the season Wherein the spirit held his wont to walk.
target: Then it’s getting close to the time When the spirit has his habit of walking.

orig: translate old to modern: Tremblingly she stood And on the sudden dropped.
target: She stood trembling, then suddenly dropped dead.

orig: translate old to modern: If you do free your children from the sword, Your children’s children quits it in your age.
target: When you free your children from the sword, your grandchildren will repay you in your old age.

orig: translate old to modern: O, forgive me my sins!
target: O, forgive me my sins!

orig: translate old to modern: The dropsy drown this fool!
target: The swelling disease drown this fool!

orig: translate old to modern: It shall be said his judgement ruled our hands; Our youths and wildness shall no whit appear, But all be buried in his gravity.
target: It shall be said that his judgment ruled our hands; Our youths and wildness won’t appear at all, But all be buried in his seriousness.

orig: translate old to modern: When we are born, we cry that we are come To this great stage of fools.
target: When we’re born, we cry because we’ve arrived on the stage of life, like all the other fools.

orig: translate old to modern: Think of me as you please.
target: I don’t care what you think of me.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, banished Kent, If thou canst serve where thou dost stand condemned, So may it come thy master, whom thou lovest, Shall find thee full of labors.
target: I love my master, and he’ll find me very hard-working.

orig: translate old to modern: If justice cannot tame you, she shall ne'er weigh more reasons in her balance.
target: If they let you off, then we’ll have to assume that Lady Justice has lost all her power.

orig: translate old to modern: O my lord, my lord, Forgive my fearful sails!
target: Oh, my lord, my lord, forgive my panic!

orig: translate old to modern: But dead they are, and devilish slave, by thee.
target: But they are dead, and you killed them, you slave of the devil.

orig: translate old to modern: You knew, none so well, none so well as you, of my daughter's flight.
target: You knew, none so well, none so well as you, of my daughter's flight.

orig: translate old to modern: O, a chair, a chair!
target: O, a chair, a chair!

orig: translate old to modern: Twere good you do so much for charity.
target: It would be good for you to do so much for charity.

orig: translate old to modern: We are haunted.
target: We are attacked by ghosts.

orig: translate old to modern: Learn of the wise and perpend: civet is of a baser birth than tar, the very uncleanly flux of a cat.
target: Learn from the wise, and comprehend: the courtier’s perfume is made from cat discharge—much more disgusting than tar.

orig: translate old to modern: I wonder none of you have thought of him.
target: I wonder why none of you’ve thought about him.

orig: translate old to modern: An you will not be answered with reason, I must die.
target: If you won’t listen to reason, I’ll have to die.

orig: translate old to modern: But who was this?
target: But who was that man?

orig: translate old to modern: If you will patiently dance in our round, And see our moonlight revels, go with us; If not, shun me, and I will spare your haunts.
target: If you will patiently join our dances, And see our moonlight parties, go with us; If not, leave me alone, and I won’t comment on where you’re going.

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll strike and cry, “Take all.”                                                           Well said.
target: When I strike, I’ll cry, “All or nothing!” Well put.

orig: translate old to modern: Say that I slew them not.
target: Let’s say I didn’t kill them.

orig: translate old to modern: Methinks it should be now a huge eclipse Of sun and moon, and that the affrighted globe Should yawn at alteration.
target: I think there should now be a huge eclipse Of sun and moon, and that the frightened globe Should yawn at changes.

orig: translate old to modern: As thou art to thyself.
target: As you are to yourself.

orig: translate old to modern: Repays he my deep service With such deep contempt?
target: Does he reward my dedicated service with such deep contempt?

orig: translate old to modern: I would they were, that I might die at once, For now they kill me with a living death.
target: I wish they were, so that I could die right now, because, at this point, I live a living death.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis well I am found by you.
target: It is good that you found me.

orig: translate old to modern: Parted you in good terms?
target: Did you leave on good terms?

orig: translate old to modern: Speak within door.
target: Speak behind the door.

orig: translate old to modern: My Lord High Constable, the English lie within fifteen hundred paces of your tents.
target: My Lord High Constable, the English lie within fifteen hundred paces of your tents.

orig: translate old to modern: You may have very fit occasion for ’t.
target: You might have a great opportunity to give it to him right now.

orig: translate old to modern: I prithee, tell me who is it quickly, and speak apace.
target: I’m begging you, tell me who it is quickly, and speak fast.

orig: translate old to modern: help!
target: help!

orig: translate old to modern: Send for him, good uncle.
target: Send for him, dear uncle.

orig: translate old to modern: There, give it your hobby-horse.
target: There, give it to your whore.

orig: translate old to modern: If I do not love her, I am a Jew.
target: If I don’t love her, I’m completely

orig: translate old to modern: Dear sovereign, hear me speak.
target: Dear master, listen to me.

orig: translate old to modern: Upon record, my gracious lord.
target: On record, my gracious lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Uncharitably with me have you dealt, And shamefully my hopes by you are butchered.
target: Stop—if you can’t be kind, at least have some shame.

orig: translate old to modern: We’ll be friends first.
target: Not until we part as friends.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, saw you anything more wonderful?
target: Why, have you seen anything more wonderful?

orig: translate old to modern: Behold, there stand the caskets, noble prince; If you choose that wherein I am contain'd, Straight shall our nuptial rites be solemniz'd; But if you fail, without more speech, my lord, You must be gone from hence immediately.
target: Behold, the chests stand there, noble Prince: If you choose the one that I am contained in, Our marriage vows will be solemnized right away; But if you fail, my lord, you must be gone from here Immediately without any more talking.

orig: translate old to modern: an excellent courtesy!
target: an excellent courtesy!

orig: translate old to modern: Get you away; I'll send for you anon.
target: Go away; I'll send for you soon.

orig: translate old to modern: Thyself shalt see the act: For, as thou urgest justice, be assur'd Thou shalt have justice, more than thou desirest.
target: You yourself shall see the law; Because, as you insist on justice, be assured You shall have justice, more than you desire.

orig: translate old to modern: Sir, you speak nobly.
target: Noble words, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: I am the man.
target: I’m the man she wants.

orig: translate old to modern: I frown the while, and perchance wind up watch, or play with my—some rich jewel.
target: While I waited, I’d frown impatiently, and perhaps wind my watch, or play with my—with some expensive piece of jewelry I happen to be wearing.

orig: translate old to modern: Pray you, if it be, give it me, for I am slow of study.
target: Please, if it is, give it to me now, because I am slow in studying my lines.

orig: translate old to modern: What think you on't?
target: What do you think about it?

orig: translate old to modern: Of a snail?
target: A snail?

orig: translate old to modern: Let me see now: To get his place, and to plume up my will In double knavery—How, how?
target: Let me see now, To get his place, and to congratulate myself In double trickery, How, how?

orig: translate old to modern: But hush, no more.
target: But I’ll be quiet; no more.

orig: translate old to modern: O Lord, Lord, it is a hard matter for friends to meet, but mountains may be removed with earthquakes and so encounter.
target: It’s difficult to bring two friends together, but even mountains can be moved together by earthquakes.

orig: translate old to modern: Here; what would my lord?
target: I’m here; what do you want?

orig: translate old to modern: So bless thee, master.
target: Bless you, master.

orig: translate old to modern: It does, my boy.
target: It does, my boy.

orig: translate old to modern: Twere good she were spoken with; for she may strew Dangerous conjectures in ill-breeding minds.
target: It would be good she were spoken with, because she May scatter dangerous ideas in rude minds.

orig: translate old to modern: Did not great Julius bleed for justice' sake?
target: Didn’t great Julius bleed for justice's sake?

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll give you a verse to this note that I made yesterday in despite of my invention.
target: I wrote a verse to this tune, though it’s not very imaginative.

orig: translate old to modern: Oh, I am slain!—My lord, you have one eye left To see some mischief on him.
target: I am dying!—My lord, you still have one eye left to see Cornwall punished.

orig: translate old to modern: Will Caesar speak?
target: What do you say, Caesar?

orig: translate old to modern: Away with it!
target: Take it away.

orig: translate old to modern: I did not think he had been acquainted with her.
target: I didn’t think he had been acquainted with her.

orig: translate old to modern: Does it not, think thee, stand me now upon— He that hath kill'd my king, and whored my mother; Popp'd in between the election and my hopes; Thrown out his angle for my proper life, And with such cozenage—is't not perfect conscience To quit him with this arm?
target: Doesn’t it, do you thank, become my responsibility to kill He that has killed my king, and whored my mother, Push himself in between the election and my hope to be King, tried to kill me, And with such knowledge, isn’t it perfect duty To kill him with this arm?

orig: translate old to modern: Prithee, keep up thy quillets.
target: I beg you, keep up your jokes.

orig: translate old to modern: I have been with your father and given him notice that the Duke of Cornwall and Regan his duchess will be here with him this night.
target: I just saw your father the Lord Gloucester and notified him that the Duke of Cornwall and his wife Regan will stay with him here tonight.

orig: translate old to modern: But why should honor outlive honesty?
target: But why should honor outlive honesty?

orig: translate old to modern: They are, my lord, without the palace gate.
target: They are, my lord, outside the palace gate.

orig: translate old to modern: Treason and murder ever kept together As two yoke-devils sworn to either’s purpose, Working so grossly in a natural cause That admiration did not whoop at them.
target: All other devils who tempt people to treason patch together some motive, put together from shreds

orig: translate old to modern: They do but jest, poison in jest; no offence i' the world.
target: They only pretend, pretend to poison, no offense in the world.

orig: translate old to modern: Give me some music.
target: Play me some music.

orig: translate old to modern: Tomorrow, as he purposes.
target: Tomorrow, as he intends.

orig: translate old to modern: I had myself notice of my brother’s purpose herein and have by underhand means labored to dissuade him from it; but he is resolute.
target: I’d heard about my brother’s plan and have been subtly trying to change his mind, but he’s determined.

orig: translate old to modern: The poor monster's my subject, and he shall not suffer indignity.
target: The poor monster's my subject, and he shall not suffer indignity.

orig: translate old to modern: This is a strange repose, to be asleep With eyes wide open; standing, speaking, moving, And yet so fast asleep.
target: This is a strange rest, to be asleep With eyes wide open; standing, speaking, moving, And yet so fast asleep.

orig: translate old to modern: Then is there mirth in heaven When earthly things, made even, Atone together.
target: There is laughter in heaven When earthly affairs are put right And people unite.

orig: translate old to modern: I' faith, if he be not rotten before he die—as we have many pocky corses nowadays that will scarce hold the laying in—he will last you some eight year or nine year.
target: Well, if he’s not rotten before he dies, as we have many small pox corpses nowadays that will scarce last beyond the wake, he will last you some eight years or nine years.

orig: translate old to modern: And so the lion vanished.
target: And then the lion vanishes.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, their endeavour keeps in the wonted pace; but there is, sir, an eyrie of children, little eyases, that cry out on the top of question and are most tyrannically clapped for't.
target: No, their work keeps them at their usual pace, but there is, sir, a brood of children, untrained, that complicate their situation, and are most tyrannically beaten for it.

orig: translate old to modern: You kill me to deny it.
target: Then, rejecting my request, you kill

orig: translate old to modern: Stay illusion!
target: Stay, illusion!

orig: translate old to modern: Mine ear is much enamored of thy note; So is mine eye enthralled to thy shape; And thy fair virtue's force perforce doth move me, On the first view to say, to swear, I love thee.
target: So my eye is very attracted to your shape; And your fair virtue's force violently moves me, On the first look of you, to say, to swear, I love you.

orig: translate old to modern: The King and Queen and all are coming down.
target: The King and Queen and all are coming down.

orig: translate old to modern: Dost thou like the plot, Trinculo?
target: Do you like the plot, Trinculo?

orig: translate old to modern: And you by land.
target: And you’ve done well on land.

orig: translate old to modern: Not shine today?
target: So, the sun won’t shine today!

orig: translate old to modern: Yet I love thee too.
target: And yet I do love you.

orig: translate old to modern: Where be the sacred vials thou shouldst fill With sorrowful water?
target: Stop arguing and listen to my plans.

orig: translate old to modern: Fortune forbid my outside have not charmed her!
target: I hope she doesn’t have a crush on me!

orig: translate old to modern: When Nature hath made a fair creature, may she not by Fortune fall into the fire?
target: Well, when Nature makes a person beautiful, can’t Fortune make her fall into a fire, thereby making her ugly after all?

orig: translate old to modern: Now, by my troth, if I had been remembered, I could have given my uncle’s grace a flout To touch his growth nearer than he touched mine.
target: Hey, if I’d remembered something about him, I could have had a good comeback for my uncle, touching on his growth worse than he touched on mine.

orig: translate old to modern: O treacherous villains!
target: O treacherous villains!

orig: translate old to modern: I wonder if Titania be awaked; Then, what it was that next came in her eye, Which she must dote on in extremity.
target: I wonder if Titania is up yet, And what it was that next came into her sight, Which she must love in the extreme.

orig: translate old to modern: That’s my fear.
target: That’s what I’m afraid of.

orig: translate old to modern: This guest of summer, The temple-haunting martlet, does approve By his loved mansionry that the heaven's breath Smells wooingly here.
target: The temple-haunting martlet, this bird of summer, Approves this place by his loved dwelling places, That heaven's breath smells wooingly here.

orig: translate old to modern: We will, my lord.
target: We will, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: God send you, sir, a speedy infirmity, for the better increasing your folly!
target: I hope you go senile soon, sir, so you can become a more foolish fool!

orig: translate old to modern: Know then I came before you here a man prepared To take this offer, but Mark Antony Put me to some impatience.
target: You should know that when I came here I was prepared to accept your offer.

orig: translate old to modern: He brings me liberty.
target: He brings me freedom.

orig: translate old to modern: Why wither not the leaves that want their sap?
target: Why aren’t the leaves withering now that the sap is all dried up?

orig: translate old to modern: I think it be.
target: I think so.

orig: translate old to modern: Art not thou the Lady Olivia’s fool?
target: Aren’t you Lady Olivia’s fool?

orig: translate old to modern: Descend, for you must be my torchbearer.
target: Go down, because you must be carry my torch.

orig: translate old to modern: Sleeping and waking, O, defend me still!
target: Defend me, God, both when I’m asleep and when I’m awake.

orig: translate old to modern: Where is the king?
target: Where is the king?

orig: translate old to modern: I never got him.— Hark, the duke’s trumpets.
target: The duke’s trumpets.
