orig: translate old to modern: I thank your lordship, you have got me one.
target: I thank you sir, you have gotten me one.

orig: translate old to modern: What will I do, thinkest thou?
target: What will I do, do you think?

orig: translate old to modern: No, it begins again.
target: No, it begins again.

orig: translate old to modern: For lo!
target: Behold!

orig: translate old to modern: Our fears in Banquo Stick deep, and in his royalty of nature Reigns that which would be fear'd.
target: Our fears of Banquo Stick deep, and there’s a lot to be afraid of in the royalty of his nature.

orig: translate old to modern: Keep thy word.
target: Keep your word.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, my co-mates and brothers in exile, Hath not old custom made this life more sweet Than that of painted pomp?
target: Now, my companions and brothers in exile, hasn’t experience made this simple life sweeter than a life of glittery pomp and circumstance?

orig: translate old to modern: Most humbly do I take my leave, my lord.
target: I take my leave most humbly, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Vouchsafe, divine perfection of a woman, Of these supposèd crimes to give me leave By circumstance but to acquit myself.
target: Divine, perfect woman, give me a chance to prove in detail that I’m innocent of the evils you accuse me of.

orig: translate old to modern: Here is more of us!
target: Here are more of us.

orig: translate old to modern: Oh, they take the part of a better wrestler than myself.
target: But they’re siding with a better wrestler than myself.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis to be doubted, madam.
target: I’m afraid that may be the case, madam.

orig: translate old to modern: Write to me very shortly, And you shall understand from me her mind.
target: Write to me very soon and I’ll let you know what she thinks.

orig: translate old to modern: I will go on the slightest errand now to the Antipodes that you can devise to send me on.
target: I’ll go to the Antipodes for any little errand you can think of.

orig: translate old to modern: But it is no English treason to cut French crowns, and tomorrow the king himself will be a clipper.
target: But it’s no treason for an Englishman to cut off a French crown—a head, I mean—and tomorrow the king himself will do some snipping.

orig: translate old to modern: For, my good liege, she is so idly kinged, Her scepter so fantastically borne By a vain, giddy, shallow, humorous youth, That fear attends her not.
target: Because, my good king, England is so poorly led, her scepter so foolishly borne by a vain, silly, shallow, impulsive youth, that she’s hardly a threat.

orig: translate old to modern: If thou hadst feared to break an oath by Him, Th' imperial metal circling now thy head Had graced the tender temples of my child, And both the princes had been breathing here, Which now, two tender bedfellows for dust, Thy broken faith hath made the prey for worms.
target: If you had been afraid to break an oath with him, the crown you are currently wearing would have graced the head of my child, and both princes would still be alive, not preyed on by worms.

orig: translate old to modern: When the wind is southerly I know a hawk from a handsaw.
target: When the wind is from the south, I know a hawk from a handsaw.

orig: translate old to modern: How dost thou, my good fellow?
target: How are you, my friend?

orig: translate old to modern: Twill be a storm.
target: There’s going to be a storm.

orig: translate old to modern: Brutus shall lead, and we will grace his heels With the most boldest and best hearts of Rome.
target: Brutus shall lead, and we will follow him With the most boldest and best hearts of Rome.

orig: translate old to modern: He, upon some action, Is now in durance at Malvolio’s suit, A gentleman and follower of my lady’s.
target: For some reason he’s in prison now on some legal technicality, on Malvolio’s orders.

orig: translate old to modern: Kneel not, gentle Portia.
target: Don’t kneel, gentle Portia.

orig: translate old to modern: For, as it is a heartbreaking to see a handsome man loose-wived, so it is a deadly sorrow to behold a foul knave uncuckolded.
target: If it’s sad to see a handsome man with a cheating wife, it’s a tragedy to see an ugly thug with a wife who’s faithful.

orig: translate old to modern: I have no will to wander forth of doors, Yet something leads me forth.
target: I don’t want to go out of doors, Yet something leads me there.

orig: translate old to modern: Choose your revenge yourself.
target: Choose your revenge.

orig: translate old to modern: He's married.
target: He's married.

orig: translate old to modern: God!
target: O God!

orig: translate old to modern: Why, here in Denmark.
target: Why, here in Denmark.

orig: translate old to modern: Still as the grave.
target: As still as the grave.

target: I don’t speak well, And I am little blessed with the soft phrase of peace Because, since these arms of mine were seven years' old, until now some nine months past, they have used Their dearest actions on the battlefield; And I can speak little of this great world, Only what relates to feats of war and battle; And therefore I shall grace my cause little By speaking for myself.

target: But I thank God that I failed in my scheme, and I rejoice in paying the penalty, as I beg God and you to pardon me.

target: And, England, if you hold my love at anything, As my great power may give you some sense, Since your scar still looks raw and red After the Danish sword, and your open fear Pays homage to us, you might not view Our sovereign process coldly, which gives you full power, By letters testifying to that effect, The present death of Hamlet.

target: Well then, it now appears you need my help; Come on, then; you come to me, and you say “'Shylock, we would have money.” You say so: You that spit on my beard, And kick me as you spurn a strange dog On your doorstep; money is what you ask for.

target: And

orig: translate old to modern: Then your hose should be ungartered, your bonnet unbanded, your sleeve unbuttoned, your shoe untied, and everything about you demonstrating a careless desolation.
target: Your stockings should be falling down around your ankles, your hat flying off your head, your sleeves unbuttoned, your shoes untied, and everything about you demonstrating carelessness and misery.

orig: translate old to modern: What, is Brutus sick, And will he steal out of his wholesome bed To dare the vile contagion of the night And tempt the rheumy and unpurged air To add unto his sickness?
target: What, is Brutus sick, And will he steal out of his wholesome bed To challenge the evil diseases of the night, And tempt the thick and unclean air To add to his sickness?

orig: translate old to modern: O, fear me not!
target: O, don’t be afraid of me.

orig: translate old to modern: So is my horse, Octavius, and for that I do appoint him store of provender.
target: So is my horse, Octavius, and for that, I appoint him keeper of the hay.

orig: translate old to modern: I did enact Julius Caesar; I was killed i' the Capitol; Brutus killed me.
target: I did enact Julius Caesar, I was killed in the Capitol, Brutus killed me.

orig: translate old to modern: He longs not for the dawning as we do.
target: He doesn’t long for the dawn as we do.

orig: translate old to modern: Content.
target: Agreed.

orig: translate old to modern: Let her hang me.
target: So let her execute me.

orig: translate old to modern: God, God, forgive us all!
target: God, God, forgive us all!

orig: translate old to modern: We are men, my liege.
target: We are men, my liege.

orig: translate old to modern: O most bloody sight!
target: O most bloody sight!

orig: translate old to modern: There are things in this comedy of Pyramus and Thisbe that will never please.
target: There are things in this comedy of “Pyramus and Thisbe” that will never please an audience.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, God give them wisdom that have it.
target: Well, we all have our special gifts.

orig: translate old to modern: A play there is, my lord, some ten words long, Which is as brief as I have known a play; But by ten words, my lord, it is too long, Which makes it tedious; for in all the play There is not one word apt, one player fitted.
target: A play there is, my lord, some ten words long, Which is as brief as I have known a play; But by ten words, my lord, it is too long, Which makes it tedious, because, in all the play There is not one appropriate word, one player a good actor.

orig: translate old to modern: There’s the cunning of it.
target: That’s what’s clever about it.

orig: translate old to modern: Be these the wretches that we played at dice for?
target: Are these the wretches that we threw dice for?

orig: translate old to modern: Have I, Malvolio?
target: I did, Malvolio?

orig: translate old to modern: But I can tell you that of late this duke Hath ta'en displeasure 'gainst his gentle niece, Grounded upon no other argument But that the people praise her for her virtues And pity her for her good father’s sake; And, on my life, his malice 'gainst the lady Will suddenly break forth.
target: But I will tell you that lately the duke has been displeased with his niece, and for no other reason than that people praise her virtues and pity her for her father’s sake.

orig: translate old to modern: I humbly thank you; well, well, well.
target: I humbly thank you, Well, well, well.

orig: translate old to modern: A vengeance on your crafty withered hide!
target: Sneaky, dried-up old coot!

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, an you be so tardy, come no more in my sight.
target: No, if you’re ever late like this again, I’ll refuse to see you.

orig: translate old to modern: Must I stand and crouch Under your testy humor?
target: Must I stand and bend Under your short-tempered mood?

orig: translate old to modern: Come your ways.
target: Come on!

orig: translate old to modern: With all my heart, sir.
target: With all my heart, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, Let’s have one other gaudy night.
target: Come, let’s have one more extravagant night.

orig: translate old to modern: My lord?
target: My lord?

orig: translate old to modern: Tis certain, every man that dies ill, the ill upon his own head.
target: It’s clear, every man must take responsibility for the manner of his own death.

orig: translate old to modern: God bless you, sir!
target: God bless you, sir!

orig: translate old to modern: Mine, sir.
target: Mine, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: I would not so much as make water but in a sink-a-pace.
target: I wouldn’t even pee without dancing a waltz.

orig: translate old to modern: O Lord, methought what pain it was to drown, What dreadful noise of waters in my ears, What sights of ugly death within my eyes.
target: Lord, how painful it was to drown.

orig: translate old to modern: Sir, they are spoken, and these things are true.
target: They’re really being spoken, sir, and they’re true.

orig: translate old to modern: A foolish heart that I leave here behind.
target: A foolish heart that I’m leaving behind here.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou canst compel no more than she entreat; Thy threats have no more strength than her weak prayers Helen, I love thee, by my life, I do; I swear by that which I will lose for thee To prove him false that says I love thee not.
target: You can order no more than she can beg; Your threats have no more strength than her weak prayers.— Helena, I love you; by my life I do; I swear, by that which I will lose for you, To prove him a liar that says I don’t love you.

orig: translate old to modern: You scarcely have the hearts to tell me so, And therefore cannot have the hearts to do it.
target: You barely have the heart to tell me, so you can’t possibly have the nerve to do it.

orig: translate old to modern: The man is, notwithstanding, sufficient;—three thousand ducats; —I think I may take his bond.
target: Three thousand dollars - I think I may take his promise to pay.

orig: translate old to modern: And truly in my youth I suffered much extremity for love, very near this.
target: In my youth I truly suffered much agony for love almost like this.

orig: translate old to modern: My Lord of Warwick, here is, praised be God for it, a most contagious treason come to light, look you, as you shall desire in a summer’s day.
target: My Lord of Warwick, a most corrupt treason—God be praised for it!—has been discovered, as plain as any you’d hope to see on a summer’s day.

orig: translate old to modern: And most chirurgeonly.
target: And almost like a licensed surgeon.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou didst drink The stale of horses and the gilded puddle Which beasts would cough at.
target: You drank horses’ urine and water from scum-covered puddles that even animals would refuse.

orig: translate old to modern: Ariel sings in Gonzalo's ear] [Ariel sings in Gonzalo's ear] While you here do snoring lie, Open-eyed conspiracy His time doth take.
target: While you lie here snoring, Open-eyed Plotting Takes his time.

orig: translate old to modern: Your reason?
target: Your reason?

orig: translate old to modern: I can hardly forbear hurling things at him.
target: I can hardly keep myself from throwing things at him.

orig: translate old to modern: If thou beest as poor for a subject as he’s for a king, thou'rt poor enough.
target: If you’re as poor a subject as he is a king, you definitely are poor.

orig: translate old to modern: Is not your lord honorable without marriage?
target: And isn’t your husband an honorable man?

orig: translate old to modern: I hope thou art not mad.
target: I hope you haven’t lost your mind.

orig: translate old to modern: If he be taken, he shall never more Be feared of doing harm.
target: If he’s caught, he’ll never make trouble for anyone again.

orig: translate old to modern: What are you?
target: Who are you?

orig: translate old to modern: She has spoke what she should not, I am sure of that.
target: She has spoken what she should not, I am sure of that.

orig: translate old to modern: What!
target: What!

orig: translate old to modern: Lovers and madmen have such seething brains, Such shaping fantasies, that apprehend More than cool reason ever comprehends.
target: Lovers and madmen have such busy brains, Such ability to shape fantasies, that they catch More than cool reason ever understands.

orig: translate old to modern: She’s but the sign and semblance of her honor.
target: She only appears honorable from the outside.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, what is it?
target: Well, what is it?

orig: translate old to modern: Villain, be sure thou prove my love a whore; Be sure of it.
target: Villain, be sure you prove my love a whore; Be sure of it.

orig: translate old to modern: If I think so, I think the same of you.
target: If that’s true, I think the same thing about you.

orig: translate old to modern: Madam, I trust, not so.
target: I hope not, Madam.

orig: translate old to modern: It sounds no more; and sure it waits upon Some god o'th’ island.
target: It’s stopped;—and surely, it’s for Some god of the island.

orig: translate old to modern: Peter Quince,— What sayest thou, bully Bottom?
target: Peter Quince— What do you say, bully Bottom?

orig: translate old to modern: Give me leave To speak my mind, and I will through and through Cleanse the foul body of th' infected world, If they will patiently receive my medicine.
target: Let me speak my mind, and I’ll rid the world of its sickness—if it will only tolerate my medicine.

orig: translate old to modern: And his kinsman too.
target: Yes, and his relative, too.

orig: translate old to modern: Abhorred villain!
target: Evil villain!

orig: translate old to modern: I must to the barber's, monsieur; for methinks I am marvellous hairy about the face; and I am such a tender ass, if my hair do but tickle me I must scratch.
target: I have to get to the barber's, sir, because I think I have an awful lot of hair on my face, and I am such a sensitive donkey, that I must scratch even if my hair only tickles me a little.

orig: translate old to modern: We are bound to the like.
target: We will do the same.

orig: translate old to modern: What is it you will see?
target: What do you want to see?

orig: translate old to modern: Now, Hamlet, where's Polonius?
target: Now, Hamlet, where's Polonius?

orig: translate old to modern: He is.
target: He is.

orig: translate old to modern: No, sir, I say his horse comes, with him on his back.
target: No, I said his horse is coming, with him on its back.

orig: translate old to modern: That would hang us, every mother's son.
target: That would hang us, every mother's son.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, I am glad that all things sort so well.
target: Well, I’m glad that everything has been sorted out.

orig: translate old to modern: What is't?
target: What is it?

orig: translate old to modern: Sir, his chests and treasure He has not with him.
target: Sir, he left his belongings and treasure.

orig: translate old to modern: Abominable villain!
target: Horrid villain!

orig: translate old to modern: Give you good morrow.
target: Have a good morning.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, with a heart as willing As bondage e'er of freedom: here's my hand.
target: Yes, with a heart as willing As slavery was ever willing of freedom: here's my hand.

orig: translate old to modern: Happily met, the happier for thy son.
target: A fortunate coincidence—more fortunate for your son.

orig: translate old to modern: Asses are made to bear, and so are you.
target: Asses are made for bearing, and so are you.

orig: translate old to modern: Remorseless, treacherous, lecherous, kindless villain!
target: Remorseless, treacherous, lecherous, kindless villain!

orig: translate old to modern: Humbly, sir, I thank you.
target: I humbly thank you.

orig: translate old to modern: With drink, sir?
target: With drink, sir?

orig: translate old to modern: I know not, madam.
target: I don’t know, madam.

orig: translate old to modern: If he awake, From toe to crown he'll fill our skins with pinches, Make us strange stuff.
target: If he awakens, He'll fill our skins with pinches from toe to head; Turn us into strange stuff.

orig: translate old to modern: Yet am I noble as the adversary I come to cope withal.
target: But I’m as noble as my opponent.

orig: translate old to modern: Look where they come.
target: Look at them.

orig: translate old to modern: You speak not as you think; it cannot be.
target: You don’t speak as you think; it cannot be.

orig: translate old to modern: Oh, make an end Of what I have begun!
target: Oh, finish what I’ve begun.

orig: translate old to modern: But heavenly Rosalind!
target: But, oh, heavenly Rosalind!

orig: translate old to modern: Propose the oath, my lord.
target: Tell us the oath, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Now civil wounds are stopped, peace lives again.
target: Civil wounds now can heal, and peace can live again.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, what worst?
target: Well, give me the worst news.

orig: translate old to modern: Through Athens I am thought as fair as she.
target: I am considered as fair as she is throughout Athens.

orig: translate old to modern: I would sing my song without a burden.
target: I’d like to sing my song solo.

orig: translate old to modern: And I beseech you instantly to visit My too much changed son.
target: And I beg you instantly to visit My too much changed son.

orig: translate old to modern: I will on with my speech in your praise and then show you the heart of my message.
target: I’ll go on with my speech praising you, and then I’ll get to the point.

orig: translate old to modern: Strange things I have in head that will to hand, Which must be acted ere they may be scann'd.
target: I have strange things in my head that need to be figured out, Which must be done quickly before others look at them closely.

orig: translate old to modern: Heart, once be stronger than thy continent.
target: Heart, for once be stronger than all the rest of the body combined.

orig: translate old to modern: I warrant you, you shall find the ceremonies of the wars and the cares of it and the forms of it and the sobriety of it and the modesty of it to be otherwise.
target: I tell you, you would find the rituals of war and, I promise you, its ceremonies and its solicitudes and its forms and its gravity and its discipline all to be quite counter to all this noise.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, and a kind one too.
target: Yes, and a nice one at that.

orig: translate old to modern: Who's there?
target: Who's there?

orig: translate old to modern: Can it be possible that no man saw them?
target: Can it be possible that no one saw them leave?

orig: translate old to modern: Remember March, the ides of March remember.
target: Remember March, remember the fifteenth of March?

orig: translate old to modern: There are no faces truer than those that are so washed.
target: There’s no face more sincere than one washed in tears.

orig: translate old to modern: In my schooldays, when I had lost one shaft, I shot his fellow of the self-same flight The self-same way, with more advised watch, To find the other forth; and by adventuring both I oft found both: I urge this childhood proof, Because what follows is pure innocence.
target: When I was in school, when I had lost one arrow, I shot another one of identical length In an identical way, with more thoughtful care, To find the one I lost, and by risking both, I often Found both.

orig: translate old to modern: Have I not reason, beldams as you are, Saucy and overbold?
target: Don’t I have reason, hags that you are, Impudent and overbold?

orig: translate old to modern: They are afoot.
target: They’re on the march.

orig: translate old to modern: Even a toy in hand here, sir.
target: This is just a trifling matter here, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: It may be, very like.
target: It may be, very likely.

orig: translate old to modern: Though it be pity to see such a sight, it well becomes the ground.
target: Though that must have been a pitiful sight, the ground looked beautiful.

orig: translate old to modern: if you tickle us, do we not laugh?
target: If you tickle us, don’t we laugh?

orig: translate old to modern: I promise you I scarcely know myself.
target: I’m telling you, I hardly know myself.

orig: translate old to modern: Good e'en, good e'en.
target: Good evening, good evening.

orig: translate old to modern: Let us hear what Antony can say.
target: Let’s hear what Antony can say.

orig: translate old to modern: Nor I know not Where I did lodge last night.
target: I can’t recall where I slept last night.

orig: translate old to modern: Madam wife, they say that I have dreamed And slept above some fifteen year or more.
target: Madam wife, they say I’ve been dreaming or asleep for more than fifteen years.

orig: translate old to modern: What news?
target: What news do you bring?

orig: translate old to modern: Let me have open means to come to them, And soon I’ll rid you from the fear of them.
target: Give me access to them, and soon you won’t have to worry about them anymore.

orig: translate old to modern: You are very well met.
target: We’re glad to see you.

orig: translate old to modern: Tell me where is fancy bred, Or in the heart, or in the head?
target: Tell me where is fancy bred, In the heart or in the head, How begot, how nourished?

orig: translate old to modern: You shall try but one fall.
target: You get only one round.

orig: translate old to modern: Though thou canst swim like a duck, thou art made like a goose.
target: Though you can swim like a duck, you are made like a goose.

orig: translate old to modern: But yet the pity of it, Iago!
target: but yet the pity of it, Iago!

orig: translate old to modern: That I distrust you.
target: That I don’t trust you.

orig: translate old to modern: What conquest brings he home?
target: What conquest does he bring home?

orig: translate old to modern: Be it so, Lysander: find you out a bed, For I upon this bank will rest my head.
target: You find yourself a bed, And I will rest my head upon this bank.

orig: translate old to modern: So smooth he daubed his vice with show of virtue That, his apparent open guilt omitted— I mean his conversation with Shore’s wife— He lived from all attainder of suspects.
target: He was so slick in covering over his plans that if it hadn’t been for his love affair with Shore’s wife, I would never have suspected him.

orig: translate old to modern: What is it that they do When they change us for others?
target: What is it that they do when they exchange us for others?

orig: translate old to modern: I fear our purpose is discovered.
target: I’m afraid our plan has been discovered.

orig: translate old to modern: But, O, what form of prayer Can serve my turn?
target: But, O, what form of prayer Can help me?

orig: translate old to modern: Farewell, kind lord.
target: Farewell, kind lord.

orig: translate old to modern: I durst, my lord, to wager she is honest, Lay down my soul at stake.
target: I dare, my lord, to bet that she is honest, Burn me at the stake.

orig: translate old to modern: Bind up my wounds!
target: Bandage my wounds!

orig: translate old to modern: Thou shalt get kings, though thou be none.
target: Your sons will be kings, even though you will not be king.

orig: translate old to modern: Good Volumnius, Thou know'st that we two went to school together; Even for that our love of old, I prithee, Hold thou my sword-hilts, whilst I run on it.
target: Good Volumnius, You know that we two went to school together; Even because that our love of old, please, Hold my sword handle while I run into it.

orig: translate old to modern: Why may not imagination trace the noble dust of Alexander till he find it stopping a bung-hole?
target: Why can’t imagination trace the noble dust of Alexander until he finds it stopping a wine barrel?

orig: translate old to modern: To you I am bound for life and education; My life and education both do learn me How to respect you; you are the lord of duty, I am hitherto your daughter.
target: To you I am bound for my life and education; My life and education both teach me How to respect you; you are the lord of duty, I am therefore your daughter.

orig: translate old to modern: The man that once did sell the lion’s skin While the beast lived was killed with hunting him.
target: The man that once sold the skin of a lion while the beast still lived died hunting him.

orig: translate old to modern: No, my lord, I saw nothing.
target: No, my lord, I saw nothing.

orig: translate old to modern: I' faith, I fear it has.
target: Trust me, I fear it has.

orig: translate old to modern: But i' faith, I should have been a woman by right.
target: But honestly, I should have been a woman.

orig: translate old to modern: What art thou?
target: But who are you?

orig: translate old to modern: Good majesty, Herod of Jewry dare not look upon you But when you are well pleased.
target: Gracious Queen, even Herod of Judea wouldn’t dare look at you unless you were in a good mood.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, I pray you let me go.
target: I beg you to let me go.

orig: translate old to modern: I am sorry that your leisure serves you not.
target: I am sorry that you cannot stay.

orig: translate old to modern: Why “with some little train,” my Lord of Buckingham?
target: Why only a few courtiers, my lord of Buckingham?

orig: translate old to modern: I found you as a morsel cold upon Dead Caesar’s trencher.
target: You were a cold crumb on dead Julius Caesar’s plate when I met you.

orig: translate old to modern: This way, my lord; the castle's gently render'd.
target: This way, my lord; the castle's gently surrounded.

orig: translate old to modern: Stephano!
target: Stephano!

orig: translate old to modern: The king falls from bias of nature—there’s father against child.
target: The king acts unnaturally—father against child.

orig: translate old to modern: Then he’s a rogue, and a passy-measures pavin.
target: Then he’s no good.

orig: translate old to modern: Tarry, Petruchio, I must go with thee, For in Baptista’s keep my treasure is.
target: Wait, Petruchio, I should go with you.

orig: translate old to modern: I'll about, And drive away the vulgar from the streets; So do you too, where you perceive them thick.
target: I'll go around And drive the low people away from the streets; You do this too, where you see many of them gathered together.

orig: translate old to modern: O sirs, consider: they that set you on To do this deed will hate you for the deed.
target: Oh sirs, consider this: those who sent you to do this deed will hate you for doing it.

orig: translate old to modern: Bid him therefore consider of his ransom, which must proportion the losses we have borne, the subjects we have lost, the disgrace we have digested, which, in weight to reanswer, his pettiness would bow under.
target: have lost, and the indignity we have endured, for which he is too insignificant to sufficiently pay us back.

orig: translate old to modern: He is address'd; press near and second him.
target: He’s ready; get closer and back him up.

orig: translate old to modern: I hope this passionate humor of mine will change.
target: I’m hoping my holy mood will pass.

orig: translate old to modern: Brutus, and Caesar: what should be in that Caesar?
target: Brutus" and "Caesar.” What is in that name, "Caesar?

orig: translate old to modern: My resolution’s placed, and I have nothing Of woman in me.
target: There’s nothing of the weak woman left in me.

orig: translate old to modern: Nothing.
target: No.

orig: translate old to modern: Farewell, for I must leave you.
target: Farewell; because I must leave you.

orig: translate old to modern: O, serve me well, and teach yourselves that duty!
target: Give me what I deserve, and do your duty!

orig: translate old to modern: Strumpet, I come!
target: Prostitute, I’m coming!

orig: translate old to modern: Fie on thee!
target: To hell with you!

orig: translate old to modern: Cunning.
target: How clever of you.

orig: translate old to modern: I think I told your lordship a year since how much I am in the favor of Margaret, the waiting gentlewoman to Hero.
target: I think it was a year ago that I told you how much Margaret, Hero’s servant woman, likes me.

orig: translate old to modern: Is he pursued?
target: Are your men searching for him?

orig: translate old to modern: Nor nothing in your letters writ of her?
target: And nothing in your letters was written about her?

orig: translate old to modern: But tell me true, are you not mad indeed?
target: But tell me honestly, are you sure you’re not insane?

orig: translate old to modern: Get you therefore hence, Poor miserable wretches, to your death, The taste whereof God of His mercy give You patience to endure, and true repentance Of all your dear offences.—Bear them hence.
target: So go to your deaths, poor miserable wretches, the pain of which may merciful God give you the strength to endure.

orig: translate old to modern: I would it might be hangers till then.
target: I would it might be hangers till then.

orig: translate old to modern: The day is yours.
target: You won it.

orig: translate old to modern: Be comforted.
target: Be comforted.

orig: translate old to modern: Worthy gentleman!
target: Worthy gentleman!

orig: translate old to modern: Indeed, I am no mourner for that news, Because they have been still my adversaries.
target: Well, I’m not sorry to hear that, because they have always been my enemies.

orig: translate old to modern: There, gentle Hermia, may I marry thee; And to that place the sharp Athenian law Cannot pursue us.
target: There, gentle Hermia, I may marry you; And the sharp Athenian law cannot follow us To that place.

orig: translate old to modern: Dismay'd not this Our captains, Macbeth and Banquo?
target: Our captains, Macbeth and Banquo, Were not upset by this?

orig: translate old to modern: Now, good my lord, lie here and rest awhile.
target: Please lie down and rest a while, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Yonder they lie, the poor old man their father making such pitiful dole over them that all the beholders take his part with weeping.
target: They’re lying over there, and the poor old man, their father, weeps so piteously over them that the whole audience has joined him in grieving.

orig: translate old to modern: Who’s there, besides foul weather?
target: Who’s there, aside from this foul weather?

orig: translate old to modern: They swore that you were well-nigh dead for me.
target: They swore that you were nearly dead with love for me.

orig: translate old to modern: My most dear Gloucester!
target: My dear Gloucester!

orig: translate old to modern: Vanish, or I shall give thee thy deserving, And blemish Caesar’s triumph.
target: Get out of my sight, or I’ll give you what you deserve and spoil Caesar’s victory.

orig: translate old to modern: Happily, amen!
target: I’m happy to say “amen” to that!

orig: translate old to modern: And then he offered it the third time; he put it the third time by; and still as he refused it, the rabblement hooted and clapped their chopped hands and threw up their sweaty nightcaps and uttered such a deal of stinking breath because Caesar refused the crown, that it had almost choked Caesar, for he swounded and fell down at it.
target: And then he was offered it the third time; he pushed it aside the third time, and still, as he refused it, the crowd shouted, and clapped their rough hands, and threw their sweaty night hats into the air, and uttered such a great deal of stinking breath because Caesar refused the crown, that the smell almost choked Caesar, because he fainted and fell down from it.

orig: translate old to modern: The crow doth sing as sweetly as the lark, When neither is attended; and, I think, The nightingale, if she should sing by day, When every goose is cackling, would be thought No better a musician than the wren.
target: The crow sings as sweetly as the lark When either is waited on, and I think The nightingale, if she sang by day, When every goose is cackling, would be considered No better a musician than the wren.

orig: translate old to modern: If he be absent, bring his brother to me.
target: If he’s not around, bring his brother Oliver to me.

orig: translate old to modern: But with much forcing of his disposition.
target: But with much forcing to make himself do it.

orig: translate old to modern: He is my dear friend, an please you.
target: He is my dear friend, your Majesty.

orig: translate old to modern: If one knight give a— Would you have a love song or a song of good life?
target: Would you rather hear a love song or a song about the good life?

orig: translate old to modern: It is engender'd.
target: It is born.

orig: translate old to modern: Had he his hurts before?
target: Was he wounded on the front of his body?

orig: translate old to modern: But, Lepidus, go you to Caesar's house, Fetch the will hither, and we shall determine How to cut off some charge in legacies.
target: But, Lepidus, go to Caesar's house; Go get the will here, and we shall determine How to cut off some appointments in legacies.

orig: translate old to modern: Cassio shall have my place.
target: Cassio shall take my place.

orig: translate old to modern: Gentlemen, my master Antonio is at his house, and desires to speak with you both.
target: Gentlemen, my master Antonio is at his house, and wants to speak with both of you.

orig: translate old to modern: Surely I do believe your fair cousin is wronged.
target: I really believe your cousin was falsely accused.

orig: translate old to modern: The canker galls the infants of the spring Too oft before their buttons be disclosed, And in the morn and liquid dew of youth Contagious blastments are most imminent.
target: An ugly disease afflicts the new flowers of the spring Too often before they have bloomed, And in the morning and liquid dew of youth Contagious shriveling is the most imminent.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou liest, thou shag-ear'd villain!
target: You lie, you shag-haired villain!

orig: translate old to modern: What think you on't?
target: What do you think about it?

orig: translate old to modern: Wast thou not charged at peril— Wherefore to Dover?—Let him first answer that.
target: Weren’t you ordered, on penalty of— Why Dover?—Let him answer that question first.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, I may chance to see you, for I would very fain speak with you.
target: Well, I maybe I’ll see you; because I would very gladly speak with you.

orig: translate old to modern: It was, so please your Highness.
target: It was, so please your highness.

orig: translate old to modern: The son of Duncan, From whom this tyrant holds the due of birth, Lives in the English court and is received Of the most pious Edward with such grace That the malevolence of fortune nothing Takes from his high respect.
target: Malcolm, Duncan’s son, From whom Macbeth withholds his birthright, Lives in the English court and is received By the most pious King Edward with such grace That the evil twist of fate takes nothing From his high respect.

orig: translate old to modern: Who knows if Donalbain be with his brother?
target: Does any one know if Donalbain be with his brother?

orig: translate old to modern: Let him answer me.— Come, follow me, boy.
target: Let me at him.

orig: translate old to modern: Methinks he looks as though he were in love.
target: He acts like a man in love.

orig: translate old to modern: Had you rather Caesar were living and die all slaves, than that Caesar were dead to live all freemen?
target: Would you rather Caesar were living, and you all die slaves, than that Caesar were dead, so you all live freemen?

orig: translate old to modern: But O, how oddly will it sound that I Must ask my child forgiveness!
target: How oddly it will sound that I Must ask my child for forgiveness!

orig: translate old to modern: It likes us well; And at our more consider'd time we'll read, Answer, and think upon this business.
target: We really like this news, And later when we have more time we'll read this Request, answer, and think upon this business.

orig: translate old to modern: You are very sensible, and yet you miss my sense: I mean, Hortensio is afeard of you.
target: That’s very sensible, but you missed my sense: I meant Hortensio is afraid of you.

orig: translate old to modern: Death of one person can be paid but once, And that she has discharged.
target: A person can only pay with their life once, and she has paid in full.

orig: translate old to modern: Work you, then.
target: Then go to work.

orig: translate old to modern: I pray you all, If you have hitherto conceal'd this sight, Let it be tenable in your silence still; And whatsoever else shall hap tonight, Give it an understanding, but no tongue.
target: I beg you all, If you have kept this sight secret so far, Keep your silence still, And whatever else shall happen tonight, Take it in, but don’t talk about it.

orig: translate old to modern: It would seem strange unto him when he waked.
target: When he woke, he wouldn’t know where he was.

orig: translate old to modern: O, balmy breath, that dost almost persuade Justice to break her sword!
target: O, balmy breath, that almost persuades Justice to break her sword!

orig: translate old to modern: This is a man’s invention, and his hand.
target: These are a man’s words, and his handwriting.

orig: translate old to modern: If that be to care for nothing, sir, I would it would make you invisible.
target: If that means I don’t care about anything, you should disappear right now, since you’re nothing.

orig: translate old to modern: Marry, God defend his grace should say us nay!
target: But God forbid he says no to us!

orig: translate old to modern: Speak softly.
target: Speak softly.

orig: translate old to modern: Bid him bring his pen and inkhorn to the jail.
target: Tell him to bring his pen and his inkwell to the jail.

orig: translate old to modern: O day untowardly turned!
target: Oh, this day has turned into a disaster!

orig: translate old to modern: We will yet do well.
target: We’ll win yet.

orig: translate old to modern: And thus it may be.
target: Then that’s the way it may turn out.

orig: translate old to modern: What, will the line stretch out to the crack of doom?
target: What, will the line stretch out to the crack of doom?

orig: translate old to modern: To mourn a mischief that is past and gone Is the next way to draw new mischief on.
target: To mourn mischief that is over and gone Is the next way to create new mischief.

orig: translate old to modern: Alas, thou hast misconstrued every thing!
target: Alas, you’ve misunderstood everything!

orig: translate old to modern: You are in the right.
target: You are right.

orig: translate old to modern: I know you are my eldest brother, and in the gentle condition of blood you should so know me.
target: I know you’re my oldest brother, and deserve more respect.

orig: translate old to modern: But, peace!
target: Only, peace!

orig: translate old to modern: But if we fail, We then can do ’t at land.
target: Even if we fail at that, we can still fight him on land.

orig: translate old to modern: Did you know him?
target: did you know him?

orig: translate old to modern: Brother— Content yourself.
target: Brother— Quiet.

orig: translate old to modern: I have lost the immortal part of myself, and what remains is bestial.
target: I have lost the immortal part of myself, and what remains is beastly.

orig: translate old to modern: As proper men as ever trod upon neats-leather have gone upon my handiwork.
target: Many proper men that ever walked on cowhide leather have walked on my work.

orig: translate old to modern: Thus die I, thus, thus, thus.
target: Ay, that left pap, Where the heart beats.— Thus die I, thus, thus, thus.

orig: translate old to modern: Get thee hence.
target: Go away.

orig: translate old to modern: What work is here, Charmian?
target: What kind of work is this, Charmian?

orig: translate old to modern: The manner of their deaths?
target: How did they die?

orig: translate old to modern: If you do fight in safeguard of your wives, Your wives shall welcome home the conquerors.
target: If you fight to protect your wives, your wives will welcome you home as conquerors.

orig: translate old to modern: Dost thou lie still?
target: Do you lie still?

orig: translate old to modern: Good morrow, Kate—for that’s your name, I hear.
target: Good morning, Kate, for I hear that’s what you’re called.

orig: translate old to modern: Mark me with what violence she first loved the Moor, but for bragging and telling her fantastical lies.
target: Watch with what violence she first loved the Moor, but with his bragging, and telling her fantastic lies.

orig: translate old to modern: How absolute the knave is!
target: How absolutely clever this chap is!

orig: translate old to modern: Most royal majesty, I crave no more than hath your highness offered.
target: Your highness, I want nothing more than what you’ve already offered.

orig: translate old to modern: Yet say I, he is in love.
target: I repeat, he’s in love.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, then, some be of laughing, as, ah, ha, he!
target: Well then, add some interjections that indicate laughter, like  Hold on, Friar.

orig: translate old to modern: O true, good Catesby.
target: Oh, right, good Catesby.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, sir.
target: Yes, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Hie therefore, Robin, overcast the night; The starry welkin cover thou anon With drooping fog as black as Acheron, And lead these testy rivals so astray As one come not within another's way.
target: Get going, then, Robin, make the night darker; Cover the stars in the sky With drooping fog, as black as Acheron, And lead these testy rivals so astray That they will not come within another's way.

orig: translate old to modern: Grim death, how foul and loathsome is thine image!
target: Alas, grim death, how vile and ugly your near-twin, sleep, is!

orig: translate old to modern: I will, lady.
target: I will, lady.

orig: translate old to modern: Did you not speak to it?
target: Didn’t you speak to it?

orig: translate old to modern: and Mustardseed!
target: and Mustardseed!

orig: translate old to modern: What company is this?
target: Who are all these people?

orig: translate old to modern: I do; and surely It is a sleepy language and thou speak'st Out of thy sleep.
target: I do: and surely It is a sleepy language, and you talk In your sleep.

orig: translate old to modern: How does my wife?
target: How is my wife?

orig: translate old to modern: You must needs yield your reason, Sir Andrew.
target: Yes, you have to tell us why, Sir Andrew.

orig: translate old to modern: Not so, my lord: I am too much i' the sun.
target: That’s not so, my lord, I am too much in the sun.

orig: translate old to modern: No, my lord.
target: No, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Both of you Know Banquo was your enemy.
target: Both of you Know Banquo was your enemy.

orig: translate old to modern: No master, sir, but a poor man's son: his father, though I say it, is an honest exceeding poor man, and, God be thanked, well to live.
target: No master, sir, only a poor man's son; his father, although I say it, is an honest, exceedingly poor man, and, thank God, well enough to live.

orig: translate old to modern: O, my Antonio!
target: Oh, my Antonio!

orig: translate old to modern: I have seen thee fight When I have envied thy behavior.
target: I’ve seen you fight and envied your skill.

orig: translate old to modern: The flat transgression of a schoolboy who, being overjoyed with finding a birds' nest, shows it his companion, and he steals it.
target: He was like a schoolboy who finds a bird’s nest and happily shows it to his friend, who then steals it from him.

orig: translate old to modern: Ah, my tender babes, My unblown flowers, new-appearing sweets, If yet your gentle souls fly in the air And be not fixed in doom perpetual, Hover about me with your airy wings And hear your mother’s lamentation.
target: If your gentle souls are still flying in the air and have not yet landed where they will remain forever, hover around me with your airy wings and hear your mother’s lament.

orig: translate old to modern: My people do already know my mind, And will acknowledge you and Jessica, In place of Lord Bassanio and myself.
target: With all my heart My staff already know my mind, And will report to you and Jessica In place of Lord Bassanio and myself.

orig: translate old to modern: I pray you, rise.
target: Please rise, Queen.

orig: translate old to modern: Where’s my fool, ho?
target: Where’s my fool?

orig: translate old to modern: One word, sir.
target: One more thing, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Then must thou needs find out new heaven, new earth.
target: Then you would have to go beyond heaven, beyond earth.

orig: translate old to modern: What think you of this fool, Malvolio?
target: What do you think of this fool, Malvolio?

orig: translate old to modern: Go, Captain, from me greet the Danish king.
target: Go, Captain, send my greetings to the Danish king.

orig: translate old to modern: Put out the light, and then put out the light.
target: Put out the light, and then put out the light.

orig: translate old to modern: Lady, you know no rules of charity, Which renders good for bad, blessings for curses.
target: Dear woman, you don’t know the rules of charity.

orig: translate old to modern: Here’s more news.
target: Here’s more news.

orig: translate old to modern: Weary se'nnights nine times nine Shall he dwindle, peak, and pine; Though his bark cannot be lost, Yet it shall be tempest-tost.
target: Though his ship will not be lost, It will be tossed about on the rough ocean.

orig: translate old to modern: If she sustain him and his hundred knights When I have showed th' unfitness— Here, madam.
target: If she welcomes him and his hundred knights after I’ve shown how inappropriately he’s behaved— Here, ma'am.

orig: translate old to modern: Dearly, my delicate Ariel.
target: Dearly, my delicate Ariel.

orig: translate old to modern: O, do not swear, my lord of Buckingham!
target: Oh, please don’t swear, my lord of Buckingham.

orig: translate old to modern: Here, sirrah Grumio.
target: Here, you there, Grumio.

orig: translate old to modern: Who cannot want the thought, how monstrous It was for Malcolm and for Donalbain To kill their gracious father?
target: Who cannot think how monstrous It was for Malcolm and for Donalbain To kill their gracious father?

orig: translate old to modern: Bloody constraint, for if you hide the crown Even in your hearts, there will he rake for it.
target: Bloodshed will force you to.

orig: translate old to modern: She is not, madam.
target: She is not, madam.

orig: translate old to modern: Pluck up thy spirits.
target: Give us a smile.

orig: translate old to modern: Adieu.
target: Adieu.

orig: translate old to modern: My other self, my council’s consistory, My oracle, my prophet, my dear cousin, I, as a child, will go by thy direction Toward Ludlow then, for we’ll not stay behind.
target: You are my other self, my oracle, my prophet, my dear brother!

orig: translate old to modern: Under a compelling occasion, let women die.
target: If it’s that important, then let the women die.

orig: translate old to modern: You know that you are Brutus that speaks this, Or, by the gods, this speech were else your last.
target: Thank your stars that you’re Brutus that speaks This way, or, by the gods, this speech would be your last.

orig: translate old to modern: I prophesied if a gallows were on land This fellow could not drown.
target: I prophesied That, if a gallows were on land, this fellow could not drown.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, I do.
target: Yes, I do.

orig: translate old to modern: Say you have wronged her, sir.
target: Admit you were wrong.

orig: translate old to modern: O wonderful, wonderful, and most wonderful wonderful, and yet again wonderful, and after that, out of all whooping!
target: Oh, this is wonderful, wonderful—just wonderful wonderful!

orig: translate old to modern: Sure, he that made us with such large discourse, Looking before and after, gave us not That capability and godlike reason To fust in us unused.
target: Surely He that made us with such large capacity, Looking before and after, didn’t give us That capability and godlike reason To go stale in us, unused.

orig: translate old to modern: Our brother is imprisoned by your means, Myself disgraced, and the nobility Held in contempt, while great promotions Are daily given to ennoble those That scarce some two days since were worth a noble.
target: My brother is imprisoned because of you, I am disgraced, and the nobility are held in contempt while those who two days ago weren’t worth a dime have suddenly been promoted.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, shall we turn to men?
target: Why, shall we turn into men?

orig: translate old to modern: Tell the clock there.
target: Read the time there.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou shouldst rather ask if it were possible any villainy should be so rich.
target: You should ask instead if it’s possible that any criminal could be so rich.

orig: translate old to modern: Impatient of my absence, And grief that young Octavius with Mark Antony Have made themselves so strong: for with her death That tidings came: with this she fell distract, And, her attendants absent, swallow'd fire.
target: Impatient that I was gone, And upset that young Octavius with Mark Antony Has made themselves so strong;—because that news came With the news of her death;—with all this, she became crazy, And, without her attendants present, swallowed fire.

orig: translate old to modern: A likely piece of work that you should find it in your chamber and not know who left it there!
target: A likely piece of work that you should find it in your bedroom and not know who left it there!

orig: translate old to modern: But that you do not love me.
target: But it’s that you don’t love me.

orig: translate old to modern: Help me hence, ho!
target: Help me here, hello!

orig: translate old to modern: Know I these men that come along with you?
target: Do I know these men that come along with you?

orig: translate old to modern: Tell the hot duke that Lear— No, but not yet.
target: Tell the hot-headed duke that I… But no, not yet.

orig: translate old to modern: Retire we to our chamber.
target: Let’s go to our bedroom.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, my Hippolyta; what cheer, my love?
target: are you okay, my love?

orig: translate old to modern: Tis no such matter.
target: Oh, well.

orig: translate old to modern: Oh, ominous!
target: Oh, that’s ominous!

orig: translate old to modern: No, cousin, I'll to Fife.
target: No, cousin, I'm going to Fife.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou hast mettle enough in thee to kill care.
target: Sir, don’t even try to beat me in a battle of wits.

orig: translate old to modern: But where is Kate?
target: But where is Kate?

orig: translate old to modern: This gentleman will out-talk us all.
target: This fellow will out-talk us all.

orig: translate old to modern: Brutus, my lord!
target: Brutus, my lord!

orig: translate old to modern: She’s desperate.
target: She’s desperate.

orig: translate old to modern: O my brave Emperor, this is fought indeed!
target: Oh, my brave Emperor, this is what I call a fight!

orig: translate old to modern: Alas the day!
target: alas the day!

orig: translate old to modern: I know that, but I would have thee hence and here again.
target: I see that you are here, but I’d like you to go there and then come back again.

orig: translate old to modern: O perdurable shame!
target: O, everlasting shame!

orig: translate old to modern: Is ’t possible?
target: Is that possible?

orig: translate old to modern: Though the nature of our quarrel yet never brooked parle, know now upon advice, it toucheth us both, that we may yet again have access to our fair mistress and be happy rivals in Bianca’s love, to labor and effect one thing specially.
target: That is, if we ever want to return to being rivals for Bianca’s love.

orig: translate old to modern: Dost thou hear, my honest friend?
target: Did you hear, my honest friend?

orig: translate old to modern: But herein mean I to enrich my pain, To have his sight thither and back again.
target: But I mean to make my pain worth suffering, To have him look at me there and back again.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou didst smile, Infused with a fortitude from heaven, When I have decked the sea with drops full salt, Under my burden groaned; which raised in me An undergoing stomach, to bear up Against what should ensue.
target: You smiled, Instilled with strength from heaven, When I have covered the sea with salty tears, Groaning under my load, which raised in me A new strength, to put with Whatever should follow.

orig: translate old to modern: For that It is not night when I do see your face, Therefore I think I am not in the night; Nor doth this wood lack worlds of company, For you, in my respect, are all the world.
target: It isn’t night whenever I see your face, So I don’t think it’s night, And this forest doesn’t lack worlds of company, For you, in my respect, are all the world.

orig: translate old to modern: Would it not make one weep?
target: Wouldn’t it make one weep?

orig: translate old to modern: Gentle cousin, Let us go thank him and encourage him.
target: Gentle cousin, let’s go thank him and encourage him.

orig: translate old to modern: This Lodovico is a proper man.
target: This Lodovico is a proper man.

orig: translate old to modern: What, strike his wife!
target: What, strike his wife!

orig: translate old to modern: Shall I hear from you anon?
target: Will I hear from you soon?

orig: translate old to modern: Relent, and save your souls.
target: Relent, and save your souls.

orig: translate old to modern: You know, he brought me out o' favor with my lady about a bear-baiting here.
target: You know, he got me in trouble with the lady of the house once when I arranged a bear-baiting here.

orig: translate old to modern: Yes, As sparrows eagles, or the hare the lion.
target: Yes; As sparrows are by eagles, or the hare is by the lion.

orig: translate old to modern: Marry, patience, Or I shall say you are all in all in spleen, And nothing of a man.
target: By Mary, have patience; Or I shall say you are totally in a temper, And not a man.

orig: translate old to modern: How but well, sir?
target: Beautifully, sir, beautifully!

orig: translate old to modern: Lear’s shadow.
target: You’re Lear’s shadow.

orig: translate old to modern: Doth his Majesty Incline to it or no?
target: Ugh!

orig: translate old to modern: Liar and slave!
target: Liar, and slave!

orig: translate old to modern: Or is he on his horse?
target: Or is he on his horse?

orig: translate old to modern: Doctor, the thanes fly from me.
target: Doctor, the Barons desert me.

orig: translate old to modern: I need not to be ashamed of your Majesty, praised be God, so long as your Majesty is an honest man.
target: I needn’t be ashamed of your Majesty, God be praised, so long as your Majesty is an honest man.

orig: translate old to modern: Before the time be out?
target: Before the debt is paid?

orig: translate old to modern: If thou darest tempt me further, draw thy sword.
target: If you insist on trying my patience any further, then take out your sword right now.

orig: translate old to modern: To prison; till fit time Of law and course of direct session, Call thee to answer.
target: To prison until the right time Of law and course of justice Call you to answer.

orig: translate old to modern: The same indeed; a very valiant fellow.
target: The same indeed; a very valiant fellow.

orig: translate old to modern: If your master Would have a queen his beggar, you must tell him, That majesty, to keep decorum, must No less beg than a kingdom.
target: If your master wants a queen to beg from him, you should tell him that a queen will beg for no less than a kingdom.

orig: translate old to modern: The gentleness of all the gods go with thee!
target: I wish you all the best.

orig: translate old to modern: I would cure you if you would but call me Rosalind and come every day to my cote and woo me.
target: I could cure you, if you just called me Rosalind and came by my cottage every day to woo me.

orig: translate old to modern: No, my lord.
target: No, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: It gives me wonder great as my content To see you here before me.
target: It surprises me as much as my joy To see you here before me.

orig: translate old to modern: Lorenzo, and thy love.
target: Lorenzo, and your love.

orig: translate old to modern: To bear all smooth and even, This sudden sending him away must seem Deliberate pause.
target: To deal with everything smoothly and evenly, this sudden sending him away must seem like a planned event.

orig: translate old to modern: Wherefore, bold peasant, Darest thou support a published traitor?
target: Whoa, man, you dare to support someone who’s been proclaimed a traitor?

orig: translate old to modern: It only stands Our lives upon to use our strongest hands.
target: In any case, our survival depends on putting together the strongest force possible.

orig: translate old to modern: Sometimes a thousand twangling instruments Will hum about mine ears, and sometime voices That, if I then had waked after long sleep, Will make me sleep again: and then, in dreaming, The clouds methought would open and show riches Ready to drop upon me, that when I waked I cried to dream again.
target: Sometimes a thousand twanging instruments Will hum about my ears; and sometimes voices, That, if I then had wakened after long sleep, Will make me sleep again: and then, in dreaming, The clouds I thought would open and show riches Ready to drop on me; that, when I wakened, I cried to dream again.

orig: translate old to modern: Then I salute you with this royal title: Long live Richard, England’s worthy king!
target: Then I salute you with this royal title: long live Richard, England’s worthy king!

orig: translate old to modern: But where the greater malady is fixed The lesser is scarce felt.
target: But whenever you feel a larger pain, the smaller one disappears.

orig: translate old to modern: If the balance of our lives had not one scale of reason to poise another of sensuality, the blood and baseness of our natures would conduct us to most preposterous conclusions.
target: If the balance of our lives had not one scale of reason to balance another of sensuality, the blood and baseness of our natures would lead us to very preposterous conclusions.

orig: translate old to modern: He threw his eye aside— And mark what object did present itself: Under an old oak, whose boughs were mossed with age And high top bald with dry antiquity, A wretched, ragged man, o'ergrown with hair, Lay sleeping on his back.
target: He looked to the side, and pay attention to what he saw then: under an oak tree—whose lower branches were mossy with age and top branches ancient and brittle—he saw a wretched beggar, with overgrown hair and beard, asleep on his back.

orig: translate old to modern: Himself in person there?
target: Is he there in person?

orig: translate old to modern: Such tricks hath strong imagination That, if it would but apprehend some joy, It comprehends some bringer of that joy; Or in the night, imagining some fear, How easy is a bush supposed a bear?
target: Such tricks have strong imagination, That, if it would only catch some joy, It understands some bringer of that joy; Or in the night, imagining some fear, How easy is a bush thought to be a bear?

orig: translate old to modern: I have heard of some kind of men that put quarrels purposely on others, to taste their valor.
target: I’ve heard of men who pick fights with other people on purpose, just to see how brave they are.

orig: translate old to modern: I prithee, do so.
target: I beg you, do so.

orig: translate old to modern: The other motive Why to a public count I might not go Is the great love the general gender bear him, Who, dipping all his faults in their affection, Would, like the spring that turneth wood to stone, Convert his gyves to graces; so that my arrows, Too slightly timber'd for so loud a wind, Would have reverted to my bow again, And not where I had aim'd them.
target: The other motive, why I couldn’t go to a public court, Is the great love the people of this country have for him, Who, dipping all his faults in their affection, Would, like the spring that turn wood to stone, Convert his crimes to graces, so that my actions, Not at all popular with the masses, Would have reflected badly on me, And not be taken as I intended them.

orig: translate old to modern: Sir, do you know me?
target: Sir, do you know who I am?

orig: translate old to modern: Thou liest, abhorred tyrant; with my sword I'll prove the lie thou speak'st.
target: You lie, abhorred tyrant; with my sword I'll prove the lie you speak.

orig: translate old to modern: There to meet with Macbeth.
target: That’s where we’ll meet with Macbeth.

orig: translate old to modern: If by your art, my dearest father, you have Put the wild waters in this roar, allay them.
target: If, my dearest father, you have put the wild waters Into this fury by your magic, stop them.

orig: translate old to modern: Dear Celia, I show more mirth than I am mistress of, and would you yet I were merrier?
target: Dear Celia—I already look much happier than I feel, but you want me to look even happier?

orig: translate old to modern: Patience, good sir.
target: Patience, good sir.

orig: translate old to modern: And you shall speak In the same pulpit whereto I am going, After my speech is ended.
target: And you shall speak After my speech is ended On the same platform where I’m going to be.

orig: translate old to modern: He swore he would never marry, and yet now, in despite of his heart, he eats his meat without grudging.
target: He swore that he’d never get married, but now, despite his earlier protestations, he loves ungrudgingly.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis pity of him.
target: It ‘s a pity of him.

orig: translate old to modern: Borachio.
target: Borachio.

orig: translate old to modern: I am glad on't.
target: I’m glad about it.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, had I power, I should Pour the sweet milk of concord into hell, Uproar the universal peace, confound All unity on earth.
target: No, if I had power, I should Pour the sweet milk of concord into hell, Disturb the universal peace, confuse All unity on earth.

orig: translate old to modern: His daughters seek his death.
target: His daughters want to kill him.

orig: translate old to modern: I might ask you for your commission, but I do take thee, Orlando, for my husband.
target: Maybe I should ask you what right you have to take me, but I’ll take you, Orlando, to be my husband.

orig: translate old to modern: Scorn and derision never come in tears.
target: You cannot find scorn and derision in tears of love.

orig: translate old to modern: So should he look That seems to speak things strange.
target: He look should look that way with so many strange things To say.

orig: translate old to modern: Where learned you this, Fool?
target: Where did you learn that song, Fool?

orig: translate old to modern: As love is, my lord, before it loves.
target: Like love, my lord, before it learns to love.

orig: translate old to modern: My good lords both, with all the heed I can.
target: My good lords, I plan to.

orig: translate old to modern: Ho, ho, ho!
target: Ha, ha, ha!

orig: translate old to modern: My lord, the first time that I ever saw him Methought he was a brother to your daughter.
target: My lord, when I first saw him I thought he was your daughter’s brother.

orig: translate old to modern: O, she will sing the savageness out of a bear.
target: O, she will sing the savageness out of a bear!

orig: translate old to modern: When comes such another?
target: When does another like him come?

orig: translate old to modern: There's rue for you, and here's some for me.
target: there's rue for you, and here's some for me.

orig: translate old to modern: My services to your lordship.
target: Very pleased to meet you, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: I have sent for these strawberries.
target: I have sent for the strawberries.

orig: translate old to modern: This is above all strangeness.
target: This is beyond weird.

orig: translate old to modern: Sir, good success.
target: Good luck, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Wherefore are these things hid?
target: Why do you hide these things?

orig: translate old to modern: I see, lady, the gentleman is not in your books.
target: I can see you don’t like this gentleman.

orig: translate old to modern: If you did wear a beard upon your chin, I’d shake it on this quarrel.
target: I am willing to fight you if I must.

orig: translate old to modern: I had no judgment when to her I swore.
target: I had no sense of judgment when I swore love to her.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, “some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrown upon them.” I was one, sir, in this interlude, one Sir Topas, sir, but that’s all one.
target: Well, you know, “some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon them.” Anyway, I was part of the trick, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Hence!
target: Get going!

orig: translate old to modern: He poisons him i' the garden for his estate.
target: He poisons him in the garden for his estate.

orig: translate old to modern: My gentle Puck, come hither.
target: My gentle Puck, come here.

orig: translate old to modern: He hath been out nine years, and away he shall again.
target: He’s been gone for nine years and he’s leaving again soon.

orig: translate old to modern: Hath it slept since?
target: Did it go to sleep it off?

orig: translate old to modern: If he come tomorrow, I’ll give him his payment.
target: If he shows up tomorrow, I’ll give him what’s coming to him.

orig: translate old to modern: I will stop your mouth.
target: I’ll stop your mouth with a kiss.

orig: translate old to modern: But being widow, and my Gloucester with her, May all the building in my fancy pluck Upon my hateful life.
target: He lost both, my lord.—Ma'am, this letter is from your sister, and needs an immediate answer.

orig: translate old to modern: But, I pray you, let none of your people stir me; I have an exposition of sleep come upon me.
target: But, I beg you, don’t let any of your people wake me up; I feel a deep sleep coming.

orig: translate old to modern: No mind that's honest But in it shares some woe, though the main part Pertains to you alone.
target: Only a mind that's honest Could share some of this woe, although the main part Pertains to you alone.

orig: translate old to modern: I have no exquisite reason for ’t, but I have reason good enough.
target: I don’t have any “brilliant” reason for it, but I have a good enough reason.

orig: translate old to modern: Marvellous sweet music!
target: Marvelous sweet music!

orig: translate old to modern: I did send, After the last enchantment you did here, A ring in chase of you.
target: After you cast your magic spell on me last time, I sent you a ring.

orig: translate old to modern: They are so still, Or thou, the greatest soldier of the world, Art turned the greatest liar.
target: My features are still that beautiful—or else you, the greatest soldier in the world, have become the greatest liar by overpraising them.

orig: translate old to modern: No cock of mine.
target: It has no fighting spirit.

orig: translate old to modern: Why had I not with charitable hand Took up a beggar’s issue at my gates, Who, smirchèd thus, and mired with infamy, I might have said, “No part of it is mine; This shame derives itself from unknown loins”?
target: Why didn’t I just adopt a beggar’s child left at my doorstep, whose shame and dishonor I could have denied, not being its true father?

orig: translate old to modern: Tell him I have moved my lord on his behalf and hope all will be well.
target: Tell him I have moved my lord on his behalf, and hope all will be well.

orig: translate old to modern: Hath your grace ne'er a brother like you?
target: Don’t you have any brothers like you?

orig: translate old to modern: So do all thoughts.
target: So do all thoughts.

orig: translate old to modern: Demand.
target: Demand.

orig: translate old to modern: O day and night, but this is wondrous strange!
target: O day and night, but this is wondrous strange!

orig: translate old to modern: Yes, gracious madam.
target: Yes, dear madam.

orig: translate old to modern: Rather than so, come, Fate, into the list, And champion me to the utterance!
target: Rather than see that happen, come, Fate, into the arena, And fight for me to the death!

orig: translate old to modern: What, and my old Venetian friend, Salerio?
target: What, and my old Venetian friend, Salanio!

orig: translate old to modern: I do suspect I have done some offense That seems disgracious in the city’s eye, And that you come to reprehend my ignorance.
target: I suspect that I have committed some offence to the city and you have come to reprimand me for not knowing better.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, but Beatrice— Sweet Hero, she is wronged, she is slandered, she is undone.
target: No, but Beatrice— Sweet Hero, she’s been wronged, she’s been slandered, she’s been ruined.

orig: translate old to modern: If one should be a prey, how much the better To fall before the lion than the wolf!
target: It’s much better to be destroyed by a noble enemy than by a cruel and heartless one.

orig: translate old to modern: Write from us to him, postposthaste dispatch.
target: Write to him from us; send it very, very quickly.

orig: translate old to modern: Look, here comes Helena.
target: Look, here comes Helena.

orig: translate old to modern: Since no man has aught of what he leaves, what is't to leave betimes?
target: Since no man has anything of what he leaves, what is it to leave soon?

orig: translate old to modern: Even so.
target: Even from that.

orig: translate old to modern: I will hear that play; For never anything can be amiss When simpleness and duty tender it.
target: I will hear that play, Because nothing can ever be wrong When simpleness and duty give it freely.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou speakest aright: I am that merry wanderer of the night.
target: I am that merry wanderer of the night.

orig: translate old to modern: Where the place?
target: Where should we meet?

orig: translate old to modern: Take in your love, and then let me alone.
target: Go, take your sweetheart and leave him to me.

orig: translate old to modern: Oh, pardon me, Signior Gremio, I would fain be doing.
target: You’re  Forgive me, Signior Gremio, but I’m anxious to get things moving.

orig: translate old to modern: But what will you be called?
target: Instead of Celia, call me Aliena.

orig: translate old to modern: I hope he is, but yet let mothers doubt.
target: I hope he is, but mothers get to have their doubts.

orig: translate old to modern: Octavius, I have seen more days than you, And though we lay these honors on this man To ease ourselves of divers slanderous loads, He shall but bear them as the ass bears gold, To groan and sweat under the business, Either led or driven, as we point the way; And having brought our treasure where we will, Then take we down his load and turn him off, Like to the empty ass, to shake his ears And graze in commons.
target: And, although we lay these honors on this man, To ease ourselves of different, disgraceful burdens, He shall only carry them as the donkey carries gold, Groaning and sweating under the load, Either led or driven, as we point the way; And having brought our treasure where we choose, We then unload him and let him loose, Like an unloaded donkey, to shake his ears And graze in the common fields.

orig: translate old to modern: I confess two sleeves.
target: I admit two sleeves.

orig: translate old to modern: She confesses it.
target: She confessed.

orig: translate old to modern: Or shall I say her uncle?
target: Or should I say it’s her uncle?

orig: translate old to modern: Hark, they roar!
target: Listen, they roar.

orig: translate old to modern: I'th’ commonwealth I would by contraries Execute all things, for no kind of traffic Would I admit; no name of magistrate; Letters should not be known; riches, poverty, And use of service, none; contract, succession, Bourn, bound of land, tilth, vineyard, none; No use of metal, corn, or wine, or oil; No occupation; all men idle, all; And women too, but innocent and pure; No sovereignty— [to Antonio] Yet he would be king on't.
target: In the country, I would carry out all things By opposites; because I wouldn’t admit Any kind of traffic; have no one named magistrate; Appeals before a court wouldn’t be recognized; riches, poverty, And slavery, none; treaties, lines of succession, Boundaries, boundary lines of land, farming, vineyards, none; No use of metal, corn, or wine, or oil; No occupations; all men idle, all: And women too, only innocent and pure; No supreme ruler,— But he would be king on it.

orig: translate old to modern: Write down “Master Gentleman Conrade.”—Masters, do you serve God?
target: Write down “Master Gentleman Conrade.”—Gentlemen, are you good Christians, and do you serve God?

orig: translate old to modern: What noise?
target: What’s that noise?

orig: translate old to modern: He stays upon your will.
target: He’s waiting outside.

orig: translate old to modern: You touched my vein at first.
target: You were right the first time.

orig: translate old to modern: Is the sword unswayed?
target: Is the army without a leader?

orig: translate old to modern: With all my heart.
target: With all my heart.

orig: translate old to modern: God bless thee, and put meekness in thy breast, Love, charity, obedience, and true duty.
target: God bless you and make you obedient, loving, and kind.

orig: translate old to modern: What, sir, not yet at rest?
target: What, sir, not in bed yet?

orig: translate old to modern: No blown ambition doth our arms incite, But love—dear love!—and our aged father’s right.
target: We’re not invading England out of ambition or greed, but out of love—dear love!—and my father’s right to his kingdom.

orig: translate old to modern: And mine, to eke out hers.
target: Mine too, to join hers.

orig: translate old to modern: Never excuse; for when the players are all dead there need none to be blamed.
target: Never excuse, for when the players are all dead, there’s no one to be blamed.

orig: translate old to modern: Grieve not that I am fallen to this for you; For herein Fortune shows herself more kind Than is her custom: it is still her use, To let the wretched man out-live his wealth, To view with hollow eye, and wrinkled brow, An age of poverty; from which lingering penance Of such misery doth she cut me off.
target: Don’t grieve that I am doing this for you, Because here Fortune shows herself more kind Than is her habit: it is still her habit To let the wretched man outlive his wealth, To view an age of poverty with hollow eye and wrinkled brow; She cuts me off from the lingering repentance Of such misery.

orig: translate old to modern: The devil take thy soul!
target: The devil take your soul!

orig: translate old to modern: He speaks home, madam.
target: He speaks freely, madam.

orig: translate old to modern: O sweet bully Bottom!
target: Oh sweet bully Bottom!

orig: translate old to modern: Fair and noble hostess, We are your guest tonight.
target: Beautiful and noble hostess, We are your guests tonight.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis a wonder, by your leave, she will be tamed so.
target: It’s amazing, if I may say so, that she let herself be tamed.

orig: translate old to modern: That I have labored With all my wits, my pains, and strong endeavors, To bring your most imperial Majesties Unto this bar and royal interview, Your mightiness on both parts best can witness.
target: Your Highnesses can both attest to the fact that I’ve strived mightily, with all my wits and energy, to bring about this royal meeting between you two imperial Majesties.

orig: translate old to modern: So I to her and so she yields to me, For I am rough and woo not like a babe.
target: I’m that great gust to her fire.

orig: translate old to modern: A miracle!
target: What a miracle!

orig: translate old to modern: No man must know.” What follows?
target: No man must know.” What comes after that?

orig: translate old to modern: Pindarus, Bid our commanders lead their charges off A little from this ground.
target: Pindarus, Ask our commanders to lead their men a little Away from this place.

orig: translate old to modern: Though Nature hath given us wit to flout at Fortune, hath not Fortune sent in this fool to cut off the argument?
target: And even though Nature has given us the wit to have this argument, hasn’t Fortune sent this fool here to stop us?

orig: translate old to modern: But if you be remembered, I did not bid you mar it to the time.
