target: But if you remember, I didn’t tell you to parody the style.

orig: translate old to modern: You gentle Romans— Peace, ho!
target: You gentle Romans,— Peace, oh!

orig: translate old to modern: Love-news, in faith.
target: Love news, in faith.

orig: translate old to modern: Sweet Beatrice, wouldst thou come when I called thee?
target: Take  Beatrice, have you come because I called for you?

orig: translate old to modern: Make your best use of this.
target: Make the best use of this information you can.

orig: translate old to modern: My lord!
target: My lord!

orig: translate old to modern: Let’s mock the midnight bell.
target: Let’s drink through midnight.

orig: translate old to modern: We shall find a time, Audrey.
target: We’ll get married at some point, Audrey.

orig: translate old to modern: Coldhearted toward me?
target: Has your heart cooled toward me?

orig: translate old to modern: You say very true, scald knave, when God’s will is.
target: That’s very true, mangy rascal, when it pleases God.

orig: translate old to modern: What, wouldst thou have me go and beg my food, Or with a base and boist'rous sword enforce A thievish living on the common road?
target: What, would you have me beg for my food?

orig: translate old to modern: I'm out of patience.
target: I am out of patience.

orig: translate old to modern: There are no tricks in plain and simple faith; But hollow men, like horses hot at hand, Make gallant show and promise of their mettle; But when they should endure the bloody spur, They fall their crests and like deceitful jades Sink in the trial.
target: There are no tricks in plain and simple trust, But hollow men, like horses very eager about something, Make gallant show and promises of their spirit, but, when They are supposed to endure a spur that will make them Bleed, they are humbled, and, like false, worthless horses Disappear from the fight.

orig: translate old to modern: Signor, you are very near my brother in his love.
target: Sir, my brother is very fond of you.

orig: translate old to modern: Throw this slave Upon the dunghill.—Regan, I bleed apace.
target: And throw this dead peasant into the manure pit.—Regan, I’m bleeding.

orig: translate old to modern: O infinite virtue, com’st thou smiling from The world’s great snare uncaught?
target: Have you returned smiling from the great battle for the world?

orig: translate old to modern: A friend.
target: A friend.

orig: translate old to modern: I find here that Don Pedro hath bestowed much honor on a young Florentine called Claudio.
target: Claudio deserves to be honored, and Don Pedro has rewarded him accordingly.

orig: translate old to modern: And all my armor laid into my tent?
target: And has my armor been put in my tent?

orig: translate old to modern: I tell you yet again, Banquo's buried; he cannot come out on's grave.
target: I tell you yet again, Banquo's buried; he cannot come out on his grave.

orig: translate old to modern: Good friend, go to him, for by this light of heaven, I know not how I lost him.
target: Good friend, go to him; because, by this light of heaven, I don’t know how I lost him.

orig: translate old to modern: Break an hour’s promise in love?
target: You’d break a date with your beloved by a whole hour?

orig: translate old to modern: You have, my lord.
target: You have, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: When I am known aright you shall not grieve Lending me this acquaintance.
target: When I’ve revealed my true identity, you’ll be glad you took the time to help me out.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, sit, sit, and a song.
target: Come, sit, sit, and sing me a song.

orig: translate old to modern: He has heard that word of some great man and now applies it to a fool.
target: He must’ve heard that phrase describing some great man and now he’s using it on a jester.

orig: translate old to modern: Truly then I fear you are damned both by father and mother: thus when I shun Scylla, your father, I fall into Charybdis, your mother: well, you are gone both ways.
target: Honestly, then I’m afraid you are dammed both by father and mother; when I keep away from the Sea Monster, your father, I fall into an equal evil, your mother; well, you are gone both ways.

orig: translate old to modern: Like to the time o’ th’ year between the extremes Of hot and cold, he was nor sad nor merry.
target: He was like that time of year halfway between the extremes of hot and cold: he was neither sad nor happy.

orig: translate old to modern: I am not taught to make anything.
target: I’ve never been taught how to make anything.

orig: translate old to modern: Keep word, Lysander; we must starve our sight From lovers' food till morrow deep midnight.
target: we must not give in To hugs and kisses until midnight tomorrow.

orig: translate old to modern: O Antony, Thou mine of bounty, how wouldst thou have paid My better service, when my turpitude Thou dost so crown with gold!
target: Oh, Antony, you extravagantly generous man, how would you have rewarded me for serving you faithfully when you reward my badness with all of this gold!

orig: translate old to modern: Be factious for redress of all these griefs, And I will set this foot of mine as far As who goes farthest.
target: Be a rebel for revenge for all these problems, And I’ll support you as far As the man who goes the farthest.

orig: translate old to modern: my lord, my lord!
target: my lord, my lord!

orig: translate old to modern: Good, i' faith.
target: That’s true.

orig: translate old to modern: I am so.
target: I am.

orig: translate old to modern: Shall I attend your Grace?
target: Shall I accompany your Grace?

orig: translate old to modern: I had rather have a fool to make me merry than experience to make me sad— and to travel for it, too.
target: I’d rather have a jester to make me happy than experience to make me sad—and to travel for all that trouble, no less!

orig: translate old to modern: O, the recorders!
target: O, the pipes.

orig: translate old to modern: He waxes desperate with imagination.
target: He’s getting crazy with expectation!

orig: translate old to modern: He hath rid his prologue like a rough colt; he knows not the stop.
target: He has ridden his prologue like a rough colt.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, with a twink.
target: Yes, with a twink.

orig: translate old to modern: What, man!
target: What, man!

orig: translate old to modern: See, doth he breathe?
target: Check and see if he’s breathing.

orig: translate old to modern: Hail, Caesar, and my lord!
target: Greetings, Caesar, my lord!

orig: translate old to modern: I take my leave at once.
target: I leave you at once.

orig: translate old to modern: Full oft ’tis seen, Our means secure us and our mere defects Prove our commodities.
target: It’s often the case that having something makes us spoiled, while not having it turns out to be advantageous.

orig: translate old to modern: Perchance till after Theseus' wedding-day.
target: Maybe until after Theseus' wedding-day.

orig: translate old to modern: One turf shall serve as pillow for us both; One heart, one bed, two bosoms, and one troth.
target: One bit of land will be a pillow for us both; One heart, one bed, two bosoms, and one trust.

orig: translate old to modern: Believe me, sir, had I such venture forth, The better part of my affections would Be with my hopes abroad.
target: Believe me, sir, if I had such venture out there, The better part of my thoughts would Be with my hope of their safe arrival.

orig: translate old to modern: Your fortune stood upon the caskets there, And so did mine too, as the matter falls: For wooing here, until I sweat again, And swearing until my very roof was dry With oaths of love, at last,—if promise last,— I got a promise of this fair one here, To have her love, provided that your fortune Achiev'd her mistress.
target: Your fortune stood on the chests there, And so did mine, as it works out; Because courting here until I worked up a sweat, And swearing promises until my mouth was dry With oaths of love, at last, if her promise lasts, I got a promise of this beautiful one here To have her love, provided that you were Lucky enough to get her mistress.

orig: translate old to modern: But this it is: our foot Upon the hills adjoining to the city Shall stay with us.
target: But here’s the plan: our army will stay with us on the hills by the city.

orig: translate old to modern: O slave!
target: O slave!

orig: translate old to modern: And, which is worse, all you have done Hath been but for a wayward son, Spiteful and wrathful: who, as others do, Loves for his own ends, not for you.
target: And, which is worse, all you have done Has been only for a wayward son, Spiteful and wrathful, who, as others do, Loves for his own ends, not for you.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, lords, will you go To comfort Edward with our company?
target: But come, lords, will you come with me to Edward’s room to comfort him?

orig: translate old to modern: What were his marks?
target: What did he say the symptoms were?

orig: translate old to modern: Look in the calendar and bring me word.
target: Look at the calendar, and come back and tell me.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis sport to maul a runner.
target: It’s fair game to mark a coward.

orig: translate old to modern: I know, sir, I am no flatterer.
target: Sir, I know I’m not a flatterer.

orig: translate old to modern: If she do, he’ll smile and take ’t for a great favor.
target: And when she does, he’ll imagine she’s flirting with him.

orig: translate old to modern: I think upon't, I think, I smell't, O villainy!
target: I think about it, I think, I smell it ; O villainy!

orig: translate old to modern: Tell him his fears are shallow, without instance.
target: Tell your master there is no sound basis for his worries.

orig: translate old to modern: Get me some poison, Iago, this night.
target: Get me some poison, Iago; this night.

orig: translate old to modern: To the Mariners] Play the men!
target: Keep the men moving.

orig: translate old to modern: This is the excellent foppery of the world that when we are sick in fortune—often the surfeit of our own behavior—we make guilty of our disasters the sun, the moon, and the stars, as if we were villains by necessity, fools by heavenly compulsion, knaves, thieves, and treachers by spherical predominance, drunkards, liars, and adulterers by an enforced obedience of planetary influence, and all that we are evil in by a divine thrusting-on.
target: This is a classic example of the idiocy of the world: when we’re down and out—often because of our own excesses —we put all the blame on the sun, the moon, and the stars, as if they forced us to be bad, or the heavens compelled us to be villainous or stupid.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, Balthasar, we’ll hear that song again.
target: Come on, Balthasar, let’s hear that song again.

orig: translate old to modern: Brown, madam, and her forehead As low as she would wish it.
target: Brown, madam, and she wouldn’t want her forehead to be any lower.

orig: translate old to modern: Ha!
target: Ha!

orig: translate old to modern: Go, get some water And wash this filthy witness from your hand.
target: Go get some water, And wash this filthy witness from your hands.

orig: translate old to modern: This was a merry message.
target: That was a humorous message.

orig: translate old to modern: O momentary grace of mortal men, Which we more hunt for than the grace of God!
target: We spend more time seeking out the fleeting glories of this temporary world than looking to the permanent grace of God!

orig: translate old to modern: To have a thousand with red burning spits Come hissing in upon 'em!
target: I see Regan and Goneril in hell—A thousand hissing devils with sizzling red pitchforks come up to them!

orig: translate old to modern: By this hand, I love thee.
target: I swear by this hand that I love you.

orig: translate old to modern: Give me your hand first.
target: Give me your hand first.

orig: translate old to modern: I have said.
target: I’ve said what I have to say.

orig: translate old to modern: My honoured lord!
target: My honored lord!

orig: translate old to modern: Well, more anon.
target: Well, more in a minute.

orig: translate old to modern: That’s twice.
target: Now I’ve said it twice.

orig: translate old to modern: God keep you from them, and from such false friends.
target: God protect you from them and from other false friends!

orig: translate old to modern: Why then, your other senses grow imperfect By your eyes' anguish.
target: Then your other senses must be getting worse because of the trauma of blindness.

orig: translate old to modern: So do I, his.
target: So I expect his.

orig: translate old to modern: Now good digestion wait on appetite, And health on both!
target: Now, may good digestion follow your appetites, And health on both!

orig: translate old to modern: Tonight I’ll mourn with Hero.
target: I will mourn Hero tonight.

orig: translate old to modern: Whereto serves mercy But to confront the visage of offence?
target: What use is mercy Except to confront the face of offense?

orig: translate old to modern: Tomorrow, my lord.
target: Tomorrow, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Bid Gloucester think of this, and he will weep.
target: Remind Richard of this, and he will weep.

orig: translate old to modern: First, of my word!
target: No, before!

orig: translate old to modern: Stand you both forth now: stroke your chins and swear by your beards that I am a knave.
target: Watch me: stroke your chins and swear by your beards that I am a knave.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, then, let them alone till they are sober.
target: Well then, leave them alone until they’re sober.

orig: translate old to modern: I beseech you, what manner of man is he?
target: What kind of man is he?

orig: translate old to modern: From top to toe?
target: From top to toe?

orig: translate old to modern: But in the beaten way of friend- ship, what make you at Elsinore?
target: But, in the beaten way of friendship, what are you doing at Elsinore?

orig: translate old to modern: Let't alone, And do the murder first.
target: Let's get going And do the murder first.

orig: translate old to modern: I dare not drink yet, madam—by-and-by.
target: I dare not drink yet, madam, by and by.

orig: translate old to modern: Not from his mouth, Had it the ability of life to thank you.
target: No thanks from his mouth, If it were alive to thank you.

orig: translate old to modern: He will find it comes from a clodpole.
target: He’ll just think an idiot wrote it.

orig: translate old to modern: Shall they hoist me up And show me to the shouting varletry Of censuring Rome?
target: Shall I let them exhibit me to the shouting mobs of Rome?

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, boy.
target: Yes, boy.

orig: translate old to modern: In my chamber window lies a book.
target: In my bedroom window there is a book.

orig: translate old to modern: God 'ild you for your last company.
target: God bless you for being here.

orig: translate old to modern: What’s he that speaks for Edmund, Earl of Gloucester?
target: Who’s the spokesman for Edmund, Earl of Gloucester?

orig: translate old to modern: For this pains Caesar hath hanged him.
target: Caesar hanged him for this service.

orig: translate old to modern: I do.
target: I do.

orig: translate old to modern: aside] Fair encounter [aside] Fair encounter Of two most rare affections!
target: Aside] Fair meeting Of two most rare loves!

target: I will live in your heart, die in your lap, and be buried in your eyes—and, what’s more, I will go with you to your uncle’s.

orig: translate old to modern: The even mead, that erst brought sweetly forth The freckled cowslip, burnet, and green clover, Wanting the scythe, withal uncorrected, rank, Conceives by idleness, and nothing teems But hateful docks, rough thistles, kecksies, burrs, Losing both beauty and utility.
target: The level meadow, where the freckled cowslip, burnet, and green clover once grew, has become useless: unmowed, it grows to seed, so that nothing springs up but weeds, rough thistles, barren plants, and burs.

target: Listen, listen to what I say: whoever strikes first, I’ll run him through with my sword, as sure as I’m a soldier.

target: her speech is nothing, Yet the random use of it moves The listeners to collect them, they aim at making sense of It, and mix her words up fit to their own ideas, Which, as her winks and nods and gestures as she Speaks, would indeed make someone think there might Be clear, though nothing for sure, yet very unhappily.

orig: translate old to modern: Hear you me, Jessica: Lock up my doors; and when you hear the drum, And the vile squealing of the wry-neck'd fife, Clamber not you up to the casements then, Nor thrust your head into the public street, To gaze on Christian fools with varnish'd faces: But stop my house's ears, I mean my casements; Let not the sound of shallow foppery enter My sober house.—By Jacob's staff I swear, I have no mind of feasting forth to-night: But I will go.—Go you before me, sirrah; Say, I will come.
target: Listen to me, Jessica: Lock up my doors, and when you hear the drum, And the vile squealing of the long-necked pipe, Don’t run up to the windows then, Or thrust your head into the public street To gaze on Christian fools with varnished masks; But stop my house's ears- I mean my windows; Don’t let the sound of shallow foolishness enter My sober house.

target: But if the gods themselves saw her then, When she saw Pyrrhus make malicious sport By chopping her husband’s limbs with his sword, The instant burst of noise that she made, Unless mortal events can’t move them at all, Would have made the burning eyes of heaven milk, And rouse passion in the gods.

target: so maybe slander, whose whisper covers the entire world As surely as the cannon hits its target and Delivers his poisoned shot, may miss our name, And not amount to anything at all.

target: It is a sin to heaven, A sin against the dead, a sin to nature, Most ridiculous to reason, whose common theme Is death of fathers, and who still has cried, From the first corpse to the man who died just today, ”This must be so.” We beg you, give up on This unusual grief, and think of us As of a father.

orig: translate old to modern: I warrant you.
target: Of course I will.

orig: translate old to modern: I have made strong proof of my constancy, Giving myself a voluntary wound Here in the thigh.
target: I have given you strong proof of my constancy, Giving myself a voluntary wound Here in the thigh.

orig: translate old to modern: Your lordship is right welcome back to Denmark.
target: Your lordship is right welcome back to Denmark.

orig: translate old to modern: Bite him to death, I prithee.
target: Bite him to death, please.

orig: translate old to modern: I pray you, let it stand.
target: Please, leave it here.

orig: translate old to modern: That is my rest; that is the rendezvous of it.
target: That’s it.

orig: translate old to modern: Alas, my lord, what may you mean by that?
target: Alas, my lord, what do you mean by that?

orig: translate old to modern: How have you made division of yourself?
target: How did you divide yourself in two?

orig: translate old to modern: Did not you tell me I should know the man By the Athenian garments he had on?
target: Didn’t you tell me I should know the man By the Athenian garments he had on?

orig: translate old to modern: I'll follow you; I'll lead you about a round, Through bog, through bush, through brake, through brier; Sometime a horse I'll be, sometime a hound, A hog, a headless bear, sometime a fire; And neigh, and bark, and grunt, and roar, and burn, Like horse, hound, hog, bear, fire, at every turn.
target: I'll follow you; I'll lead you in a circle, Through bog, through bush, through more bushes, through brier; Sometimes I’ll be a horse, sometimes a hound dog, A hog, a headless bear, sometimes a fire; And neigh, and bark, and grunt, and roar, and burn, Like horse, hound, hog, bear, fire, at every turn.

orig: translate old to modern: Rebellious hell, If thou canst mutine in a matron's bones, To flaming youth let virtue be as wax And melt in her own fire.
target: Rebellious hell, If you can rebel in an old lady’s bones, Then let virtue be like wax to burning youth, And melt in her own fire.

orig: translate old to modern: I say, O Caesar, Antony is dead.
target: Caesar, I’m telling you that Antony is dead.

orig: translate old to modern: You ever gentle gods, take my breath from me.
target: Gentle gods in heaven, please let me die.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis well you offer it behind her back; The wish would make else an unquiet house.
target: It’s well you offer it behind her back; The wish would other make a noisy house.

orig: translate old to modern: I will speak lower.
target: Think about it.

orig: translate old to modern: The news is true, my lord.
target: The news is true, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, if fortune be a woman, she's a good wench for this gear.—Father, come.
target: Well, if Fortune is a woman, she's a good woman for this guy.

orig: translate old to modern: If you do fight against your country’s foes, Your country’s fat shall pay your pains the hire.
target: When you fight against your country’s enemies, you will be paid for your efforts with your country’s wealth.

orig: translate old to modern: Beshrew me, but I love her heartily: For she is wise, if I can judge of her; And fair she is, if that mine eyes be true; And true she is, as she hath prov'd herself; And therefore, like herself, wise, fair, and true, Shall she be placed in my constant soul.
target: Curse me, but I love her heartily; Because she is wise, if I can judge her, And she is beautiful, if my eyes can really see, And she is true, as she has proved herself; And so, like herself, wise, beautiful, and true, She shall be placed in my faithful soul.

orig: translate old to modern: That ever holds: who riseth from a feast With that keen appetite that he sits down?
target: That’s true: who gets up from a feast With the same hunger that he had when he sat down?

orig: translate old to modern: Dost grant me, hedgehog?
target: You’ll grant me, you hedgehog?

orig: translate old to modern: Statilius show'd the torch-light, but, my lord, He came not back.
target: Statilius showed the torchlight, but, my lord, He didn’t come back.

orig: translate old to modern: He hath a person and a smooth dispose To be suspected; framed to make women false.
target: He has a person, and a smooth disposition, To be suspected, framed to make women lie.

orig: translate old to modern: A knave very voluble; no further conscionable than in putting on the mere form of civil and humane seeming, for the better com- passing of his salt and most hidden loose affection?
target: A very changeable rogue, having no further conscience than assuming the mere form of civil and humane behavior, for the better measure of his worth and very hidden loose affections?

orig: translate old to modern: Yes, by heaven!
target: Yes, by heaven!

orig: translate old to modern: Thy truth then be thy dower.
target: The truth will be all the inheritance you get.

orig: translate old to modern: with Lysander?
target: with Lysander?

orig: translate old to modern: Let us go.
target: Let’s go.

orig: translate old to modern: I leave an arrant knave with your Worship, which I beseech your Worship to correct yourself, for the example of others.
target: I leave a slimy bastard with you, your Worship, for you to punish and make an example of.

orig: translate old to modern: an upright judge, a learned judge!
target: an upright judge, a learned judge!

orig: translate old to modern: Pardon me, sweet one, even for the vows We made each other but so late ago.
target: But please forgive me, darling, for the sake of the vows we made to each other so recently.

orig: translate old to modern: O, 'tis too true!
target: O, it is too true!

orig: translate old to modern: Plantagenet.
target: Plantagenet.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, my good lord.
target: Yes, my good lord.

orig: translate old to modern: If thou dost find him tractable to us, Encourage him and show him all our reasons.
target: If he seems game to our plan, encourage him to join us and explain all our reasons.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, masters, we hear our charge.
target: Well gentlemen, we’ve heard our assignment.

orig: translate old to modern: I think thou dost; And for I know thou'rt full of love and honesty And weigh'st thy words before thou givest them breath, Therefore these stops of thine fright me the more; For such things in a false disloyal knave Are tricks of custom; but in a man that's just They're close dilations, working from the heart, That passion cannot rule.
target: I think you do; And, because I know you are full of love and honesty And weigh your words carefully before saying them, These stops of yours frighten me even more, Because such things in a false, disloyal rogue Are tricks of custom, but in a man that's just They're hidden delays, working from the heart, That passion cannot control.

orig: translate old to modern: Is thy union here?
target: Is your marriage here?

orig: translate old to modern: He hath refus'd it in the open court; He shall have merely justice and his bond.
target: He has refused it in the open court; He shall merely have justice, and his promise to pay.

orig: translate old to modern: Yea, my lord, but I can cross it.
target: Yes, my lord, but I can spoil it.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, pray you throw none away.
target: No, don’t throw any of it away.

orig: translate old to modern: Silence bestows that virtue on it, madam.
target: Silence bestows that virtue on it, madam.

orig: translate old to modern: Let her live To join our kingdoms and our hearts, and never Fly off our loves again!
target: She will be the bond that joins our kingdoms and our hearts.

orig: translate old to modern: It will be laid to us, whose providence Should have kept short, restrain'd, and out of haunt This mad young man.
target: It will be our fault, who Should’ve kept this mad young man on a short leash, Restrained, and out of society.

orig: translate old to modern: Then leave her, sir, for by the power that made me, I tell you all her wealth.
target: Then leave her, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Be the players ready.
target: Are the players ready?

orig: translate old to modern: So much for him.
target: So much for him!

orig: translate old to modern: to Adrian] How lush and How green!
target: How green!

orig: translate old to modern: Which she shall purchase with still-lasting war.
target: She will purchase that peace with an everlasting war.

orig: translate old to modern: Rightly to be great Is not to stir without great argument, But greatly to find quarrel in a straw When honour's at the stake.
target: Rightly to be great Is not to move without great argument, But to find quarrel greatly in worthless land When honor’s at stake.

orig: translate old to modern: Yet Caesar shall go forth, for these predictions Are to the world in general as to Caesar.
target: Still, Caesar shall go out, because these predictions Are not only for Caesar but also for the world in general.

orig: translate old to modern: Give me the cups; And let the kettle to the trumpet speak, The trumpet to the cannoneer without, The cannons to the heavens, the heaven to earth, ‘Now the King drinks to Hamlet.’ Come, begin.
target: Give me the cups, And let the kettle drum speak to the trumpet, The trumpet to the cannon man outside, The cannons to the heavens, the heavens to earth, 'Now the king drinks to Hamlet.” Come, begin.

orig: translate old to modern: Pray you, sit still.
target: I beg you, sit still.

orig: translate old to modern: He hath the jewel of my life in hold, His youngest daughter, beautiful Bianca, And her withholds from me and other more, Suitors to her and rivals in my love, Supposing it a thing impossible, For those defects I have before rehearsed, That ever Katherina will be wooed.
target: His youngest daughter, the beautiful Bianca, is the jewel of my life, and he keeps her hidden away from me and other rivals for her hand.

orig: translate old to modern: Speak not against it.
target: Don’t argue against it.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, my lord.
target: Yes, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: This lion is a very fox for his valour.
target: This lion is a very fox for his courage.

orig: translate old to modern: They bleed on both sides.
target: They bleed on both sides.

orig: translate old to modern: Here, quite confounded with this mutiny.
target: Here, quite confused by this mutiny.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis not so now.
target: It is not so now.

orig: translate old to modern: If it might please you to enforce no further The griefs between ye, to forget them quite Were to remember that the present need Speaks to atone you.
target: If it’s okay with you, you should not press your grievances any further, but realize that the current situation should be enough to reconcile you.

orig: translate old to modern: And therefore ’tis called a sensible tale.
target: That’s what makes it “sensitive” news.

orig: translate old to modern: O, my lord, my lord, I have been so affrighted!
target: Alas, my lord, I have been so frightened!

orig: translate old to modern: What say you, uncle?
target: What did you say, uncle?

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, go your ways, go your ways.
target: Oh, go, leave me.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou dost conspire against thy friend, Iago, If thou but think'st him wrong'd and makest his ear A stranger to thy thoughts.
target: You conspire against your friend, Iago, If you only think him wronged and won’t let him be Anything but a stranger to your thoughts.

orig: translate old to modern: I conjure you, by that which you profess, Howe'er you come to know it, answer me: Though you untie the winds and let them fight Against the churches, though the yeasty waves Confound and swallow navigation up, Though bladed corn be lodged and trees blown down, Though castles topple on their warders’ heads, Though palaces and pyramids do slope Their heads to their foundations, though the treasure Of nature's germens tumble all together Even till destruction sicken, answer me To what I ask you.
target: Though you untie the winds, and let them fight Against the churches, though the roaring waves Confuse sailors and sink ships, Though corn on the cob be torn from its stalks, and trees blown down, Though castles topple on their guards' heads, Though palaces and pyramids bend Their heads to their foundations, though the treasure Of nature's buds tumble all together, Even until destruction makes everything sick, answer The questions I ask you.

orig: translate old to modern: Emilia, come.
target: Emilia, come.

orig: translate old to modern: By mine honor I will, and when I break that oath, let me turn monster.
target: I swear I will, and if I ever break my promise let me turn into a monster.

orig: translate old to modern: Hell is murky.
target: Hell is murky!

orig: translate old to modern: Excellent.
target: It looks great.

orig: translate old to modern: Some haste, my lord!
target: A bit of a hurry, my lord!

orig: translate old to modern: A kind good night to all!
target: A kind good-night to all!

orig: translate old to modern: You shall have letters from me to my son In your behalf, to meet you on the way.
target: I’ll write to my stepson Richmond on your behalf, so that he’ll meet you on the way.

orig: translate old to modern: If there were no more women but Fulvia, then had you indeed a cut, and the case to be lamented.
target: If Fulvia were the last woman on earth, there would be a reason to grieve.

orig: translate old to modern: Merciful powers, Restrain in me the cursed thoughts that nature Gives way to in repose!
target: Merciful powers, Hold me back from the cursed thoughts that nature Gives way to when we sleep!

orig: translate old to modern: No more but e’en a woman, and commanded By such poor passion as the maid that milks And does the meanest chares.
target: Now I am no more than a woman, ruled by the same lowly passion as the maid who milks and does the humblest chores.

orig: translate old to modern: Speak; tell me.
target: Speak; tell me.

orig: translate old to modern: Keep close, I thee command.
target: And keep yourself hidden, I command you.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis done by me, and ends in “Margaret.”   Thus have you breathed your curse against yourself.
target: I’ve finished it for you, and it ends in “Margaret.” He’s turned your curse against you, Margaret.

orig: translate old to modern: Most welcome home!
target: A great welcome home!

orig: translate old to modern: And one Deformed is one of them.
target: I know him; he wears a lock of hair.

orig: translate old to modern: I will roar that I will do any man's heart good to hear me; I will roar, that I will make the duke say ‘Let him roar again, let him roar again.’ An you should do it too terribly, you would fright the duchess and the ladies, that they would shriek; and that were enough to hang us all.
target: I will roar so well that it will do any man's heart good to hear me; I will roar so well that I will make the duke say, “Let him roar again, let him roar again.” If you should do it too terribly, you would so frighten the duchess and the ladies, that they would scream; and that would be enough to hang us all.

orig: translate old to modern: Get you a place.
target: Go get yourself a seat.

orig: translate old to modern: The duke of York commends him to your Majesty.

target: You’ll know more about it later.

target: I’m not insane, Sir Topas.

orig: translate old to modern: Will you dine with me tomorrow?
target: Will you dine with me tomorrow?

orig: translate old to modern: I charge thee, speak!
target: I order you to speak!

orig: translate old to modern: And to see how he prizes the fool- ish woman your wife!
target: And to see how he prizes the foolish woman, your wife!

target: The princes are under some strange misunderstanding.

orig: translate old to modern: O my good master!
target: Oh, my good master!

target: I won’t sort you with the rest of my servants, because, to speak to you like an honest man, I am most dreadfully attended.

orig: translate old to modern: I must needs tell thee all.
target: I must tell you everything.

orig: translate old to modern: I your servant.
target: And I your servant.

target: Yes, yes, it was Bassanio, I think, or so he was called.

orig: translate old to modern: Ha, art thou bedlam?
target: Are you mad?

orig: translate old to modern: She had a prophesying fear Of what hath come to pass.
target: She had a premonition of what has actually happened.

orig: translate old to modern: aside] Honest lord, [aside] Honest lord, Thou hast said well, for some of you there present Are worse than devils.
target: Honest lord, What you say is true, because some of you there present Are worse than devils.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, we will leave you then till dinner-time.
target: OK, we’ll leave you then until dinnertime.

target: Anyway, sir, should I go see the lady?

orig: translate old to modern: This is as uncivil as strange.
target: This is as rude as it is strange.

target: On the condition that Publius shall not live, Who is your nephew, Mark Antony.

target: Tell me, please: how many boys and girls will I have?

orig: translate old to modern: I speak in understanding.
target: I know what I’m talking about.

orig: translate old to modern: Most mighty sovereign, You have no cause to hold my friendship doubtful.
target: Most mighty sovereign, you have no reason to doubt my friendship.

target: Isn’t that the king?

orig: translate old to modern: Good my friends, consider You are my guests.
target: My friends, remember that you’re my guests here.

target: Where are you going?

target: If anything of sorrow or wonder, stop your search.

orig: translate old to modern: Woo’t thou fight well?
target: Will you fight well?

orig: translate old to modern: Witness this army, of such mass and charge, Led by a delicate and tender prince, Whose spirit with divine ambition puff'd, Makes mouths at the invisible event, Exposing what is mortal and unsure To all that fortune, death, and danger dare, Even for an eggshell.
target: Look at this army, of such size and power, Led by a delicate and tender prince, Whose spirit, with divine ambition puffed up, Makes faces at the invisible event, Exposing what is mortal and unsure To all that luck, death, and danger dare to do, Even for an eggshell.

orig: translate old to modern: The very place puts toys of desperation, Without more motive, into every brain That looks so many fathoms to the sea And hears it roar beneath.
target: The very place puts desperate ideas, Without any motive, into every brain That looks so many fathoms into the sea And hears it roar beneath.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, I’ll come.
target: I’m coming, don’t worry.

orig: translate old to modern: Oh, temperance, lady!
target: Oh, control yourself, lady!

orig: translate old to modern: Slight, will you make an ass o' me?
target: Are you trying to make fun of me?

orig: translate old to modern: Hence, horrible shadow!
target: Here, horrible shadow!

orig: translate old to modern: How if I answer no?
target: What if I say no?

orig: translate old to modern: Speak to me what thou art.
target: Tell what you are.

orig: translate old to modern: Here's Decius Brutus, he shall tell them so.
target: Here's Decius Brutus, he shall tell them so.

target: And will you tear our ancient love apart To join with men in scorning your poor friend?

orig: translate old to modern: No, boy.
target: No, boy.

orig: translate old to modern: Here hung those lips that I have kissed I know not how oft.
target: Here hung those lips that I have kissed I don’t know how many times.

target: Come here, Ventidius.

orig: translate old to modern: Do you not hear him?
target: Don’t you hear him?

target: Please, get some excellent music, because tomorrow we want to serenade Lady Hero at her bedroom window.

orig: translate old to modern: Call him.
target: Call him.

orig: translate old to modern: How now, Grumio?
target: What’s up, Grumio?

orig: translate old to modern: Welcome, then, Thou unsubstantial air that I embrace!
target: So I welcome this wind freely.

orig: translate old to modern: Old fashions please me best.
target: I like doing things the old-fashioned way.

orig: translate old to modern: Delay not, Caesar; read it instantly.
target: Don’t delay, Caesar; read it instantly.

target: Doesn’t Benedick deserve as much luck with a mate as he would have with Beatrice?

orig: translate old to modern: Spirits, which by mine art I have from their confines call'd to enact My present fancies.
target: Spirits, which, by my magic, I have called from their borders to enact My present wishes.

orig: translate old to modern: Take you, as 'twere, some distant knowledge of him, As thus, ‘I know his father and his friends, And in part him.’ Do you mark this, Reynaldo?
target: Assume, as it were, that you have only heard about him, Such as, “I know his father and his friends, And in part him”, are you listening to me, Reynaldo?

orig: translate old to modern: No, I will not.
target: No, I won’t.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou’dst shun a bear, But if thy flight lay toward the raging sea Thou’dst meet the bear i' th' mouth.
target: You would run away from a bear, but if the only way to run was into the stormy ocean, you’d turn around and confront the bear.

orig: translate old to modern: Lo, she is one of this confederacy!
target: Wow, she is one of this conspiracy!

orig: translate old to modern: That which I gave you.
target: The one I gave you.

orig: translate old to modern: I am to blame to be thus waited for.
target: I’m to blame to be waited for like this.— Now, Cinna;—now, Metellus;—what, Trebonius!

orig: translate old to modern: Where be these knaves?
target: Where are those bastards?

orig: translate old to modern: I would thou hadst told me of another father.
target: I wish you had told me you had a different father.

orig: translate old to modern: We do not come, as minding to content you, Our true intent is.
target: We don’t come, as we mean to content you, Is our true intent.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, Eros.
target: Now, Eros.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, Hamlet.
target: Yes, Hamlet.

orig: translate old to modern: Drink thou.
target: Drink up.

orig: translate old to modern: Do so: to ebb Hereditary sloth instructs me.
target: Do so: laziness I inherited teaches me to go down, Oh!

orig: translate old to modern: Sir, I bade them take away you.
target: I told them to take  Oh, what a big mistake!

orig: translate old to modern: Now pile your dust upon the quick and dead Till of this flat a mountain you have made To o'ertop old Pelion or the skyish head Of blue Olympus.
target: Now bury the living and dead, Until you have made a mountain from this flat earth To be higher than the mountain of Italy or the skyish head Of blue Mount Olympus.

orig: translate old to modern: Very foul.
target: Very bad.

orig: translate old to modern: The wager thou hast won, and I will add Unto their losses twenty thousand crowns, Another dowry to another daughter, For she is changed as she had never been.
target: You’ve won the wager, and I will add twenty thousand crowns to what they owe you.

orig: translate old to modern: Lay breath so bitter on your bitter foe.
target: Say these bitter things to your bitter foe.

orig: translate old to modern: He should, for that, commit your godfathers.
target: He should imprison the person who named you, instead.

orig: translate old to modern: If we walk not in the trodden paths our very petticoats will catch them.
target: If we walk on the well-worn paths, they won’t get caught in our petticoats.

orig: translate old to modern: For when she saw— Which never shall be found—you did suspect She had disposed with Caesar, and that your rage Would not be purged, she sent you word she was dead.
target: Afraid that your anger would not subside, she sent you word she was dead.

orig: translate old to modern: Give me mine armor.
target: Give me my amour.

orig: translate old to modern: Go, Sir Andrew.
target: Go, Sir Andrew.

orig: translate old to modern: Thy death and fortunes bid thy followers fly.
target: Your death and destiny advise your followers to escape.

orig: translate old to modern: trick up with new-tuned oaths; and what a beard of the general’s cut and a horrid suit of the camp will do among foaming bottles and ale-washed wits is wonderful to be thought on.
target: And what a beard trimmed like the general’s or a rough uniform will do among foaming mugs and brains washed with ale, you wouldn’t believe.

orig: translate old to modern: Judgment!
target: Judges?

orig: translate old to modern: You had musty victual, and he hath holp to eat it.
target: You had rotten food, and he helped you eat it.

orig: translate old to modern: The Moor is of a free and open nature, That thinks men honest that but seem to be so; And will as tenderly be led by the nose As asses are.
target: The Moor is of a free and open nature, That thinks men are honest that only seem to be so; And will as tenderly be led by the nose As asses are.

orig: translate old to modern: I will, my lord.
target: I’ll stay, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: I would not be mad.
target: I don’t want to go mad.

orig: translate old to modern: He did me kindness, sir, drew on my side, But in conclusion put strange speech upon me.
target: But then he said strange things to me.

orig: translate old to modern: But for my daughter Katherine, this I know, She is not for your turn, the more my grief.
target: As for my daughter Katherine, this much I know: she’s not for you—more’s the pity.

orig: translate old to modern: This is the motley-minded gentleman that I have so often met in the forest.
target: This is the jester I have met so many times in the forest.

orig: translate old to modern: Come to me, Tyrrel, soon at after-supper, When thou shalt tell the process of their death.
target: Tyrrel, come back shortly after dinner and tell me the details of their deaths.

orig: translate old to modern: Faith, half asleep.
target: Faith, half asleep.

orig: translate old to modern: He was furnished like a hunter.
target: He was dressed like a hunter.

orig: translate old to modern: But why unkindly didst thou leave me so?
target: But why did you leave me so unkindly?

orig: translate old to modern: Thus have I politicly begun my reign, And ’tis my hope to end successfully.
target: Well, I’ve begun my reign with a carefully thought-out plan, and I have every hope of succeeding.

orig: translate old to modern: Dost fall?
target: Did you fall?

orig: translate old to modern: Take from them now The sense of reck'ning ere th' opposèd numbers Pluck their hearts from them.
target: Rob them of the ability to count before the numbers against them overwhelm their courage.

orig: translate old to modern: Solemn music] [Solemn music] [to Alonso] A solemn air, and the best comforter [to Alonso] A solemn To an unsettled fancy, cure thy brains, Now useless, boiled within thy skull.
target: A solemn song, and the best comforter To an unsettled mind, cure for your brains, Now useless, boiled inside your skull!

orig: translate old to modern: My lord?
target: My lord?

orig: translate old to modern: Vouchsafe good morrow from a feeble tongue.
target: Allow a good morning from a feeble tongue.

orig: translate old to modern: You pull'd me by the cloak; would you speak with me?
target: You pulled my sleeve; do you want to speak with me?

orig: translate old to modern: Here comes your father.
target: Here comes your father.

orig: translate old to modern: Ha!
target: Huh?

orig: translate old to modern: No, my noble lord, It is not for you.
target: No, my noble lord, It is not for you.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, get you gone!
target: Why, get going.

orig: translate old to modern: Where is my lord of Gloucester?
target: Where is Gloucester?

orig: translate old to modern: I never shall endure her.
target: I can’t stand her.

orig: translate old to modern: Trip away; make no stay; Meet me all by break of day.
target: Dance away: Don’t delay: All of you meet me by dawn.

orig: translate old to modern: I pray you all, stand up.

orig: translate old to modern: Beware Of entrance to a quarrel; but being in, Bear't that the opposed may beware of thee.
target: Beware Of getting into a quarrel, but, once you are in, Fight so that the man you fight with may beware of you.

orig: translate old to modern: Caesar gets money where He loses hearts.
target: Caesar loses supporters wherever he raises money.

orig: translate old to modern: Where’s my knave, my fool?—Go you, and call my fool hither.
target: Where’s my fool?—Go call my fool and have him come here.

orig: translate old to modern: But I will tarry.
target: But I’ll linger.

orig: translate old to modern: Here come the officers.
target: The police are here.

orig: translate old to modern: Take them away.
target: Take them away.

orig: translate old to modern: Here was a Caesar!
target: Here was a Caesar!

orig: translate old to modern: Well, come, my Kate.
target: Ah well, my Kate.

orig: translate old to modern: Look to't, I charge you.
target: Do as I say, I order you.

orig: translate old to modern: Here’s the place.
target: This is the place.

orig: translate old to modern: Tush, I may as well say the fool’s the fool.
target: C’mon, I might as well say the fool’s the fool!

orig: translate old to modern: Arise, dissembler.
target: Get up, liar.

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll give ’t him.
target: I’ll give it to him.

orig: translate old to modern: We do it wrong, being so majestical, To offer it the show of violence; For it is, as the air, invulnerable, And our vain blows malicious mockery.
target: We do it wrong, its being so like the king, To offer it the show of violence, Because it is, like the air, unable to be hurt, And our empty blows seem like a malicious joke.

orig: translate old to modern: What proof shall I make of that?
target: What will be my evidence?

orig: translate old to modern: Since this fortune falls to you, Be content, and seek no new.
target: Since this fortune falls to you, Be content and seek no other new one.

orig: translate old to modern: Madam, I had rather seal my lips Than to my peril speak that which is not.
target: Madam, I’d rather sew my lips shut than tell a lie when my life depends upon it.

orig: translate old to modern: The earl of Pembroke keeps his regiment— Good Captain Blunt, bear my goodnight to him, And by the second hour in the morning Desire the earl to see me in my tent.
target: Good Captain Blunt, tell the earl goodnight from me, and tell him that by two in the morning I would like him to visit my tent.

orig: translate old to modern: What is it, my good friends?
target: What’s the news, my good friends?

orig: translate old to modern: O, yes, my lord, but very idle words.
target: Oh yes, you spoke, my lord, but total nonsense.

orig: translate old to modern: Was ’t you that did so oft contrive to kill him?
target: Was it you that was always plotting to kill him?

orig: translate old to modern: How will this fadge?
target: Ah, how will this all turn out?

orig: translate old to modern: Alas, good gentleman!
target: Alas, good gentleman!

orig: translate old to modern: That we shall die, we know; 'tis but the time And drawing days out that men stand upon.
target: We know we shall die, we know; it’s only time And drawing days out that men live on.

orig: translate old to modern: Were you well served, you would be taught your duty.
target: If you got what you deserved, you would learn some respect.

orig: translate old to modern: Canst thou blame him?
target: Can you blame him?

orig: translate old to modern: Besides, old Gremio is heark'ning still, And happily we might be interrupted.
target: My servants might overhear, and old Gremio is still hanging around, so we might be interrupted.

orig: translate old to modern: Who sued to me for him?
target: Who pleaded with me to pardon

orig: translate old to modern: Worthy prince, I know ’t.
target: I know, prince.

orig: translate old to modern: He's for a jig or a tale of bawdry, or he sleeps.
target: He's for a jig or a dirty tale, or he sleeps.

orig: translate old to modern: The revelers are entering, brother.
target: The partygoers have arrived.

orig: translate old to modern: I hid me under the dead moon-calf's gaberdine for fear of the storm.
target: I hid myself under the dead dreamer’s covering because I was afraid of the storm.

orig: translate old to modern: Make good room.
target: Let’s give them room.

orig: translate old to modern: But fear not yet To take upon you what is yours.
target: Only don’t be afraid To take upon you what is yours.

orig: translate old to modern: In your bad strokes, Brutus, you give good words.
target: In your bad strokes, Brutus, you give good words.

orig: translate old to modern: What, a feast, a feast?
target: What, are we having a feast?

orig: translate old to modern: You think none but your sheets are privy to your wishes.
target: You seem to think no one outside of your bedroom knows what you wish.

orig: translate old to modern: And, sir, tonight, I do entreat that we may sup together.
target: And, sir, tonight, I beg you that we may dine together.

orig: translate old to modern: What bloody man is that?
target: What man is that with blood all over him?

orig: translate old to modern: And of all Christian souls, I pray God.
target: And of all Christian souls, I pray God.

orig: translate old to modern: This same is she, and I do give you her.
target: This one, and I will give her to you.

orig: translate old to modern: I would have blowed up the town, so Chrish save me, la, in an hour.
target: I could have blown up the town in an hour.

orig: translate old to modern: But do not go with it!
target: But don’t go with it!

orig: translate old to modern: Why, how should she be murdered?
target: Why should she be murdered?

orig: translate old to modern: Went they not quickly, I should die with laughing.
target: They’re certainly a peaceful couple!

orig: translate old to modern: When are you married, madam?
target: When are you getting married, madam?

orig: translate old to modern: And fair words to them.
target: I’m sure you do.

orig: translate old to modern: I say unto thee, I bid thy master cutout the gown, but I did not bid him cut it to pieces.
target: I tell you I requested that your master cut out the gown, but I didn’t ask him to cut it all to pieces.

orig: translate old to modern: Claudius!
target: Claudius!

orig: translate old to modern: There lies your way, due west.
target: I wish you all the best.

orig: translate old to modern: Amen, with all my heart!
target: Amen, with all my heart!

orig: translate old to modern: Live a little, comfort a little, cheer thyself a little.
target: Live a little, be comforted a little, cheer up a little.

orig: translate old to modern: Will you go hunt, my lord?
target: Do you want to go hunting, my lord?

orig: translate old to modern: Moved,” in good time.
target: Driven?” Really?

orig: translate old to modern: His antique sword, Rebellious to his arm, lies where it falls, Repugnant to command.
target: His old sword, Rebelling against his arm, lies where it falls, Resisting his commands.

orig: translate old to modern: Why then, he is alive.
target: Well, then he must be alive.

orig: translate old to modern: I hope, in no place so unsanctified Where such as thou mayst find him.
target: I hope, in no place so unsanctified or shamed as Where such as you may find him.

orig: translate old to modern: Still better, and worse.
target: Even better, and worse.

orig: translate old to modern: What masque?
target: What play?

orig: translate old to modern: What does the tyrant?
target: What is the tyrant doing?

orig: translate old to modern: The players cannot keep counsel; they'll tell all.
target: The players cannot keep a secret, they'll tell all.

orig: translate old to modern: Pause awhile, And let my counsel sway you in this case.
target: Hold on a moment, and listen to my advice.

orig: translate old to modern: And Cassio kill'd?
target: And Cassio killed?

orig: translate old to modern: Hail!
target: Hail!

orig: translate old to modern: The direful spectacle of the wreck, which touched The very virtue of compassion in thee, I have with such provision in mine art So safely ordered that there is no soul— No, not so much perdition as an hair Betid to any creature in the vessel Which thou heard'st cry, which though saw'st sink.
target: The sad spectacle of the wreck, which touched The very virtue of compassion in you, I have ordered so safely with similar use of my magic That there is no soul— No, not so much damage as to one hair Happened to any creature on the vessel Which you heard cry, which you saw sink.

orig: translate old to modern: O, this is hire and salary, not revenge!
target: O, this is a contract and pay, not revenge.

orig: translate old to modern: Three thousand ducats, for three months, and Antonio bound.
target: Three thousand dollars, for three months, and Antonio obligated.

orig: translate old to modern: Then comes the time, who lives to see ’t, That going shall be used with feet.
target: And whoever lives to see that day Will walk with his feet.

orig: translate old to modern: Prithee, dispatch.
target: I beg you, leave.

orig: translate old to modern: No, I protest, I know not the contents.
target: No, I swear, I don’t even know what’s in it.

orig: translate old to modern: Sweetly in force unto her fair life’s end.
target: Until her beautiful life’s end.

orig: translate old to modern: I almost die for food, and let me have it.
target: I’m dying for food, so let me have some.

orig: translate old to modern: Bring it to that, The gold I give thee will I melt and pour Down thy ill-uttering throat.
target: If that’s what you mean, I’ll melt this gold and pour it down your throat that speaks these hateful words.

orig: translate old to modern: I think so too.
target: I think so too.

orig: translate old to modern: How beauteous mankind is!
target: How beautiful mankind is!

orig: translate old to modern: Goes the King hence today?
target: Does the king leave here today?

orig: translate old to modern: Who is't that cried!
target: Who is it that cried!

orig: translate old to modern: You are too much mistaken in this king.
target: You are completely wrong about this king.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, there then!
target: Well, then, there!

orig: translate old to modern: He is a very proper man.
target: He’s a very proper man.

orig: translate old to modern: Do not you wear your dagger in your cap that day, lest he knock that about yours.
target: You’d better not wear your dagger in your cap that day, or he might slap your head with it.

orig: translate old to modern: And so doth mine.
target: Mine, too.

orig: translate old to modern: But, look you, Cassius, The angry spot doth glow on Caesar's brow, And all the rest look like a chidden train: Calpurnia's cheek is pale, and Cicero Looks with such ferret and such fiery eyes As we have seen him in the Capitol, Being cross'd in conference by some senators.
target: Calpurnia's cheek is pale, and Cicero Looks with the same beady and fiery eyes That we have seen on him in the Capitol, When some senators disagreed with him in a meeting.

orig: translate old to modern: Therefore be merry, Cassio, For thy solicitor shall rather die Than give thy cause away.
target: Therefore be happy, Cassio; Because your lawyer would rather die Than lose your case.

orig: translate old to modern: Stay, dog, for thou shalt hear me.
target: Don’t move, dog.

orig: translate old to modern: How now?
target: How strange I’m feeling!

orig: translate old to modern: Doth Fortune play the huswife with me now?
target: Has Fortune turned on me, like the whore she is?

orig: translate old to modern: Return with her?
target: Go back with her?

orig: translate old to modern: My talk to thee must be how Benedick Is sick in love with Beatrice.
target: It’ll be my job to talk about how Benedick is sick with love for Beatrice.

orig: translate old to modern: The limit of your lives is out.
target: Your lives are over.

orig: translate old to modern: Now have I done a good day’s work.
target: Now I’ve done a good day’s work.

orig: translate old to modern: I cannot speak enough of this content; It stops me here; it is too much of joy: And this, and this, the greatest discords be They kiss.
target: I cannot speak enough of this contentment; It stops me here; it is too joyful.

orig: translate old to modern: Here's my son, sir, a poor boy,— Not a poor boy, sir, but the rich Jew's man; that would, sir, as my father shall specify,— He hath a great infection, sir, as one would say, to serve,— Indeed, the short and the long is, I serve the Jew, and have a desire, as my father shall specify,— His master and he (saving your worship's reverence) are scarce cater-cousins:— To be brief, the very truth is, that the Jew having done me wrong, doth cause me, as my father, being I hope an old man, shall frutify unto you, — I have here a dish of doves, that I would bestow upon your worship; and my suit is,— In very brief, the suit is impertinent to myself, as your worship shall know by this honest old man; and, though I say it, though old man, yet, poor man, my father.
target: Here is my son, sir, a poor boy— Not a poor boy, sir, but the rich Jew's man, that would, sir,—as my father shall specify— He has a great infection, sir, as one would say, to serve— Indeed the short and the long is, I serve the Jew, and have a desire, as my father shall specify— His master and he, God save you, sir, are almost like cousins— To be brief, the very truth is that the Jew, having done me wrong, causes me,—as my father, being I hope an old man, shall frutify to you— I have here a dish of doves that I wish to give you, sir; and what I want is— In very brief, what he asks is impertinent to myself, as you, sir, shall know from this honest old man; and, though I say it, though old man, yet poor man, my father.

orig: translate old to modern: His beard was as white as snow, All flaxen was his poll.
target: His beard was as white as snow, All white was his hair.

orig: translate old to modern: Earth's increase, foison plenty, Barns and garners never empty, Vines and clust'ring bunches growing, Plants and goodly burden bowing; Spring come to you at the farthest In the very end of harvest!
target: Earth's increase, plenty of feasting, Barns and storage for game never empty; Vines growing with clustering bunches of grapes; Plants bowing with heavy loads of fruit ; Spring come to you as long as possible, Even to the very end of harvest!

orig: translate old to modern: If she live long, And in the end meet the old course of death, Women will all turn monsters.
target: If she lives a long and happy life, then all women may as well turn into monsters.

orig: translate old to modern: Do grace to Caesar's corse, and grace his speech Tending to Caesar's glories, which Mark Antony, By our permission, is allow'd to make.
target: Respect Caesar's corpse, and respect his speech About Caesar's glory, which Mark Antony Is allowed to make with our permission.

orig: translate old to modern: It is the very error of the moon; She comes more nearer earth than she was wont And makes men mad.
target: It is the very mistake of the moon; She comes more nearer earth than she usually does And makes men mad.

orig: translate old to modern: I would not kill thy soul.
target: I would not kill your soul.

orig: translate old to modern: Who's that?
target: Who's that?

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, the man hath no wit that cannot, from the rising of the lark to the lodging of the lamb, vary deserved praise on my palfrey.
target: No, the man who cannot extol the virtues of my horse from dawn to dusk is not particularly clever.

orig: translate old to modern: No watch?
target: no guard?

orig: translate old to modern: Come, shall we about it?
target: Shall we get started?

orig: translate old to modern: Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon 'em.
target: Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon them.

orig: translate old to modern: They shall be apprehended by and by.
target: How smooth and cool they seem!

orig: translate old to modern: Fiery”?
target: Passionately”?

orig: translate old to modern: make haste; thou know'st where I will tarry.
target: Hurry: you know where I’ll wait for you.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou shalt know more hereafter: Nay, get thee gone.
target: Get going, I say; you shall know more later; No, get going.

orig: translate old to modern: A Daniel come to judgment!
target: A prophet from the Bible come to judgment!

orig: translate old to modern: Not too fast!
target: Ah, no.

orig: translate old to modern: Pray you, away.
target: Now please go.

orig: translate old to modern: True,” said she, “a fine little one.” “No,” said I, “a great wit.” “Right,” says she, “a great gross one.” “Nay,” said I, “a good wit.” “Just,” said she, “it hurts nobody.” “Nay,” said I, “the gentleman is wise.” “Certain,” said she, “a wise gentleman.” “Nay,” said I, “he hath the tongues.” “That I believe,” said she, “for he swore a thing to me on Monday night, which he forswore on Tuesday morning; there’s a double tongue, there’s two tongues.” Thus did she an hour together transshape thy particular virtues.
target: True,” she said, “a fine little one.” “No,” I said, “a huge wit.” “Right,” she said, “a hugely awful one.” “No,” I said, “he has a good wit.” “Exactly,” she said, “it’s good and mild; it doesn’t hurt anyone.” “No,” I said, “Benedick is wise.” “He is certainly,” she said,  She cried a lot at that, and said she didn’t care.

orig: translate old to modern: Be warned by me, then: they that ride so, and ride not warily, fall into foul bogs.
target: Take a tip from me, then.

orig: translate old to modern: Give me that man That is not passion's slave, and I will wear him In my heart's core, ay, in my heart of heart, As I do thee.
target: Give me that man That is not passion's slave, and I will wear him In my heart's core, yes, in my heart of heart, As I do you.

orig: translate old to modern: But not by him!
target: But he didn’t do it.

orig: translate old to modern: Here thought they to have done Some wanton charm upon this man and miad, Whose vows are that no bed-right shall be paid Till Hymen's torch be lighted—but in vain.
target: They thought they would do Some naughty charm on this man and maiden, Who have vowed that they will not sleep together Until the god of marriage's torch is lit, but they thought so in vain.

orig: translate old to modern: If thou didst ever thy dear father love— O God!
target: If you ever loved your dear father — O God!

orig: translate old to modern: I'll tell you what you shall do.
target: I'll tell you what you shall do.

orig: translate old to modern: I am only sorry  He had no other death’s-man.
target: I’m just sorry I had to be the one to kill him.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, Fool?
target: Why, Fool?

orig: translate old to modern: Examples gross as earth exhort me.
target: Examples, as obvious as dirt, urge me.

orig: translate old to modern: My brother never Did urge me in his act.
target: My brother didn’t use my name to justify his rebellion.

orig: translate old to modern: If we offend, it is with our good will.
target: If we offend you, it is with our good will.

orig: translate old to modern: We judge no less.—Uncle of Exeter, Enlarge the man committed yesterday That railed against our person.
target: Uncle of Exeter, release the man who was arrested yesterday for railing against me.

orig: translate old to modern: My lord?
target: My lord?

orig: translate old to modern: To make you answer truly to your name.
target: We just want you to answer to your real name.

orig: translate old to modern: I will neither be faced nor braved.
target: I will not be faced or bested.

orig: translate old to modern: For our losses, his exchequer is too poor; for th' effusion of our blood, the muster of his kingdom too faint a number; and for our disgrace, his own person, kneeling at our feet but a weak and worthless satisfaction.
target: His coffers are too poor to atone for our losses, his entire kingdom too small to account for the amount of blood we’ve shed, and the sight of him kneeling at our feet an empty satisfaction compared to the indignity we have put up with.

orig: translate old to modern: I shall grow jealous of you shortly, Launcelot, if you thus get my wife into corners.
target: I shall grow jealous of you shortly, Launcelot, if you thus get my wife into corners.

orig: translate old to modern: Go, Biondello, bid your mistress come to me.
target: Biondello, go and tell your mistress to come to me.

orig: translate old to modern: Mistress, we have.
target: Yes, ma'am, we have.

orig: translate old to modern: how am I false?
target: How am I false?

orig: translate old to modern: Stand still.
target: Stand still.

orig: translate old to modern: The Moor replies That he you hurt is of great fame in Cyprus And great affinity, and that in wholesome wisdom He might not but refuse you; but he protests he loves you, And needs no other suitor but his likings To take the safest occasion by the front To bring you in again.
target: The Moor replies That the man you hurt is very famous in Cyprus And has a great reputation, and that, in pure wisdom, He might not refuse you, but he protests he loves you And needs no other person begging than his own opinion To take the safest public occasion To bring you back again.

orig: translate old to modern: Though I die for it—as no less is threatened me—the king my old master must be relieved.
target: Even if I have to die—as they threaten—I have to help the king.

orig: translate old to modern: You shall not write my praise.
target: You shall not write my praise.

orig: translate old to modern: Save his majesty!
target: Save his Majesty!

orig: translate old to modern: No; I will resist such entertainment till Mine enemy has more power.
target: No; I will resist such treatment until My enemy has more power to fight.

orig: translate old to modern: I'll call upon you straight.
target: I'll call upon you in a minute.

orig: translate old to modern: Good friend, I prithee, take him in thy arms.
target: Please get him, my friend, I beg you.

orig: translate old to modern: How does Lieutenant Cassio?
target: How does Lieutenant Cassio?

orig: translate old to modern: But let that go.
target: But ignore that.

orig: translate old to modern: My charity is outrage, life my shame, And in that shame still live my sorrows' rage.
target: How dare you talk about kindness or shame.

orig: translate old to modern: Marry, will I, sir.
target: I certainly will, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Sir, I do know you, And dare upon the warrant of my note Commend a dear thing to you.
target: Sir, I know you, and I trust you enough to share something very important with you.

orig: translate old to modern: You need not fear, lady, the having any of these lords: they have acquainted me with their determinations: which is, indeed, to return to their home, and to trouble you with no more suit; unless you may be won by some other sort than your father's imposition, depending on the caskets.
target: You don’t need to be afraid, lady, of having any of these lords; they have told me their intentions, which is indeed to go back to their homes, and to trouble you with no more suits, unless you may be won by some other way than your father's command, that getting you depends on the chests.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis not unknown to you, Antonio, How much I have disabled mine estate, By something showing a more swelling port Than my faint means would grant continuance: Nor do I now make moan to be abridg'd From such a noble rate; but my chief care Is to come fairly off from the great debts Wherein my time, something too prodigal, Hath left me gag'd.
target: You know, Antonio, How much I have wasted my money By putting on a fancier appearance Than my small funds could support; I don’t come to you now to ask that you Forgive my debts, because my chief concern Is to make good on these great debts Which my behavior, sometimes reckless And wasteful, has left me broke.

orig: translate old to modern: It shall be done, my lord.
target: I’ll do that, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Shall I be tempted of the devil thus?
target: Shall I be tempted by the devil?

orig: translate old to modern: Fetch us in fuel, and be quick, thou'rt best, To answer other business.—Shrug'st thou, malice?
target: Get fuel for us and you had better be quick About answering the other business.

orig: translate old to modern: Every inordinate cup is unblest, and the ingredient is a devil.
target: Every uncontrolled cup is evil, and the ingredient is a devil.

orig: translate old to modern: No more!
target: No more!

orig: translate old to modern: Nothing can be made out of nothing.
target: Nothing can be made out of nothing.

orig: translate old to modern: I have this present evening from my sister Been well informed of them—and with such cautions That if they come to sojourn at my house I’ll not be there.
target: Tonight I received a letter from my sister telling me all about them—and warning me not be at home in case they come to stay at my house.

orig: translate old to modern: How now, my sweet Bianca!
target: Come now, my sweet Bianca!

orig: translate old to modern: Under this conjuration, speak, my lord, For we will hear, note, and believe in heart That what you speak is in your conscience washed As pure as sin with baptism.
target: With this in mind, speak, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: That a woman conceived me, I thank her.
target: I was conceived by a woman, and I thank her very much for all her effort.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, that he was.
target: Yes, that he was.

orig: translate old to modern: To thine own peace.
target: Only to your own satisfaction.

orig: translate old to modern: Simple, plain Clarence, I do love thee so That I will shortly send thy soul to heaven, If heaven will take the present at our hands.
target: I love you so much that I’ll send your soul to heaven very soon—if heaven will accept anything from me, that is.

orig: translate old to modern: I thank you.
target: I thank you.

orig: translate old to modern: Here is a place reserved, sir.
target: Here is a place reserved, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Methinks I see these things with parted eye, When every thing seems double.
target: I think I see these things with unfocused eyes, As when every thing seems double.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, I prithee, put on this gown and this beard.
target: No, I’m telling you, put on this robe and beard.

orig: translate old to modern: Then every soldier kill his prisoners.
target: Then every soldier must kill his prisoners.

orig: translate old to modern: For that he dares us to ’t.
target: Because he’s daring us to do it.

orig: translate old to modern: You a man?
target: You’re a man?

orig: translate old to modern: My fool usurps my body.
target: There’s a fool sharing my bed now.

orig: translate old to modern: How comes it?
target: Why?

orig: translate old to modern: Give the word through.
target: Spread the word.

orig: translate old to modern: My lord and master loves you.
target: My lord loves you.

orig: translate old to modern: O, throw away the worser part of it, And live the purer with the other half, Good night—but go not to my uncle's bed.
target: O, throw away the worse part of it, And live the purer life with the other half.

orig: translate old to modern: A knave teach me my duty!
target: A rogue teaching me my duty!

orig: translate old to modern: With courtesy and with respect enough, But not with such familiar instances, Nor with such free and friendly conference, As he hath used of old.
target: With courtesy and with respect enough, Only not with such familiar instances, Or with such free and friendly conversation, As he used to in the old days.

orig: translate old to modern: One word more Shall make me chide thee, if not hate thee.
target: One word more Shall make me scold you, if not hate you.

orig: translate old to modern: Before the days of change, still is it so.
target: It’s always like this in times of change.

orig: translate old to modern: If he could right himself with quarreling, Some of us would lie low.
target: If it’s fighting he is after, some of us here should run and hide.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, come, the cause.
target: Come, come, the reason.

orig: translate old to modern: By'r lakin, a parlous fear.
target: Damn, a risky business.

orig: translate old to modern: Thus we may see,” quoth he, “how the world wags.
target: This way, we can see how the world moves.

orig: translate old to modern: I had rather be any kind o' thing than a fool.
target: I’d rather be anything besides a fool.

orig: translate old to modern: So the gods keep you And make the hearts of Romans serve your ends.
target: So, may the gods protect you and change the hearts of the Romans so that they turn and give you their support.

orig: translate old to modern: No, I am a Welshman.
target: No, I am a Welshman.

orig: translate old to modern: Ready, so please your grace.
target: Ready, if it pleases your Grace.

orig: translate old to modern: Ring the alarum bell.
target: Ring the alarms bell.

orig: translate old to modern: Where have I been?
target: Where have I been?

orig: translate old to modern: Besides, it should appear, that if he had The present money to discharge the Jew, He would not take it.
target: Besides, it seems that, even if he had The money right now to pay the Jew, He wouldn’t take it.

orig: translate old to modern: I can stay with Regan, I and my hundred knights.
target: Meanwhile I’ll stay with Regan with my hundred knights.

orig: translate old to modern: Signior Bassanio, hear me: If I do not put on a sober habit, Talk with respect, and swear but now and then, Wear prayer-books in my pocket, look demurely; Nay more, while grace is saying, hood mine eyes Thus with my hat, and sigh, and say Amen; Use all the observance of civility, Like one well studied in a sad ostent To please his grandam,—never trust me more.
target: Mr. Bassanio, listen to me: If I don’t put on a sober habit, Talk with respect, and swear only now and then, Wear prayer-books in my pocket, look demurely, No more, while grace is saying, hood my eyes Like this with my hat, and sigh, and say “amen;” Use all the observances of manners, As one well studied in a sad display in order To please his grandmother, never trust me anymore.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou hotly lust’st to use her in that kind  For which thou whipp’st her.
target: You should be whipping yourself, since you lust after her and yearn to do the same thing for which you’re punishing her.

target: I grow old, and all dignity has been thrashed out of me.

target: Maybe you think that I think you’re in love.

target: No, gentle madam.

target: Very likely; one of them Is a plain fish, and, no doubt, marketable.

target: No.

target: Oh, you should have done it without telling me!

target: Now I am alone.

target: Hide her for a while in your house, and tell everyone that she has, in fact, died.

target: It’s pointless to talk now.

target: I rather think You haven’t sought her help, by whose soft grace, I have received her royal aid for a similar loss, And I am at peace.

target: I wish I might Only see that man again!

target: Stay you, good gentlemen.

target: Whichever one you want.

orig: translate old to modern: No jewel is like Rosalind.
target: There is no jewel like Rosalind.

target: Not poppy, nor mandragora, Nor all the drowsy drugs of the world, Shall ever bring you that sweet sleep Which you had yesterday.

target: Sir, a word before you go.

orig: translate old to modern: A friend.
target: A friend.

target: I eat the air, crammed with promises.

target: What, faithful to being mean and nasty?

target: You would be committing a wicked sin by chiding other people for sinning, because you yourself have been a terrible sinner, as carnal in your appetites as lust itself, and all the swollen pustules of sin that you acquired in your freedom you now want to burst and shoot back into the world at large.

orig: translate old to modern: You may go to the devil’s dam!
target: You can go straight to hell!

orig: translate old to modern: You are—a senator.
target: You are a senator.
