target: I feel better already, and I know there’s more good advice where that came from.

orig: translate old to modern: Roast me in sulphur!
target: Roast me in fires of sulphur!

orig: translate old to modern: I said, an elder soldier, not a better.
target: I said, an elder soldier, not a better.

orig: translate old to modern: Behold, I have a weapon; A better never did itself sustain Upon a soldier's thigh.
target: Behold, I have a weapon; A better one never sustained itself On a soldier's thigh.

orig: translate old to modern: Mark Antony shall say I am not well, And, for thy humor, I will stay at home.
target: Mark Antony shall say I’m not well, And, to make you happy, I’ll stay home.

target: Huntsman, look after my hounds.

target: Get out of my sight!

target: He may win; And what is music then?

target: For your sake, jewel, I am glad at soul I have no other child, Because your escape would teach me tyranny, To hang logs on them.

target: For all the rest, They'll take a suggestion as a cat licks up milk: They'll turn the clock to any business that We say is right for the hour.

target: OK!

target: You are building your nest in

target: Don’t be lost So badly in your thoughts.

target: The folly of this island!

target: It’s been this way ever since the first government was organized.

target: Emperor Caesar, dead and turned to clay, Might stop a hole to keep the wind away.

target: O, for two special reasons, Which may to you, perhaps, seem a bit cowardly, But yet to me they are strong.

orig: translate old to modern: These wise men that give fools money get themselves a good report—after fourteen years' purchase.
target: Wise men who give fools money might get a good reputation—if they keep up regular payments for fourteen years.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, my good lord.
target: Yes, my good lord.

orig: translate old to modern: What news?
target: What’s the news?

orig: translate old to modern: Draw and come.

orig: translate old to modern: These clothes are good enough to drink in, and so be these boots too.
target: They’re good enough to drink in, and so are these boots.

orig: translate old to modern: Not I, my lord, by heaven!
target: Not I, my lord, by heaven.

orig: translate old to modern: I could marry this wench for this device.
target: I could marry that Maria for thinking this up.

target: In the fact that it’s solitary, I enjoy it very much; but in the sense that it’s private, it’s terrible.

orig: translate old to modern: If you should die before him, where’s her dower?
target: Otherwise—forgive me, but if you should die before him, what becomes of her dowry?

target: What’s going on, Malvolio?

target: I’ll poison you, or beat you with a club, or stab you with a sword.

orig: translate old to modern: Look, here it is.
target: Look, here it is.

orig: translate old to modern: Not so, neither.
target: No, I’m not wound up.

target: Last night she got no sleep, and she won’t get any tonight.

orig: translate old to modern: Therefore perpend, my princess, and give ear.
target: So listen up, princess.

orig: translate old to modern: It is to be all made of faith and service, And so am I for Phoebe.
target: It means being faithful and ready to serve, just like I am for Phoebe.

target: We were about to have our noses snapped off by two old men with no teeth.

orig: translate old to modern: Where’s the Queen?
target: Where’s the Queen?

orig: translate old to modern: I say it is the moon that shines so bright.
target: I say it’s the moon that shines so bright.

orig: translate old to modern: No, my fair cousin.
target: No, my dear cousin.

orig: translate old to modern: I was contracted to them both.
target: I was engaged to both of them.

orig: translate old to modern: Hold then my sword, and turn away thy face, While I do run upon it.
target: Hold my sword, then, and turn away your face, While I run on it.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, if they lead to any ill, I will leave them at the next turning.
target: No, if they try to lead us to harm, I will leave the dance floor at the next song.

orig: translate old to modern: There's no offence, my lord.
target: There's no offense, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: You, ladies, you, whose gentle hearts do fear The smallest monstrous mouse that creeps on floor, May now, perchance, both quake and tremble here, When lion rough in wildest rage doth roar.
target: You, ladies, you, whose gentle hearts fear The smallest monstrous mouse that creeps on floor, May now, perhaps, both quake and tremble here, When a rough lion roars in wildest rage.

orig: translate old to modern: Prithee, be content.
target: I promise.

orig: translate old to modern: And I have met a gentleman Hath promised me to help me to another, A fine musician to instruct our mistress.
target: And I have met a gentleman who promises to help me find a good music tutor to instruct our lady love.

orig: translate old to modern: Now take them up,” quoth he, “if any list.”   Trembled and shook, for why he stamped and swore As if the vicar meant to cozen him.
target: She trembled and shook because he stamped and swore and carried on as though the vicar were trying to put something over on him.

orig: translate old to modern: But such officers do the King best service in the end.
target: But such officers do the king best service in the end.

orig: translate old to modern: Look you pale, mistress?
target: Do you Look pale, mistress?

orig: translate old to modern: That he was never trainèd up in arms.
target: That he was never trained as a soldier.

orig: translate old to modern: You saw my master wink and laugh upon you?
target: You saw my master wink and laugh at you?

orig: translate old to modern: Sir, sir, that cannot be.
target: Sir, sir, that can’t be true.

orig: translate old to modern: I cannot wish the fault undone, the issue of it being so proper.
target: Well, I wouldn’t want to undo the naughtiness, since the boy turned out so well.

orig: translate old to modern: Most radiant, exquisite and unmatchable beauty—I pray you, tell me if this be the lady of the house, for I never saw her.
target: What stunning, exquisite, and unmatchable beauty—but please, tell me if you’re the lady of the house, because I’ve never seen her.

orig: translate old to modern: Though in the trade of war I have slain men, Yet do I hold it very stuff o' the conscience To do no contrived murder.
target: Although I have slain men during a war, I believe it is a grave matter of the conscience To do a premeditated murder.

orig: translate old to modern: You see, her eyes are open.
target: You see, her eyes are open.

orig: translate old to modern: Bring it hither to me in the orchard.
target: Go get it and bring it to me here in the orchard.

target: We can only learn that the confident tyrant Still stays in Dunsinane, and will put up with Our settling down before it.

orig: translate old to modern: Let me have surgeons.
target: I need a doctor.

orig: translate old to modern: His ceremonies laid by, in his nakedness he appears but a man, and though his affections are higher mounted than ours, yet when they stoop, they stoop with the like wing.
target: And though his feelings may be pitched higher than ours, when they plummet, they plummet that much farther.

orig: translate old to modern: I remember him well; and I remember him worthy of thy praise.
target: I remember him well, and I remember him worthy of your praise.

target: You shall not put your seal to such a promise to pay For me; I’d rather live in my poverty.

orig: translate old to modern: Take me up.
target: Pick me up.

orig: translate old to modern: How if they will not?
target: And what if they won’t go?

target: Our men have all broken ranks.

target: May I speak with Antonio?

orig: translate old to modern: Naught that I am, Not for their own demerits, but for mine, Fell slaughter on their souls.
target: Nothing that I am, Not for their own sins, only for mine, Cruel slaughter on their souls.

orig: translate old to modern: Welcome, dear madam.
target: Welcome, dear madam.

orig: translate old to modern: Where is Montjoy the herald?
target: Where is Montjoy, the herald?

orig: translate old to modern: Why may not that be the skull of a lawyer?
target: why can’t that be the skull of a lawyer?

orig: translate old to modern: tis e'en so.
target: That’s true.

orig: translate old to modern: Trip, Audrey, trip, Audrey.—I attend, I attend.
target: Hurry up, Audrey, hurry.—I’m coming, I’m coming.

orig: translate old to modern: I am the king himself.
target: I’m the king himself.

orig: translate old to modern: Bind fast his corky arms.
target: Tie up his withered old arms.

orig: translate old to modern: Go in, Nerissa; Give order to my servants, that they take No note at all of our being absent hence; Nor you, Lorenzo:—Jessica, nor you.
target: Go in, Nerissa: Give orders to my servants that they take No notice at all of our being absent from here; Nor you, Lorenzo; Jessica, nor you.

orig: translate old to modern: Here is the place, my lord.
target: Here’s the hut, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Do; with like timorous accent and dire yell As when, by night and negligence, the fire Is spied in populous cities.
target: Go ahead; yell with frightening accent and distress As when a fire Is seen in big cities at night and by accident.

orig: translate old to modern: Is it sport?
target: Is it sport?

orig: translate old to modern: More of this matter cannot I report.
target: I can’t report more of this matter, But men are men; the best sometimes forget themselves.

orig: translate old to modern: My lord, I have remembrances of yours That I have longed long to redeliver.
target: My lord, I have mementos of yours That I have longed to re-deliver to you for a long time.

orig: translate old to modern: It beckons you to go away with it, As if it some impartment did desire To you alone.
target: It beckons you to go away with it, As if it had something to say To you alone.

orig: translate old to modern: And be all traitors that do so?
target: And are all traitors like that?

orig: translate old to modern: Have you any further trade with us?
target: Have you any else to tell me?

orig: translate old to modern: Is this your speeding?
target: Is this your idea of success?

orig: translate old to modern: Fled this way, sir, when by no means he could— Pursue him, ho!
target: He ran out that way, sir, when he couldn’t— Follow him, now!

orig: translate old to modern: I do require them of you, so to use them As we shall find their merits and our safety May equally determine.
target: tody of them so I can do what’s best out of concern for their honor and the safety of the kingdom.

orig: translate old to modern: This green plot shall be our stage, this hawthorn-brake our tiring-house; and we will do it in action, as we will do it before the Duke.
target: This green plot shall be our stage, this hawthorn bush our dressing room, and we will do it just as we will do it before the duke.

orig: translate old to modern: As with the meat, some undeservèd fault I’ll find about the making of the bed, And here I’ll fling the pillow, there the bolster, This way the coverlet, another way the sheets.
target: Just as I did with the meat, I’ll make up some problem with the way the bed is made, and throw the pillow one way and the cushion the other, and the blanket over here and the sheets over there.

orig: translate old to modern: Let our just censures Attend the true event, and put we on Industrious soldiership.
target: Let a true evaluation of the military situation Wait until we have won the battle.

orig: translate old to modern: O Cassius, you are yoked with a lamb, That carries anger as the flint bears fire, Who, much enforced, shows a hasty spark And straight is cold again.
target: O Cassius, you’re connected to a lamb That carries anger as a match makes fire, Who, very irritated, shows a hasty spark, And right away is cold again.

orig: translate old to modern: You did.
target: You did.

orig: translate old to modern: You have too courtly a wit for me.
target: Your wit is too courtly for me.

orig: translate old to modern: Where is Antony?
target: Where's Antony?

orig: translate old to modern: What is the matter with thee?
target: What’s the matter with you?

orig: translate old to modern: How do you, my good lady?
target: How are you, my good lady?

orig: translate old to modern: The bloody proclamation to escape, That followed me so near—O our lives' sweetness,
target: To escape the decree condemning me

orig: translate old to modern: How may the Duke be therewith satisfied, Whose messengers are here about my side, Upon some present business of the state To bring me to him?
target: How may the duke be satisfied with that, Whose messengers are here by my side, On some urgent business of the state, To bring me to him?

orig: translate old to modern: The revenges we are bound to take upon your traitorous father are not fit for your beholding.
target: You shouldn’t have to see the punishment we inflict on your father.

orig: translate old to modern: I am not so reputed!
target: I don’t have that kind of reputation!

orig: translate old to modern: Nor none that live, I hope.
target: Nor living ones, I hope.

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll never see ’t!
target: I’ll never see it.

orig: translate old to modern: I know I cannot please you.
target: I know I won’t please you.

orig: translate old to modern: My lord, for aught I know.
target: My lord, for all I know.

orig: translate old to modern: to Alonso] It is foul weather in us all, good sir, [to Alonso] It is foul weather in us all, good sir, When you are cloudy.
target: It is bad weather in us all, good sir, When you are cloudy.

orig: translate old to modern: Fare thee well, dame.
target: Farewell, lady.

orig: translate old to modern: Follow me then.
target: Follow me then.

orig: translate old to modern: This is Lucentio’s house.
target: This is Lucentio’s house.

orig: translate old to modern: Call Claudius and some other of my men, I'll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.
target: Call Claudius and some Others of my men; I'll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.

orig: translate old to modern: O, that that earth, which kept the world in awe Should patch a wall to expel the winter's flaw!
target: O, that the earth which kept the world in fear Should patch a wall to expel the winter's cold!

orig: translate old to modern: He shall think, by the letters that thou wilt drop, that they come from my niece, and that she’s in love with him.
target: He’ll think these letters are from Olivia and that she’s in love with him.

orig: translate old to modern: A friendly eye could never see such faults.
target: A friendly eye could never see such faults.

orig: translate old to modern: This is not altogether fool, my lord.
target: Well, you’ve given away all your other rightful titles.

orig: translate old to modern: When will he be here?
target: When will he be here?

orig: translate old to modern: This was his basket.
target: This was the basket.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, give us a taste of your quality.
target: Come, give us a bit of your quality.

orig: translate old to modern: I will weary you then no longer with idle talking.
target: I won’t exhaust you anymore with idle chitchat.

orig: translate old to modern: It would become me As well as it does you; and I should do it With much more ease, for my good will is to it, And yours it is against.
target: It would be as natural to me As it is to you: and I should do it Much more easily, because my good will is in it, And yours is against it.

orig: translate old to modern: Where joy most revels, grief doth most lament; Grief joys, joy grieves, on slender accident.
target: Where joy celebrates, grief mourns greatly, Grief joys, joy griefs, on a very slender event.

orig: translate old to modern: You may, sir.
target: You may, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Himself.
target: I’m my own spokesman.

orig: translate old to modern: I' faith, sir, you shall never need to fear.
target: Don’t worry, I couldn’t care less.

orig: translate old to modern: Forth, my sword; he dies.
target: Go forth, my sword; he dies.

orig: translate old to modern: Speak the word along.
target: Pass the word along.

orig: translate old to modern: So that by my foes, sir I profit in the knowledge of myself, and by my friends, I am abused.
target: My enemies help me understand myself better, which is an advantage, and my friends help me lie about myself, which is a disadvantage.

orig: translate old to modern: What is it thou didst say?
target: What is it you said?

orig: translate old to modern: She says you have some goodly jest in hand.
target: She says she thinks this is a prank.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, would that have mended my hair?
target: Why, would that have fixed my hair?

orig: translate old to modern: Are all the rest come back?
target: Are all the rest returning?

orig: translate old to modern: Do not muse at me, my most worthy friends.
target: Do not muse at me, my most worthy friends.

orig: translate old to modern: I'll bring you to him.
target: I'll bring you to him.

orig: translate old to modern: The plainsong” is most just, for humors do abound.
target: You can see how it is all around.

orig: translate old to modern: Merciful heaven!
target: Merciful heaven!

orig: translate old to modern: Prithee, my king, be quiet.
target: Please, my king, be quiet.

orig: translate old to modern: What, my old worshipful old master?
target: My honorable, reverend master?

orig: translate old to modern: He did bewray his practice, and received This hurt you see striving to apprehend him.
target: He exposed Edgar’s murderous plot, and was wounded, as you see there, when trying to apprehend him.

orig: translate old to modern: Some of my shame, if you will know of me What man I am, and how, and why, and where This handkercher was stained.
target: It’s about who I am, and how, why, and where this handkerchief was stained.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, unto thy bones good night!
target: Now I say good night to your bones, Hero.

orig: translate old to modern: Hortensio, peace.
target: Hush, Hortensio.

orig: translate old to modern: How dost thou, Guildenstern?
target: How are you, Guildenstern?

orig: translate old to modern: Canidius, Our nineteen legions thou shalt hold by land, And our twelve thousand horse.
target: Canidius, take our nineteen

orig: translate old to modern: They are entirely welcome.
target: I thank you, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: News, friends: our wars are done, the Turks are drown'd.
target: News, friends; our wars are done, the Turks are drowned.

orig: translate old to modern: I will reward thee Once for thy sprightly comfort and tenfold For thy good valor.
target: I’ll reward you once for your cheerfulness and ten times for your courage.

orig: translate old to modern: And these does she apply for warnings and portents And evils imminent, and on her knee Hath begg'd that I will stay at home today.
target: And these she interprets for warnings and portents And imminent evil, and on her knee, Has begged me to stay home today.

orig: translate old to modern: Then say at once what is it thou requests.
target: Then hurry up and tell me what you want.

orig: translate old to modern: I did, my lord.
target: I did, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Wisdom and goodness to the vile seem vile.
target: Bad people can’t appreciate wisdom or goodness.

orig: translate old to modern: What I am and what I would are as secret as maidenhead.
target: Who I am and what I want are a secret.

orig: translate old to modern: The air bites shrewdly; it is very cold.
target: The air bites sharply, It is very cold.

orig: translate old to modern: And look to have it yielded with all kindness.
target: You’ll find I’ll give it to you very willingly.

orig: translate old to modern: I would exult, man.
target: I’ll be thrilled.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou hast hit it.
target: You’re right, actually.

orig: translate old to modern: A dream itself is but a shadow.
target: A dream itself is but a shadow.

orig: translate old to modern: how noble in reason!
target: How noble in reason!

orig: translate old to modern: To plainness honor’s bound When majesty falls to folly.
target: When a majestic king starts acting silly, then it’s my duty to be blunt.

orig: translate old to modern: Fair is foul, and foul is fair.
target: Beautiful is disgustingly filthy, and disgustingly filthy is beautiful.

orig: translate old to modern: How every fool can play upon the word!
target: How every fool can play on the word!

orig: translate old to modern: Was he not born of woman?
target: Didn’t a woman give birth to him?

orig: translate old to modern: Never come such division 'tween our souls!
target: Never let such disagreements come between our souls!

orig: translate old to modern: And, Kate, when France is mine and I am yours, then yours is France and you are mine.
target: And, Kate, when France is mine and I am yours, then France is yours and you are mine.

orig: translate old to modern: Dead, then?
target: Is she dead, then?

orig: translate old to modern: The skin is good for your broken coxcomb.
target: The skin is good for your cracked head.

orig: translate old to modern: Do you know Where we may apprehend her and the Moor?
target: Do you know Where we may catch her and the Moor?

orig: translate old to modern: Words, words, words.
target: Words, words, words.

orig: translate old to modern: Good my sovereign, Take up the English short, and let them know Of what a monarchy you are the head.
target: My good King, surprise the English and let them know what kind of kingdom you rule over.

orig: translate old to modern: This is her very guise, and, upon my life, fast asleep.
target: This is her very disguise, and, upon my life, fast asleep.

orig: translate old to modern: She ate no meat today, nor none shall eat.
target: She had no food today and will have none.

orig: translate old to modern: Good Enobarbus, ’tis a worthy deed, And shall become you well, to entreat your captain To soft and gentle speech.
target: Good Enobarbus, you would be doing a very good thing if you advised your captain to speak calmly and quietly.

orig: translate old to modern: Rosalind lacks then the love Which teacheth thee that thou and I am one.
target: Well, then, you don’t have the affection that would teach you that you and I are one.

orig: translate old to modern: Think you my uncle did dissemble, grandam?
target: You think my uncle was lying, grandmother?

orig: translate old to modern: Good my lord, vouchsafe me a word with you.
target: My good my lord, may I a word with you.

orig: translate old to modern: When I do name him, let it be thy part To praise him more than ever man did merit.
target: Whenever I mention him, praise him more than any man deserves.

orig: translate old to modern: Richard of York, how fares our loving brother?
target: Richard of York, how are you doing, my loving brother?

orig: translate old to modern: But where is he?
target: But where is he?

orig: translate old to modern: Thou art the ruins of the noblest man That ever lived in the tide of times.
target: You’re the ruins of the noblest man That ever lived in the tide of times.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, Gertrude, we'll call up our wisest friends And let them know both what we mean to do And what's untimely done.
target: Come, Gertrude, we'll call up our wisest friends, And let them know both what we mean to do And what's done at an unfortunate time.

orig: translate old to modern: But oh, how vile an idol proves this god!
target: But oh, what a deceiver he turned out to be!

orig: translate old to modern: Tell him I would speak with him.
target: Tell him I want to speak with him.

orig: translate old to modern: Stay, I prithee, tell me what thou thinkest of me.
target: You do Stay, Please, tell me what you think of me.

orig: translate old to modern: My Queen and Eros Have by their brave instruction got upon me A nobleness in record.
target: My Queen and Eros have by their brave examples beaten me to the history books.

orig: translate old to modern: But was not this nigh shore?
target: But wasn’t this near the shore?

orig: translate old to modern: Ho, awake!
target: Ho, awake!

orig: translate old to modern: You may do so:—but let it be so hasted, that supper be ready at the farthest by five of the clock.
target: You may do so; but let it be quickly so that supper is ready by five of the clock at the latest.

orig: translate old to modern: are there masques?
target: are there parties?

orig: translate old to modern: Being thus benetted round with villainies— Or I could make a prologue to my brains, They had begun the play—I sat me down, Devised a new commission, wrote it fair.
target: Being surrounded like this with evil plans, Before I could start thinking about it, before They could execute the plan, I sat myself down, Though up a new order, wrote it just like the original.

orig: translate old to modern: It is good to grow.
target: It’s good to grow.

orig: translate old to modern: I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.
target: I wouldn’t think much of it even if it were heavier.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, fear not, man, I will not forfeit it; Within these two months,—that's a month before This bond expires,—I do expect return Of thrice three times the value of this bond.
target: Why, don’t be afraid, man; I won’t default in payment; Within the next two months, that's a month before This promise to pay expires, I expect to get a return Of three times three of the value of this promise to pay.

orig: translate old to modern: Cheerly, cheerly, my hearts!
target: Look lively, look lively, my good men!

orig: translate old to modern: God be wi' you; take mine office.
target: God be with you; take my job.

orig: translate old to modern: Ecstasy?
target: Imagination!

orig: translate old to modern: Thou art a soldier only.
target: You are only a soldier.

orig: translate old to modern: But will my Rosalind do so?
target: But will my Rosalind do this, too?

orig: translate old to modern: What art thou that usurp'st this time of night, Together with that fair and warlike form In which the majesty of buried Denmark Did sometimes march?
target: What are you, that seizes this time of night, Taking the same fair and warlike form In which the dead king of Denmark, now buried, Did sometimes march?

orig: translate old to modern: He doth entreat your Grace, my noble lord, To visit him tomorrow or next day.
target: My lord, he asks that you please visit him tomorrow or the next day.

orig: translate old to modern: But if you would consider the true cause Why all these fires, why all these gliding ghosts, Why birds and beasts from quality and kind, Why old men fool, and children calculate, Why all these things change from their ordinance, Their natures and preformed faculties, To monstrous quality, why, you shall find That heaven hath infused them with these spirits To make them instruments of fear and warning Unto some monstrous state.
target: But if you would think about the true cause, Why all these fires, why all these gliding ghosts, Why birds and beasts, from quality and kind; Why old men, fools, and children think about it— Why all these things change from their usual order, Change their natures, and their normal events To monstrous disorder—why, you shall find That Heaven has infused the lightening with these spirits, To make them instruments of fear and warning About some monstrous state.

orig: translate old to modern: By my troth, a pleasant-spirited lady.
target: I swear, she’s a very good-natured lady.

orig: translate old to modern: If he be not born to be hanged, our case is miserable.
target: If he is not born to be hanged, then our present state is pitiful.

orig: translate old to modern: So turns she every man the wrong side out And never gives to truth and virtue that Which simpleness and merit purchaseth.
target: And so she turns men inside out and never acknowledges the integrity and merit that a man has.

orig: translate old to modern: Men should be what they seem; Or those that be not, would they might seem none!
target: Men should be what they seem; Or those that are not, I wish wouldn’t seem so!

orig: translate old to modern: Go bid thy mistress, when my drink is ready, She strike upon the bell.
target: Go tell your mistress that, when my drink is ready, She should ring the bell.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou worms' meat in respect of a good piece of flesh, indeed.
target: You are about as much of a thinker as worm’s meat is a nice steak.

orig: translate old to modern: Poor Tom hath been scared out of his good wits.
target: Poor Tom has been scared out of his mind.

orig: translate old to modern: I wish him joy of her.
target: Right over to that  I hope he enjoys her.

orig: translate old to modern: What, master, read you?
target: What are you reading, teacher?

orig: translate old to modern: She will taste as like this as a crab does to a crab.
target: I know that Regan will taste just like Goneril—both of them sour crabapples.

orig: translate old to modern: How have the hours racked and tortured me Since I have lost thee!
target: I’ve been so tortured since I lost track of you!

orig: translate old to modern: How now, my lord!
target: How now, my lord!

orig: translate old to modern: What two crowns shall they be?
target: Which two crowns would those be?

orig: translate old to modern: Peter, didst ever see the like?
target: Peter, did you ever see anything like it?

orig: translate old to modern: But this is most falliable, the worm’s an odd worm.
target: But this is a sure thing: the snake’s an odd snake.

orig: translate old to modern: Now he tells how she plucked him to my chamber.
target: Now he tells how she brought him to my bedroom.

orig: translate old to modern: Hath he ask'd for me?
target: Has he asked for me?

orig: translate old to modern: Mistress, your father prays you leave your books And help to dress your sister’s chamber up.
target: Mistress, your father requests that you leave your books and come help decorate your sister’s room.

orig: translate old to modern: You look as you had something more to say.
target: You look like you have something more to say.

orig: translate old to modern: Your praise is come too swiftly home before you.
target: Your praise has beaten you home.

orig: translate old to modern: O me!
target: Oh me!

orig: translate old to modern: Is there any cause in nature that makes these hard hearts?
target: Is there any natural cause for hardening of the heart?

orig: translate old to modern: These things seem small and undistinguishable, Like far-off mountains turned into clouds.
target: These things seem small and murky, Like far-off mountain tops turned into clouds.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou liest, thou thread, thou thimble, Thou yard, three-quarters, half-yard, quarter, nail!
target: It’s a lie, you thread, you thimble, you measurement!

orig: translate old to modern: For him, I think not on him.
target: As for him, I never think about him.

orig: translate old to modern: The shallowest thick-skin of that barren sort, Who Pyramus presented, in their sport Forsook his scene and ent'red in a brake; When I did him at this advantage take, An ass's nole I fixed on his head.
target: The stupidest man of these dim country-folk Who acted Pyramus in their rehearsal, Exited from his scene and entered in a bunch of bushes, When I took advantage of him And I fixed donkey's head on his head.

orig: translate old to modern: I hear horses.
target: I hear horses.

orig: translate old to modern: Thus conscience does make cowards of us all, And thus the native hue of resolution Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought, And enterprises of great pitch and moment With this regard their currents turn awry And lose the name of action.
target: In this way, a conscience can make cowards of us all, And in this way the natural color of making up your mind Is covered with the pale shadow of thinking, And projects of great substance and significance, And in this regard, their movement turns erratic, And lose the name of action.

orig: translate old to modern: To be thus is nothing, But to be safely thus.
target: To be king in this way is nothing, Only to be safely king in this way matters.

orig: translate old to modern: aside] The charm dissolves apace, [aside] The charm dissolves apace, And as the morning steals upon the night, Melting the darkness, so their rising senses Begin to chase the ignorant fumes that mantle Their clearer reason.—O good Gonzalo, My true preserver, and a loyal sir To him you follow'st!
target: The charm dissolves quickly; And as the morning steals on into the night, Melting the darkness, so their rising senses Begin to chase the ignorant fumes that cloud Their clearer reason.—O good Gonzalo!

orig: translate old to modern: My daughter tells us all.
target: My daughter told me everything.

orig: translate old to modern: We wait upon your Grace.
target: We will wait on you, your majesty.

orig: translate old to modern: Set him before me; let me see his face.
target: Bring him here; let me see his face.

orig: translate old to modern: The tyrant's people on both sides do fight, The noble thanes do bravely in the war; The day almost itself professes yours, And little is to do.
target: The tyrant's people fight on both sides; The noble barons fight bravely in the war; The day almost professes itself to be yours, And little is to do.

orig: translate old to modern: What manner of man?
target: Just a man, like any other.

orig: translate old to modern: At first And last the hearty welcome.
target: To the first And the last, a hearty welcome.

orig: translate old to modern: Good madam!
target: Good madam!

orig: translate old to modern: O earth, which this blood drink’st revenge his death!
target: Oh earth, which soaks up this blood, revenge his death!

orig: translate old to modern: Let us to the great supper.
target: Let’s go to this great feast.

orig: translate old to modern: O heavenly mingle!
target: Oh, heavenly mixture!

orig: translate old to modern: He said the truth.
target: That’s true.

orig: translate old to modern: I will talk further with you.
target: Let’s discuss it some more.

orig: translate old to modern: I am myself indifferent honest, but yet I could accuse me of such things that it were better my mother had not borne me.
target: I don’t care about my sincerity, but I could accuse myself of such things that it were better my mother had not had me.

orig: translate old to modern: If only to go warm were gorgeous, Why, nature needs not what thou gorgeous wear’st, Which scarcely keeps thee warm.
target: If you dressed only to stay warm, you wouldn’t need these gorgeous clothes you’re wearing—which don’t keep you warm at all.

orig: translate old to modern: It is a good divine that follows his own instructions: I can easier teach twenty what were good to be done, than be one of the twenty to follow mine own teaching.
target: It is a good prophet that follows his own instructions; It’s easier for me to teach twenty people what was good to do than to be one of that twenty and follow my own teaching.

orig: translate old to modern: But as we often see, against some storm, A silence in the heavens, the rack stand still, The bold winds speechless, and the orb below As hush as death—anon the dreadful thunder Doth rend the region; so, after Pyrrhus' pause, Aroused vengeance sets him new a-work; And never did the Cyclops' hammers fall On Mars's armour, forged for proof eterne, With less remorse than Pyrrhus' bleeding sword Now falls on Priam.
target: But, as we often see a silence in the heavens, After some storm, the gales stand still, The bold winds speechless, and the earth below As hushed as death, and eventually the dreadful thunder Tears the region, so, after Pyrrhus' pause, A roused anger renews him and he begins to work, And never did the One-eyed monster’s hammers fall On the god of war’s amour, forged for eternal strength, With less sorrow than Pyrrhus' bleeding sword Now falls on Priam.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, let's do so; For every minute is expectancy Of more arrivance.
target: Come, let's do so, Because every minute is to expect More arrival.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou canst not fear us, Pompey, with thy sails.
target: Pompey, you cannot frighten us with your navy.

orig: translate old to modern: The urging of that word “judgment” hath bred a kind of remorse in me.
target: That word “judgment” makes me feel a bit guilty.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, truly; for the power of beauty will sooner transform honesty from what it is to a bawd than the force of honesty can translate beauty into his likeness.
target: Yes, truly, for the power of beauty will transform sincerity from what it is to a pimp faster than the force of sincerity can translate beauty into his image.

orig: translate old to modern: I will not say so, for fear I should be faced out of my way.
target: I’d say the same thing, but I’m afraid I’d be faced out of my way.

orig: translate old to modern: I love your majesty According to my bond, no more nor less.
target: I love you as a child should love her father, neither more nor less.

orig: translate old to modern: No, pray thee, good Meg, I’ll wear this.
target: No, please good Meg, I’ll wear this one.

orig: translate old to modern: No?
target: No?

orig: translate old to modern: She is cunning past man’s thought.
target: She’s more cunning than anyone can imagine.

target: Okay, just do this, noble Catesby: sound out Lord Hastings, but make it seem as if you’re just mulling over the idea, that it hasn’t been firmed up yet.

orig: translate old to modern: Still through the hawthorn blows the cold wind, says, “Suum, mun, nonny.” Dauphin my boy, my boy, cessez.
target: The cold wind’s still blowing through the hawthorn tree.

orig: translate old to modern: I pray you, sir, go forth, And give us truth who 'tis that is arrived.
target: I beg you, sir, go outside, And give us truth about who it is that has arrived.

orig: translate old to modern: Faith, here's an equivocator that could swear in both the scales against either scale, who committed treason enough for God's sake, yet could not equivocate to heaven.
target: Truly, it must be a liar who could swear on both sides of the scale against either side, who committed treason enough for God's sake, yet couldn’t lie to heaven.

orig: translate old to modern: How’s that?
target: How’s that?

orig: translate old to modern: He is all the mother’s, from the top to toe.
target: He’s his mother’s child from head to toe.

orig: translate old to modern: Fellows, let’s be gone.
target: Let’s go.

orig: translate old to modern: My remedy is then to pluck it out.
target: All I have to do is remove it.

orig: translate old to modern: Away, get thee away.
target: Away, get out of here.

orig: translate old to modern: We’ll hear him what he says.
target: Let’s hear what he has to say.

orig: translate old to modern: Approach and speak.
target: Come forward and speak.

orig: translate old to modern: You are a royal one, and we obey you.
target: Catch me if you can!

orig: translate old to modern: Do not talk to me, Emilia; I cannot weep, nor answer have I none But what should go by water.
target: Don’t talk to me, Emilia; I cannot weep, and I don’t have any answers, Except what should go by water.

orig: translate old to modern: It were a delicate stratagem to shoe A troop of horse with felt.
target: How ingenious to make horseshoes out of felt.

orig: translate old to modern: You strike my people, and your disordered rabble Make servants of their betters.
target: You hit my servants, and your disorderly mob of knights treat their superiors like servants.

orig: translate old to modern: Not that we love words better, as you do.
target: Not because we love words better, as you do.

orig: translate old to modern: Good night.
target: Good-night.

orig: translate old to modern: And for my name of George begins with  It follows in his thought that I am he.
target: He thinks “G” is me.

orig: translate old to modern: Farewell, Ophelia, and remember well What I have said to you.
target: Goodbye, Ophelia, and remember well What I have said to you.

orig: translate old to modern: Haply your eye shall light upon some toy You have desire to purchase, and your store, I think, is not for idle markets, sir.
target: Maybe you’ll see some little trinket you want to buy.

orig: translate old to modern: Shall they see us?
target: Shall they see us?

orig: translate old to modern: Such as I am, I come from Antony.
target: Humble as I am, I represent Antony.

orig: translate old to modern: There’s my key.
target: Here’s my key.

orig: translate old to modern: How now, my noble friend?
target: How are you, my friend?

orig: translate old to modern: If he love her not, And he not from his reason fall'n thereon Let me be no assistant for a state, But keep a farm and carters.
target: If he doesn’t love her, And he’s not gone crazy because of love, Let me be no assistant for a state, But be a farmer and horse carter.

orig: translate old to modern: I long to hear him call the drunkard “husband,” And how my men will stay themselves from laughter When they do homage to this simple peasant.
target: I can’t wait to hear him call the drunkard “husband,” and to watch my men smother their laughter as they pay their respects to this simple peasant.

orig: translate old to modern: He hath every month a new sworn brother.
target: Every month he has a new best friend.

orig: translate old to modern: Give me your hands all over, one by one.
target: Let’s shake hands all over again, one by one.

orig: translate old to modern: Shylock is my name.
target: Shylock is my name.

orig: translate old to modern: Farewell, good Strato.
target: Goodbye, good Strato.

orig: translate old to modern: O, in the duke of Gloucester’s purse.
target: Oh, in the duke of Gloucester’s wallet.

orig: translate old to modern: We shall further think on ’t.
target: We’ll have to think about it carefully.

orig: translate old to modern: Foh!
target: Argh!

orig: translate old to modern: Now, if these men have defeated the law and outrun native punishment, though they can outstrip men, they have no wings to fly from God.
target: Even if these men have escaped the law and punishment at home, they cannot escape God.

orig: translate old to modern: The sorrow that I have by right is yours, And all the pleasures you usurp are mine.
target: The sorrow that I feel actually belongs to you, and the high life you enjoy actually belongs to me.

target: On Tuesday last, A falcon, towering in her pride of place, Was hawked at and killed by an owl that usually eats mice.

orig: translate old to modern: Go seek him.
target: Go find him.

orig: translate old to modern: Would I were in an alehouse in London!
target: I wish I were in an alehouse in London!

orig: translate old to modern: Crack thy frail case!—Apace, Eros, apace.
target: Faster, Eros, faster.

orig: translate old to modern: And for mine own part, I durst not laugh for fear of opening my lips and receiving the bad air.
target: And, for mine part, I didn’t dare laugh for fear of opening my lips and inhaling the bad air.

orig: translate old to modern: And then the justice, In fair round belly with good capon lined, With eyes severe and beard of formal cut, Full of wise saws and modern instances; And so he plays his part.
target: He’s full of wise sayings and up-to-the-minute anecdotes: that’s the way he plays his part.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, beshrew my father’s ambition!
target: Curse my father’s ambition!

orig: translate old to modern: Tell me, Laertes, Why thou art thus incensed.
target: Tell me, Laertes, Why are you so angry like this?

orig: translate old to modern: I would my horse had the speed of your tongue and so good a continuer.
target: I wish my horse moved as fast as your mouth and was as tireless.

orig: translate old to modern: Bear’st thou her face in mind?
target: Do you remember her face?

orig: translate old to modern: If't be so, For Banquo's issue have I filed my mind, For them the gracious Duncan have I murdered, Put rancors in the vessel of my peace Only for them, and mine eternal jewel Given to the common enemy of man, To make them kings, the seed of Banquo kings!
target: If the prophecy is true, I have defiled my soul for Banquo's sons; I have murdered the gracious Duncan for them, Put doubts and bitter feelings into my mind Only for them, and I have given my soul To the common enemy of man, just To make them kings, the sons of Banquo kings!

orig: translate old to modern: What dogs are these!
target: You bastards!

orig: translate old to modern: Thou shalt not choose but go.
target: You have to come with me.

target: What are you fighting about?

target: If you do, by Mary, I’ll give you this curse for your wedding gift: whether you as chaste as ice, as pure as snow, you shalt not escape slander.

orig: translate old to modern: Heaven rest them now!
target: Heaven rest them now!

orig: translate old to modern: Weep'st thou for him to my face?
target: You weep for him to my face?

orig: translate old to modern: Nobody come?
target: Nobody comes?

target: When truth kills truth, oh devilish-holy fight!

target: That’s not holy, it’s heresy.

target: End it, then, and everything is over.—Eros!—I’m coming, my Queen!—Eros!—Wait for me.

orig: translate old to modern: If you could hurt, Your swords are now too massy for your strengths And will not be uplifted.
target: If you could hurt us, Your swords are now too heavy for your strengths, And won’t be lifted up.

target: I want this to provoke confrontations, so I can give him a piece of my mind.

target: No.

target: I cannot only remember such things that were, That were most precious to me.

target: Why do you speak so haltingly and angrily?

target: Beautiful ladies, please don’t treat me badly.

target: What do you think, will my friends prove loyal?

target: This Caesar was a tyrant.

target: He’s somewhere else in the house.

target: Signed, she who would be your servant,     The Fortunate Unhappy.” This is as clear as sunlight in an open field.

orig: translate old to modern: What, Ariel!
target: What, Ariel!

target: Indeed, she gives a very good testimony of the snake’s power.

orig: translate old to modern: In heaven.
target: In heaven.

target: If these are true eyes in my head, here's a goodly sight.

target: I gave my love a ring, and made him swear Never to part with it, and here he stands, I would dare to swear for him that he would not leave it Nor pluck it from his finger for all the wealth In the world.

orig: translate old to modern: Set me the stoups of wine upon that table.
target: Set up the goblets of wine for me on that table.

target: Many men seek their fortune at seventeen; at eighty, it’s a bit late.

target: The lack of time and the risk I’m under will have to keep us from bonding and catching up on each other’s news the way we usually would after not seeing each other for so long.

orig: translate old to modern: O, yes, my lord!
target: O, yes, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: By such despair I should accuse myself.
target: Such an expression of despair would only prove that I was guilty.

target: Come, uncle Exeter, enter Harfleur.

target: These tears are full of grace.

target: Where is my love?

target: No.

target: She already has a face.

orig: translate old to modern: I entreat you both That, being of so young days brought up with him, And sith so neighbour'd to his youth and haviour, That you vouchsafe your rest here in our court Some little time; so by your companies To draw him on to pleasures, and to gather So much as from occasion you may glean, Whether aught to us unknown afflicts him thus That open'd lies within our remedy.
target: I beg you both That, being childhood friends and brought up with him, And since you know well his youth and disposition, That you will be pleased to rest here in our court For a while, so that, with your company, you Draw him on to enjoy himself, and to gather, So much as from any occasion you may glean, Whether anything, unknown to us, afflicts him like this, That, once we know, we can make better.

orig: translate old to modern: Adieu!—tears exhibit my tongue.
target: Tears exhibit my voice.

target: What do you want, fellow?

target: What, am I being denied death, as well?

target: No, sure, I cannot believe That he would steal away so guiltily, Seeing you coming.

target: My lord, he has wrung from me my reluctant permission By asking me again and again, and I Finally had to give in.

orig: translate old to modern: So well thy words become thee as thy wounds; They smack of honor both.
target: Your words suit you as your wounds do; They both tell of honor.

target: Since you have given me my dukedom again, I will repay you with just as good a thing; At least bring out a wonder, to make you as happy As I am to have my dukedom.

orig: translate old to modern: Knock Knock Knock, knock!
target: Knock, knock.

orig: translate old to modern: Welcome, wanderer.
target: Welcome, wanderer.

target: Sir Toby, I’ve got to be frank with you.

orig: translate old to modern: Hortensio, to what end are all these words?

target: Many times, You’ve climbed up to the walls and lookout posts, To the towers and windows, yes, to chimney tops, Your infants in your arms, and you’ve sat there The entire day, waiting patiently To see great Pompey pass through the streets of Rome.

orig: translate old to modern: tis brief, my lord.
target: It is short, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: I think nothing, my lord.
target: I think nothing, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: It were a tedious difficulty, I think, To bring them to that prospect.
target: It’s a lengthy problem, I think, To bring them to that event.

target: If this young gentleman has offended you, I’ll take the blame for it.

target: We’ll watch them starve to death first.

orig: translate old to modern: With Demetrius.
target: With Demetrius.

target: I have so much care and pity for you that you could call me friend.

target: At least I don’t have a horse for my mistress—or a saying so beside the point.

target: I have no gift for the one and no strength for the other, though I have the gift of strength.

orig: translate old to modern: Which else were shame, that then necessity Will call discreet proceeding.
target: However, this is an extreme situation, and it’s more important to control it than to worry about how you’ll look.

orig: translate old to modern: Hark how our steeds for present service neigh.
target: Listen to our horses neighing, longing to be working.

target: I need to speak a word with you.

orig: translate old to modern: Cure her of that.

target: I’ll follow in the center of the troop formation, which I’ll defend with my best horse, and with Saint George on my side, as well!

target: I'll swear on that bottle to be your true subject, because that liquor is not earthly.

target: Coward, why don’t you come?

target: Who's there?

target: You were kneeled to and otherwise begged By all of us; and the fair soul herself Considered at which option she should take, Between reluctance and obedience.

orig: translate old to modern: May be she doth but counterfeit.
target: Maybe she’s just pretending.

orig: translate old to modern: O villain, villain!
target: Oh, what a villain!

target: Lucentio!

target: My brother thinks highly of you, and because of his affection, has helped arrange your marriage—but that was definitely a waste of his time and energy.

orig: translate old to modern: Speak.
target: Tell me.

orig: translate old to modern: Have you the lion's part written?
target: Have you written the lion's part?

orig: translate old to modern: Out of my sight!
target: Out of my sight!

orig: translate old to modern: Honest?
target: Honest!

target: swagger?

target: Heaven help her!—Get him out of here for now.

target: What, you want them to weep our horses' blood?

orig: translate old to modern: O, no, he loves me, and he holds me dear.
target: No, he loves and cherishes me.

orig: translate old to modern: I will look further into ’t.
target: I’ll look into it further.

orig: translate old to modern: The sun was not so true unto the day As he to me.
target: The sun was not as true to the daytime As he was to me.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay.
target: Yes.

target: How dare you try to be my friend when you refuse to fight my enemy.

target: I would’ve been happy if the entire camp, Pioneers and all, had tasted her sweet body, As long as I didn’t know about it.

orig: translate old to modern: Thus credulous fools are caught: And many worthy and chaste dames even thus, All guiltless, meet reproach.
target: Believing fools are caught like this; And many worthy and chaste dames just like this, All innocent, meet punishment.

orig: translate old to modern: I am informed thoroughly of the cause.
target: I am thoroughly informed about the case.

orig: translate old to modern: I am bound to your niece, sir.
target: I’m headed for your niece, sir.

target: A villain kills my father, and for that, I, his sole son, do this same villain send To heaven.

target: My honored lord, you know right well you did, And with them, words composed of so sweet an air As made the things more rich.

orig: translate old to modern: too old to be engag'd to young.
target: I am too old to be engaged to someone so young!

target: You’re really on time.

target: Knock at the gate?

target: The old proverb is very well parted between my master Shylock and you, sir: you have the grace of God, sir, and he has enough.

target: Therefore, willingly and yielding.

target: I know it.

target: Why should I play the Roman fool and die On my own sword?

target: Really, I had no intention of going for my sword.

target: The Tower’s chaplain has buried them, but to tell you the truth, I don’t know where.

target: Your worst fault is being in love.

orig: translate old to modern: You break jests as braggarts do their blades, which, God be thanked, hurt not.—My lord, for your many courtesies I thank you.
target: The wit you flaunt is like a blunt sword—it can’t hurt anyone, thank God.—My lord, I thank you for your many kindnesses.

orig: translate old to modern: My name is Mary, sir.
target: My name is Mary, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Take not the quarrel from His powerful arm; He needs no indirect or lawless course To cut off those that have offended Him.
target: God doesn’t need to use indirect or illegal means to kill those who have offended him.

orig: translate old to modern: Good Master Fabian, grant me another request.
target: Dear Mr. Fabian, do me another favor first.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis in ourselves that we are thus or thus.
target: It is in ourselves that we are like this or like that.

target: No, I don’t know you, and my lady didn’t send me to get you, and I’m not supposed to tell you to come speak with her, and your name is not Master Cesario, and this is not my nose, either.

orig: translate old to modern: Alack, sir, you cannot see your way.
target: But you can’t see where you’re going, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: You bring me out.

target: Noble Sebastian, You let your fortune sleep — die rather: wink While you are waking.

orig: translate old to modern: Natures of such deep trust we shall much need.
target: I need people as trustworthy as you.

orig: translate old to modern: Hope I may choose, sir.
target: I believe I have some choice in the matter, sir.

target: What mercy can you give him, Antonio?

target: Sweet Phoebe, have pity on me.

target: Piss off!

target: Neighbors, hello.

target: Stand close; this is the same Athenian.

target: Now, by my mother’s son, and that’s me, it will be moon or star or whatever I want before I’ll travel to your father’s house.

target: Today shall always be remembered as a holy day.

target: Come with me and let me advise you.

target: What should such a fool Do with so good a wife?

orig: translate old to modern: Can such things be, And overcome us like a summer's cloud, Without our special wonder?
target: Can such things be, that Can overcome us like a summer's cloud, Without puzzling us?

orig: translate old to modern: Beat me!
target: Beat me!
