orig: translate old to modern: We doubt not now But every rub is smoothèd on our way.
target: I’m now sure that every bump in the road has been removed.

orig: translate old to modern: Not very well, but I have met him oft, And he hath bought the cottage and the bounds That the old carlot once was master of.
target: Not very well, but I’ve met him several times.

orig: translate old to modern: There’s another.
target: Here it is.

orig: translate old to modern: It did always seem so to us.
target: We used to think so too.

orig: translate old to modern: I would have sworn it had, my lord, especially against Benedick.
target: I would have sworn that, too, my lord, especially against Benedick.

orig: translate old to modern: song] You spotted snakes with double tongue, Thorny hedgehogs, be not seen; Newts and blind-worms, do no wrong, Come not near our fairy Queen.
target: You spotted snakes, with double tongue, Thorny hedgehogs, be not seen; Newts and blindworms do no wrong; Come not near our fairy queen.

orig: translate old to modern: What should such fellows as I do, crawling between earth and heaven?
target: What should such fellows as I do crawling between earth and heaven?

orig: translate old to modern: You, you, sirrah, where’s my daughter?
target: You, sir, where’s my daughter?

orig: translate old to modern: Marry, he told me so himself; and he said he cared not who knew it.
target: Why, he told me so himself, and he said he didn’t care who knew it.

orig: translate old to modern: Not a soul But felt a fever of the mad and played Some tricks of desperation.
target: There wasn’t a soul that Only felt a fever of the madness and played Some tricks out of desperation.

orig: translate old to modern: O God!
target: Oh God!

orig: translate old to modern: O piteous spectacle!
target: O piteous spectacle!

orig: translate old to modern: Fool, I’ll requite it in the highest degree.
target: Fool, I’ll repay you for this favor.

orig: translate old to modern: Indeed, he plied them both with excellent praises.
target: He certainly flattered them both with extravagant compliments.

orig: translate old to modern: Macbeth!
target: Macbeth!

orig: translate old to modern: The King of Naples, being an enemy To me inveterate, hearkens my brother's suit; Which was that he, in lieu o'th’ premises Of homage and I know not how much tribute, Should presently extirpate me and mine Out of the dukedom, and confer fair Milan, With all the honours, on my brother; whereon, A treacherous army levied, one midnight Fated to th’ purpose did Antonio open The gates of Milan, and, i'th’ dead of darkness, The ministers for th’ purpose hurried thence Me and thy crying self.
target: This King of Naples, being an old enemy Of mine, listens my brother's request, Which was, that he, instead of the promises Of allegiance and I don’t know how much protection money, Should presently drive me and my family Out of the dukedom, and give the fair city of Milan, With all the honors to my brother: which, With a treacherous army recruited, on a midnight Assigned to the purpose, Antonio opened The gates of Milan; and, in the dead of darkness, The ones given the job hurried Me and your crying self from there.

orig: translate old to modern: Even he, madam.
target: That’s him, madam.

orig: translate old to modern: Untimely comes this hurt.
target: It’s a bad time for such an injury.

orig: translate old to modern: And now, Octavius, Listen great things.
target: And now, Octavius, Listen to great things.

orig: translate old to modern: Let it alone.
target: Never mind.

orig: translate old to modern: I have begun to plant thee, and will labor To make thee full of growing.
target: I have begun to nurture your career, and will labor To make the most of yourself.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, he was met even now As mad as the vexed sea, singing aloud, Crowned with rank fumiter and furrow-weeds, With burdocks, hemlock, nettles, cuckoo-flowers, Darnel, and all the idle weeds that grow In our sustaining corn.—A century send forth.
target: They saw him just now as mad and deranged as the stormy sea, singing loudly, wearing a crown of nettles, thorns, hemlock, and all the other weeds that grow in our cornfields.—Send out a hundred soldiers to find him.

orig: translate old to modern: And for thy life let justice be accus'd.
target: And, for your life, let justice be blamed.

orig: translate old to modern: A single thing, as I am now, that wonders To hear thee speak of Naples.
target: An alone thing, as I am now, that is amazed To hear you speak of Naples.

orig: translate old to modern: We should hold day with the Antipodes, If you would walk in absence of the sun.
target: We should hold day with the direct opposite, If you would walk in absence of the sun.

orig: translate old to modern: Give me a cup of wine.
target: Give me a cup of wine.

orig: translate old to modern: Quick, quick, I pray thee, draw the curtain straight; The Prince of Arragon hath ta'en his oath, And comes to his election presently.
target: Quickly, quickly, please, draw the curtain right away; The Prince of Aragon has taken his oath, And comes to make his choice now.

orig: translate old to modern: Yet here's a spot.
target: Still here's a spot.

orig: translate old to modern: It is a nipping and an eager air.
target: It is a nipping and an eager air.

orig: translate old to modern: What’s the matter?
target: What’s the matter?

orig: translate old to modern: Up and down, up and down, I will lead them up and down.
target: Up and down, up and down; I will lead them up and down.

orig: translate old to modern: Those that Hobgoblin call you, and sweet Puck, You do their work, and they shall have good luck.
target: Those that call you Hobgoblin, and sweet Puck, You do their work, and they shall have good luck.

orig: translate old to modern: Your son and daughter found this trespass worth The shame which here it suffers.
target: That’s why your daughter and son-in-law are punishing me shamefully.

orig: translate old to modern: Ha, ha, ha!
target: Ha, ha, ha!

orig: translate old to modern: They that reap must sheaf and bind, Then to cart with Rosalind.
target: After you harvest, you have to sheaf and bind So throw ripe Rosalind on the harvest cart.

orig: translate old to modern: Here comes my lady.
target: Here comes my lady.

orig: translate old to modern: He cannot by the duello avoid it.
target: The rules of dueling say he has to.

orig: translate old to modern: I do not like the office; But sith I am enter'd in this cause so far, Prick'd to't by foolish honesty and love, I will go on.
target: I don’t like the job; But, since I am entered already so far into this cause, Encouraged to it by foolish honesty and love, I will go on.

orig: translate old to modern: I prithee, who doth he trot withal?
target: Okay, who does it trot for?

orig: translate old to modern: Is't come to this?
target: Has it come to this?

orig: translate old to modern: Would it not grieve a woman to be overmastered with a piece of valiant dust?
target: What woman wouldn’t be distressed, being lorded over by a handful of dust?

orig: translate old to modern: I was provokèd by her sland'rous tongue, That laid their guilt upon my guiltless shoulders.
target: She provoked me with her lying mouth, accusing me of crimes I didn’t commit.

orig: translate old to modern: But yet thou art my flesh, my blood, my daughter— Or rather a disease that’s in my flesh, Which I must needs call mine.
target: But you’re still my child, my flesh and blood—or rather you’re a disease in my flesh, a disease I still have to call my own.

orig: translate old to modern: Talkest thou nothing but of ladies?
target: Can’t you talk about anything besides ladies?

orig: translate old to modern: All this done Upon the gad?—Edmund, how now?
target: All this so suddenly?—Edmund, what’s going on?

orig: translate old to modern: Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember a pretty jest your daughter told.
target: Now that you speak of paper, I remember a funny story of Hero’s.

orig: translate old to modern: Give me thy hand, Roderigo.
target: Give me your hand, Roderigo.

orig: translate old to modern: I have, my lord.
target: I have, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: She gave it him, and he hath given it his whore.
target: She gave it him, and he has given it his whore.

orig: translate old to modern: Fear not my government.
target: Don’t be afraid of what I think.

orig: translate old to modern: Stones have been known to move and trees to speak; Augures and understood relations have By maggot pies and choughs and rooks brought forth The secret'st man of blood.
target: Stones have been known to move, and trees to speak.

orig: translate old to modern: She swoons to see them bleed.
target: She swoons to see them bleed.

orig: translate old to modern: Unless he have a fancy to this foolery, as it appears he hath, he is no fool for fancy, as you would have it appear he is.
target: Unless you’re talking about his love for this kind of foolishness—which, judging from his appearance, he has—he is no fool for love, as you pretend.

orig: translate old to modern: No, my good lord.
target: No, my good lord.

orig: translate old to modern: He longs to eat the English.
target: He wants to eat the English.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, tailor, let us see these ornaments.
target: Now, tailor, let’s see what you’ve got.

orig: translate old to modern: He that shall see this day, and live old age, Will yearly on the vigil feast his neighbors And say, “Tomorrow is Saint Crispian.” Then will he strip his sleeve and show his scars, And say, “These wounds I had on Crispin’s day.”
target: He who survives this day and lives to see old age shall yearly entertain his neighbors on the eve, saying, “Tomorrow is

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, let's follow him.
target: No, let's follow him.

orig: translate old to modern: When I think, I must speak.
target: Whatever I think, I have to say.

orig: translate old to modern: Save thee, Curan.
target: Hello, Curan.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, come, come, come, give me your hand.
target: Come, come, come, come, give me your hand.

orig: translate old to modern: Alack, I had forgot!
target: Alack, I had forgotten.

orig: translate old to modern: Would the night were come.
target: I wish the night were here now!

orig: translate old to modern: Fie, what a slug is Hastings that he comes not To tell us whether they will come or no!
target: And what a slug Hastings is that he hasn’t even arrived to tell us whether they’re coming!

orig: translate old to modern: That eye that told you so looked but asquint.
target: You’re so infatuated with him that you’re hallucinating.

orig: translate old to modern: What, is there such a place?
target: Is there such a place?

orig: translate old to modern: See how they kiss and court!
target: Look how they kiss and carry on!

orig: translate old to modern: They have dispatched with Pompey; he is gone.
target: They finished their business with Pompey, and Pompey has left.

orig: translate old to modern: Mock not, Enobarbus.
target: Don’t joke about this, Enobarbus.

orig: translate old to modern: The chariest maid is prodigal enough If she unmask her beauty to the moon.
target: The most careful maid is wasteful enough If she unmasks her beauty to the moon.

orig: translate old to modern: First, madam, he is well.
target: Let me say first, madam, that he is well.

orig: translate old to modern: For Antony, I have no ears to his request.
target: As for Antony, I’m not interested in his requests.

orig: translate old to modern: Where love is great, the littlest doubts are fear; Where little fears grow great, great love grows there.
target: Where love is great, the littlest doubts are very fearful, Where little fears grow great, great love also grows there.

orig: translate old to modern: When you take occasions to see leeks hereafter, I pray you, mock at 'em, that is all.
target: When you see leeks in the future, I hope you keep mocking them.

orig: translate old to modern: Give me Bianca for my patrimony.
target: Give me Bianca for my inheritance.

orig: translate old to modern: So.
target: Like that.

orig: translate old to modern: A bitter fool.
target: You’re a bitter fool.

orig: translate old to modern: Good Lord for alliance!
target: Thank the lord for alliances!

orig: translate old to modern: As it ebbs, the seedsman Upon the slime and ooze scatters his grain, And shortly comes to harvest.
target: The harvest comes shortly after that.

orig: translate old to modern: The competitors enter.
target: Here come the conspirators.

orig: translate old to modern: How is it, general?
target: How is it, general?

orig: translate old to modern: Make it no wonder.
target: Not tonight—today.

orig: translate old to modern: That's not so good now.
target: That's not so good now.

orig: translate old to modern: My good knave Eros, now thy captain is Even such a body.
target: Eros, my young friend, your captain is now just like that cloud.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis cowardly and womanish.
target: That’s cowardly and womanish.

orig: translate old to modern: You must bear with me.
target: You’ll have to bear with me.

orig: translate old to modern: Bassanio, lord Love, if thy will it be.
target: Bassanio, lord Love, if it is your will!

orig: translate old to modern: No, I will go seek Some ditch wherein to die.
target: No, I’ll go find some ditch to die in.

orig: translate old to modern: What it should be, More than his father's death, that thus hath put him So much from the understanding of himself, I cannot dream of.
target: What the problem should be, More than his father's death that has put him So much from the understanding of himself, I cannot dream of.

orig: translate old to modern: Take in the topsail.
target: Take in the top sail.

orig: translate old to modern: What was ’t That moved pale Cassius to conspire?
target: Why did Cassius conspire against Caesar?

orig: translate old to modern: Dear general, I never gave you cause.
target: Dear general, I never gave you any reason.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, come, away.
target: Come on, come on.

orig: translate old to modern: What, my gracious lord?
target: What, my dear lord?

orig: translate old to modern: If it be so, It is a chance which does redeem all sorrows That ever I have felt.
target: If that’s true, it makes up for all the sorrows I’ve ever known.

orig: translate old to modern: Their lips were four red roses on a stalk, And in their summer beauty kissed each other.
target: Their lips, like four red roses on a stalk, touched.

orig: translate old to modern: Go make thee ready; Our letters are prepared.
target: My letters are ready to go.

orig: translate old to modern: Though that his joy be joy, Yet throw such changes of vexation on't As it may lose some color.
target: even if his joy is joy, Still throw such aggravation on it That he won’t stay happy for long.

orig: translate old to modern: I see you all are bent To set against me for your merriment.
target: I see you all are bent To set against me for your entertainment.

orig: translate old to modern: One would think his mother’s milk were scarce out of him.
target: He looks like he just recently stopped breastfeeding.

orig: translate old to modern: How say you, Cassio?
target: What do you think, Cassio?

orig: translate old to modern: Now, my dearest Queen— Pray you, stand farther from me.
target: Now, my dearest Queen— Please, stand farther away from me.

orig: translate old to modern: If he do bleed, I'll gild the faces of the grooms withal, For it must seem their guilt.
target: If he bleeds, I'll smear the faces of the grooms with it, Because it must seem that they are guilty.

orig: translate old to modern: Conrade, I say!
target: Conrade, I say!

orig: translate old to modern: We have willing dames enough; there cannot be That vulture in you, to devour so many As will to greatness dedicate themselves, Finding it so inclined.
target: We have willing dames enough, so there cannot be That vulture in you, to devour so many As will dedicate themselves to greatness, Finding greatness so inclined.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis passing good.
target: Oh, lovely.

orig: translate old to modern: For your intent In going back to school in Wittenberg, It is most retrograde to our desire; And we beseech you, bend you to remain Here in the cheer and comfort of our eye, Our chiefest courtier, cousin, and our son.
target: As for your intentions To go back to school in Wittenberg, Leaving here is not something that we want, And we beg you to give into remaining Here in the happiness and pleasure of our eyes, Our most important courtier, cousin, and our son.

orig: translate old to modern: To be Count Malvolio!
target: Just think, I could be Count Malvolio!

orig: translate old to modern: tis a quick lie, sir; 'twill away again from me to you.
target: It is a quick lie, sir, it will go away again from me to you.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, with my lord, madam.
target: Why, with my lord, madam.

orig: translate old to modern: My ever gentle cousin, welcome hither.
target: My ever-gentle cousin, welcome here.

orig: translate old to modern: How now, my dear Othello!
target: How are you, my dear Othello!

orig: translate old to modern: Shall I keep your hogs and eat husks with them?
target: Should I tend your pigs and eat husks with them?

orig: translate old to modern: Drunk!
target: Drunk!

orig: translate old to modern: Would I could answer This comfort with the like!
target: I wish I could answer This comfort with a similar one!

orig: translate old to modern: Hell and night Must bring this monstrous birth to the world's light.
target: Hell and night Must bring this monstrous birth to the world's light.

orig: translate old to modern: He is a craven and a villain else, an ’t please your Majesty, in my conscience.
target: If I may say so, your Majesty, as I see it he would be a coward and a villain not to.

orig: translate old to modern: It is perchance that you yourself were saved.
target: It was a total fluke that you yourself were saved.

orig: translate old to modern: Octavia is of a holy, cold, and still conversation.
target: Octavia has a pious, chaste, meek disposition.

orig: translate old to modern: Heaven preserve you!
target: Heaven preserve you!

orig: translate old to modern: Then murder 's out of tune, And sweet revenge grows harsh.
target: Then murder's out of tune, And sweet revenge grows harsh.

orig: translate old to modern: Did you say all?
target: Did you say all?

orig: translate old to modern: Alas, poor rogue!
target: Alas, poor rogue!

orig: translate old to modern: Now Edmund, where’s the villain?
target: Edmund, where’s your wicked brother?

orig: translate old to modern: What to him from England?
target: What’s the message from the English king?

orig: translate old to modern: Fie, my lord, fie!
target: For shame, my lord, for shame!

orig: translate old to modern: I understand you not, my lord.
target: I don’t understand you, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: In the same figure, like the King that's dead.
target: It looks just like the dead king!

orig: translate old to modern: Answer me directly.
target: Just tell me that.

orig: translate old to modern: Kate like the hazel-twig Is straight and slender and as brown in hue As hazel nuts, and sweeter than the kernels.
target: Kate is as straight and slender as a hazel-twig, her hair as brown as hazelnut shells, and she herself sweeter than the kernels.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, sooth; so humbled, That he hath left part of his grief with me, To suffer with him.
target: Yes, truly, so humbled That he has left part of his grief with me To suffer with him.

orig: translate old to modern: Here I am Antony, Yet cannot hold this visible shape, my knave.
target: Here and now I seem like Antony, but I can’t keep myself in this form, my boy.

orig: translate old to modern: About the ninth hour, lady.
target: Almost nine o’clock, lady.

orig: translate old to modern: My duty, madam, and most humble service.
target: I give you my obedience and my humble service, madam.

orig: translate old to modern: If this were played upon a stage now, I could condemn it as an improbable fiction.
target: If this were a play, I’d complain it was unrealistic.

orig: translate old to modern: Say he is sick.
target: Say he’s sick.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, Casca, tell us what hath chanced today, That Caesar looks so sad.
target: Yes, Casca, tell us what has happened today That makes Caesar look so sad.

orig: translate old to modern: I now perceive it was not altogether your brother’s evil disposition made him seek his death, but a provoking merit set awork by a reprovable badness in himself.
target: Now I realize your brother tried to kill your father not just because your brother is an evil man, but because your father deserved it by being wicked himself.

orig: translate old to modern: Every offence is not a hate at first.
target: Every wrong is not a hate at first.

orig: translate old to modern: A most unhappy one.
target: A very unhappy one.

orig: translate old to modern: Dost thou know me, fellow?
target: Do you know me?

orig: translate old to modern: For what had he to do to chide at me?
target: What right did he have to scold me like that?

orig: translate old to modern: Your Grace, we think, should soonest know his mind.
target: You, I think, would best know what he’s thinking.

orig: translate old to modern: Like aqua vitae with a midwife.
target: Like medicine for a sick man.

orig: translate old to modern: All disconsolate, With Pindarus his bondman, on this hill.
target: All very upset, With Pindarus his slave, on this hill.

orig: translate old to modern: True or false, it hath made thee Earl of Gloucester.
target: Right or not, it’s made you the Earl of Gloucester.

orig: translate old to modern: A piece of ice.
target: A piece of ice.

orig: translate old to modern: O vassal!
target: Oh, you lowlife!

orig: translate old to modern: Yet you have all the vantage of her wrong.
target: But you have all the advantages from the harm done.

orig: translate old to modern: That?
target: That!

orig: translate old to modern: Art thou some god, some angel, or some devil That makest my blood cold, and my hair to stare?
target: Are you some god, some angel, or some devil, That makes my blood cold and my hair to stand on end?

orig: translate old to modern: He says he’ll come.
target: He says he’ll come.

orig: translate old to modern: That he hath used thee.
target: That he has used you.

orig: translate old to modern: The testament!
target: The testament!

orig: translate old to modern: All you gods, In general synod take away her power; Break all the spokes and fellies from her wheel, And bowl the round nave down the hill of heaven, As low as to the fiends!
target: All you gods, In general meeting, take away her power, Break all the spokes and curved rims from her wheel, And bowl the hub of the wheel down the hill of heaven, As low as you can to kill the fiends!

orig: translate old to modern: Well, well, well— Pray God it be, sir.
target: Well, well, well, Pray God it be, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Die for adultery?
target: To die for adultery?

orig: translate old to modern: There lay he, stretched along like a wounded knight.
target: He lay there, stretched out like a wounded knight.

orig: translate old to modern: Would thou’dst be ruled by me!
target: I wish you’d do what I ask!

orig: translate old to modern: He never did harm that I heard of.
target: He never did harm that I heard of.

orig: translate old to modern: Yea, marry, let them come before me.
target: Yes, indeed, bring them before me.

orig: translate old to modern: Still so cruel?
target: Are you still so cruel?

orig: translate old to modern: I am gone, though I am here.
target: My body waits here, but the rest of me is gone.

orig: translate old to modern: No Thisbe do I see.
target: I don’t see Thisbe.

orig: translate old to modern: Ere the bat hath flown His cloister'd flight; ere to black Hecate's summons The shard-borne beetle with his drowsy hums Hath rung night's yawning peal, there shall be done A deed of dreadful note.
target: Before the bat has flown His hidden flight, before black Hecate's summons are heard, Before the dung beetle, with his drowsy hums, Rings the bell to end the night, there shall be done A deed of dreadful note.

orig: translate old to modern: Farewell, thou lob of spirits; I'll be gone.
target: Farewell, you group of spirits; I have to get going.

orig: translate old to modern: Where?
target: Where?

orig: translate old to modern: The messenger Came on my guard, and at thy tent is now Unloading of his mules.
target: The messenger arrived on my watch and is unloading his mules at your tent.

orig: translate old to modern: Only th’ adulterous Antony, most large In his abominations, turns you off And gives his potent regiment to a trull That noises it against us.
target: Only the adulterous and abominable Antony abandons you, giving his power to a whore who turns that power against us.

orig: translate old to modern: And now to our French causes.
target: And now, let’s turn to our business with the French.

orig: translate old to modern: But speak you this with a sad brow?
target: But tell me, are you speaking seriously?

orig: translate old to modern: But, soft!
target: But quiet.

orig: translate old to modern: This damned witch Sycorax, For mischiefs manifold and sorceries terrible To enter human hearing, from Algiers Thou know'st was banished—for one thing she did They would not take her life.
target: They would not take her life for one thing she did.

orig: translate old to modern: No, not to live.
target: No, not to live!

orig: translate old to modern: Why, what make you here?
target: What are you doing here?

orig: translate old to modern: The barbarous Scythian, Or he that makes his generation messes To gorge his appetite, shall to my bosom Be as well neighbored, pitied, and relieved As thou my sometime daughter.
target: Foreign savages who eat their own children for dinner will be as close to my heart as you, ex-daughter of mine.

orig: translate old to modern: No, as I am a man.
target: No, I swear it as a man.

orig: translate old to modern: If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds, Behold this pattern of thy butcheries.
target: If you enjoy looking at your awful deeds, take a look at this noteworthy example of your butcheries.

orig: translate old to modern: I have an humor to knock you indifferently well.
target: I’m in a mood to beat you up pretty good.

orig: translate old to modern: I am no fighter.
target: I’m not a fighter.

orig: translate old to modern: What hour now?
target: What time is it now?

orig: translate old to modern: pointing to Caliban] This is a strange thing as e'er I [pointing to Caliban] This is a strange thing as e'er I look'd on.
target: This is as strange a thing as I have ever looked on.

orig: translate old to modern: I would thou couldst stammer, that thou might’st pour this concealed man out of thy mouth as wine comes out of a narrow-mouthed bottle—either too much at once, or none at all.
target: I wish you could just stammer this hidden man out of your mouth like wine out of a narrow-necked bottle: either too much at once or none at all.

orig: translate old to modern: So much for this, sir; now shall you see the other.
target: So much for this, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Truly, my name is Cinna.
target: Truly, my name is Cinna.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, but I fear you speak upon the rack, Where men enforced do speak anything.
target: Yes, but I’m afraid you speak out of torture, Where men will say anything.

orig: translate old to modern: But cheer thy heart, and be thou not dismayed.
target: Fool, do not flatter yourself.

orig: translate old to modern: If you would know your wronger, look on me.
target: If you want to see your deceiver, then look at me.

orig: translate old to modern: Would all the world but he had quite forsworn!
target: It’s revolting!

orig: translate old to modern: For who would bear the whips and scorns of time, The oppressor's wrong, the proud man's contumely, The pangs of disprized love, the law's delay, The insolence of office, and the spurns That patient merit of the unworthy takes, When he himself might his quietus make With a bare bodkin?
target: There's the respect That makes a mess of long life, For who would bear the whips and scorns of time, The oppressor's wrong, the proud man's insults, The pangs of rejected love, the law's delay, The inexperience of office, and the disdain That patient merit takes from the unworthy, When he himself might his final settlement make With a bare, sharp knife?

orig: translate old to modern: Hast thou slain him, then?
target: Have you slain him, then?

orig: translate old to modern: And I beseech you come again tomorrow.
target: And I beg you, please come here again tomorrow.

orig: translate old to modern: Thy spirits are most tall.
target: That’s enough.

orig: translate old to modern: So, adieu.

target: Now he goes, With no less confidence, but with much more love, Than young Alcides went to redeem The sacrifice of young women made by howling Troy To the sea-monster: I stand for sacrifice; The rest aloof are the Dardanian wives, With tear-stained faces coming out to view The outcome of the event.

target: You know I would never approve a war against my own cause.

target: Are you all good and honest men?

target: You left him out in the storm in the black night, bareheaded, a storm so terrible that if it had happened at sea, the waters would have risen up and extinguished the fire burning in the stars.

target: Beautiful ladies, you drop holy bread in the way Of starved people.

orig: translate old to modern: Damn'd as thou art, thou hast enchanted her, For I'll refer me to all things of sense, If she in chains of magic were not bound, Whether a maid so tender, fair, and happy, So opposite to marriage that she shunn'd The wealthy, curled darlings of our nation, Would ever have, to incur a general mock, Run from her guardage to the sooty bosom Of such a thing as thou—to fear, not to delight.
target: Damned as you are, you have cast a spell on her; Because I'll restore myself to all things of sense, If she wasn’t bound in chains of magic, Would a maid so tender, beautiful, and happy, So opposed to marriage that she shunned The wealthy, curled darlings of our country, Would she ever have, to merit a public joke, Run from her father to the black bosom Of a thing such as you, to fear, not to delight in?

target: Captain Macmorris, I beg your pardon, but would you grant me a discussion or two with you, see, partly touching on or concerning the practice of war, the Roman wars, for the sake of argument, see, and friendly conversation?

orig: translate old to modern: I, thus neglecting worldly ends, all dedicated To closeness and the bettering of my mind With that which, but by being so retired, O'er prized all popular rate, in my false brother Awakened an evil nature; and my trust, Like a good parent, did beget of him A falsehood, in its contrary as great As my trust was, which had indeed no limit, A confidence sans bound.
target: My neglecting worldly responsibilities like that, Dedicating everything to seclusion and the bettering Of my mind with that which, only by being so secluded, Was worth more than all popular opinion, awoke in my False brother an evil nature; and my trust, Like a good parent, made him Lie, a lie as great As my trust was, which had no limit indeed, A confidence without boundaries.

orig: translate old to modern: I found him under a tree like a dropped acorn.
target: I found Orlando under a tree, like a dropped acorn.

orig: translate old to modern: then bid them prepare dinner.

target: What we want to do, We should do when we would, for this 'would' changes, And has stoppages and delays as many As there are voices, hands, accidents, And then this 'should' is like the sigh of a spendthrift, That hurts by easing up.

orig: translate old to modern: Once more unto the breach, dear friends, once more, Or close the wall up with our English dead!
target: Attack the breach in the city wall once more, dear friends, attack it once more—or else let’s close it up with English corpses.

target: Lay her in the earth, And may violets spring from her fair And unpolluted flesh!

target: What do you say?

target: Lay your finger like this, and let your soul be instructed.

target: Well, that’s what you get to do.

target: If I had known this young man was his son, I would have tried harder to convince him not to fight.

orig: translate old to modern: Look you lay home to him.
target: See that you are direct with him.

target: There is scorn and disdain in her eyes, and those sparkling eyes despise everything they look upon.

target: Yet she must die, or else she'll betray more men.

target: This man, with lantern, dog, and thorn bush, Represents Moonshine, because, if you want to know, These lovers think it’s no shame to meet at Ninus' tomb By moonshine, there, there to court each other.

orig: translate old to modern: If you will not murder me for my love, let me be your servant.
target: Please let me be your servant so I can be with you.

target: Whether they meant to bathe in fresh, bleeding wounds, Or create another Crucifixion scene, I cannot tell.

orig: translate old to modern: Tomorrow, soldier, By sea and land I’ll fight.
target: Tomorrow, soldier, I’ll fight by sea and land.

orig: translate old to modern: I do agnize A natural and prompt alacrity I find in hardness; and do undertake These present wars against the Ottomites.
target: I recognize A natural and prompt speed that I find in hardness, and undertake These present wars against the Ottoman.

orig: translate old to modern: I think oxen and wainropes cannot hale them together.
target: I don’t think a team of oxen could get them close enough to fight.

target: Cassio screwed her; ask your husband otherwise.

target: Come, let’s be off!

target: You see that any morals she has left are preventing her from denying the charges: she doesn’t want to add perjury to her list of sins.

orig: translate old to modern: Hark, Petruchio: she says she’ll see thee hanged first.
target: Listen to that Petruchio: she says she’ll see you hanged first.

orig: translate old to modern: Do that good mischief which may make this island Thine own for ever, and I, thy Caliban, For aye thy foot-licker.
target: Do that good deed which may make this island Your own forever, and I, your Caliban, Your foot-licker forever.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, then, good night our part.
target: So much for our plan.

orig: translate old to modern: Fate, show thy force.
target: Fate, do your work.

target: Hello, good Cassio!

orig: translate old to modern: Who's there, i’ the name of Belzebub?
target: Who's there, in the name of the Devil?

orig: translate old to modern: But remember, For that's my business to you, that you three From Milan did supplant good Prospero; Exposed unto the sea, which hath requit it, Him and his innocent child; for which foul deed, The powers, delaying, not forgetting, have Incensed the seas and shores, yea, all the creatures, Against your peace.
target: But, remember— Because that's my business to you,—that you three From Milan replaced good Prospero; Exposed him and his innocent child to the sea, Which has repaid it: for which evil deed, The powers, delaying but not forgetting, have Angered the seas and shores, yes, all the creatures, Against your peace of mind.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou hast served me with much faith.
target: You’ve served me faithfully.

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll come to him.
target: I’ll go to him.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou canst not choose but know who I am.
target: You must have figured out who I am.

orig: translate old to modern: I would you had won the fleece that he hath lost!
target: I wish you had won the fleece that he has lost.

orig: translate old to modern: He has no children.
target: He has no children.

orig: translate old to modern: What do you mean by this haunting of me?
target: What do you mean by this haunting of me?

orig: translate old to modern: Not I, my lord.
target: Not I, my lord.

target: If they do this, as they will, God willing, my ransom will soon be raised.

orig: translate old to modern: My dearest coz, I pray you, school yourself.
target: My dearest cousin, I beg you, have patience yourself.

orig: translate old to modern: It were not for your quiet nor your good, Nor for my manhood, honesty, or wisdom, To let you know my thoughts.
target: It’s not good for your peace or your wellbeing, Or for my manhood, honesty, or wisdom To let you know my thoughts.

orig: translate old to modern: And me too, good Lord!
target: Me too, Lord!

orig: translate old to modern: I tell you true.
target: I’m telling you the truth.

orig: translate old to modern: I have no way, and therefore want no eyes.
target: I don’t have anywhere to go, so I don’t need to see.

orig: translate old to modern: Dost thou say so?
target: You say so?

orig: translate old to modern: In weightier things you’ll say a beggar nay.
target: For more important things, you’ll say no.

orig: translate old to modern: Your friends at Pomfret, they do need the priest; Your Honor hath no shriving work in hand.
target: Your friends at Pomfret, they’re the ones who need a priest.

orig: translate old to modern: God defend me from these two!
target: God defend me from these two!

orig: translate old to modern: This to be true I do engage my life.
target: I swear on my life that I’m speaking the truth.

orig: translate old to modern: Observe him, for the love of mockery, for I know this letter will make a contemplative idiot of him.
target: This letter’s going to turn him into a starry-eyed idiot.

orig: translate old to modern: What's he That was not born of woman?
target: Who is he That was not born of woman?

orig: translate old to modern: Then would to God that I had never seen't!
target: Then I wish to God that I had never seen it!

orig: translate old to modern: Swear your love.
target: Swear your love for each other.

orig: translate old to modern: A sovereign shame so elbows him.
target: He’s too overwhelmed with shame.

orig: translate old to modern: Is ’t possible you will away tonight?
target: You’re not thinking of leaving tonight, surely?

orig: translate old to modern: God and our good cause fight upon our side.
target: We have God and a good cause on our side.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis a vile thing to die, my gracious lord, When men are unprepared and look not for it.
target: It’s a horrible thing to die when you’re not prepared for it, my gracious lord.

orig: translate old to modern: It is my day, my life.
target: They are my daylight, my life.

orig: translate old to modern: Even so great men great losses should endure.
target: Even so great men should endure great losses.

orig: translate old to modern: By this kind of chase I should hate him, for my father hated his father dearly.
target: By that kind of logic, I should hate Orlando, since my father hates his father.

orig: translate old to modern: Away!
target: Let’s go!

orig: translate old to modern: That I am guiltless of your father's death, And am most sensibly in grief for it, It shall as level to your judgment pierce As day does to your eye.
target: It shall penetrate your understanding That I am innocent of your father's death, And am most sincerely in grief for it, As day penetrates your eye.

orig: translate old to modern: No, not a denier.
target: No, not a penny.

orig: translate old to modern: Revolving this will teach thee how to curse.
target: Think like this all day, and you’ll learn how to curse.

orig: translate old to modern: Sir, I never loved you much, but I ha’ praised ye When you have well deserved ten times as much As I have said you did.
target: Sir, I wouldn’t say I was your friend, but I’ve praised you when you deserved ten times more praise than I gave.

orig: translate old to modern: But now I see our lances are but straws, Our strength as weak, our weakness past compare, That seeming to be most which we indeed least are.
target: But now I see our weapons are like straws, our strength like a straw’s weakness, and our weakness past comparison, so that we seem to be the thing we most are not.

orig: translate old to modern: We know thy charge, Brakenbury, and will obey.
target: We know you have a job to do, Brakenbury, and we’ll do what you say.

orig: translate old to modern: Use lenity, sweet chuck.
target: Be lenient, dearest!

orig: translate old to modern: For if she be not honest, chaste, and true, There's no man happy; the purest of their wives Is foul as slander.
target: Because if she is not honest, chaste, and true, There's no man happy; the purest of their wives Is wicked as the leis about them.

orig: translate old to modern: If you deny them, all the land will rue it.
target: If you refuse it, the whole country will regret it.

orig: translate old to modern: Tom will throw his head at them.—Avaunt, you curs!
target: Tom will chase them off.—Go away, you mongrels!

orig: translate old to modern: In my stars I am above thee, but be not afraid of greatness.
target: By my birth I rank above you, but don’t be afraid of my greatness.

orig: translate old to modern: If every ducat in six thousand ducats Were in six parts, and every part a ducat, I would not draw them,—I would have my bond.
target: If every dollar in six thousand dollars Were in six parts, and every part a dollar, I would not take them; I want my promise to pay.

orig: translate old to modern: If he do resist, Subdue him at his peril.
target: If he resists, Subdue him at his peril.

orig: translate old to modern: Farewell, therefore, Hero.
target: Goodbye then, Hero.

orig: translate old to modern: waking] Why, how now?
target: Why are your swords drawn?

orig: translate old to modern: It is not moonlight now.
target: It is not nighttime now.

orig: translate old to modern: Possess them not with fear.
target: Don’t let them know fear.

orig: translate old to modern: I think our father will hence tonight.
target: I think that our father will leave here tonight.

orig: translate old to modern: Would thou and those thy scars had once prevailed To make me fight at land!
target: I wish you and your scarred self had convinced me to wage our last battle on land.

orig: translate old to modern: Then but forbear your food a little while Whiles, like a doe, I go to find my fawn And give it food.
target: Then please, put off your eating for a little while I, like a mother doe, find my fawn and bring it food.

orig: translate old to modern: I owe you much; and, like a wilful youth, That which I owe is lost: but if you please To shoot another arrow that self way Which you did shoot the first, I do not doubt, As I will watch the aim, or to find both, Or bring your latter hazard back again, And thankfully rest debtor for the first.
target: I owe you a lot, and, like a willful youth, I have lost what I owe you, but if you will please Lend me money in the identical way That you lent me the first money, I don’t doubt, As I’ll be more careful, to find both sums, Or I’ll bring your second loan back again And just owe you thankfully for the first.

orig: translate old to modern: And mine, but it grows something stale with me.
target: And like mine, but I’m getting a little tired of it.

orig: translate old to modern: The instances that second marriage move Are base respects of thrift, but none of love.
target: The reasons for a second marriage Are low respects of saving money, but not for love.

orig: translate old to modern: Stand, ho!
target: Stop, oh!

orig: translate old to modern: Fie!
target: Damn!

orig: translate old to modern: Worthy Macbeth, we stay upon your leisure.
target: Worthy Macbeth, we are waiting for you.

orig: translate old to modern: Good reasons must of force give place to better.
target: Good reasons must, of course, yield to better reasons.

orig: translate old to modern: Not sick, my lord, unless it be in mind; Nor well, unless in mind: his letter there Will show you his estate.
target: He’s not sick, my lord, unless it’s in his mind; But he’s not well, unless in his mind; his letter there Will show you his state of affairs.

orig: translate old to modern: But I have none.
target: But I have none.

orig: translate old to modern: Made she no verbal question?
target: She didn’t ask anything?

orig: translate old to modern: But look, the morn, in russet mantle clad, Walks o'er the dew of yon high eastward hill.
target: But, look, the morning, dressed in a red cape, Walks over the dew of that high hill in the east.

orig: translate old to modern: Down with the topmast!
target: Down with the top mast!

orig: translate old to modern: Nor rain, wind, thunder, fire are my daughters.
target: The rain, the wind, the thunder and lightning are not my daughters.

orig: translate old to modern: We wait upon your Grace.
target: We’ll come with you, your Grace.

orig: translate old to modern: If you would conjure in her, you must make a circle; if conjure up Love in her in his true likeness, he must appear naked and blind.
target: For love to appear in his true likeness, he would have to be as Cupid is: naked and blind.

orig: translate old to modern: It must be by his death, and, for my part, I know no personal cause to spurn at him, But for the general.
target: He must die, and, for my part, I don’t know a personal cause to throw at him, But for the general complaints.

orig: translate old to modern: He’s coming, madam; but in very strange manner.
target: He’s coming, madam; but he’s acting very strangely.

orig: translate old to modern: There is, there is.
target: There is a crab-apple here.

orig: translate old to modern: That's not amiss; But yet keep time in all.
target: There’s nothing wrong with that, But still be patient in all.

orig: translate old to modern: You may think I love you not.
target: You may think that I don’t love you.

orig: translate old to modern: He misses not much.
target: He doesn’t miss much.

orig: translate old to modern: I can say little more than I have studied, and that question’s out of my part.
target: I’m sorry, but I memorized what I’m supposed to say here today, and that question isn’t part of the speech I learned.

orig: translate old to modern: In Sicyon.
target: In Sicyon.

orig: translate old to modern: For Monsieur Malvolio, let me alone with him.
target: As for Monsieur Malvolio, let me take care of him.

orig: translate old to modern: I prithee, peace.
target: Please be quiet.

orig: translate old to modern: I am justly kill'd with mine own treachery.
target: I am justly killed with my own wickedness.

orig: translate old to modern: All for our vantage.
target: All to our advantage.

orig: translate old to modern: Follow that lord, and look you mock him not.
target: Follow that lord, and see you don’t mock him.

orig: translate old to modern: Who has a breast so pure, But some uncleanly apprehensions Keep leets and lawdays, and in session sit With meditations lawful?
target: Who has a breast so pure That some unclean thoughts Keep court records and legal holidays, and sit in session With lawful deliberations?

orig: translate old to modern: I pray thee, Rosalind, sweet my coz, be merry.
target: Please, Rosalind, my sweet cousin—be happy.

orig: translate old to modern: Why dost thou lash that whore?
target: Why are you whipping that whore?

orig: translate old to modern: Turning th' accomplishment of many years Into an hour-glass; for the which supply, Admit me chorus to this history; Who, prologue-like, your humble patience pray Gently to hear, kindly to judge our play.
target: And, as the speaker of any prologue should, I ask you to hear our play courteously and to judge it kindly.

orig: translate old to modern: Most veritable; therefore look to't well.
target: Very true; therefore look well for it.

orig: translate old to modern: Have you not read, Roderigo, Of some such thing?
target: Haven’t you read, Roderigo, Of some such thing?

orig: translate old to modern: Well, I will do it, though I take thee in the king’s company.
target: I’ll do it even if I find you in the company of the king himself.

orig: translate old to modern: what, Lucius!
target: Hey, Lucius!

orig: translate old to modern: Well, my lord.
target: Well, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Write loyal cantons of contemned love And sing them loud even in the dead of night.
target: I’d write sad songs about unrequited love and sing them loudly in the middle of the night.

orig: translate old to modern: What should I say to you?
target: What should I say to you?

orig: translate old to modern: I have a speech of fire, that fain would blaze But that this folly drowns it.
target: I have a rumor of fire, that I would gladly spread, Before this news puts the fire out.

orig: translate old to modern: Gentlewoman, my lady calls.
target: Maria, our lady wants you.

orig: translate old to modern: Riotous madness, To be entangled with those mouth-made vows Which break themselves in swearing!
target: It was wild insanity to believe promises made by the mouth and not the heart.

orig: translate old to modern: Wherefore did they not That hour destroy us?
target: Why didn’t they Destroy us then and there?

orig: translate old to modern: Good Maria, let this fellow be looked to.
target: Maria, take care of this poor fellow here.

orig: translate old to modern: A mellifluous voice, as I am true knight.
target: A beautiful voice, I swear.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou shall present me as an eunuch to him.
target: You’ll introduce me to him as a eunuch.

orig: translate old to modern: If there be cords or knives, Poison or fire, or suffocating streams, I'll not endure it.
target: If there are ropes or knives, Poison or fire, or suffocating streams, I'll not endure it.

orig: translate old to modern: No cause, no cause.
target: I had no reason, no reason.

orig: translate old to modern: Silence!
target: Silence!

orig: translate old to modern: There are the players.
target: There are the players.

orig: translate old to modern: From seventeen years till now almost fourscore Here livèd I, but now live here no more.
target: From the time I was seventeen, over sixty years ago, I have lived in this house, but now I will live here no more.

orig: translate old to modern: I am pale, Charmian.
target: I’m sick, Charmian.

orig: translate old to modern: to Sebastian] Temperance was a delicate wench.
target: Climate was a delicate mistress.

orig: translate old to modern: Seven of my people, with an obedient start, make out for him.
target: I’d send seven of my servants to go get him.

orig: translate old to modern: Now my spirit is going.
target: Now I feel my soul leaving.

orig: translate old to modern: O thou weed, Who art so lovely fair and smell'st so sweet That the sense aches at thee, would thou hadst ne'er been born!
target: O you weed, Who are so lovely beautiful, and smell so sweet, That the sense aches at you, I wish you had never been born!

orig: translate old to modern: It is, my lord.
target: It is, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Give me the letter, sir.
target: Give me that letter, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Know’st thou the way to Dover?
target: Do you know the way to Dover?

orig: translate old to modern: That I beheld.
target: I saw that.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis not the king that sends you to the Tower.
target: The king isn’t the one sending you to the Tower, Clarence.

orig: translate old to modern: What, you look merrily.
target: What, you look amused.

orig: translate old to modern: Sport royal, I warrant you.
target: It’s going to be fun, I promise.

orig: translate old to modern: It will not let you eat, nor talk, nor sleep, And, could it work so much upon your shape As it hath much prevail'd on your condition, I should not know you, Brutus.
target: It won’t let you eat, or talk, or sleep; And, if it could affect your face and body So much that it conquers your spirit, I shouldn’t know you, Brutus.

orig: translate old to modern: Do but now promise, Kate, you will endeavor for your French part of such a boy; and for my English moiety take the word of a king and a bachelor.
target: Do promise, Kate, that you’ll do your French part to bring forth such a boy; and for my English half, take the word of a king and a bachelor.

orig: translate old to modern: Antonio, gratify this gentleman, For, in my mind, you are much bound to him.
target: Antonio, thank this gentleman, Because, in my opinion, you owe him a lot.

orig: translate old to modern: Yes, that the king is dead.
target: Yes, that the king is dead.

orig: translate old to modern: Fear you not my part of the dialogue.
target: Let’s start.

orig: translate old to modern: Then music is Even as the flourish, when true subjects bow To a new-crowned monarch: such it is, As are those dulcet sounds in break of day, That creep into the dreaming bridegroom's ear, And summon him to marriage.
target: Then music is Sounds as the trumpets when true subjects bow To a new-crowned king; music is Those sweet sounds at sunrise That creep into the dreaming bridegroom's ear And summon him to marriage.

orig: translate old to modern: Just, just; and the men do sympathize with the mastiffs in robustious and rough coming on, leaving their wits with their wives.
target: And the men resemble their English hounds in their loud, showy ferocity, too, leaving their brains behind with their wives.

orig: translate old to modern: Do you see nothing there?
target: Do you see nothing there?

orig: translate old to modern: But what talk we of fathers when there is such a man as Orlando?
target: He writes brave poems, speaks brave words, makes brave promises, and then breaks them just as bravely.

orig: translate old to modern: See'st thou this sweet sight?
target: Do you see this sweet sight?

orig: translate old to modern: Why, that the Moor first gave to Desdemona; That which so often you did bid me steal.
target: Why, the one that the Moor first gave to Desdemona; The one that you asked me so often to steal.

orig: translate old to modern: To save her life, I’ll say she is not so.
target: To save her life, I’ll say she doesn’t.

orig: translate old to modern: I think it was to see my mother's wedding.
target: I think it was to see my mother's wedding.

orig: translate old to modern: Come on.
target: Come on.

orig: translate old to modern: My lord, it shall be done.
target: My lord, it shall is done.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, there's no remedy.
target: Why, there's no remedy; it is the curse of the military.

orig: translate old to modern: Most shallow man.

target: Mean you his majesty?

target: Yes, kind sister.

target: Now, herald, have the dead been counted?

target: Yes, dear little chick, come along with me.—Shut up, man!

orig: translate old to modern: What is the matter, my lord?
target: What is the matter, my lord?

orig: translate old to modern: Rise, and lend thine ear.
target: Get up and listen to me.

target: In that case, he’s more obliged to you than I am.

target: So you don’t love me?

target: It’ll be OK.

target: You have nothing to be afraid of, my lord; I’ll do it.

target: What bout your thought, Iago?

target: Well, Petruchio, all this is very encouraging.

target: Do you maintain the same story?

target: You’ve said it, friend, and farewell to you.

target: When you see a huge wheel rolling down a hill, you shouldn’t try to hold on to it or it’ll break your neck.

target: If she offers him her love, it’s very possible that he’ll scorn it, since, as we all know, he tends to be contemptuous.

orig: translate old to modern: Fair daylight?
target: Is it daytime?

target: He'll still be hanged, Although every drop of water swears against it And open very wide to fill him up.

target: It’s too bad I’m so hard-hearted, because I really don’t love anyone.

target: The king—whom I hope God will protect better than you would like—can’t get a minute’s rest without you bothering him with your outrageous complaints.

orig: translate old to modern: Fool, do not flatter.
target: Fool, do not flatter yourself.

orig: translate old to modern: Call you?
target: Did you call?

orig: translate old to modern: Nor send you out o' the way?
target: Nor send you out of the way?

target: Listen to him talk about war, and you’ll hear elegant and thrilling accounts of the battles.

target: How can a tailor make a person?

target: Please don’t ruin any more of my poems by reading them so badly.

target: Do I blame Nature for being so thrifty?

orig: translate old to modern: Who’s there?

target: For none neither.

target: My lord?

target: I have words to speak into your ear will make you speechless, but are they much too light for the heart of the matter.

target: His letter’s going to be hilarious.

target: Which ones are the malefactors?

target: A really good exploit, a manly enterprise, To bring up tears in a poor maid's eyes With your insults!

target: Now sir, this done, as it is a very compelling and natural position, who is outstanding and first in the degree of this luck as Cassio is?

orig: translate old to modern: Why, then, build me thy fortunes upon the basis of valor.
target: Well then, improve your situation with a show of courage.

orig: translate old to modern: Count Claudio?
target: Claudio?

orig: translate old to modern: Never anger Made good guard for itself.
target: Anger does not protect the angry well.

orig: translate old to modern: The Queen, my lord, is dead.
target: The queen, my lord, is dead.

orig: translate old to modern: O sir, to wilful men, The injuries that they themselves procure Must be their schoolmasters.
target: Oh, sir, impetuous people learn their lessons from the consequences of their foolish actions.

orig: translate old to modern: She Is daughter to this famous Duke of Milan, Of whom so often I have heard renown, But never saw before; of whom I have Received a second life; and second father This lady makes him to me.
target: She Is daughter to this famous Duke of Milan, Who I have so often heard has a great reputation, But that I never saw before; of whom I have Received a second life: and this lady makes him A second father to me.

orig: translate old to modern: Tell me, heavenly bow, If Venus or her son, as thou dost know, Do now attend the queen.
target: Tell me, heavenly rainbow, if you know, If Venus the goddess of love or Cupid, her son, Now wait on the queen?

target: In your christening, you shall have two godfathers; If I had been the judge, you should have had ten more, To bring you to the gallows, not to the baptismal font.

orig: translate old to modern: All ready.
target: Everything’s ready.

orig: translate old to modern: Why should not I then prosecute my right?
target: Why shouldn’t I pursue Hermia?

orig: translate old to modern: Know you not he has?
target: Don’t you know he has?

orig: translate old to modern: It shall go hard if “Cambio” go without her.
target: It will be hard if “Cambio” loses her.

orig: translate old to modern: For the most part, too, they are foolish that are so.
target: Usually that means a person is foolish.

orig: translate old to modern: Better thou Hadst not been born than not t' have pleased me better.
target: It would’ve been better for you not to have been born at all than to displease me as you did.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, by heaven, my lord.
target: Yes, by heaven, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: And I in all unwillingness will go.
target: It has hatched a    I go unwillingly.

orig: translate old to modern: Do you love me?
target: Do you love me?

orig: translate old to modern: Our army shall In solemn show attend this funeral, And then to Rome.
target: Our army shall somberly attend this funeral and then depart for Rome.

orig: translate old to modern: I am, my lord, as well derived as he, As well possess'd; my love is more than his; My fortunes every way as fairly rank'd, If not with vantage, as Demetrius'; And, which is more than all these boasts can be, I am belov'd of beauteous Hermia.
target: I am, my lord, as well born as he is, As rich; my love is better than his; My fortunes, no matter which way you look at it, Are as good as Demetrius'; And, furthermore, which is more important than all these qualities, Hermia loves me too!

orig: translate old to modern: I have seen you gleeking and galling at this gentleman twice or thrice.
target: I’ve seen you bait and mock this man more than once.

orig: translate old to modern: It was well done, and thou shalt sleep again; I will not hold thee long.
target: You did well, and you shall sleep again; I’ll not keep you long.

orig: translate old to modern: Are you my wife and will not call me “husband”?
target: You call yourself my wife, yet you don’t call me “husband”?

orig: translate old to modern: Go to, then.
target: As you please.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, my dread lord—so must I call you now.
target: Very well, my supreme lord—that’s what I have to call you now.

orig: translate old to modern: O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!
target: O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!

orig: translate old to modern: Are not Those in commission yet return'd?
target: Haven’t Those in charge of it returned yet?

orig: translate old to modern: What profane wretch art thou?
target: Who the hell are you?

orig: translate old to modern: Jove shield thee well for this!
target: Jove protect you well for this!

orig: translate old to modern: Taurus!
target: Taurus!

target: And I had to be away from home!

orig: translate old to modern: By Chrish, la, ’tish ill done.
target: Christ, it’s a disaster.

orig: translate old to modern: And you, sir.
target: Hello, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Good night, good brother.
target: Good night, good brother.

target: By God, I will tell the king about these taunts.

orig: translate old to modern: Niggard of question, but of our demands Most free in his reply.
target: Difficult to question, but, when we ask for something, He is most free in his reply.

orig: translate old to modern: Our wars are done.
target: Our wars are over.

orig: translate old to modern: The nature of bad news infects the teller.
target: The bearer of bad news is often blamed for it.

orig: translate old to modern: I'll not be made a soft and dull-ey'd fool, To shake the head, relent, and sigh, and yield To Christian intercessors.
target: I won’t be made a soft and dull-eyed fool, To shake my head, give in, and sigh, and surrender To Christian intercessors.

orig: translate old to modern: Wash me in steepdown gulfs of liquid fire!
target: Wash me in steep-down gulfs of liquid fire!

orig: translate old to modern: I say amen to her.
target: But I say amen to everything she said.

orig: translate old to modern: Suffolk first died, and York, all haggled over, Comes to him where in gore he lay insteeped And takes him by the beard, kisses the gashes That bloodily did yawn upon his face.
target: Suffolk died first, and York, cut to pieces, came to him where he lay in his blood and took him by the face, kissing his gashes.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, sir, what’s your conceit in that?
target: Why, what’s the problem?

orig: translate old to modern: Good, I will expect you.
target: Good, I’ll expect you.

orig: translate old to modern: It is a man’s office, but not yours.
target: It’s a job meant for a man, but not you.

orig: translate old to modern: But when we in our viciousness grow hard— Oh, misery on ’t!—the wise gods seel our eyes, In our own filth drop our clear judgments, make us Adore our errors, laugh at ’s while we strut To our confusion.
target: But when our vices become habits—Oh, the sadness of it!—the wise gods blind us, shade our better judgment, make us love our mistakes, and laugh as we strut to our ruin.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, this is evident to any formal capacity.
target: Why, anyone can see what this means.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, there thou say'st!
target: Why, there you’ve said it.

orig: translate old to modern: But how, my lord, shall we resist it now?
target: But how will we keep it from being passed now, my lord?

orig: translate old to modern: By heaven, it is as proper to our age To cast beyond ourselves in our opinions As it is common for the younger sort To lack discretion.
target: It seems it is as proper for our age To cast beyond ourselves in our opinions As it is common for the younger sort To lack discretion.

orig: translate old to modern: Quick, quick; fear nothing; I'll be at thy elbow.
target: Quickly, quickly; fear nothing; I'll be at your elbow.

orig: translate old to modern: Draw together, And when I rear my hand, do you the like, To fall it on Gonzalo.
target: Pull out your sword when I do: And when I raise my hand, you do the same, So that it falls on Gonzalo.

orig: translate old to modern: What drink’st thou oft, instead of homage sweet, But poisoned flattery?
target: What do you get to drink, instead of sweet obedience, but poisonous flattery?

orig: translate old to modern: Mend the instance, shepherd.
target: Fix your example, shepherd.

orig: translate old to modern: Charmian!
target: Charmian!

orig: translate old to modern: My gorge rises at it.
target: I want to vomit.

orig: translate old to modern: They will scarcely believe this without trial.
target: Of course, they won’t believe you without proof.

orig: translate old to modern: No.
target: Well, I don’t.

target: Hound or spaniel, bitch or dog, Whether your tail is short or curly— Tom will make you cry and wail.

orig: translate old to modern: Say she be mute and will not speak a word; Then I’ll commend her volubility, And say she uttereth piercing eloquence.
target: If she is silent and won’t speak at all, I’ll praise her chattiness and say she speaks with piercing eloquence.

orig: translate old to modern: Stand!
target: Stop!

target: This toast is for Lepidus!

orig: translate old to modern: Come, throw it o'er my face.
target: Come, put it over my face.

orig: translate old to modern: And then for her To win the Moor, were't to renounce his baptism, All seals and symbols of redeemed sin, His soul is so enfetter'd to her love, That she may make, unmake, do what she list, Even as her appetite shall play the god With his weak function.
target: And then for her To win the Moor, if it meant renouncing his own baptism, All seals and symbols of forgiveness, His soul is so chained to her love That she may make, unmake, do whatever she wants, Even as her wishes shall play the god With his weak ability to think.

target: Sometimes, imitate Lysander’s voice, To stir up Demetrius’ anger; And sometimes, sound like Demetrius; And that way you can lead them from each other, Until sleep imitating death creeps over their eyebrows With leaden legs and batty wings.

target: You remember That time I sat on a big rock by the ocean, And heard a mermaid, on a dolphin's back, Singing such a sweet and melodious song That the rough sea became calm when it heard it, And certain stars shot madly out of their orbits To hear the sea-maid's music?

target: We had some food and some fresh water that A noble Neapolitan, Gonzalo,—who, being then appointed Supervisor of this plot,— gave us out of his goodness, with Rich garments, linens, stuffs, and other necessities, Which have since been very useful: so, of his gentleness, Knowing how I loved my books, he supplied me, With volumes from my own library that I prize more than my dukedom.

target: Allow me to continue.—I am a gentleman of Verona, sir, who, hearing of your daughter’s beauty and wit, her friendly disposition and bashful modesty, her uncommon virtues and her mild behavior, have taken the liberty of presenting myself as a guest at your house in the hope of seeing for myself if what I’ve heard is true.

orig: translate old to modern: Thus says my king: an if your father’s Highness Do not, in grant of all demands at large, Sweeten the bitter mock you sent his Majesty, He’ll call you to so hot an answer of it That caves and womby vaultages of France Shall chide your trespass and return your mock In second accent of his ordinance.
target: And my king goes on: if your royal father does not sweeten the bitter insult you sent my king and grant all our demands, Henry’s artillery will give you so resounding an answer that the very caves and vaulted cathedrals of France shall echo your mocking of him back in your face.

orig: translate old to modern: to choose love by another's eyes.

target: Do you like me, Kate?

target: But I don’t worry about being deceived because I don’t need to trust.

orig: translate old to modern: Unbutton here.

target: My friend Stephano, let them know, please, Within the house, that your mistress is at hand, And bring your music outside.

orig: translate old to modern: First, if all obstacles were cut away And that my path were even to the crown As the ripe revenue and due of birth, Yet so much is my poverty of spirit, So mighty and so many my defects, That I would rather hide me from my greatness, Being a bark to brook no mighty sea, Than in my greatness covet to be hid And in the vapor of my glory smothered.
target: First of all, even if all the obstacles were eliminated and my path led straight to the crown—if it were truly my birthright—I would rather hide from my greatness than hide inside the greatness of the position itself and be smothered by it.

orig: translate old to modern: Which now we find Each putter-out of five for one will bring us Good warrant of.
target: Now we find that One traveler out of five will bring us News about them.

orig: translate old to modern: It is determined, not concluded yet; But so it must be if the king miscarry.
target: Has it been decided that Richard will be  It’s been decided, though not yet officially announced.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, there was a crown offered him, and being offered him: he put it by with the back of his hand, thus, and then the people fell a-shouting.
target: Why, there was a crown offered to him, and when it was Offered to him, he pushed it away with the back of his hand, like this, And then the people started shouting.

orig: translate old to modern: a sweet woman!
target: A sweet woman!

orig: translate old to modern: The last she spake Was “Antony, most noble Antony!” Then in the midst a tearing groan did break The name of Antony.
target: Most noble Antony!” Then, as she was speaking your name, a strangled groan split her words.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, that he did.

target: I almost faint with fear.

target: He keeps tearing out his white hair, which the blindly raging winds catch up and blow away into nothingness.

target: How did you come to be the attack of this dreamer?

target: Go quickly—hurry—to the castle, for I’ve given orders to have Lear and Cordelia killed.

target: You torture me, Tubal: It was my turquoise ring; I got from Leah, my wife, when I was still single; I wouldn’t have traded it for a wilderness of monkeys.

orig: translate old to modern: She is importunate, indeed distract.
target: She is unfortunate, indeed deranged.

target: If you really are Sir Rowland’s son, as you’ve just whispered to me—and I can absolutely see the likeness in your face— you are truly welcome here.

target: OK. What’s the bet?

target: They commanded me to lock my doors and leave you out in this merciless storm, but I’ve come out here to find you and take you where there’s warmth and food.

target: And now, Laertes, what's the news with you?

target: Are my master and his wife coming, Grumio?

target: What's your gracious pleasure?

target: Therefore, my lord,— Damn it, what a waste he makes of his words!

orig: translate old to modern: Thou almost mak'st me waver in my faith, To hold opinion with Pythagoras, That souls of animals infuse themselves Into the trunks of men: thy currish spirit Govern'd a wolf, who, hang'd for human slaughter, Even from the gallows did his fell soul fleet, And, whilst thou lay'st in thy unhallow'd dam, Infus'd itself in thee; for thy desires Are wolvish, bloody, sterved, and ravenous.
target: Your dog-like spirit That must have been ruled by a wolf Hanged for killing a human, his evil soul Falling quickly even from the gallows, And, while you lay in your unholy mother, Sent itself into you, because your desires Are wolfish, bloody, starved, and hungry.

orig: translate old to modern: Thence we looked toward England And cited up a thousand fearful times, During the wars of York and Lancaster That had befall'n us.
target: Looking toward England, we reminisced about the countless frightening experiences we’d had in the wars between the Yorks and the Lancasters.

target: It is a creature That dotes on Cassio, as it is the whore's disease To trick many and be tricked by one.

target: I’m sorry about your daughter’s death, but I swear our accusations were true, and backed up with proof.

target: With this marriage, all the petty jealousies that now seem huge, and all the great fears that are dangerous in themselves, would disappear.

orig: translate old to modern: Signior Antonio, many a time and oft, In the Rialto you have rated me About my moneys, and my usances: Still have I borne it with a patient shrug, For sufferance is the badge of all our tribe: You call me,—misbeliever, cut-throat dog, And spet upon my Jewish gaberdine, And all for use of that which is mine own.
target: Mr. Antonio, many times and often In the Marketplace you have abused me About my monies and my interest rates; I still have taken it with a patient shrug, Because suffering is the badge of all our tribe; You call me misbeliever, cut-throat dog, And spat on my Jewish clothes, And all because of using of that which is my own.

orig: translate old to modern: Pretty soul!
target: Pretty soul!

orig: translate old to modern: He being thus lorded, Not only with what my revenue yielded, But what my power might else exact, like one Who having into truth, by telling of it, Made such a sinner of his memory To credit his own lie, he did believe He was indeed the duke; out o'th’ substitution, And executing the outward face of royalty With all prerogative; hence his ambition growing— Dost thou hear?
target: Playing the lord like that, Not only with what my money yielded, But also whatever else my power might get him,—like one Who having lied so often by telling it enough, Made his memory such a sinner that it gave Truth to his own lie,—he believed He was indeed the Duke, making substitution for me, And wearing the outward show of royalty, With all rights and privileges.—Here his ambition growing— Are you listening?

orig: translate old to modern: Oh, ’tish ill done, ’tish ill done, by my hand, ’tish ill done.
target: Oh, it’s a disaster, a disaster, by this hand, it’s a disaster.

orig: translate old to modern: What tidings can you tell me of my lord?
target: What news can you tell me of my lord?

target: Why are you telling me about robbing?

orig: translate old to modern: I know him well.
target: I know him well.

orig: translate old to modern: Fie, there is no such man; it is impossible.

target: Caesar, I have news about Menecrates and Menas, notorious pirates who prowl the sea in a variety of ships.

orig: translate old to modern: Harp on it still shall I till heart-strings break.
target: I will harp on it till my heartstrings break.

target: Welcome, my lord.

target: What's to be done?

target: There they launched us, To cry to the sea that roared at us, to sigh To the winds, whose pity, sighing back again, Only did us loving wrong.

orig: translate old to modern: I desire your more acquaintance, good Master Mustardseed.
target: I want to get to know you as well, good Master Mustardseed.

orig: translate old to modern: But hast thou yet latch'd the Athenian's eyes With the love-juice, as I did bid thee do?
target: But have you touched the Athenian's eyes With the love-juice yet, as I told you to?

target: Even by the rule of that knowledge By which I blamed Cato for his suicide— I don’t know why, But I think it’s cowardly and vile to take Your own life because of the fear of what might happen— Arming myself with the patience To wait for the help of some high powers That govern us here below.

orig: translate old to modern: Patience, gentle Audrey.
target: Be patient.

orig: translate old to modern: Now we speak upon our cue, and our voice is imperial.
target: Now the time is right for us to speak, and we do so with imperial authority.

orig: translate old to modern: Then go we in to know his embassy, Which I could with a ready guess declare Before the Frenchman speak a word of it.
target: Then let’s go in and hear what he has to say—though I think I can guess before the Frenchman has uttered a word.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, Catesby, what says his grace?
target: What’s up, Catesby, what does your master say?

orig: translate old to modern: tell not me of mercy;— This is the fool that lent out money gratis;— Gaoler, look to him.
target: Don’t tell me about mercy; This is the fool that lent out money for free: Jailer, look to him.

target: What!

target: You’re not too sharp, Casca, and those sparks of life That should be in a Roman, you want, Or else, you don’t use what you have.

orig: translate old to modern: Be not afraid of greatness.” 'Twas well writ.
target: Don’t be afraid of greatness.” That was well written.

orig: translate old to modern: too high to be enthrall'd to low.
target: I am too good to be in love with someone so low!

target: Lulla, lulla, lullaby; lulla, lulla, lullaby.

target: He is already named King; and gone to Scone To be invested.

target: Caesar, I will.

orig: translate old to modern: That shall you know hereafter.
target: You’ll know about that later.

target: What time is it?

orig: translate old to modern: It was about to speak, when the cock crew.
target: It was about to speak, when the rooster crowed.

orig: translate old to modern: What is your parentage?” “Above my fortunes, yet my state is well.
target: But I’m still fairly high-ranking.

target: Why have you become so rude?

target: What did he do to you?

orig: translate old to modern: How all occasions do inform against me And spur my dull revenge!
target: How every event works against me To spur my dull revenge!

orig: translate old to modern: That island of England breeds very valiant creatures.
target: That island of England breeds very valiant creatures.

orig: translate old to modern: Come you from old Bellario?
target: Give me your hand; do you come from old Bellario?

orig: translate old to modern: Know you not the cause?
target: Didn’t you know?

orig: translate old to modern: Run away, I pray you!
target: Run away, I beg you!

orig: translate old to modern: Makest thou this shame thy pastime?
target: Are you sitting around in this humiliation to amuse yourself?

orig: translate old to modern: Ourself will mingle with society And play the humble host.
target: We will mingle with these people, And play the humble host.

target: We know each other’s faces, but as for our thoughts, he doesn’t know any more about my thinking than I do about yours or his—or you do about mine.
