orig: translate old to modern: Answer every man directly.
target: Answer every man directly.

orig: translate old to modern: I will do't!
target: I’ll do it.

orig: translate old to modern: Infected be the air whereon they ride, And damn'd all those that trust them!
target: Let the air they ride on be infected And let all those that trust them be damned!

orig: translate old to modern: But let him come.
target: But let him come.

orig: translate old to modern: Before you can say ‘Come’ and ‘Go,’ And breathe twice and cry ‘So, so,’ Each one, tripping on his toe Will be here with mop and mow.
target: Before you can say, “Come” and “Go,” And breathe twice, and cry “so, so,” Each one, tripping on his toe, Will be here with tricks and pranks.

orig: translate old to modern: Prithee, put up.
target: Come on, put it away.

target: If either of you knows any secret reason why you two should not be joined in marriage, I order you on your souls to say so.

orig: translate old to modern: Here is the will, and under Caesar's seal.
target: Here is the will, and under Caesar's seal.

orig: translate old to modern: I think Alexander the Great was born in Macedon.
target: I think Alexander the Great was born in Macedon.

orig: translate old to modern: The mercy that was quick in us but late By your own counsel is suppressed and killed.
target: The mercy that was alive in me a moment ago was smothered and killed by your own advice.

orig: translate old to modern: Very well mended.
target: Nice save!

orig: translate old to modern: No port is free, no place That guard and most unusual vigilance Does not attend my taking.
target: Every town and port is crawling with henchmen on the lookout, waiting to capture me.

orig: translate old to modern: Her length of sickness, with what else more serious Importeth thee to know, this bears.
target: In this letter you’ll find details of her illness and other, more serious matters that concern you.

orig: translate old to modern: May I with right and conscience make this claim?
target: Can I justifiably and in good conscience make this claim?

orig: translate old to modern: Thou shalt not lose by it.
target: You won’t regret this.

orig: translate old to modern: Caesar's better parts Shall be crown'd in Brutus.
target: Caesar's better parts Shall be crowned in Brutus.

orig: translate old to modern: Night hangs upon mine eyes, my bones would rest That have but labor'd to attain this hour.
target: Night hangs on my eyes; my bones that have only Labored to attain this hour want to rest.

target: I see your own business needs you, And you take this opportunity to leave.

target: Draw your sword and get on your toes, because your assailant is quick, skillful, and deadly.

orig: translate old to modern: such bugs and goblins in my life, That on the supervise, no leisure bated, No, not to stay the grinding of the axe, My head should be struck off.
target: such ghosts and goblins in my life, That, on my arrival, without any delay, No, not even to wait for the grinding of the axe, My head should be chopped off.

orig: translate old to modern: Or else she could not have the wit to do this.
target: Right.

target: Hold, for your lives!

target: My lord, what is your will?

target: Goneril, are you coming with us?

target: Count Claudio, when do you plan to go to church and be married?

target: You mournful princes and grieving gentlemen who have been sharing this burden of grief, now it’s time to cheer each other up with love.

target: No, first let’s talk to him.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, there’s the villany.

orig: translate old to modern: What, household stuff?
target: What, like stuff from a house?

target: The wolves have finished preying for the night, and look—the gentle dawn is rising, dappling the sleepy eastern sky with spots of light.

orig: translate old to modern: Farewell.
target: Goodbye.

orig: translate old to modern: No doubt but he hath got a quiet catch.
target: There’s no doubt that Petruchio’s got quite a catch.

target: If this hadn’t been a gentlewoman, she should have been buried without a Christian burial.

orig: translate old to modern: Leave wringing of your hands.
target: Leave wringing of your hands.

target: Abandon the person that has abandoned himself.

orig: translate old to modern: I heard nothing.
target: I heard nothing.

target: By God, I’ll go after him again and beat him up.

target: But, pity the time!

orig: translate old to modern: My mind is changed.
target: I changed my mind.

target: And if it doesn’t go well, then you can keep her hidden in a nunnery, the best place for someone with her kind of dirtied reputation—away from the public’s eyes, tongues, mind, and insults.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, so we will.
target: We will.

orig: translate old to modern: I am afraid this great lubber, the world, will prove a cockney.
target: What an idiotic place this world is.

target: She speaks a lot about her father, she says she hears There are tricks in the world, and coughs, and beats her chest, Kicks enviously at nothing, says things in doubt That only make half sense.

target: Everything that glitters is not gold, Often have you heard that told; Many a man has sold his life Just to look at my outside: Gilded tombs wrap around worms.

orig: translate old to modern: How far is't call'd to Forres?
target: How far is it to the town of Forres?

target: I don’t know what I shall think of that; but I am Launcelot, the Jew's man, and I am sure Margery your wife is my mother.

orig: translate old to modern: I think he would not wish himself anywhere but where he is.
target: I don’t think he wants to be anywhere but where he is.

target: Men may sleep, and when they do they may have their throats with them, and some people say knives have blades.

target: Run off, go visit fairs and festivals!

target: Madam, although I’m saying it in front of you, You have a noble and a true understanding Of godlike friendship, which appears most strongly In your behaving like this in the absence of your lord.

orig: translate old to modern: King Lear hath lost, he and his daughter ta'en.
target: He and his daughter are captured.

orig: translate old to modern: Praised be God, and not our strength, for it!
target: God, not our strength, be praised!

target: On top of this, they’ve either burned or carried away everything that was in the king’s tent.

orig: translate old to modern: He, for his father’s sake, so loves the prince That he will not be won to aught against him.
target: Hastings loved the prince’s father so much that we won’t be able to persuade him to do anything against the prince.

orig: translate old to modern: One of them rates All that is won and lost.
target: One of your tears is worth everything that was won and lost.

target: I have promissory notes from Florence that I have to deliver.

target: I hate him because he is a Christian; But more, because, in his low simplicity, He lends out money free, and brings down The rate of interest with us here in Venice.

target: But here's my husband; And as much duty as my mother showed To you, preferring you before her father, So much I dispute that I may profess Due to the Moor, my lord.

target: God save you, sir!

target: Oh, you prophesied that the time would come when I would want your help in cursing that humpbacked spider, that hideous toad!

orig: translate old to modern: The gods forbid!
target: The gods forbid!

target: What if it tempts you toward the ocean, my lord, Or to the dreadful summit of the cliff That hangs so threateningly over his base into the sea, And once there, assumes some other horrible form Which might deprive you of the ability to think, And draw you into madness?

target: Exactly, madam, until I sleep with you.

target: Sweet remembrancer!

target: I feel this pinprick.

target: My words go up, my thoughts stay here below.

target: I now give my opinion: hold it no longer; this is no fish, but an islander, that has lately been struck by lightning.

target: A king, perhaps— My lord— How is it that the prophet didn’t tell me at the time that I would kill him?

orig: translate old to modern: Away!
target: Away!

target: No, by Our Lady, I’m not such a fool to think what I please, and I don’t please to think what I can, and in fact I cannot think, even if I could think my heart right past thinking, that you are in love or that you will be in love or even that you can be in love.

target: What's the news?

target: Ha!

target: Say when.

target: When I told you That I had nothing, I should have told you then That I had less than nothing, because indeed I have indebted myself to a dear friend, Indebted my friend to his notorious enemy, To feed my needs.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, get thee gone.
target: Well, you can go now.

orig: translate old to modern: She well instructs me.
target: She instructs me well.

orig: translate old to modern: Keep your purse.
target: Keep your money.

target: Henry the Sixth, crowned king of France and England while still in his infancy, succeeded him.

orig: translate old to modern: And she is exceeding wise.
target: And she is very smart.

orig: translate old to modern: The king’s a bawcock, and a heart of gold, A lad of life, an imp of fame, Of parents good, of fist most valiant.
target: The king’s a dear boy with a heart of gold, he’s a lively lad, a wag, born of fine parents, good with his fists.

orig: translate old to modern: What I should deny— As this I would, ay, though thou didst produce My very character—I’d turn it all To thy suggestion, plot, and damnèd practice.
target: I’d deny whatever evidence you had against me—even if it were in my own handwriting—and turn it all into evidence against you and your plans for treachery.

orig: translate old to modern: Now.
target: Now.

orig: translate old to modern: to Stephano] Lo, how he mocks me!
target: Look, how he mocks me!

orig: translate old to modern: Let sorrow split my heart if ever I Did hate thee or thy father.
target: I swear I never hated you or your father!

orig: translate old to modern: Friends, begone.
target: Friends, go.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou shouldst not have been old till thou hadst been wise.
target: You’re not supposed to get old until you’re wise.

orig: translate old to modern: I do entreat your Grace to pardon me.
target: I beg your grace to pardon me.

orig: translate old to modern: Good morrow, both.
target: Good morning to you both!

orig: translate old to modern: This were kindness.
target: This was kindness?

orig: translate old to modern: With this there grows In my most ill-composed affection such A stanchless avarice that, were I King, I should cut off the nobles for their lands, Desire his jewels and this other's house, And my more-having would be as a sauce To make me hunger more, that I should forge Quarrels unjust against the good and loyal, Destroying them for wealth.
target: With this there grows, In my most ill-composed affection, such A unbendable greed, that, if I were king, I should seize the nobles’ lands, Desire their jewels, and their houses, And my wanting to have more would be as a sauce To make me hunger more, that I should start Unfair quarrels against the good and loyal, Destroying them for wealth.

orig: translate old to modern: One minded like the weather, most unquietly.
target: Someone whose mood is as foul as the weather, very troubled.

target: The throng that follows Caesar at his heels, Of Senators, of Praetors, common suitors, Will crowd a feeble man almost to death.

orig: translate old to modern: I have a health for you.
target: I want to drink your health.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, what else?
target: What else?

target: They didn’t come by you?

target: I’ll smear my face with filth, put on a loincloth, make my hair matted and tangled, and face the bad weather wearing almost nothing.

orig: translate old to modern: Ye elves of hills, brooks, standing lakes and groves, And ye that on the sands with printless foot Do chase the ebbing Neptune and do fly him When he comes back; you demi-puppets that By moonshine do the green sour ringlets make, Whereof the ewe not bites, and you whose pastime Is to make midnight mushrooms, that rejoice To hear the solemn curfew; by whose aid, Weak masters though ye be, I have bedimmed The noontide sun, called forth the mutinous winds, And ’twixt the green sea and the azured vault Set roaring war—to the dread rattling thunder Have I given fire, and rifted Jove's stout oak With his own bolt; the strong-based promontory Have I made shake, and by the spurs plucked up The pine and cedar: graves at my command Have waked their sleepers, oped, and let ’em forth By my so potent art.
target: You elves of hills, brooks, standing lakes, and groves; And you that chase the ebbing ocean on the sands Without leaving a foot print, and run from him When he comes back; you half-puppets that Make the green ringlets sour by moonshine, Where the ewe doesn’t bite; and you whose pastime Is to make midnight mushrooms that are happy To hear the curfew sound; by whose aid,— Weak masters though you are,—I have dimmed The noontide sun, called the mutinous winds, And set roaring between the green sea and The blue sky: I haven given fire to the dreaded Rattling thunder, and split Jove's stout oak With his own lightning bolt: I have made the strong-based Land that stuck out into the ocean shake; and plucked up The pine and cedar by the roots: at my command, graves Have awakened the dead, opened the coffins, and Let them walk out by my so powerful magic.

orig: translate old to modern: Could you on this fair mountain leave to feed, And batten on this Moor?
target: Could you feed on this fair mountain, And glut yourself on this swamp?

orig: translate old to modern: I have it here about me.
target: I have it on me here.

orig: translate old to modern: But for his purpose in the coronation, I have not sounded him, nor he delivered His gracious pleasure any way therein.
target: I know he holds me dear, but I haven’t asked him about the coronation, and he hasn’t told me.

orig: translate old to modern: I do beseech your Grace, Let me the knowledge of my fault bear with me.
target: Please, your Grace, tell me what crime I have committed.

orig: translate old to modern: Sir, you and I must part, but that’s not it.
target: Sir, you and I must part company—no, that’s not it.

orig: translate old to modern: How dost thou, Benedick, the married man?
target: How does it feel to be Benedick the Married Man?

orig: translate old to modern: Hang there, my verse, in witness of my love.
target: Hang there on this tree, you lines of poetry, and bear witness to my love.

orig: translate old to modern: But for your husband, He is noble, wise, judicious, and best knows The fits o’ the season.
target: Your husband, Is noble, wise, judicious, and best knows What to do in these times.

orig: translate old to modern: You seem to understand me, By each at once her choppy finger laying Upon her skinny lips.
target: You seem to understand me, Since you each are laying a scrawny finger Upon your skinny lips.

orig: translate old to modern: I hope so.
target: I hope so.

orig: translate old to modern: No, he’s a yeoman that has a gentleman to his son, for he’s a mad yeoman that sees his son a gentleman before him.
target: No, he’s an ordinary guy who ’s got a gentleman for a son, since someone would have to be crazy to let his son become a gentleman before he’s achieved that distinction himself.

orig: translate old to modern: Only I have left to say, More is thy due than more than all can pay.
target: I can only say that You are due more than all of us can ever pay.

orig: translate old to modern: Good morrow, masters.
target: Good morning, gentlemen.

orig: translate old to modern: Pray, give me that; I'll carry it to the pile.
target: Please give me that; I'll carry it to the pile.

orig: translate old to modern: Or that there were such men Whose heads stood in their breasts?
target: Or that there were similar men Whose heads were in their chests?

orig: translate old to modern: That it should come to this!
target: That it should come to this!

orig: translate old to modern: Kind souls, what weep you when you but behold Our Caesar's vesture wounded?
target: Kind souls, what, do you weep when you only see Our Caesar's clothes wounded?

orig: translate old to modern: You will be schoolmaster And undertake the teaching of the maid: That’s your device.
target: You will pretend to be a schoolmaster and offer to teach the girl.

orig: translate old to modern: Fortune and victory sit on thy helm!
target: Let fortune and victory be yours!

orig: translate old to modern: Let him send no more— Unless perchance you come to me again To tell me how he takes it.
target: Tell him not to send any more messengers—unless you feel like coming back to tell me how he took the bad news.

orig: translate old to modern: She is herself a dowry.
target: She herself is as valuable as any dowry could ever be.

orig: translate old to modern: What, not a word?
target: What, not a word?

orig: translate old to modern: This is too long.
target: This is too long.

orig: translate old to modern: Madam!
target: Madam!

orig: translate old to modern: That is done, sir; they have all stomachs.
target: That is done, sir; they have all stomachs.

orig: translate old to modern: Yes, it is apparel.
target: Yes, it’s just clothing.

orig: translate old to modern: Signior Hortensio, ’twixt such friends as we Few words suffice.
target: Hortensio, good friends like us can get by on a few words.

orig: translate old to modern: No, my good lord.
target: No, my lord, that was me.

orig: translate old to modern: But mark, poor knight, What dreadful dole is here!
target: But mark,—poor knight, What dreadful sorrow is here!

orig: translate old to modern: Who lies i’ the second chamber?
target: Who’s in the second chamber?

orig: translate old to modern: An if they live, I hope I need not fear.
target: Well, I hope not.

orig: translate old to modern: Dies] [Dies] Moonshine and Lion are left to bury the dead.
target: Moonshine and lion are left to bury the dead.

orig: translate old to modern: I should make very forges of my cheeks, That would to cinders burn up modesty, Did I but speak thy deeds.
target: I should make very fires of my cheeks Burn modesty into ashes, If I only spoke your deeds.

orig: translate old to modern: Or does he walk?
target: Or is he walking?

orig: translate old to modern: Help!
target: Help!

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, do not quarrel with us, good old man.
target: Come on, don’t quarrel with us, good old man.

orig: translate old to modern: Which of these is he?
target: Which one is it?

orig: translate old to modern: Then how can it be said I am alone When all the world is here to look on me?
target: Then how can it be said I am alone When the entire world is here to look at me?

orig: translate old to modern: There is no love in you.
target: You don’t really love me.

orig: translate old to modern: Now I feed myself With most delicious poison.
target: I’m killing myself with this provocative speculation . . .

orig: translate old to modern: I now repent I told the pursuivant, As too triumphing, how mine enemies Today at Pomfret bloodily were butchered, And I myself secure in grace and favor.
target: And I regret having bragged to the messenger about how my enemies were being butchered at Pomfret while I, as I said, was in good standing with Richard.

orig: translate old to modern: I am boy to them all three, but all they three, though they would serve me, could not be man to me.
target: Yet not one among them, if all three were to wait on me, could be my “man,” because three such fakes don’t amount to a man.

orig: translate old to modern: Never.
target: Never.

orig: translate old to modern: And what confederacy have you with the traitors Late footed in the kingdom?
target: And what’s your connection with the traitors who landed in our kingdom recently?

orig: translate old to modern: You have loved him well; He hath not touch'd you yet.
target: You have loved him well; He hasn’t touched you yet.

orig: translate old to modern: It is not seen enough; you should wear it in your cap.
target: It doesn’t get seen enough; you should wear it in your cap, the way fools wear coxcombs.

orig: translate old to modern: We'll bring him to his house with shouts and clamors.
target: We'll bring him to his house with shouts and clamors.

orig: translate old to modern: Yet I fear him, For in the ingrafted love he bears to Caesar— Alas, good Cassius, do not think of him.
target: I still fear him, Because in the acquired love he bears to Caesar— Alas, good Cassius, don’t think of him.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, what’s the matter?
target: Why, what’s the matter with him?

orig: translate old to modern: I must prevent thee, Cimber.
target: I must stop you, Cimber.

orig: translate old to modern: Fair thoughts and happy hours attend on you!
target: Beautiful thoughts and happy hours attend on you!

orig: translate old to modern: She died, my lord, but whiles her slander lived.
target: She was only dead, my lord, as long as her slander lived.

orig: translate old to modern: None, but a holy hermit, and her maid.
target: No one but a holy hermit and her maid.

orig: translate old to modern: They in themselves, good-sooth, are too-too light.
target: They in themselves, to tell the truth, are as light as a flute.

orig: translate old to modern: Help, help, ho!
target: Help, help, ho!

orig: translate old to modern: Thank you.
target: Thank you.

orig: translate old to modern: Shall I go win my daughter to thy will?
target: Should I go convince my daughter to marry you?

orig: translate old to modern: Go, get thee gone, I say.
target: Get out of here, you measly, lying wretch.

orig: translate old to modern: We are the makers of manners, Kate, and the liberty that follows our places stops the mouth of all find- faults, as I will do yours for upholding the nice fashion of your country in denying me a kiss.
target: You and I, Kate, we are the makers of custom, and the freedom that goes with our position silences all who would criticize, as I will silence you for upholding the prudish custom of your country in refusing me a kiss.

orig: translate old to modern: Sure we thank you.
target: Thank you, I’m sure.

orig: translate old to modern: Shall we go see the relics of this town?
target: Should we go see the sights in the town?

orig: translate old to modern: O, fie upon them!
target: O, damn on them!

orig: translate old to modern: What to ourselves in passion we propose, The passion ending, doth the purpose lose.
target: What we promise ourselves in a fit of passion, When the passion ends, so does the promise.

orig: translate old to modern: How shall we find the concord of this discord?
target: How shall we find the concord of this discord?

orig: translate old to modern: Would Katherine had never seen him, though!
target: Maybe, but I wish I’d never laid eyes on him.

orig: translate old to modern: I have a suit to you.
target: I have to ask you something.

orig: translate old to modern: They call it Agincourt.
target: Agincourt.

orig: translate old to modern: I'll be thy second.
target: I'll be right behind you.

orig: translate old to modern: Look, my lord, it comes!
target: Look, my lord, it comes!

orig: translate old to modern: You have taken it wiselier than I meant you should.
target: You have taken it more seriously than I meant you to.

orig: translate old to modern: Blest pudding!
target: Blessed pudding!

orig: translate old to modern: Most certain.
target: It’s undeniable.

orig: translate old to modern: I know I can do it.
target: I know I can do it.

orig: translate old to modern: Sure, her offense Must be of such unnatural degree That monsters it (or your fore-vouched affection Fall into taint), which to believe of her Must be a faith that reason without miracle Could never plant in me.
target: But it’d take a miracle to make me believe she could do anything that horrible.

orig: translate old to modern: He, sir, that must marry this woman.
target: Why, the he that will marry this woman.

orig: translate old to modern: Fie, fie!
target: shame on you!, shame on you!!

orig: translate old to modern: Pray you, make haste.
target: I beg you, hurry.

orig: translate old to modern: And I have built Two chantries where the sad and solemn priests Sing still for Richard’s soul.
target: And I’ve built two chapels where solemn priests sing continually for Richard’s soul.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, but their sense is shut.
target: Yes, only she doesn’t see anything.

orig: translate old to modern: Keep thee warm.
target: Stay warm.

orig: translate old to modern: What's the matter, lady?
target: What's the matter, lady?

orig: translate old to modern: I saw it in his hand: It was a handkerchief, an antique token My father gave my mother.
target: It was a handkerchief, an antique token My father gave my mother.

orig: translate old to modern: What shall we do, Enobarbus?
target: What are we going to do, Enobarbus?

orig: translate old to modern: Adieu.
target: Good-bye.

orig: translate old to modern: Please it your Grace lead on?
target: If it pleases you, your highness, will you lead us all inside?

orig: translate old to modern: Where's your father?
target: Where's your father?

orig: translate old to modern: The time is free.
target: We are free.

orig: translate old to modern: Yea, art thou there?
target: Hey, are you there?

orig: translate old to modern: And then came Pyramus.
target: And here comes Pyramus.

orig: translate old to modern: Dost thou hear, Iago?
target: Do you hear me, Iago?

orig: translate old to modern: If not, to say to thee that I shall die is true, but for thy love, by the Lord, no.
target: If not, to tell you I will die is true, but not for love, by God.

orig: translate old to modern: Could he dig without arms?
target: Could he dig without arms?

orig: translate old to modern: Art thou aught else but place, degree, and form, Creating awe and fear in other men, Wherein thou art less happy, being feared, Than they in fearing?
target: You’re less happy, being feared, than they are in fearing you.

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll help you, Sir Toby, because we’ll be dressed together.
target: I’ll help you, Sir Toby.

orig: translate old to modern: What's your will?
target: What can I do for you?

orig: translate old to modern: Thou wouldst be great; Art not without ambition, but without The illness should attend it.
target: You could be great; You are not without ambition, only without The drive should usually goes with it.

orig: translate old to modern: She replied It should be better he became her guest, Which she entreated.
target: She replied by saying that it would be better for him to be her guest instead.

orig: translate old to modern: Alack, poor gentleman!
target: Oh, the poor man!

orig: translate old to modern: Since his Majesty went into the field, I have seen her rise from her bed, throw her nightgown upon her, unlock her closet, take forth paper, fold it, write upon't, read it, afterwards seal it, and again return to bed; yet all this while in a most fast sleep.
target: Since his majesty went into the field, I have seen her rise from her bed, throw her nightgown upon her, unlock her closet, take out paper, fold it, write upon it, read it, afterwards seal it, and again return to bed.

orig: translate old to modern: My curses on her!
target: I curse her.

orig: translate old to modern: Will it never be day?
target: Oh, will it never be day?

orig: translate old to modern: Look with thine ears.
target: Look with your ears.

orig: translate old to modern: The Queen, your mother, in most great affliction of spirit hath sent me to you.
target: The queen, your mother, in most great affliction of spirit, has sent me to you.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, and I trust I may go too, may I not?
target: I don’t think so!

orig: translate old to modern: To punish me for what you make me do Seems much unequal.
target: It’s not fair to punish me for something you make me do.

orig: translate old to modern: Have you come by night, And stolen my love's heart from him?
target: have you come by night, And stolen my love's heart from him?

orig: translate old to modern: I thank it.
target: I’m glad about that.

orig: translate old to modern: Vexed I am Of late with passions of some difference, Conceptions only proper to myself, Which give some soil perhaps to my behaviors; But let not therefore my good friends be grieved— Among which number, Cassius, be you one— Nor construe any further my neglect Than that poor Brutus with himself at war Forgets the shows of love to other men.
target: I’m annoyed lately With different passions, Ideas that only I can know, Which are perhaps seen in my behavior; But don’t let my good friends be upset— Cassius, you’re one of them— Or try to understand my indifference any further Than that poor Brutus, at war with himself, Forgets to show friendship to other men.

orig: translate old to modern: If Brutus will vouchsafe that Antony May safely come to him and be resolved How Caesar hath deserved to lie in death, Mark Antony shall not love Caesar dead So well as Brutus living, but will follow The fortunes and affairs of noble Brutus Thorough the hazards of this untrod state With all true faith.
target: If Brutus will guarantee that Antony May safely come to him and is ready to tell How Caesar deserved to die, Mark Antony shall love Brutus living Better than Caesar dead, and will follow The fortunes and affairs of noble Brutus with all true faith Thorough the hazards of this unconquered state.

orig: translate old to modern: I go, my lord.
target: I’m coming, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Confirmed, confirmed!
target: Then it’s confirmed!

orig: translate old to modern: I know into what straits of fortune she is driven, and it is not impossible to me, if it appear not inconvenient to you, to set her before your eyes tomorrow, human as she is, and without any danger.
target: I know where she is and, if you don’t mind, I will set her before you tomorrow, whole and unharmed.

orig: translate old to modern: There is tears for his love, joy for his fortune, honor for his valor, and death for his ambition.
target: There are tears for his love; joy for his fortune; honor for his valor, and death for his ambition.

orig: translate old to modern: If they’ll do neither, we will come to them And make them skirr away as swift as stones Enforcèd from the old Assyrian slings.
target: If they’ll do neither, we’ll come to them and make them fly like stones shot from powerful slings.

orig: translate old to modern: Of so high and plenteous wit and invention!
target: Of so high and full intelligence and imagination!

orig: translate old to modern: Regan, I think you are.
target: I believe you are, Regan.

orig: translate old to modern: You have broken The article of your oath, which you shall never Have tongue to charge me with.
target: You will never be able to say the same about me.

orig: translate old to modern: That the soul of our grandam might haply inhabit a bird.
target: That our grandmother’s soul could end up inhabiting a bird.

orig: translate old to modern: I saw him not.
target: I didn’t see him.

orig: translate old to modern: Madam, madam— Antonio’s dead!
target: Madam, madam— Antony’s dead!

orig: translate old to modern: Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you.
target: Buckingham, I need to have a word with you.

orig: translate old to modern: A contract of true love to celebrate; And some donation freely to estate On the blest lovers.
target: To celebrate a contract of true love, And to bestow some free gifts On the blessed lovers.

orig: translate old to modern: There’s nothing in her yet.
target: She doesn’t have anything going for her so far.

orig: translate old to modern: These evils thou repeat'st upon thyself Have banish'd me from Scotland.
target: These evils you repeat upon yourself Have banished me from Scotland.

orig: translate old to modern: I will tell you.
target: I’ll tell you.

orig: translate old to modern: Thus may we gather honey from the weed And make a moral of the devil himself.
target: Think like that, and you’ll manage to get honey out of a common weed and find a moral lesson in the devil himself.

orig: translate old to modern: The day, my friends, and all things stay for me.
target: The day, my friends, and everything await me.

orig: translate old to modern: O God!
target: Oh God!

orig: translate old to modern: As I have life and honor, there shall he sit till noon.
target: I swear on my life and honor, he’ll sit here in the stocks until noon.

orig: translate old to modern: swear?
target: swear?

orig: translate old to modern: If you shall send them word you will not come, Their minds may change.
target: If you send them word you’ll not come, They may change their minds.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, how dost thou look now?
target: Now, how do you look now?

orig: translate old to modern: Ho, Lucilius!
target: Oh, Lucilius!

orig: translate old to modern: Lysander, if you live, good sir, awake.
target: Lysander, if you live, good sir, wake up!

orig: translate old to modern: Do but encave yourself, And mark the fleers, the gibes, and notable scorns, That dwell in every region of his face; For I will make him tell the tale anew, Where, how, how oft, how long ago, and when He hath and is again to cope your wife: I say, but mark his gesture.
target: Only hide yourself, And mark the sneers, the taunts, and outstanding scorns, That dwell in every region of his face, Because I will make him tell the story as if it were new, About where, how, how often, how long ago, and when He has had, and is again to have, sex with your wife.

orig: translate old to modern: They shall have none, I swear, but these my joints, Which, if they have, as I will leave 'em them, Shall yield them little.
target: I swear the only ransom will be these bones of mine.

orig: translate old to modern: His countenance likes me not.
target: I don’t like his face.

orig: translate old to modern: I stand dishonored, that have gone about To link my dear friend to a common stale.
target: I’ve been dishonored: I arranged for a friend of mine to marry a common whore.

orig: translate old to modern: No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity.
target: Even the fiercest wild animal has some touch of pity.

orig: translate old to modern: I must catechise you for it, madonna.
target: I’ll have to ask you some questions, madam.

orig: translate old to modern: If you will see it, follow me.
target: If you want to watch, follow me.

orig: translate old to modern: I think he bought his doublet in Italy, his round hose in France, his bonnet in Germany and his behaviour everywhere.
target: I think he bought his shirt in Italy, his hose in France, his hat in Germany, and his behavior everywhere.

orig: translate old to modern: What, frighted with false fire?
target: What, frightened by false fire!

orig: translate old to modern: And I for Ganymede.
target: And like I am for Ganymede.

orig: translate old to modern: Reproach and everlasting shame Sits mocking in our plumes.
target: Regret and everlasting shame sit on our helmets, mocking us.

orig: translate old to modern: For there was never yet fair woman but she made mouths    in a glass.
target: For there never was a pretty woman who didn’t like to preen in the mirror.

orig: translate old to modern: I have already.
target: I have already.

orig: translate old to modern: Till noon?
target: Only until noon, my lord?

orig: translate old to modern: So that in these ten thousand they have lost, There are but sixteen hundred mercenaries.
target: Among the ten thousand the French have lost only sixteen hundred are mercenaries.

orig: translate old to modern: They say the owl was a baker's daughter.
target: They say the owl was a baker's daughter.

orig: translate old to modern: And to deal plainly I fear I am not in my perfect mind.
target: To put it plainly, I’m afraid I’m not quite sane.

orig: translate old to modern: Kent banished thus?
target: Kent’s been banished just like that?

orig: translate old to modern: Stars, my lord.
target: Stars, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Your worm is your only emperor for diet.
target: Your worm is your only emperor for diet.

orig: translate old to modern: My falcon now is sharp and passing empty, And, till she stoop, she must not be full-gorged, For then she never looks upon her lure.
target: My falcon is now hungry and unfed and must not be given enough to eat until she comes to me, for if her hunger is satisfied, she’ll pay no attention to the bait.

orig: translate old to modern: Edward Plantagenet, why art thou dead?
target: Edward Plantagenet, why are you dead?

orig: translate old to modern: Thanks for that.
target: Thanks for that.

orig: translate old to modern: Let them all come down.
target: Let all the soldiers come down.

orig: translate old to modern: Shall we go send them dinners and fresh suits, And give their fasting horses provender, And after fight with them?
target: Shall we go send them food and fresh clothing and feed their starving horses before we fight them?

orig: translate old to modern: All but mariners Plunged in the foaming brine and quit the vessel, Then all afire with me: the King's son Ferdinand, With hair up-staring—then like reeds, not hair— Was the first man that leapt, cried, ’Hell is empty, And all the devils are here.’ Why, that's my spirit!
target: All except the sailors Jumped in the foaming ocean and abandoned ship, Then I was all on fire: the King's son, Ferdinand, With hair standing up straight —then like reeds, not hair— Was the first man that jumped, crying “Hell is empty, And all the devils are here.” Why, that's my spirit!

orig: translate old to modern: most horrible!
target: Most horrible!

orig: translate old to modern: Thy brother by decree is banished.
target: Your brother is banished by decree.

orig: translate old to modern: Here.
target: Here.

orig: translate old to modern: If ever thou wilt thrive, bury my body.
target: I know you well.

orig: translate old to modern: But, good lieutenant, is your general wived?
target: But, good lieutenant, is your general married?

orig: translate old to modern: How now?
target: What’s the news!

orig: translate old to modern: I could do more to do Antonius good, But ’twould offend him, and in his offense Should my performance perish.
target: I could do more to help Antony, but to do so would insult him.

orig: translate old to modern: Poor men alone?
target: Only for poor men?

orig: translate old to modern: If you can, your reason?
target: Tell me why, if you can.

orig: translate old to modern: We are less afraid to be drowned than thou art.
target: Bastard, arrogant noisemaker, we’re less afraid to be drowned than you are.

orig: translate old to modern: You shall not go.
target: Listen to me: you shall not go.

orig: translate old to modern: When you are gentle, you shall have one too, And not till then.
target: When you are gentle, you shall have one, too, and not till then.

orig: translate old to modern: Are you a man?
target: Are you a man?

orig: translate old to modern: I know his heart.
target: I know how his mind works.

orig: translate old to modern: What’s the matter here?
target: What’s going on here?

orig: translate old to modern: For this same lord, I do repent; but heaven hath pleas'd it so, To punish me with this, and this with me, That I must be their scourge and minister.
target: I am sorry, but heaven has decided it to be this way, To punish me with this act, and punish this act with me, That I must be their whip and whip-er.

orig: translate old to modern: Have you done yet?
target: Are you done yet?

orig: translate old to modern: How goes it with my brave Mark Antony?
target: How does it go with my magnificent Mark Antony?

orig: translate old to modern: Hear you ought of her in yours?
target: Did you hear anything about her in yours?

orig: translate old to modern: What kind of god art thou, that suffer’st more Of mortal griefs than do thy worshippers?
target: What kind of god is ceremony, which suffers more than its worshippers do?

orig: translate old to modern: What then?
target: What then?

orig: translate old to modern: Unknit that threat'ning unkind brow And dart not scornful glances from those eyes To wound thy lord, thy king, thy governor.
target: This disrespectful stance toward the man who is your lord, your king, your governor tarnishes your beauty the way the frosts of winter blights the land.

orig: translate old to modern: In happy time.
target: In happy time.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, Desdemona, Once more well met at Cyprus.
target: Come, Desdemona, Once more happily brought to Cyprus.

orig: translate old to modern: But thou'rt too much my friend, And I’ll not wish thee to her.
target: But you’re too good a friend for me to wish her on you.

orig: translate old to modern: Let me speak proudly: tell the constable We are but warriors for the working day; Our gayness and our gilt are all besmirched With rainy marching in the painful field.
target: Let me speak proudly: tell the Constable we’re only workaday soldiers.

orig: translate old to modern: I took him sleeping,—that is finish'd too,— And the Athenian woman by his side; That, when he waked, of force she must be eyed.
target: I did it while he was sleeping,—that is finished too,— And the Athenian woman by his side, So that, when he woke up, she must, of course, be the first he saw.

orig: translate old to modern: Must I observe you?
target: Must I watch you?

orig: translate old to modern: So much for praising myself, who, I myself will bear witness, is praiseworthy.
target: That’s why I praise myself, who—if I do say so myself—is quite praiseworthy.

orig: translate old to modern: Here.
target: Here!

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll bear thy blame And take thy office from thee, on my peril.
target: Officer, I’ll take the responsibility from you, and the blame too.

orig: translate old to modern: But truly, for mine own part, if I were as tedious as a king, I could find it in my heart to bestow it all of your worship.
target: But truly, if I were as

orig: translate old to modern: You were best knock louder.
target: You’d better knock louder.

orig: translate old to modern: What, my young lady and mistress?
target: What, my young lady and mistress!

orig: translate old to modern: You love me not.
target: You’re not my friend.

orig: translate old to modern: I pray you, leave me.
target: Please, leave me alone.

orig: translate old to modern: Where is thy leather apron and thy rule?
target: Where is your leather apron and your ruler?

orig: translate old to modern: I have heard that Julius Caesar Grew fat with feasting there.
target: I heard that Julius Caesar got fat from all the feasting there.

orig: translate old to modern: Good friends, sweet friends, let me not stir you up To such a sudden flood of mutiny.

target: If he offers to choose, and chooses the right chest, you would be refusing to perform your father's will, if you refused to accept him.

orig: translate old to modern: I am sorry that I am deceived in him.
target: I am sorry that I was wrong about him.

target: As I was standing my watch upon the hill, I looked toward Birnam, and in a minute, I thought, The wood began to move.

target: I have looked on the world for twenty eight years, and since I could distinguish between a benefit and a disadvantage, I’ve never found man that knew how to love himself.

target: Ensign, go with them; you know the place best.

target: I know you.

orig: translate old to modern: Lend thy hand, And pluck my magic garment from me.—So: [Lays down his cloak] [Lays down his cloak] Lie there, my art.—Wipe thou thine eyes; have comfort.
target: Give me your hand, And take my magic cloak from me.—So: Lie there my magic.—Wipe your eyes; have comfort.

orig: translate old to modern: Where souls do couch on flowers, we’ll hand in hand, And with our sprightly port make the ghosts gaze.
target: In the place where souls recline on beds of flowers we’ll walk hand in hand and amaze the other ghosts with our spirited demeanor.

orig: translate old to modern: The world esteemed thy father honorable, But I did find him still mine enemy.
target: The whole world thought your father was an honorable man, but he was always my enemy.

orig: translate old to modern: Let me entreat you.
target: Goodbye to you all.

orig: translate old to modern: Doth not the day break here?
target: Doesn’t the day break here?

orig: translate old to modern: O mighty Caesar!
target: O mighty Caesar!

orig: translate old to modern: Thy reason, dear venom, give thy reason.
target: Why are you leaving, my angry friend?

orig: translate old to modern: Let him alone awhile.
target: Let him be for a bit.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, by this hand, I swear, I scorn the term, Nor shall my Nell keep lodgers.
target: I swear, I scorn the word.

orig: translate old to modern: Tie up the libertine in a field of feasts, Keep his brain fuming.
target: Keep this libertine occupied with endless debauchery.

orig: translate old to modern: We'll burn his body in the holy place And with the brands fire the traitors' houses.
target: We'll burn his body in the holy place, And we’ll set the traitors' houses on fire with the torches.

orig: translate old to modern: With this strange virtue He hath a heavenly gift of prophecy, And sundry blessings hang about his throne That speak him full of grace.
target: With this strange virtue, He has a heavenly gift of prophecy, And various blessings hang about his throne, That say he is full of grace.

orig: translate old to modern: Shylock, the world thinks, and I think so too, That thou but lead'st this fashion of thy malice To the last hour of act; and then, 'tis thought Thou'lt show thy mercy and remorse, more strange Than is thy strange apparent cruelty: And where thou now exact'st the penalty, (Which is a pound of this poor merchant's flesh,) Thou wilt not only loose the forfeiture, But, touch'd with human gentleness and love, Forgive a moiety of the principal; Glancing an eye of pity on his losses, That have of late so huddled on his back, Enough to press a royal merchant down, And pluck commiseration of his state From brassy bosoms, and rough hearts of flint, From stubborn Turks and Tartars, never train'd To offices of tender courtesy.
target: Shylock, the world thinks, and I think so too, That you only carry this kind of malice To the very last hour of action; and then, it’s thought, You'll show your mercy and remorse, more strangely Than your strange apparent cruelty is; And where you now exact the penalty,— Which is a pound of this poor merchant's flesh,— You will not only loose the default, But, touched with human gentleness and love, Forgive half of the borrowed amount, Glancing with an eye of pity on his losses, That have been so heaped on his back lately, Enough to press a royal merchant down, And get sympathy for his state From brassy bosoms and rough hearts of stone, From stubborn Turks and Tartars, never trained To uses of tender courtesy.

orig: translate old to modern: Let us rather Hold fast the mortal sword, and like good men Bestride our downfall'n birthdom.
target: Let us rather Stop the mortal sword quickly, and, like good men, Climb over our down-fallen country.

orig: translate old to modern: That by proscription and bills of outlawry Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus Have put to death an hundred senators.
target: That Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus Have put to death an hundred Senators By decrees of death and bills in defiance of the law.

orig: translate old to modern: Is ’t long or round?
target: Was it long or round?

orig: translate old to modern: I will not.
target: I will not.

target: Where are you all off to?

orig: translate old to modern: Bleed, bleed, poor country!
target: Bleed, bleed, poor country!

orig: translate old to modern: How long within this wood intend you stay?
target: How long do you intend to stay within this forest?

orig: translate old to modern: That.
target: Yes, that’s the one.

orig: translate old to modern: I dare damnation.
target: I dare damnation.

target: What good does heaven have in store that can do me any good now?

target: Yes, it’s William, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: The rest march on with me.
target: Everyone else, march on with me.

target: She seemed to be trying to control her emotions, which were overwhelming her.

orig: translate old to modern: Help, ho!
target: Help, ho!

orig: translate old to modern: Then the whining schoolboy with his satchel And shining morning face, creeping like snail Unwillingly to school.
target: Then he’s the whining schoolboy, with a book bag and a bright, young face, creeping like a snail unwillingly to school.

orig: translate old to modern: Ready.
target: Ready.

orig: translate old to modern: And at her late being here She gave strange oeillades and most speaking looks To noble Edmund.
target: And when she was here recently she flirted with Edmund and gave him significant glances.

orig: translate old to modern: My brother and thy uncle, called Antonio— I pray thee mark me, that a brother should Be so perfidious—he whom next thyself Of all the world I loved, and to him put The manage of my state; as at that time Through all the signories it was the first, And Prospero the prime duke, being so reputed In dignity, and for the liberal arts Without a parallel; those being all my study, The government I cast upon my brother, And to my state grew stranger, being transported And rapt in secret studies.
target: My brother and your uncle, called Antonio— Please, listen to me,—that a brother should Be so guilty of breaking a trust!—he, whom I loved in All the world, after you, and I let him Manage of my city, since, at that time, It was the first of all the cities, And Prospero the best duke, being considered so In dignity, and for the liberal arts, Without equal: since these two items took up all my time in study, I cast the government on my brother, And I became a stranger to my city, being absorbed And wrapped up in my secret studies.

orig: translate old to modern: Now attest That those whom you called fathers did beget you.
target: Prove that the men you call your fathers did truly conceive you.

orig: translate old to modern: This naughty man Shall face to face be brought to Margaret, Who I believe was packed in all this wrong, Hired to it by your brother.
target: This wicked man will be brought face to face with Margaret, who I believe was hired by Don John to take part in this plot.

orig: translate old to modern: So take her to thee, shepherd.
target: So take her, shepherd, and God bless you.

orig: translate old to modern: An now tell me, how doth your cousin?
target: But tell me, how is your cousin?

target: You’ve forgotten the will I told you of.

orig: translate old to modern: Oh!
target: Oh!

orig: translate old to modern: Do not deny.
target: Please don’t say no.

orig: translate old to modern: To every article.
target: In every detail.

target: Everyone knows where a wasp wears its stinger.

target: Have you ever cured anyone this way before?

orig: translate old to modern: Harder, harder.
target: Harder, harder.

orig: translate old to modern: He is not here.
target: But he isn’t here now.

orig: translate old to modern: Come, some music!
target: Come, some music!

target: What is the matter?

target: That’s uncivilized and unnatural!

target: Where do they live?

target: We'll not run, Monsieur monster.

target: Didn’t feel like it?

target: I’m telling you, this house is dark.

target: You mean a devil!

target: Now, whether or not he kills Cassio, Or Cassio him, or each do kill the other, I gain in every way.

target: Don’t you care about me?

target: Don’t insult my master’s generosity by killing yourself.

target: I hope that God restores you to health.

orig: translate old to modern: My lord.
target: Yes, my lord?

orig: translate old to modern: Roundly replied.
target: A very candid reply.

orig: translate old to modern: By this sword, I will.
target: By this sword, I will.

target: Oh, let me kiss This princess hand of pure white, this seal of bliss!

orig: translate old to modern: By 'r lady, I think it be so.
target: By our Lady, I think that’s true.

orig: translate old to modern: But all the story of the night told over, And all their minds transfigured so together, More witnesseth than fancy's images, And grows to something of great constancy, But howsoever strange and admirable.
target: But the whole story of the night told over, And all their minds changed all at the same time, Shows more witnesses than just images of the mind, And grows to something of great lasting; But, nevertheless, strange and admirable.

orig: translate old to modern: What means this lady?
target: What’s she trying to say?

orig: translate old to modern: Thou sure and firm-set earth, Hear not my steps, which way they walk, for fear Thy very stones prate of my whereabout, And take the present horror from the time, Which now suits with it.
target: Sure and firm-set earth, Don’t hear my steps, which ever way they walk, for fear Your very stones disclose my whereabouts, And take the current horror from the time, Which now suits it.

orig: translate old to modern: I doubt not but his friends will turn to us.
target: I suspect his friends will join us.

target: I would do a lot To reconcile them, for the love I bear to Cassio.

target: The King never Sighed by himself, but with the whole country’s groan.

orig: translate old to modern: out, cur!

orig: translate old to modern: Madam, with all my heart.
target: And  Madam, with all my heart.

target: Get up.

target: Exchange forgiveness with me, noble Hamlet.

target: And will he not come again?

target: And yet it is almost against my conscience.

target: Ever since Cordelia left for France, sir, the fool has been depressed.

target: Are there scales here to weigh The flesh?

target: murder!

target: Marry her as you should have married her cousin, and I will let my revenge die.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, then may you leave a casement of the great chamber window, where we play, open; and the moon may shine in at the casement.
target: Why, then may you leave a panel of the great chamber-window, where we play, open; and the moon may shine in at that panel.

orig: translate old to modern: I had rather be a dog, and bay the moon, Than such a Roman.
target: I had rather be a dog, and howl the moon, Than be such a Roman.

orig: translate old to modern: Lo, where it comes again!
target: Look where it comes again!

orig: translate old to modern: It is just so high as it is, and moves with its own organs.
target: It is only as high as it is and moves with its own legs.

target: No, a woman’s gentle brain could never have come up with such crude expressions and even harsher meanings.

orig: translate old to modern: I have seen nothing.
target: I haven’t seen anything.

target: Her father loved me, often invited me; Still questioned me the story of my life, From year to year, the battles, sieges, fortunes, That I have been in.

target: Here comes young Mr. Ganymede, my new mistress’s brother.

target: O Banquo, Banquo!

target: They

orig: translate old to modern: And I, of ladies most deject and wretched, That suck'd the honey of his music vows, Now see that noble and most sovereign reason, Like sweet bells jangled, out of tune and harsh; That unmatch'd form and feature of blown youth Blasted with ecstasy.
target: And I of all ladies most dejected and wretched That has tasted the honey of his musical vows, Now see that noble and most royal mind, Like sweet bells jangling, out of tune and harsh to hear, That form and feature of blown youth without equal Totally crazy.

target: Valiant Othello, we must straight send you Against the general enemy Ottoman.

target: Do you think that I’m no stronger than my sex, Being so fathered and so married?

orig: translate old to modern: Why, I am sorry for thee, gentle Silvius.
target: Well, I’m sorry for you, gentle Silvius.

orig: translate old to modern: is't gone?
target: Is it gone?

target: Goodbye.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, march we on, To give obedience where ’tis truly owed.
target: Well, we march on, To give obedience where it is truly owed.

target: He has distinguished himself as a great soldier in his own right, deserving more than any honor your can bestow on him.

orig: translate old to modern: A hundred then.
target: A hundred then.

orig: translate old to modern: She’s dead, my Queen.
target: She’s dead, my Queen.

target: I should be ridiculed if I were offended so easily—and laughed at even more for speaking of you disrespectfully, when I had no reason to speak of you at all.

target: But sir, have you married my daughter without my consent?

orig: translate old to modern: A thousand thousand!
target: A thousand thousand!

orig: translate old to modern: Well praised!
target: Well praised!

target: I’ll stay in Messina until you’re married, and then I’ll go to Aragon.

orig: translate old to modern: I am satisfied in nature, Whose motive in this case should stir me most To my revenge.
target: I am satisfied in nature, Whose motive, in this case, should move me the most To my revenge.

orig: translate old to modern: Something of moment then.
target: Something of the moment, then.

orig: translate old to modern: Tush, tush, man, never fleer and jest at me.
target: Damn you, don’t mock and sneer at me.

orig: translate old to modern: I talked with no man at that hour, my lord.
target: I wasn’t talking to any man at that time, my lord.

target: Hurry.—Oh, love, if you could only watch the battle today and see how expert I am at my craft.

orig: translate old to modern: Then belike my children shall have no names.
target: Then my children will probably be illegitimate.

target: You haven’t got dreams or fantasies Which busy care draws in the brains of men.

target: Isn’t that him heading this way?

target: murder!

target: What I can do, I will; and I will do as much more Than I dare do for myself.

target: I must go attend Caesar.

orig: translate old to modern: We will greet the time.
target: We’ll be ready when the time comes.

target: I’ll kiss your hand, and with that I leave you.

target: Whisper to her that Ursula and I are walking in the orchard and that we’re talking all about her.

orig: translate old to modern: Sport?
target: Sport?

orig: translate old to modern: But well and free, If thou so yield him, there is gold, and here My bluest veins to kiss—a hand that kings Have lipped, and trembled kissing.
target: Kings have trembled to kiss this hand.

orig: translate old to modern: I spoke with some of the sailors that escaped the wrack.
target: I spoke with some of the sailors that escaped the wreck.

orig: translate old to modern: This is not yet an Alexandrian feast.
target: This hasn’t reached the level of an Egyptian feast yet.

orig: translate old to modern: The earth sings when he touches it.
target: The earth sings when he touches it.

target: So, please, my lord, don’t assume that I’m treacherous just because I’m poor, with no titles to my name.

orig: translate old to modern: To have no man come over me!
target: You certainly deserve it.

orig: translate old to modern: Commend me to him and tell him I will not fail him at supper, for indeed he hath made great preparation.
target: Give him my respects, and tell him I’ll definitely be there for dinner, since I know he has gone to great lengths for this meal.

target: Othello?

target: Take that, and that.

target: Is this the finest of his fine art, and the seizure of his house seizures, to have his fine pate full of fine dirt?

orig: translate old to modern: I come to fetch you to the Senate-house.
target: I come to go get you to the Senate-house.

target: I became his guide, I led him and begged for him, and kept him from suicide.

orig: translate old to modern: And an ill singer, my lord.
target: And a bad singer, my lord.

target: You’ll be sorry later, but it’ll be too late.

target: Hold off your hands.

orig: translate old to modern: Spit, fire!

target: Let me shake your hand, Salanio.

target: First go with me to church and marry me, And then go away to Venice to your friend; Because you shall never lie by Portia's side With an uneasy soul.

orig: translate old to modern: The King comes here tonight.
target: The king comes here tonight.

orig: translate old to modern: Damn them then, If ever mortal eyes do see them bolster More than their own!
target: Damn them then, If ever mortal eyes see them in any bed Other than their own!

orig: translate old to modern: That’s a degree to love.
target: That’s a step in the direction of love.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis time I should inform thee farther.
target: It is time I should tell you more.

target: She is Ten times more gentle than her crabby father, And he's made of harshness.

orig: translate old to modern: On him I lay what you would lay on me, The right and fortune of his happy stars, Which God defend that I should wring from him.
target: God forbid that I snatch the crown from him.

orig: translate old to modern: Approach, rich Ceres, her to entertain.
target: Approach, rich Ceres, to entertain her.

orig: translate old to modern: If I lose a scruple of this sport, let me be boiled to death with melancholy.
target: If I miss this, let me be boiled alive.

orig: translate old to modern: Yield, or thou diest.
target: Yield, or you die.

orig: translate old to modern: There’s my hand.
target: Here’s my hand.

orig: translate old to modern: Wilt thou be lord of the whole world?
target: Would you like to be king of the entire world?

orig: translate old to modern: I have told him, Lepidus was grown too cruel, That he his high authority abused And did deserve his change.
target: I answered that Lepidus had become too brutal and abused his position.

orig: translate old to modern: This night.
target: This night.

orig: translate old to modern: He is unqualitied with very shame.
target: He’s not himself because he feels so ashamed.

target: Assemble our squadrons on the other side of the hill, in sight of Caesar’s navy.

orig: translate old to modern: Make the doors upon a woman’s wit, and it will out at the casement.
target: If you close the doors on a woman’s wit, it’ll fly out the window.

orig: translate old to modern: It is meat and drink to me to see a clown.
target: It warms my heart to encounter such a country bumpkin.

target: My lord shall never rest; I'll watch him calmly, and talk him out of patience; His bed shall seem like a school, his meals a confessional; I'll intermingle everything he does With Cassio's suit.

orig: translate old to modern: Whose tongue?
target: Whose tongue?

orig: translate old to modern: Tis false.
target: It’s not true.

orig: translate old to modern: And liegemen to the Dane.

target: But how wonderful that she should be so fond of Signior Benedick, whom she has always appeared to hate.

orig: translate old to modern: Will you be prick'd in number of our friends, Or shall we on, and not depend on you?
target: Will you be counted in the number of our friends, Or shall we go on and not depend on you?

orig: translate old to modern: My language!
target: My language!

orig: translate old to modern: What might you think?
target: What else could you possibly think of me?

orig: translate old to modern: I find you passing gentle.
target: I find you quite gentle.

orig: translate old to modern: Big Mars seems bankrupt in their beggared host And faintly through a rusty beaver peeps.
target: The horsemen stand frozen like candlesticks, torches in their hands.

target: Does that necessarily mean you should love his son?

orig: translate old to modern: Now die, die, die, die, die.
target: Now die, die, die, die, die.

orig: translate old to modern: This is most brave, That I, the son of a dear father murder'd, Prompted to my revenge by heaven and hell, Must, like a whore, unpack my heart with words And fall a-cursing like a very drab, A scullion!
target: This is most brave, That I, the son of a dear father murdered, Prompted to my revenge by heaven and hell, Must, like a whore, release the content of my heart with words, and fall down cursing like a very drab, Menial servant in the kitchen!

orig: translate old to modern: I pray you, what thinks he of our estate?
target: Tell me, what does he think of our situation?

orig: translate old to modern: I am he.
target: I am Benedick.

orig: translate old to modern: You all do know this mantle.
target: You all know this cloak.

orig: translate old to modern: You are resolute, then?
target: You’ve made up your mind, then?

orig: translate old to modern: The sun will not be seen today.
target: The sun will not appear today.

orig: translate old to modern: They have letters for him.
target: They have letters for him.

orig: translate old to modern: Happy is your Grace, That can translate the stubbornness of fortune Into so quiet and so sweet a style.
target: It bothers me, though, that these poor spotted innocents, who, after all, are this deserted city’s native citizens, should be gouged with arrows.

orig: translate old to modern: I could find in my heart to beat him— Come, kiss.
target: I could find it in my heart to beat him,— Come, kiss.

target: Now you have only the memory of what you were, which tortures you when you consider what you’ve become.

target: Their understanding Begins to increase, and the approaching tide of understanding Will shortly fill the reasonable shores of their minds That are now corrupt and muddy.

target: That will never be.

target: Well.— Now come, my Ariel!

target: will she still love him for chattering?

target: But what about Cicero?

target: On what compulsion must I?

target: Stop there!

target: I always pray for them

target: If the Turkish fleet is not Sheltered and in a bay, they are drowned; It is impossible to wait it out.

target: I’m going to make you a rich man.

target: I’ll look for him and secretly help him.

target: Don’t you hope your children shall be kings, When those things that gave the Baron of Cawdor to me Promised no less to your children?

target: I will catch up with you, Cleopatra, and weep for your forgiveness.

target: A thin face, which you don’t have; a sleepless, sunken eye, which you don’t have; an irritable temper, which you don’t have; a neglected beard, which you don’t have—but that might not be so telling, since you don’t have much beard anyway.

target: Fathers, from now on don’t believe you can know your daughters' minds from the way you see them act.

target: Until the day we die, my lord.

target: Pooh!

target: No, my Brutus; You’ve got some sick worry on your mind, Which, by the right and virtue of my place, I ought to know of, and, on my knees, I order you, by my once commended beauty, By all your vows of love, and that marriage vow Which joined us and made us one, That you tell me, yourself, your half of me, Why you’re so depressed, and what men Have come to you tonight, because there have been Some six or seven here, who hid their faces Even from darkness.
