orig: translate old to modern: Not a word.
target: Not a word.

orig: translate old to modern: O heaven!
target: O heaven!

orig: translate old to modern: What, not a whore?
target: What, not a whore?

orig: translate old to modern: Dead?
target: Dead?

orig: translate old to modern: He that will think to live till he be old, Give me some help!
target: Oh, help me, anyone who wants to live long!

orig: translate old to modern: There is a play tonight before the King.
target: There is a play tonight before the king.

orig: translate old to modern: Foul whisperings are abroad.
target: Disgustingly filthy rumors are circulating.

orig: translate old to modern: If it please you to dine with us.
target: If it pleases you to dine with us.

orig: translate old to modern: Be assured you may.
target: Be assured you may.

orig: translate old to modern: My leg is cut in two.
target: My leg is cut in two.

orig: translate old to modern: Gentlemen, you are welcome to Elsinore.
target: Gentlemen, you are welcome to Elsinore.

orig: translate old to modern: That’s not so good.
target: That’s not in her favor.

orig: translate old to modern: Prepare you, generals.
target: Prepare yourselves, generals.

orig: translate old to modern: He says so.
target: That’s what he says.

orig: translate old to modern: Or is your gold and silver ewes and rams?
target: Or is your gold and silver ewes and rams?

orig: translate old to modern: Com’st thou again for ransom?
target: Are you coming again for ransom?

orig: translate old to modern: Tis done already, and the messenger gone.
target: It has been done already, and the messenger is on his way.

orig: translate old to modern: Things must be as they may.
target: Things are what they are.

orig: translate old to modern: You must not put another scandal on him, That he is open to incontinency.
target: You must not put another scandal on him, That he is open to inconstancy.

orig: translate old to modern: Why ever wast thou lovely in my eyes?
target: Why did you once seem lovely to me?

orig: translate old to modern: Thou art The armorer of my heart.
target: You armor my heart.

orig: translate old to modern: His eyes were set at eight i' the morning.
target: His eyes started glazing over around eight in the morning.

orig: translate old to modern: Part them!
target: Part them.

orig: translate old to modern: We are spoiled and yonder he is!
target: There he is!

orig: translate old to modern: Tis but one cast away, and so, come, death.
target: So, take me, death!

orig: translate old to modern: Eight score eight hours?
target: One hundred sixty-eight hours?

orig: translate old to modern: Very vilely in the morning, when he is sober; and most vilely in the afternoon, when he is drunk: when he is best, he is a little worse than a man; and when he is worst, he is little better than a beast: and the worst fall that ever fell, I hope I shall make shift to go without him.
target: Very disgusting in the morning when he is sober, and most disgusting in the afternoon when he is drunk: when he is best, he is a little worse than a man, and when he is worst, he is little better than a beast.

orig: translate old to modern: Very easily possible.
target: It’s entirely possible.

orig: translate old to modern: Do this suddenly, And let not search and inquisition quail To bring again these foolish runaways.
target: Do this immediately, and don’t stop searching and interrogating until you’ve brought home these foolish runaways.

orig: translate old to modern: Tomorrow will it please you to be crowned?
target: Will you be crowned tomorrow?

orig: translate old to modern: Return you to my sister.
target: Go back to my sister’s.

orig: translate old to modern: Why then, your uncle and the Prince and Claudio Have been deceived.
target: Well then, your uncle and the Prince and Claudio have been deceived.

orig: translate old to modern: O madam, my old heart is cracked, it’s cracked.
target: Oh, madam, my old heart is broken, broken.

orig: translate old to modern: Twas where you wooed the gentlewoman so well.
target: It was the play in which you wooed the gentlewoman so successfully.

orig: translate old to modern: Here’s snip and nip and cut and slish and slash, Like to a censer in a barber’s shop.
target: Snip and snip and cut and slash—it’s got more holes than a sieve!

orig: translate old to modern: And let us do it with no show of fear, No, with no more than if we heard that England Were busied with a Whitsun morris-dance.
target: Let’s do it with no show of anxiety—no, with no more fear than if we’d heard that the English were busying themselves with folk dancing.

orig: translate old to modern: What stay had we but Clarence?
target: What support did we have besides our father?

orig: translate old to modern: Is she not a modest young lady?
target: Isn’t she a well-mannered young lady?

orig: translate old to modern: Once more, what news?
target: Once again, what’s the news?

orig: translate old to modern: Good madam, keep yourself within yourself.
target: Good madam, restrain yourself.

orig: translate old to modern: God keep your Worship!
target: God bless your Worship!

orig: translate old to modern: O heavens!
target: O heavens!

orig: translate old to modern: Then show it me.
target: Show me.

orig: translate old to modern: O, once tell true; tell true, even for my sake!
target: For once tell the truth; tell the truth, even for my sake.

orig: translate old to modern: I do not in position Distinctly speak of her; though I may fear, Her will, recoiling to her better judgement, May fall to match you with her country forms, And happily repent.
target: I don’t have the position To speak knowingly of her; although I may fear, Her will, rebelling against her better judgment, May decide to match you with her countrymen, And happily repent her ways.

orig: translate old to modern: It nothing ill becomes thee.— Aboard my galley I invite you all.
target: I invite you all aboard my ship.

orig: translate old to modern: In cunning I must draw my sword upon you.
target: I have to pretend to threaten you with my sword.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, sir, cobble you.
target: Yes, sir, mend you.

orig: translate old to modern: How hath your lordship brooked imprisonment?
target: How did you tolerate prison?

orig: translate old to modern: Music!
target: Music!

orig: translate old to modern: Ay my lord, So you will not o'errule me to a peace.
target: Yes, my lord, Just as long as you don’t ask me to forget about it.

orig: translate old to modern: I did not think, sir, to have met you here.
target: I didn’t think I would see you here.

orig: translate old to modern: Therefore, great King, We yield our town and lives to thy soft mercy.
target: Therefore, great king, we surrender our town and lives to your kind mercy.

orig: translate old to modern: Antonio, I arrest thee at the suit of Count Orsino.
target: Antonio, you’re under arrest on the orders of Count Orsino.

orig: translate old to modern: We therefore have great cause of thankfulness And shall forget the office of our hand Sooner than quittance of desert and merit According to the weight and worthiness.
target: Yes, I have great cause to be thankful.

orig: translate old to modern: My young remembrance cannot parallel A fellow to it.
target: I can’t remember there being another Like it.

orig: translate old to modern: The devil speaks in him.
target: The devil speaks in him.

orig: translate old to modern: I knew you at the first You were a moveable.
target: I had you figured for a piece of furniture.

orig: translate old to modern: Fairies, skip hence; I have forsworn his bed and company.
target: Fairies, let’s go; I have sworn not to go to his bed or to keep his company.

orig: translate old to modern: Go thrust him out at gates, and let him smell His way to Dover.
target: He can sniff his way to Dover.

orig: translate old to modern: What, the fair Ophelia?
target: What, the fair Ophelia?

orig: translate old to modern: Conceit upon her father.
target: Thinking on her father.

orig: translate old to modern: Sweet, adieu!
target: Sweetheart, goodbye!

orig: translate old to modern: I promise you your kindred hath made my eyes water ere now.
target: I promise you your relatives have made my eyes water before now.

orig: translate old to modern: Of her society Be not afraid.
target: Don’t be afraid Of her company.

orig: translate old to modern: Welcome, good friends.
target: Welcome, good friends.

orig: translate old to modern: O worthiest cousin!
target: O worthiest cousin!

orig: translate old to modern: I cry you mercy.
target: I be your mercy.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, and wisely.
target: Yes, and wisely.

orig: translate old to modern: And in good time, Here comes Sir Richard Ratcliffe and the duke.
target: And just in time, here he comes with Sir Richard Ratcliffe.

orig: translate old to modern: We should have met you By sea and land, supplying every stage With an augmented greeting.
target: I would have met you by sea and again by land.

orig: translate old to modern: Go, go, good countrymen, and, for this fault, Assemble all the poor men of your sort, Draw them to Tiber banks, and weep your tears Into the channel, till the lowest stream Do kiss the most exalted shores of all.
target: Go, go, good countrymen, and, for this mistake, Get all the poor men like you together, Bring them to the Tiber River’s banks and weep your tears Into the water, until the lowest stream Floods the highest shores of heaven.

orig: translate old to modern: What, will you not suffer me?
target: You mean you don’t even want to hear my side?

orig: translate old to modern: Why, farewell, Portia.
target: Why, goodbye, Portia.

orig: translate old to modern: What would you say to me now, an I were your very, very Rosalind?
target: What would you say to me now if I really were your precious little Rosalind?

orig: translate old to modern: They have made him drink alms-drink.
target: They made him drink the leftover wine usually given to the poor.

orig: translate old to modern: I see you do not mean to part with her, Or else you like not of my company.
target: I see you don’t intend to part with her—or perhaps you don’t like my company.

orig: translate old to modern: So I am—to let him live.
target: I am resolved—to let him live.

orig: translate old to modern: When valor preys on reason, It eats the sword it fights with.
target: When courage consumes reason, it destroys its only weapon.

orig: translate old to modern: The selfsame name, but one of better nature.
target: Someone else has the same name, but he’s a better man.

orig: translate old to modern: Lie thou there (throwing down a letter), for here comes the trout that must be caught with tickling.
target: Now, you lie there on the path.

orig: translate old to modern: Because my name is George.
target: Because my name is George.

orig: translate old to modern: I do believe that these applauses are For some new honors that are heap'd on Caesar.
target: I believe that this applause is For some new honors that are to be heaped on Caesar.

orig: translate old to modern: not yet quite dead?
target: Not yet quite dead?

orig: translate old to modern: Didst thou not hear somebody?
target: But don’t you see what a    Did you hear someone?

orig: translate old to modern: Farewell, thou woeful welcomer of glory.
target: Goodbye.

orig: translate old to modern: He is a god and knows What is most right.
target: He is like a god and knows the truth.

orig: translate old to modern: What is he at the gate, cousin?
target: Who’s that at the gate, uncle?

orig: translate old to modern: Remember First to possess his books, for without them He's but a sot, as I am, nor hath not One spirit to command—they all do hate him As rootedly as I.
target: Remember To possess his books first, because, without them, He's only a fool, as I am, and hasn’t One spirit to command: they all hate him As deeply as I do.

orig: translate old to modern: Who does it, then?
target: Who does it, then?

orig: translate old to modern: Discuss unto me: art thou officer or art thou base, common, and popular?
target: Or are you low, vulgar, and of the common people?

orig: translate old to modern: And when was he wont to wash his face?
target: And when has he ever been known to wash his face?

orig: translate old to modern: True, madam; he, of all the men that ever my foolish eyes looked upon, was the best deserving a fair lady.
target: True, madam; he, that, of all the men that I have ever seen with my foolish eyes, was the most deserving of a beautiful lady.

orig: translate old to modern: The dead man's knell Is there scarce ask'd for who, and good men's lives Expire before the flowers in their caps, Dying or ere they sicken.
target: No one hardly asks who The dead man's knell is for, and good men's lives Expire before the flowers in their caps, Dying before the flowers show signs of sickness.

orig: translate old to modern: What, in my sight?—Bianca, get thee in.
target: What, in my presence?

orig: translate old to modern: Lie they upon thy hand And be undone by ’em!
target: Let it stay in your inventory until it bankrupts you.

orig: translate old to modern: Rather make My country’s high pyramides my gibbet And hang me up in chains!
target: I’d rather be hung in chains from one of our pyramids!

orig: translate old to modern: O, that a man might know The end of this day's business ere it come!
target: O, that a man might know How today's business ends before it comes!

orig: translate old to modern: Go, Hercules!
target: Go, Hercules!

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, when the special thing is well obtained, That is, her love, for that is all in all.
target: That counts for everything.

orig: translate old to modern: But art not thou thyself giddy with the fashion too, that thou hast shifted out of thy tale into telling me of the fashion?
target: But you’re all wound up about fashion, too.

orig: translate old to modern: First, Pyramus must draw a sword to kill himself; which the ladies cannot abide.
target: First, Pyramus must draw a sword to kill himself, which the ladies cannot stand.

orig: translate old to modern: Do you know, sirrah, where Lieutenant Cassio lies?
target: Do you know, servant, where Lieutenant Cassio lies?

orig: translate old to modern: Your reasons are too shallow and too quick.
target: Your answers are too shallow and too hasty.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, I know not What counts harsh Fortune casts upon my face, But in my bosom shall she never come To make my heart her vassal.
target: Well, I cannot tell how my difficult life has weathered my face, but I will never let those difficulties subdue my courage.

orig: translate old to modern: We must incline to the king.
target: We have to take the king’s side.

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll wait upon your Lordship.
target: I’ll follow you, my lord.

orig: translate old to modern: Nature wants stuff To vie strange forms with fancy, yet t’ imagine An Antony were nature’s piece ’gainst fancy, Condemning shadows quite.
target: Antony would easily outshine all imaginary beings.

orig: translate old to modern: What's the matter, lieutenant?
target: What's the matter, lieutenant?

orig: translate old to modern: What cares these roarers for the name of the king?
target: What do these noisy storms care about the name of king?

orig: translate old to modern: Rosalind of a better leer than you.
target: Come on, woo me, woo me.

orig: translate old to modern: You shall hear me.
target: You will listen to me.

orig: translate old to modern: Against my will, I am sent to bid you come in to dinner.
target: Against my will, I’ve been told to bring you in to dinner.

orig: translate old to modern: Let them come in.
target: Let them in.

orig: translate old to modern: Portia, what mean you?
target: Portia, what are you doing?

orig: translate old to modern: My lord, my lord!
target: My lord, my lord!

orig: translate old to modern: I have heard him read many lectures against it, and I thank God I am not a woman, to be touched with so many giddy offenses as he hath generally taxed their whole sex withal.
target: Thank God I’m not a woman and afflicted with all the giddiness that troubles that entire sex.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis strange.
target: It’s very strange.

orig: translate old to modern: Are you a suitor to the maid you talk of, yea or no?
target: Are you a suitor to the girl we speak of, yes or no?

orig: translate old to modern: How likes Gremio these quick-witted folks?
target: What do you think of these quick-witted folks, Gremio?

orig: translate old to modern: I am no strumpet, but of life as honest As you that thus abuse me.
target: I am no prostitute, but have life as honest As you that abuse me like this.

orig: translate old to modern: I cannot live to hear the news from England, But I do prophesy the election lights On Fortinbras.
target: I cannot live to hear the news from England, But I do predict that the throne belongs To Fortinbras.

orig: translate old to modern: She, dying, as it must so be maintained, Upon the instant that she was accused, Shall be lamented, pitied and excused Of every hearer.
target: We’ll maintain that she died the instant she was accused, and everyone who hears this will grieve for her, pity her, and excuse her actions.

orig: translate old to modern: I'll tear her all to pieces.
target: I'll tear her all to pieces.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis better, sir, to be brief than tedious.—Let him see our commission, and talk no more.
target: Well, sir, it’s better to say little than to be tedious.

orig: translate old to modern: He dares not come there for the candle; for, you see, it is already in snuff.
target: He doesn’t dare come there for the candle, because you see, it’s already out.

orig: translate old to modern: Repent not you that you shall lose your friend, And he repents not that he pays your debt; For, if the Jew do cut but deep enough, I'll pay it instantly with all my heart.
target: Only be sorry that you shall lose your friend, And he is not sorry that he pays your debt; Because if the Jew only cuts deep enough, I'll pay it instantly with all my heart.

orig: translate old to modern: But, soft!
target: But, hang on!

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, there it is.
target: Yes, there it is.

orig: translate old to modern: They are.
target: They are.

orig: translate old to modern: I'll devil-porter it no further.
target: I'll be a devil-porter no further.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, but he prated And spoke such scurvy and provoking terms Against your honor That, with the little godliness I have, I did full hard forbear him.
target: No, but he chattered on, And spoke such scurvy and provoking terms Against your honor, That, with the little godliness I have, I worked hard to tolerate him.

orig: translate old to modern: Never talk to me.
target: Don’t talk to me.

orig: translate old to modern: In the secret parts of Fortune?
target: In the secret parts of fortune?

orig: translate old to modern: There are yet missing of your company Some few odd lads that you remember not.
target: There are still some few odd lads Missing from your company that you forget.

orig: translate old to modern: Suppose th' Ambassador from the French comes back, Tells Harry that the king doth offer him
target: Imagine the French ambassador returning to inform Harry that the king offers him

orig: translate old to modern: Are these, I pray you, wind instruments?
target: Are these, I beg you, wind instruments?

orig: translate old to modern: Give me some wine, fill full.
target: Give me some wine, fill my cup full.

orig: translate old to modern: Take the fool away.
target: Get that fool out of here.

orig: translate old to modern: What is his name?
target: What’s his name?

orig: translate old to modern: your gambols?
target: Your games?

orig: translate old to modern: Prithee, say true.
target: I beg you, tell the truth.

orig: translate old to modern: Take hence this jack and whip him.
target: Take away this lout and whip him.

orig: translate old to modern: Come hither, mistress.
target: Come here, ma'am.

orig: translate old to modern: Madman, thou errest.
target: You’re wrong, you madman.

orig: translate old to modern: The Prince and Monsieur Love!
target: Look, it’s the Prince and Mr. Love.

orig: translate old to modern: to Antonio] No marrying ’mong his subjects?
target: No marrying among his subjects?

orig: translate old to modern: Therefore, my sweet Rose, my dear Rose, be merry.
target: So please, my sweet Rose, my dear Rose, be happy.

orig: translate old to modern: I will assume desert:—Give me a key for this, And instantly unlock my fortunes here.
target: Give me a key for this, And instantly unlock my fortunes here.

orig: translate old to modern: Captain Macmorris, I think, look you, under your correction, there is not many of your nation—  Of my nation?
target: Captain Macmorris, I think, see—correct me if I’m wrong—there are not many of your nation— My nation?

orig: translate old to modern: And if your love Can labor ought in sad invention, Hang her an epitaph upon her tomb And sing it to her bones.
target: And if your love can produce something from its sadness, write a poem for her; hang it on her grave and sing it to her bones.

orig: translate old to modern: Here is the money.
target: Here is the money.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, we shall make him mad indeed.
target: Wow, we’re really going to drive him crazy.

orig: translate old to modern: What do you see?
target: What do you see?

orig: translate old to modern: There is but one hope in it that can do you any good; and that is but a kind of bastard hope neither.
target: There is only one hope in it that can do you any good, and that is only a kind of bastard hope.

orig: translate old to modern: I dare swear he is no hypocrite but prays from his heart.
target: I think he’s actually serious, and not just being polite.

orig: translate old to modern: I am a spirit of no common rate; The summer still doth tend upon my state; And I do love thee; therefore, go with me.
target: I am a spirit of no simple power— The summer still waits for me And I love you.

orig: translate old to modern: Come to me, that of this I may speak more.
target: Come talk to me about this.

orig: translate old to modern: Judge, O you gods, how dearly Caesar loved him!
target: Judge, O you gods, how dearly Caesar loved him!

orig: translate old to modern: This must be known; which, being kept close, might move More grief to hide than hate to utter love.
target: This must be known, which, if kept secret, might mean More trouble to hide it than hate for utter love.

orig: translate old to modern: O, ’twas the foulest deed to slay that babe, And the most merciless that e'er was heard of!
target: Oh, killing that child was the dirtiest, most merciless deed there ever was!

orig: translate old to modern: He's a traitor.
target: He's a traitor.

orig: translate old to modern: How say you now?
target: What do you say now?

orig: translate old to modern: You are a counsellor; if you can command these elements to silence, and work the peace of the present, we will not hand a rope more; use your authority.
target: You are a council member: if you can command these elements to be silent, And make this present storm more peaceful, we won’t need To work the ropes anymore.

orig: translate old to modern: No, no.
target: No, no.

orig: translate old to modern: Yes, it doth shine that night.
target: Yes, it does shine that night.

orig: translate old to modern: This was well done, my bird.
target: Well done, my bird.

orig: translate old to modern: Your Majesty, hear now, saving your Majesty’s manhood, what an arrant, rascally, beggarly, lousy knave it is.
target: Your Majesty, see here—if it won’t offend your Grace—what a complete, rascally, beggarly, lousy rat this is.

orig: translate old to modern: This was a way to thrive, and he was blest; And thrift is blessing, if men steal it not.
target: This was a way to thrive, and he was blest; And good luck is blessing, if men don’t steal it.

orig: translate old to modern: Are all thy conquests, glories, triumphs, spoils, Shrunk to this little measure?
target: Do all your conquests, glories, triumphs, spoils, Boil down to this?

orig: translate old to modern: do you mark that?
target: Do you see that?

orig: translate old to modern: Do not learn of him, Emilia, though he be thy husband.
target: Don’t learn from him, Emilia, although he is your husband.

orig: translate old to modern: thieves!
target: Thieves!

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, madam.
target: Yes, madam.

orig: translate old to modern: Your eyes do menace me.
target: Your eyes look threatening.

orig: translate old to modern: In sooth, you are to blame.
target: In truth, you are to blame.

orig: translate old to modern: Show me the place.
target: Take me to him.

orig: translate old to modern: Wilt thou know The effect of what I wrote?
target: Do you want to know The effect of what I wrote?

orig: translate old to modern: Yet Brutus says he was ambitious, And sure he is an honorable man.
target: Yet Brutus says he was ambitious; And, sure, he’s an honorable man.

orig: translate old to modern: What did he when thou saw’st him?
target: What did he do when you saw him?

orig: translate old to modern: Is he gone?
target: He’s gone?

orig: translate old to modern: This was the noblest Roman of them all.
target: This was the noblest Roman of them all.

orig: translate old to modern: O gods, ye gods!
target: O gods, you gods!

orig: translate old to modern: Let them not live to taste this land’s increase, That would with treason wound this fair land’s peace.
target: Let those who would mar this fair land’s peace with treason die before they can enjoy its wealth.

orig: translate old to modern: Good now, some excellent fortune!
target: Be kind now and tell me some excellent fortune.

orig: translate old to modern: My lord, the army of great Buckingham— Out on you, owls!
target: Buckingham himself has wandered away alone to who knows where.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, he that cuts off twenty years of life Cuts off so many years of fearing death.
target: Why, he that spends twenty years fearing death Cuts twenty years off his life.

orig: translate old to modern: to Antonio] For you, most wicked sir, whom to call [to Antonio] For you, most wicked sir, whom to call brother Would even infect my mouth, I do forgive Thy rankest fault, all of them, and require My dukedom of thee, which perforce I know Thou must restore.
target: Because you, most wicked sir, whom to call brother Would even infect my mouth, I forgive Your worst fault, all of them, and require My dukedom from you, which I know You must restore to me by necessity.

orig: translate old to modern: I overheard him and his practices.
target: I overheard him and his plans.

orig: translate old to modern: Very like, very like.
target: I’m sure it would’ve, I’m sure it would’ve.

orig: translate old to modern: And we will hear it.
target: And we’ll hear it.

orig: translate old to modern: Can you do me greater harm than hate?
target: can you do me greater harm than hate?

orig: translate old to modern: Go but with me tonight, you shall see her chamber window entered, even the night before her wedding day.
target: Come with me tonight, and you’ll see a man enter her bedroom chamber—even tonight, the night before her wedding.

orig: translate old to modern: And when you saw his chariot but appear, Have you not made an universal shout, That Tiber trembled underneath her banks To hear the replication of your sounds Made in her concave shores?
target: And when you saw his chariot appear, Haven’t you made one great big shout that was so loud The Tiber River trembled underneath her banks To hear the echo of your sounds That bounced off her hollow shores?

orig: translate old to modern: Is he alone?
target: Is he alone?

orig: translate old to modern: What paper were you reading?
target: What’s that paper you were reading?

orig: translate old to modern: You are welcome for his sake.
target: You are welcome for his sake.

orig: translate old to modern: As good a gentleman as the emperor.
target: I’m as good a gentleman as the emperor.

orig: translate old to modern: We did, my lord, weeping and commenting Upon the sobbing deer.
target: We did, my lord, weeping and carrying on about the sobbing deer.

orig: translate old to modern: Take your time.
target: Take your time.

orig: translate old to modern: The king and prince at prayers!
target: The King and Prince are saying prayers!

orig: translate old to modern: I am none of these, my lord.
target: You lowlife son-of-a-bitch!

orig: translate old to modern: If sight and shape be true, Why then, my love adieu.
target: If my eyes aren’t deceiving me, goodbye, love.

orig: translate old to modern: Experience, manhood, honor, ne’er before Did violate so itself.
target: Terrible.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis not to make me jealous To say my wife is fair, feeds well, loves company, Is free of speech, sings, plays, and dances well; Where virtue is, these are more virtuous.
target: It won’t make me jealous, To say my wife is beautiful, cooks well, loves company, Is free of speech, sings, plays, and dances well; Where virtue is, these are more virtuous.

orig: translate old to modern: Upon my life, my lord, I’ll undertake it.
target: Upon my life, my lord, I’ll do it.

target: I’ve set dangerous plans in motion, using lies, drunken prophecies, and stories about dreams to set my brother Clarence and the king against each other.

target: I heard you do a speech once, but it was never acted, or if it was, not more than once, for the play, I remember, didn’t please the crowd, it was caviar to the particular, but it was, as I took it, and others, whose judgments in such matters far exceed mine, an excellent play, well organized in the scenes, set down with as much modesty as skill.

target: My way of life Is fallen into the dry, withered yellow leaf, And the things which should accompany old age, Honor, love, obedience, troops of friends, I think I’ll have, but, instead of them, I’ll have Curses, not loud, only deep, mouth-honor, breath, Which the poor heart would gladly deny, and dare not.

target: Invoke his warlike spirit and that of Edward the Black Prince, your great-uncle, who fought a tragic battle on French soil, routing the French army in full force while his mighty father stood by on a hilltop, smiling to see his son steeped in the blood of French noblemen.

orig: translate old to modern: Now would I give a thousand furlongs of sea for an acre of barren ground—long heath, brown furze, anything.

orig: translate old to modern: Howe'er thou art a fiend, A woman’s shape doth shield thee.
target: But I won’t attack a woman, even if she is a demon.

orig: translate old to modern: A worthy pioner!
target: A worthy pioneer!

orig: translate old to modern: I thank you for this profit, and from hence I'll love no friend sith love breeds such offense.
target: I thank you for this lesson; and from this point forward, I'll love no friend, since love breeds such contempt.

orig: translate old to modern: But art thou not advised, he took some care To get her cunning schoolmasters to instruct her?
target: Still, did you notice how ready he was to hire good tutors for her?

orig: translate old to modern: Will you lead, lords?

orig: translate old to modern: There's blood upon thy face.

target: Stanley, pay attention to your wife’s doings.

orig: translate old to modern: Well this was Signor Benedick that said so.
target: Well, it must have been Signior Benedick.

target: His lips were nice and red, a little more lively and passionate than the red that was in his cheeks—one was pure red and the other more pink.

target: The gods are fair, and they use our little vices to punish us.

target: You should be women, Only since you have beards, I can’t say That you are women.

target: My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua.

target: They’re such oversexed gluttons that I feel like we’re living in a pub or a whorehouse rather than a respectable palace.

orig: translate old to modern: I could make as true a boast as that if I had a sow to my mistress.
target: I could make the same boast even if I had a pig as my mistress.

target: I don’t think there’s a man under the sun who’s worse at hiding his love or hate than Richard.

orig: translate old to modern: Chop off his head.
target: Chop off his head.

orig: translate old to modern: My liege, your highness now may do me good.
target: Before you make  My lord, you could really help me out now.

orig: translate old to modern: I partly know the man.
target: I know the man a bit.

target: I thank you for your pains and courtesy.

target: Many of Antonio's creditors came with me to Venice, swearing he can only go broke.

target: Well then, can’t I act as Rosalind for you tomorrow?

orig: translate old to modern: Is that the uttermost?

orig: translate old to modern: No indeed, my lord.
target: No indeed, my lord.

target: Good-bye.

target: O brave Iago, honest and just, That have such noble sense of your friend's wrong!

orig: translate old to modern: Thou dost here usurp The name thou ow'st not; and hast put thyself Upon this island as a spy, to win it From me, the lord on't.
target: Here you steal The name you don’t own and have put yourself On this island as a spy, to win it From me, the lord of it.

target: For your part, Our swords have leaden points to you, Mark Antony; Our arms in strength of friendship, and our hearts Of brotherly disposition, receive you With all kind love, good thoughts, and reverence.

target: Didn’t you hear her, guys?

target: Too late, good Diomedes.

target: I won’t sleep until I see her, Hortensio.

target: Isn’t it strange?

orig: translate old to modern: But, hark thee, Charmian.
target: But listen, Charmian.

target: When it is paid according to the terms.

target: Farewell, sir.

target: Didn’t you hear their shouts?

orig: translate old to modern: And so farewell.—Katherina, you may stay, For I have more to commune with Bianca.
target: Katherina, you may stay.

orig: translate old to modern: Tomorrow dinner then?
target: Tomorrow night at dinner then?

target: Oh, madam, madam, madam!

target: He’s given his empire to a whore, and now they’re gathering kings to wage a war.

target: You said the enemy would not come down, But keep the hills and upper regions.

target: Damn it, sir, to bid my old master, the Jew, to come to supper tonight with my new master, the Christian.

orig: translate old to modern: I’ll make division of my present with you.
target: Take this.

orig: translate old to modern: O gull!
target: O fool!

target: This madman will murder me.

target: Have you stolen it from her?

target: Why, to keep the eyes on the sides, so that you can see anything that you can’t sniff out.

orig: translate old to modern: We shall obey, were she ten times our mother.
target: We shall obey, if she were ten times our mother.

orig: translate old to modern: And turns the sun to shade.
target: But you turn that sun into a shadow.

target: I wish she were in love with me instead.

target: O Setebos, these are brave spirits indeed.

target: They bore him barefaced on the bier Hey no nonny, nonny, hey nonny And on his grave rained many a tear.

orig: translate old to modern: Is he not here?
target: Isn’t he here?

orig: translate old to modern: Hover about her; say that right for right Hath dimmed your infant morn to agèd night.
target: Hover about her and tell her she got what she deserved, with her children dead before their time.

orig: translate old to modern: He shall enlarge him.

target: Fillet of a snake that lived in a bog, In the caldron boil and bake; Eye of newt, and toe of frog, Wool of bat, and tongue of dog, A black snake’s forked tongue, and its cousin’s sting, Lizard's leg, and owlet's wing, For a charm of powerful trouble, Like a hell-broth, boil and bubble.

orig: translate old to modern: This a dull sight.
target: My vision is dull.

orig: translate old to modern: When it appears to you where this begins, Turn your displeasure that way, for our faults Can never be so equal that your love Can equally move with them.
target: When you find out who started this disagreement, turn your anger upon them.

orig: translate old to modern: I love you the better; the hearers may cry “Amen.” God match me with a good dancer!
target: That makes me love you even more.

orig: translate old to modern: The ambassadors from Norway, my good lord, Are joyfully return'd.
target: The ambassadors from Norway, my good lord, Are joyfully returned.

orig: translate old to modern: And even for that do I love you the more.
target: And even for that, I love you all the more.

orig: translate old to modern: Donalbain.
target: Donalbain.

orig: translate old to modern: Tonight, my lord?
target: Tonight, my lord?

orig: translate old to modern: How, how I pray you?
target: Please, please tell me!

orig: translate old to modern: What a brazen-faced varlet art thou to deny thou knowest me!
target: What a shameless jerk you are to pretend you don’t know me!

orig: translate old to modern: One of these three contains her heavenly picture.
target: One of these three chests contains her heavenly picture.

orig: translate old to modern: My voice is ragged.
target: My voice is ragged.

orig: translate old to modern: Thyself art coming To see performed the dreaded act which thou So sought’st to hinder.
target: You’re coming here yourself to see the dreaded act you had tried to stop.

orig: translate old to modern: Let me love him for that, and do you love him because I do.
target: Let me love him because he deserves it, and you can love him because I do.

orig: translate old to modern: You have been factious one against the other.— Wife, love Lord Hastings.
target: Take my hand, Hastings.

orig: translate old to modern: Buzz, buzz!
target: Buzz, buzz!

orig: translate old to modern: Even so.
target: Well, there they are.

orig: translate old to modern: Last night of all, When yond same star that's westward from the pole Had made his course to illume that part of heaven Where now it burns, Marcellus and myself, The bell then beating one— Peace!
target: Last night, When that star up there, that's west of the North Pole, Had moved around to light that part of the sky Where now it burns, Marcellus and myself, The clock’s bell then tolling one, Quiet, stop!

orig: translate old to modern: For he partly begs To be desired to give.
target: He almost begs for the opportunity to help you.

orig: translate old to modern: Now she’s gone for ever.— Cordelia, Cordelia, stay a little.
target: Now she’s gone forever.—Cordelia, Cordelia, stay a while.

orig: translate old to modern: O Kate, content thee.
target: Calm down, Kate.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, like enough, for I stay dinner there.
target: Yes, probably, because I’m staying for lunch.

orig: translate old to modern: Horns?
target: Horns?

orig: translate old to modern: Now this overdone, or come tardy off, though it make the unskilful laugh, cannot but make the judicious grieve; the censure of the which one must in your allowance o'erweigh a whole theatre of others.
target: Now, this overacting, or lateness, though it make the ignorant laugh, can only make the experienced grieve, in whose opinion, you must outdo a whole theatre of other audiences in your performance.

orig: translate old to modern: But repetition of what thou hast marred.
target: Only describing what you have ruined.

orig: translate old to modern: And so, I pray thee, call Beatrice.
target: Now please, tell Beatrice to come out.

orig: translate old to modern: Therefore, Lord Constable, haste on Montjoy And let him say to England that we send To know what willing ransom he will give.
target: Have Montjoy hurry, then, Lord Constable, and have him ask the king of England what he is willing to pay us to get out of the war.

orig: translate old to modern: Censure me in your wisdom, and awake your senses, that you may the better judge.
target: Judge me in your wisdom, and wake up your senses, so you can be a better judge.

orig: translate old to modern: I am stuffed, cousin.
target: Sorry, I’m all stuffed.

orig: translate old to modern: Sir, I lack advancement.
target: Sir, I don’t have a promotion.

orig: translate old to modern: Is not this something more than fantasy?
target: Is this not more than our imaginations?

orig: translate old to modern: O, there has been much throwing about of brains.
target: O, there has been a lot of bashing of brains going on.

orig: translate old to modern: All may be well; but if God sort it so, 'Tis more than we deserve or I expect.
target: So, if all turns out fine, as you say, it’s more than we deserve or I expect.

orig: translate old to modern: Let it be a quarrel between us, if you live.
target: Let it be a quarrel between us, if you live.

orig: translate old to modern: Unless I have mista'en his colors much, Which well I am assured I have not done, His regiment lies half a mile, at least, South from the mighty power of the king.
target: Unless I’ve mistaken his battle flags, which I’m sure I haven’t, his regiment lies at least half a mile south of the king’s mighty army.

orig: translate old to modern: Would I were satisfied!
target: I wish I were satisfied!

orig: translate old to modern: Wrinkles forbid!
target: May my wrinkles forbid that!

orig: translate old to modern: Eight wild boars roasted whole at a breakfast—and but twelve persons there!
target: We heard that once you were served eight wild boars roasted whole for breakfast—for only twelve people!

orig: translate old to modern: Dost thou squiny at me?
target: Are you squinting at me?

orig: translate old to modern: Here, kiss the book.
target: Passing the bottle] Here, kiss the book [gives TRINCULO a drink].

orig: translate old to modern: But let it rest.—Now, Litio, to you.
target: But let it go.—Now, Litio, it’s your turn.

orig: translate old to modern: So says the Prince and my new-trothèd lord.
target: That’s what the Prince and my fiancé say.

orig: translate old to modern: To these injunctions every one doth swear, That comes to hazard for my worthless self.
target: Everyone swears to these conditions Who come to take a chance for my worthless self.

orig: translate old to modern: Let the great gods That keep this dreadful pudder o'er our heads Find out their enemies now.
target: Let the gods who stirred up this dreadful storm bring their enemies to light.

orig: translate old to modern: Woe to the land that’s governed by a child.
target: It’s bad news when a country is ruled by a child.

orig: translate old to modern: Ay.
target: Yes.

orig: translate old to modern: How now, sweet Queen?
target: What now, sweet queen!

orig: translate old to modern: The gods forbid!
target: The gods forbid!

orig: translate old to modern: So that, dear lords, if I be left behind, A moth of peace, and he go to the war, The rites for which I love him are bereft me, And I a heavy interim shall support By his dear absence.
target: So much so, dear lords, if I am left behind, A moth of peace, and he goes to the war, The rites for which I love him I am deprived of, And I shall endure a sad interval caused By his dear absence.

orig: translate old to modern: Can you tell if Rosalind, the duke’s daughter, be banished with her father?
target: Can you tell me whether Rosalind, Duke Senior’s daughter, has also been banished?

orig: translate old to modern: When shall we three meet again?
target: When should the three of us meet again?

orig: translate old to modern: It harrows me with fear and wonder.
target: It fills me with fear and wonder.

orig: translate old to modern: It might have since been answered in repaying What we took from them, which, for traffic’s sake, Most of our city did.
target: The whole quarrel might have been resolved since then when we repaid what we stole from them—which most of our city did, for the sake of friendly trade relations.

orig: translate old to modern: For, by this heaven, now at our sorrows pale, Say what thou canst, I’ll go along with thee.
target: I swear by the heavens, which have grown pale in sympathy with us, I’m going with you, whatever you say.

orig: translate old to modern: Here in these confines slyly have I lurked To watch the waning of mine enemies.
target: I’ve lurked in the shadows here to watch the downfall of my enemies.

orig: translate old to modern: Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard, Who rated him for speaking well of Pompey.
target: Caius Ligarius doesn’t like Caesar, Who berated him for speaking well of Pompey.

orig: translate old to modern: Off, pluck off!
target: Take off my armor.

orig: translate old to modern: His name's Gonzago.
target: His name's Gonzago.

orig: translate old to modern: Know’st thou Fluellen?
target: Do you know Fluellen?

orig: translate old to modern: Poor bird!
target: Poor bird!

orig: translate old to modern: The one the other poisoned for my sake, And after slew herself.
target: One of the sisters poisoned the other out of love for me, and then killed herself.

orig: translate old to modern: What, ho!
target: What, ho!

orig: translate old to modern: I know no ways to mince it in love, but directly to say, “I love you.” Then if you urge me farther than to say, “Do you, in faith?” I wear out my suit.
target: I don’t know any fancy ways of talking about love, only to say right out, “I love you.” If you press me any further than with the question, “Do you really?” my love scene is over.

orig: translate old to modern: If not, elsewhere they meet with charity.
target: And if they don’t find charity there, they find it someplace else.

orig: translate old to modern: Who hath made this havoc with them?
target: Who did this to him?

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, I dare not swear it.
target: Well, no, not literally.

orig: translate old to modern: Filth, thou liest!
target: Filth, you lie!

orig: translate old to modern: He has broke my head across and has given Sir Toby a bloody coxcomb too.
target: He cut my head and gave Sir Toby a bloody head, too.

orig: translate old to modern: Realms and islands were As plates dropped from his pocket.
target: Kingdoms and provinces dropped from his pockets like loose change.

orig: translate old to modern: I am not bid for love; they flatter me: But yet I'll go in hate, to feed upon The prodigal Christian.—Jessica, my girl, Look to my house.—I am right loath to go; There is some ill a-brewing towards my rest, For I did dream of money-bags to-night.
target: I am very reluctant to go; There is some ill disturbing my rest, Because I dreamt of moneybags tonight.

orig: translate old to modern: Is the King stirring, worthy Thane?
target: Is the king awake yet, worthy baron?

orig: translate old to modern: There's such divinity doth hedge a king That treason can but peep to what it would, Acts little of his will.
target: There's such divinity that surrounds a king, That treason can only peep to what it would do, Acts little by his will.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, we’ll see ’t.
target: Well, let’s watch it.

orig: translate old to modern: What, I will be jovial.
target: Then there’s still a chance.

orig: translate old to modern: My villainy?
target: My wickedness?

orig: translate old to modern: Murder, murder!
target: Murder, murder!

orig: translate old to modern: I am thus bold to put your Grace in mind Of what you promised me.
target: I’m reminding your grace what you promised me.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis true.
target: That’s true.

orig: translate old to modern: Not a word of me.
target: Not a word from me.

orig: translate old to modern: in apprehension how like a god!
target: in understanding, how like a god!

orig: translate old to modern: Mistrust of good success hath done this deed.
target: Lack of trust in good success has done this deed.

orig: translate old to modern: On, on, you noblest English, Whose blood is fet from fathers of war-proof, Fathers that, like so many Alexanders, Have in these parts from morn till even fought And sheathed their swords for lack of argument.
target: On, on, you noblest Englishmen, descended as you are from battle-tested fathers, fathers who, like so many Alexander the Greats, have fought in these regions from morning until night, sheathing their swords only when there was no one left to fight.

orig: translate old to modern: No, his mouth is stopp'd; Honest Iago hath ta'en order for't.
target: No, his mouth is stopped; Honest Iago has taken orders for it.

orig: translate old to modern: I'll not be far from you.
target: I won’t be far from you.

orig: translate old to modern: Were not you even now with the Countess Olivia?
target: Excuse me, weren’t you with Countess Olivia just now?

orig: translate old to modern: By which honor I dare not swear thou lovest me, yet my blood begins to flatter me that thou dost, notwithstanding the poor and untempering effect of my visage.
target: And though I wouldn’t dare to swear that you love me, still my blood begins to flatter me that you do, despite the ill effects of my face.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis very good; I must be circumstanced.
target: That’s very good; I must be patient.

orig: translate old to modern: Orlando.
target: Orlando.

orig: translate old to modern: Welcome, Horatio.
target: Welcome, Horatio.

orig: translate old to modern: Where?
target: Where?

orig: translate old to modern: Marry, well said, very well said.
target: By Mary, well said, very well said.

orig: translate old to modern: Thus it is, general.
target: It’s like this, general.

orig: translate old to modern: Here, sir, but trouble him not.
target: He’s here, sir, but please don’t bother him.

orig: translate old to modern: The breaking of so great a thing should make A greater crack.
target: When such a great man dies there should be a thunderclap.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou'rt a scholar.
target: You’re a smart guy.

orig: translate old to modern: The very conveyances of his lands will scarcely lie in this box; and must the inheritor himself have no more, ha?
target: The very transfers of his lands will scarcely lie in this box, and must the inheritor himself have no more, huh?

orig: translate old to modern: Come on, sir.
target: Come on, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: How can that be, when you have the voice of the King himself for your succession in Denmark?
target: How can that be, when the king himself says you will succeed him to the throne in Denmark?

orig: translate old to modern: Madam, his majesty doth call for you,— And for your Grace, —and yours, my gracious lords.
target: Madam, his majesty asks for you, and for you, Duke of Gloucester, and for you, my noble lords.

orig: translate old to modern: And you, sir.
target: Hello to you too, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: Oh, ’tis treason!
target: That’s treason!

orig: translate old to modern: What is the success?
target: Who’s winning?

orig: translate old to modern: An it had not fallen flat-long.
target: If it had not fallen dead flat.

orig: translate old to modern: Nor ever heard, nor ever did suspect.
target: Not ever heard, or ever suspected.

orig: translate old to modern: Her fallow leas The darnel, hemlock, and rank fumitory Doth root upon, while that the coulter rusts That should deracinate such savagery.
target: Her fallow fields are overgrown with weeds, while the blade that should uproot such wilderness lies rusting.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, she was dead ere thou wast born.
target: Why, she was dead before you were even born.

orig: translate old to modern: Is your Englishman so expert in his drinking?
target: Is your Englishman so expert in his drinking?

orig: translate old to modern: Can anything be made of this?
target: Can anything be made out of this?

orig: translate old to modern: You may do your will, But he's a tried and valiant soldier.
target: You may do what you want to, But I say he's a tried and valiant soldier.

orig: translate old to modern: Royal Lear, Whom I have ever honored as my king, Loved as my father, as my master followed, As my great patron thought on in my prayers— The bow is bent and drawn.
target: King Lear, I’ve always honored you as king, loved you as my father, obeyed you as my master, and thanked you in my prayers— I’m furious and ready to snap.

orig: translate old to modern: But I hope you have no intent to turn husband, have you?
target: But, hey, this doesn’t mean you’re looking to get married, does it?

orig: translate old to modern: Think on me, That am with Phoebus’ amorous pinches black And wrinkled deep in time.
target: Are you thinking about me?

orig: translate old to modern: What a full fortune does the thicklips owe, If he can carry't thus!
target: What great luck the thick lips have, If he can get away with this!

orig: translate old to modern: Ride, ride, Messala, ride, and give these bills Unto the legions on the other side.
target: Ride, ride, Messala, ride, and give these bills To the legions on the other side.

orig: translate old to modern: I have no hope That he's undrowned.
target: I have no hope That he's not drowned.

orig: translate old to modern: You rascal!
target: You rascal!

orig: translate old to modern: Come by and by to my chamber.
target: Come to my room later on.

orig: translate old to modern: Since thou dost give me pains Let me remember thee what thou hast promised, Which is not yet performed me.
target: Since you give me so much trouble, Let me remind you what you have promised, Which is not yet done for me.

orig: translate old to modern: We must have your doublet and hose plucked over your head and show the world what the bird hath done to her own nest.
target: We should rip off your man’s clothing and show the world the woman who has represented her own kind so badly.

orig: translate old to modern: O you sir, you, come you hither, sir.
target: You there, sir, come here please.

orig: translate old to modern: Come hither, fellow.
target: Come here, man.

orig: translate old to modern: Well.
target: Well.

orig: translate old to modern: Where is the horse that doth untread again, His tedious measures with the unbated fire, That he did pace them first?
target: Where is the horse that retraces his boring steps again With the same fire That he walked them in the first place?

orig: translate old to modern: What you would have I’ll stay to know at your abandoned cave.
target: I’ll wait for you in your cave, where you can tell me what you need from me.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, that’s certain.
target: That’s true.

orig: translate old to modern: Detain no jot, I charge thee.
target: Don’t keep anything back, I insist.

orig: translate old to modern: Perish the man whose mind is backward now!
target: Let any man perish who isn’t ready now!

orig: translate old to modern: So you thought him, And took his voice who should be prick'd to die In our black sentence and proscription.
target: You thought so, And took his side when we decided who should die, In our black punishment and condemning to death.

orig: translate old to modern: Expound unto me, boy.
target: Explain, boy.

orig: translate old to modern: Yes, one, and in this manner.
target: Yes, one, and this is how I did it.

orig: translate old to modern: Good my mouse of virtue, answer me.
target: Please answer, my good little student.

orig: translate old to modern: I see the ruin of my house.
target: I see the downfall of my family.

orig: translate old to modern: Those that were your father’s enemies Have steeped their galls in honey, and do serve you With hearts create of duty and of zeal.
target: Those who were bitter enemies of your father in his time have turned their bitterness to sweetness, serving you loyally and wholeheartedly.

orig: translate old to modern: I rather tell thee what is to be fear'd Than what I fear, for always I am Caesar.
target: I would rather tell you what to be afraid of More than what I am afraid of, for I’m always Caesar.

orig: translate old to modern: And do you now put on your best attire?
target: And do you now put on your best attire?

orig: translate old to modern: I will verify as much in his beard.
target: I will say as much to his face.

orig: translate old to modern: Both which, Master Constable— You have.
target: Both of which, master constable— You have.

orig: translate old to modern: Therefore be doubledamn'd; Swear thou art honest.
target: Therefore be double-damned, Swear you are honest.

orig: translate old to modern: The more the pity that some honest neighbors will not make them friends.
target: The more’s the pity that some honest neighbors will not make them friends.

orig: translate old to modern: Up, my lords.
target: Awake, my lords!

orig: translate old to modern: No, let me know; And knowing what I am, I know what she shall be.
target: No, let me know; And knowing what I am, I know what she shall be.

orig: translate old to modern: We would have all such offenders so cut off, and we give express charge that in our marches through the country there be nothing compelled from the villages, nothing taken but paid for, none of the French upbraided or abused in disdainful language; for when lenity and cruelty play for a kingdom, the gentler gamester is the soonest winner.
target: I want all such offenders to be dealt with that way, and I give precise orders that in our progress through the country there shall be nothing seized from the villages, nothing taken that is not paid for, none of the French harassed or abused in disrespectful language.

orig: translate old to modern: Here is the man, this Moor; whom now, it seems, Your special mandate for the state affairs Hath hither brought.
target: Here is the man, this Moor; who now, it seems, Has been brought here by Your special mandate for the state affairs.

orig: translate old to modern: Thou shalt not die.
target: I’ll commute your death sentence.

orig: translate old to modern: And from thy hated presence part I so; See me no more, whether he be dead or no.
target: You will see me no more, whether he be dead or not.

orig: translate old to modern: Fathers that wear rags  Do make their children blind.
target: Fathers who wear rags Make their children neglect them.

orig: translate old to modern: And let the laboring bark climb hills of seas Olympus high, and duck again as low As hell's from heaven!
target: And let the laboring ship climb hills of oceans As high as Olympus, and duck down again as low As hell is from heaven!

orig: translate old to modern: Nothing that is so is so.
target: Nothing is what it is.

orig: translate old to modern: You have among you killed a sweet and innocent lady.
target: The three of you have killed a sweet, innocent woman.

orig: translate old to modern: If in Naples I should report this now, would they believe me’ If I should say I saw such islanders?
target: If I should report this now in Naples, Would they believe me?

orig: translate old to modern: Then was this island— Save for the son that she did litter here, A freckled whelp, hag-born—not honoured with A human shape.
target: Then this was an island—except for the son that she had here, A freckled pup, born of a witch—not resembling Any human shape.

orig: translate old to modern: A plague upon you all!
target: Damn you all!

orig: translate old to modern: It shall to the barber's, with your beard.
target: It shall go to the barber's, to be cut with your beard.

orig: translate old to modern: Vent my folly?
target: Blab my nonsense?

orig: translate old to modern: O sir, I do, and will repute you ever The patron of my life and liberty.
target: Oh sir, I accept.

orig: translate old to modern: You bid me make it orderly and well, According to the fashion and the time.
target: You told me to make it well and properly and in keeping with the current style.

orig: translate old to modern: Excellent well.
target: Excellent well.

orig: translate old to modern: Tell me your counsels, I will not disclose em.
target: Tell me your secrets, I won’t reveal them.

orig: translate old to modern: Tis very grievous to be thought upon.
target: Very sad.

orig: translate old to modern: Nor know I aught By me that's said or done amiss this night; Unless self-charity be sometimes a vice, And to defend ourselves it be a sin When violence assails us.
target: I don’t know anything That I said or did wrong this night, Unless self-love is sometimes a vice, And to defend ourselves is a sin When we are attacked violently.

orig: translate old to modern: Dolabella, I shall remain your debtor.
target: Dolabella, I will always be in debt to you.

orig: translate old to modern: Call up all my people!
target: Wake up all my servants!

orig: translate old to modern: Here, as I point my sword, the sun arises, Which is a great way growing on the south, Weighing the youthful season of the year.
target: Here, where I point my sword, the Sun rises, Which is going a great way to the South, Bringing in spring.

orig: translate old to modern: I think their inhibition comes by the means of the late innovation.
target: I think their traveling to perform a play is a new innovation.

orig: translate old to modern: Where are these hearts?
target: Where are these hearts?

orig: translate old to modern: No, let's come in!
target: No, let's come in.

orig: translate old to modern: Use them after your own honour and dignity.
target: Use them according to your class.

orig: translate old to modern: Well, I conceive.
target: Well, I understand.

orig: translate old to modern: Talk you of young Master Launcelot?—Mark me now—now will I raise the waters.—Talk you of young master Launcelot?
target: Are you talking about young Master Launcelot?

orig: translate old to modern: Lives, sir.
target: He lives, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: As I intend to prosper and repent, So thrive I in my dangerous affairs Of hostile arms!
target: May I only do well in these dangerous battles if my intention to repent and prosper is sincere!

orig: translate old to modern: I will this night, In several hands, in at his windows throw, As if they came from several citizens, Writings, all tending to the great opinion That Rome holds of his name, wherein obscurely Caesar's ambition shall be glanced at.
target: Tonight, I will throw writings in his windows, All tending to the great opinion that Rome holds his name, by several different hands, as if they came from several citizens, In these writings, I will analyze, although obscurely, Caesar's ambition.

orig: translate old to modern: Leave you your power to draw, And I shall have no power to follow you.
target: Even if you didn’t have the power to pull me, I would still be powerless not to follow you.

orig: translate old to modern: When I know the gentleman, I’ll tell him what you say.
target: When I meet this gentleman, I’ll tell him what you’ve said.

orig: translate old to modern: And some have greatness thrust upon them.” Heaven restore thee!
target: And some have greatness thrust upon them.” Heaven help you!

orig: translate old to modern: Fear it, Ophelia, fear it, my dear sister, And keep you in the rear of your affection, Out of the shot and danger of desire.
target: Fear it, Ophelia, fear it, my dear sister, And keep your affections deep within you, Out of the range and danger of desire.

orig: translate old to modern: Things base and vile, holding no quantity, Love can transpose to form and dignity.
target: Love can transpose things that are low and ugly, Having no good qualities at all, Into things that have beauty and dignity.

orig: translate old to modern: Casca, you are the first that rears your hand.
target: Casca, you’re the first one to strike.

orig: translate old to modern: I noted her not, but I looked on her.
target: I saw her, but I didn’t notice her.

orig: translate old to modern: I rather will subject me to the malice Of a diverted blood and bloody brother.
target: I’d rather give myself up to the hatred of a violent brother who refuses to recognize that we are brothers.

orig: translate old to modern: To make an account of her life to a clod of wayward marl?
target: Can you imagine being hitched to a lump of clay?

orig: translate old to modern: As I do live, my honour'd lord, 'tis true; And we did think it writ down in our duty To let you know of it.
target: I swear, my honored lord, it is true, And we thought it was our duty To let you know about it.

orig: translate old to modern: I'll follow, Stephano.
target: I'll follow, Stephano.

orig: translate old to modern: Run to the Capitol, and nothing else?
target: Run to the Capitol, and nothing else?

orig: translate old to modern: Some friendship will it lend you 'gainst the tempest.
target: It will give you some protection from this storm.

orig: translate old to modern: What should I say, sweet lady?
target: What should I say, sweet lady?

orig: translate old to modern: I marvel what kin thou and thy daughters are.
target: I’m amazed how similar you and your daughters are.

orig: translate old to modern: Go, And with your speediest bring us what she says And how you find of her.
target: Go, and hurry back to bring us her reply and news of her state of mind.

orig: translate old to modern: Of us must Pompey presently be sought, Or else he seeks out us.
target: Either we go after Pompey or he’ll come after us.

orig: translate old to modern: Had my lips that power, Thus would I wear them out.
target: If my lips had the power to give life, I would wear them out like this.

orig: translate old to modern: Do not you chide; I have a thing for you.
target: Don’t scold; I have something for you.

orig: translate old to modern: Your Grace is too costly to wear every day.
target: You are too expensive to wear every day.

orig: translate old to modern: Nay, ’tis no matter, sir, what he 'leges in Latin.
target: I don’t care what he told you in Latin.

orig: translate old to modern: Yes, in truth it is, sir.
target: Yes, it truly is.

orig: translate old to modern: High-day, freedom!
target: High-day, freedom!

orig: translate old to modern: Why, well.
target: Why, well.

orig: translate old to modern: My first false speaking Was this upon myself.
target: My first lie ever Was these things I said about myself.

orig: translate old to modern: Take pains; be perfect; adieu.
target: Be careful; be perfect; goodbye.

target: Now I only scold, but I should give you worse; Because you, I fear, has given me cause to curse.

target: The gown was made just as my master was directed.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, so didst thou.
target: Why, so did you.

target: Sure, but don’t do it at full volume until there’s no danger in it.

orig: translate old to modern: Demetrius and Egeus, go along; I must employ you in some business Against our nuptial, and confer with you Of something nearly that concerns yourselves.
target: Demetrius and Egeus, go ahead; I must ask you to do a few things about the wedding, And meet with you about some issues that affect you.

orig: translate old to modern: This is some monster of the isle with four legs, who hath got, as I tak it, an ague.
target: This is some monster of the island with four legs, who has got, as I take it, malaria.

orig: translate old to modern: Arms, arms, sword, fire, corruption in the place!

orig: translate old to modern: A calendar, a calendar!
target: A calendar, a calendar!

orig: translate old to modern: She doth well.
target: She’s probably right.

orig: translate old to modern: In this, though I cannot be said to be a flattering honest man, it must not be denied but I am a plain-dealing villain.
target: Though I am not a flattering, righteous man, at least you can say that I am honest about being a villain.

orig: translate old to modern: I'll not serve him; he's not valiant.
target: I won’t serve him: he’s not valiant.

orig: translate old to modern: Do me right, or I will protest your cowardice.
target: lain.

orig: translate old to modern: I had thought t’ have held it poor; but since my lord Is Antony again, I will be Cleopatra.
target: I had planned to celebrate it quietly, but since my lord is once more himself, I will be Cleopatra again.

orig: translate old to modern: Pompey doth this day laugh away his fortune.
target: Today Pompey laughs away his fortune.

orig: translate old to modern: When didst thou sleep when such a deed was done?
target: Have you ever slept before while such a terrible deed was done?

orig: translate old to modern: Let her come in.
target: Let her come in.

orig: translate old to modern: What likelihood?
target: what likelihood?

orig: translate old to modern: I do love nothing in the world so well as you.
target: There is nothing in the world that I love as much as you.

orig: translate old to modern: There is an old poor man Who after me hath many a weary step Limped in pure love.
target: There is a poor old man who, purely out of love, has limped after me for miles.

orig: translate old to modern: And wilt thou have me?
target: And will you have me?

orig: translate old to modern: What trumpet’s that?
target: What’s that trumpet?

orig: translate old to modern: Amen.
target: Amen!

orig: translate old to modern: Tis no matter.
target: It won’t matter.

orig: translate old to modern: Thy love ne'er alter till thy sweet life end!
target: May your love never change until your sweet life ends!

target: The human being unburdened by the trappings of civilization is no more than a poor, naked, two-legged animal like you.

orig: translate old to modern: This business is well ended.
target: This business is well ended.

orig: translate old to modern: I am come To bid my king and master aye good night.
target: I’ve come to say farewell to my king and master.

orig: translate old to modern: Let the galled jade winch; our withers are unwrung.
target: Let the bitter hussy kick, our saddles don’t pinch.

orig: translate old to modern: What if this cursed hand Were thicker than itself with brother's blood, Is there not rain enough in the sweet heavens To wash it white as snow?
target: What if this cursed hand Were thicker than itself with my brother's blood, Isn’t there enough rain in the sweet heavens To wash it as white as snow?

orig: translate old to modern: Alack, alack!
target: Oh, oh!

orig: translate old to modern: Is't frailty that thus errs?
target: Is it frailty makes mistakes like this?

orig: translate old to modern: Speed him hence.
target: Send him on his way quickly.

orig: translate old to modern: My mother stays.
target: My mother is waiting.

orig: translate old to modern: All school-days' friendship, childhood innocence?
target: All school-days' friendship, childhood innocence?

orig: translate old to modern: Dear Kate, you and I cannot be confined within the weak list of a country’s fashion.
target: You and I cannot be held within the confines of a country’s arbitrary customs, dear Kate.

orig: translate old to modern: Look what I have.
target: Look what I have.

orig: translate old to modern: Sir, here is newly come to court Laertes; believe me, an absolute gentleman, full of most excellent differences, of very soft society and great showing.
target: Sir, here Laertes is newly come to court, believe me, an absolute gentleman, full of most excellent traits, of very soft manners and looking great.

target: Let’s dance to “You Jerk.” You mean, “Shut up, you jerk”?

target: I only wish I could load him up with all the praise he deserves!

orig: translate old to modern: This is a sorry sight.

target: Come here.

target: What does a crocodile look like?

orig: translate old to modern: Sword” is an oath, and oaths must have their course.
target: By this sword” is an oath, and oaths must be kept.

orig: translate old to modern: I pray you, in your letters, When you shall these unlucky deeds relate, Speak of me as I am; nothing extenuate, Nor set down aught in malice.
target: I beg you, in your letters, When you shall tell about these unlucky deeds, Speak of me as I am; nothing farfetched, And don’t write anything in malice.

orig: translate old to modern: If we are like you in the rest, we will resemble you in that.
target: If we are like you in the rest, we’ll resemble you in that.

orig: translate old to modern: Why, the night gone by.
target: Why, last night.

orig: translate old to modern: A pox o’ your throat, you bawling, blasphemous, incharitable dog!
target: Damn your voice, you loud, cursing, selfish dog!

target: What you have spoken may be so perhaps.

orig: translate old to modern: Let’s then determine with the ancient of war On our proceedings.
target: Then let’s meet with our senior command and discuss what to do next.

orig: translate old to modern: An interlude!
target: What a farce!

orig: translate old to modern: Princes and counties!
target: Princes and counts!

orig: translate old to modern: Shake off this downy sleep, death's counterfeit, And look on death itself!
target: Shake off this soft sleep, death's disguise, And look on death itself!

orig: translate old to modern: Ay, marry, why was he sent into England?
target: Yes, by Mary, why was he sent to England?

orig: translate old to modern: Exchange me for a goat, When I shall turn the business of my soul To such exsufflicate and blown surmises, Matching thy inference.
target: Trade me for a goat When I shall turn the business of my soul To such puffed up and blown suspicions, Matching your suggestion.

orig: translate old to modern: We will go walk a little in the orchard, And then to dinner.
target: Let’s take a little walk in the orchard before dinner.

orig: translate old to modern: And so I thank you for your good counsel.
target: and so I thank you for your good counsel.

orig: translate old to modern: Tell him myself, the mayor, and aldermen, No less importing than our general good, In deep designs, and matters of great moment Are come to have some conference with his grace.
target: Tell him that the mayor, some citizens, and I have come to confer with his grace in matters of great importance concerning the general good.

orig: translate old to modern: Bear them from hence.
target: Carry them away.

orig: translate old to modern: If she find him not, To England send him; or confine him where Your wisdom best shall think.
target: If she can’t find out what’s wrong, Then send him to England, or lock him up where You think is the best place.

orig: translate old to modern: Enough to purchase what you have made known.
target: Enough to buy everything you have declared.

orig: translate old to modern: Then you shall be his surety.
target: Then you shall be his insurance.

orig: translate old to modern: As the cony that you see dwell where she is kindled.
target: Just like the rabbit, who lives where she is born.

orig: translate old to modern: Now, what news on the Rialto?
target: Now, what’s the news in the Marketplace?

orig: translate old to modern: Not to kill him, having a warrant, but to be damned for killing him, from the which no warrant can defend me.
target: Not of killing him, because I have a warrant for it, but of being damned for killing him, which no warrant can protect me from.

orig: translate old to modern: It is the cry of women, my good lord.
target: It is the cry of women, my good lord.

orig: translate old to modern: I think, i'faith, she loves me.
target: I think, in faith, she loves me.

target: Time to buy myself a mirror and employ a few dozen tailors to dress me up in the current fashions.

target: Well, we almost fought and then realized that we had reached the seventh cause.

target: You have a beautiful half-sister, Octavia.

orig: translate old to modern: O my follies!
target: What a fool I’ve been!

orig: translate old to modern: What are they that do play it?
target: Who are they that do play it?

target: Off!

target: Make sure the ones who have wronged you suffer too.

target: Regan gives good advice.

target: Stop right now or I’ll throw your dagger over the roof.

orig: translate old to modern: Even now, sir.

orig: translate old to modern: More to know Did never meddle with my thoughts.
target: It never entered my mind To know more.

target: Your highness will have to force me to tell.

target: How did you get this sober?

target: Master, master, I’ve been on the lookout so long, I’m ready to fall down dead—but I’ve got one, finally!

orig: translate old to modern: A credulous father, and a brother noble— Whose nature is so far from doing harms That he suspects none, on whose foolish honesty My practices ride easy.
target: A gullible father and a brother who’s so innocent that he can’t suspect anyone else of wanting to hurt him—these are the two fools I need for my plan to work.

orig: translate old to modern: So full of artless jealousy is guilt It spills itself in fearing to be spilt.
target: Guilt is so full of artless jealousy, that It spills itself in fearing to be spilled.

orig: translate old to modern: I have a man's mind, but a woman's might.
target: I have a man's mind, but a woman's might.

target: In youth when I did love, did love, I thought it was very sweet, To contract, O, the time for, ah, my reason, O, I thought there was nothing meet.

orig: translate old to modern: I hope all will be well.
target: I hope all will be well.

orig: translate old to modern: Where is he?
target: Where is he?

target: How now, you secret, black, and midnight hags!

target: Then I shall bleed to death.

target: Poison never came from such a sweet place.

target: Where was she born?

target: A very pleasing night to honest men.

target: Whose solid virtue Could be neither grazed nor pierced by The shot of accident or dart of fate?

target: In places I go to, great clerks have purposed To greet me with prepared welcomes; I have seen them shiver and look pale, Make full stops in the middle of sentences, Mess up their practiced speeches in their fears, And, in conclusion, stop all together, dumbstruck, Not paying me a welcome.

orig: translate old to modern: Do we so.

target: Don’t you have any modesty, any maiden shame, Any touch of bashfulness?

target: Cassio, my lord, has killed a young Venetian Called Roderigo.

target: Keep this man safe, Give him all kindness; I would rather have Such men as my friends than enemies.

target: If each grain of sand had a tongue to eulogize, my horse would be a topic for them all.

target: He may command me as my king, but you still have power over me as a relative.

target: Where should Othello go?

target: Like hell!

target: Madam, I heard her speak.

target: No, don’t be ashamed, Cleopatra.

target: I accept that offer happily, madam.

target: Where’s Antonio, then?

target: Yes, as kind as snow to a harvest.

orig: translate old to modern: Caesar, all hail!
target: Caesar, all hail!

orig: translate old to modern: Would't had been done!
target: I wish I had!

orig: translate old to modern: He is very well-favored, and he speaks very shrewishly.
target: He’s very handsome and speaks well, but he’s very young.

orig: translate old to modern: Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.
target: Lovely Beatrice, I thank you for taking the pains to tell me that.
